column2: Photos from a recent superhero costume party and leading gay and lesbian comic characters.
Women's Professional Soccer, now in its second season, will not only Webcast a live game this Sunday, it will also provide a stream to users of Apple's iPhone.
Leave it to Richard X. Bove, the outspoken banking analyst at Rochdale Securities, to call for the leaders of Goldman Sachs to "fall on their swords."

One of the great tragedies of the developing world is the number of women who die in pregnancy and childbirth. But what is that number? Several studies had put it at somewhat more than 500,000 a year, while a new and apparently more rigorous study suggests that it has dropped to less than 350,000 a year.

Updated: All 41 Senate Republicans have signed a letter urging the majority leader, Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, to adopt a more bipartisan approach in developing legislation to tighten regulation of the nation's financial system.
Two activists honored by President Obama for leading a movement against President Robert Mugabe were jailed again after a march, according to their organization, Women of Zimbabwe Arise.
More than 6 in 10 Americans expect their taxes to go up in the next year, according to Gallup. Even a majority of low-income taxpayers foresee an increase in their taxes:

Here are a few thoughts on the conversation that Julian Sanchez started with a post on the American right's "epistemic closure" problem (i.e. the closing of the conservative mind), and which has subsequently been taken in all sorts of interesting directions by Matt Yglesias, Noah Millman, Megan McArdle, Sanchez again, Jonah Goldberg, and Conor Friedersdorf, among others.
Clouds of volcanic ash blanketed parts of rural Iceland as a vast, invisible plume of grit drifted over Europe, emptying the skies of planes.

Last year in an effort to cancel my Time Warner cable, I bought an Apple TV. I came home with my new fancy sleek white packaging, tore open the box and plugged the Apple TV into my television. It took about 15 minutes before I went from excited to utterly frustrated.

The securities fraud case against Goldman Sachs found its way into the Senate's debate over the financial regulatory bill on Friday as senators from both parties tried to use it to their advantage, although the Democrats seemed more vocal.
Ladies, gentlemen and park users of all ages, meet Pearl. She'll be your cartoon squirrel.
Robert Whiteman hopes to rekindle interest in the once-popular magazine, which stopped publishing in 1950.

Brands have long encouraged consumers to refer to them by nicknames or diminutives. Coca-Cola is Coke. Chevrolet is Chevy. Stolichnaya is Stoli. Now, in that same vein, Belvedere vodka is introducing a campaign that suggests calling the brand as "Belve," pronounced Bell-vee.

Pad Thai has become a takeout staple in the United States, but there is no reason to fear making it at home. This recipe is fast enough, and easy enough, that it should become a from-scratch favorite.
Mark Bittman makes the noodle dish Pad Thai with shrimp.
Apple's chief executive apparently believes that his company made a mistake when it rejected an iPhone app from a cartoonist who is now a Pulitzer Prize winner.

In 2001, T.J. Stiles, a writer now living in San Francisco, embarked on a biographical project as uncompromising and ambitious as its subject. For seven years, he holed up in an archive or wrote and rewrote in his Presidio home. The long hibernation has now been well rewarded.

This weeks rumblings of a Google slate PC stirred up the blogosphere and the Bits comments. The post A Google Tablet Could Be Good News for Adobe asked if Google could be a white knight for Adobe and its struggling Flash platform and generated a healthy debate about the future of both companies' battle against Apple's iPhone operating system. An anonymous commenter summed up Google's goals:
Professors Peter J. Henning and Steven M. Davidoff examine the stakes in the securities fraud case against Goldman Sachs.
Ford's new map-based navigation system has three options: the fastest route, the shortest route and also the "Eco-Route."

Despite the media attention given Jeffrey Katzenberg's recent negative comments about the poor-quality 3D conversion of "Clash of the Titans," the DreamWorks Animation chief executive is convinced that 3-D production is real, and will soon overtake standard 2-D fare in quantity.

Old Acapulco is finding inspiration these days in its glittery past. The latest retro revival is the Hotel Boca Chica, a '50s era hideaway that gave birth to the margarita and sheltered John Wayne and his Hollywood cronies. Reopened a few weeks ago by Grupo Habita - the ultrahip owners of the Condesa DF in Mexico City, among other culty hotels - the Antonio Peláez-designed property has 36 minimalist rooms tucked away in a quiet cove beneath pink and white modernist bungalows that spill down the seaside cliffs where Rita Hayworth shot scenes for "The Lady From Shanghai" (1947) and Elvis filmed "Fun in Acapulco" (1963).
The light-emitting diodes that are now common in traffic lights seem poised to move into more streetlights -- and to get smarter.
A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

Heath Pearce brings a soccer fan's enthusiasm and the deliberation of a graduate student to the F.C. Dallas back line. If all goes well for the 25-year-old Pearce, he will do the same for the United States national team at the World Cup in South Africa.

Edicoo, the name of a new member of Icom, a worldwide network of independent advertising agencies, is odd, but certainly not unusual in an industry whose players bear names like Anomaly and StrawberryFrog. But where Edicoo is located may seem unusual: in Erbil, in the autonomous Kurdistan region of Iraq.
Musicians never read reviews. Just ask them.
All the fashion news of the week that's fit to reprint.

It happened in Concepción, Chile, and in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, before that: dust-covered earthquake victims rescued against all odds from graves of rubble and twisted metal. We see it now in China's Qinghai Province (Slide 1), where a girl was rescued 50 hours after being buried by a 7.1-magnitude quake. The chances of survival are dimming, but rescuers keep clambering over the remnants of schools, hotels and mud-brick homes looking for signs that a few of the hundreds of people still missing might be alive (Slide 3).
New Yorkers with suddenly dashed European travel plans were not the only ones in town inconvenienced by the eruption of a volcano 2,800 miles away.

Republican members of the Senate Judiciary Committee spooled out lines of attack on Friday that may well signal the themes for the Supreme Court confirmation battle looming ahead. In a more immediate way, their criticisms and concerns portend trouble for Goodwin Liu, the appeals court nominee who testified before them today.

In the special Europe issue, Christine Muhlke, the food editor of The New York Times Magazine, searches for reasonably priced prix-fixe deals at Paris restaurants.  She finds six low-key spots opened by a new generation of young chefs.  Some forgo atmosphere on the plate and in the room, but offer creative cooking at a price most can afford.

The Goldman case today had a devastating impact on investors in Deutsche Bank, which is said to have packaged similar securities as the one in the Goldman case.  But maybe today's action indicates Deutsche is in the clear.

Over the last few years Spazio Rossana Orlandi has become a must on the the Milan design circuit. The eight-year-old charmingly ramshackle former factory is not only a showcase for everything from high-end sofas to plastic forks but also a laboratory for emerging designers.

Got a lot of questions just now from a guy who calls himself NYTourist, from New York. I'm going to break them apart because they're good questions, and answer his queries as best I can. If the answers aren't very good, and they very well might not be, it might be partly because I had lunch today - a dozen clams on the half shell followed by a salad and half a turkey club sandwich, followed by a coffee - and I'm feeling a little dazed. I went to the gym in the morning and just hammered the weights and the stair-climbing machine, and by the time I got to lunch I was ravenous. Ruh-oh. Should have gone to the gym after lunch and written in the morning instead. Either way, I would have liked to have walked about 10 more blocks than I did in advance of returning to this hot seat to write. Also because: I have a dinner reservation in a couple of hours. Welcome to my life!
In this week's Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan points to high returns in hedge funds of late and evidence that wealthy investors are creeping back in again.

Banks operating in the European Union will have to accept stricter external supervision and be required to set aside more funds to prevent another crisis under a regulatory proposal to be presented by the European Commission in June, The New York Times's Raphael Minder reports from Madrid.

The S.E.C. civil suit against Goldman Sachs essentially accuses the bank of putting together a really bad investment so a hedge fund client could short it, and then selling that investment to clients without disclosing why the investment was created.  Goldman says it did nothing wrong.
One of the more fascinating first-round N.B.A. playoff series is the all-Texas matchup between Dallas and San Antonio, mainly because it could mark the beginning of the end of the Tim Duncan era.
Adam Lach, a Polish photographer on assignment for The New York Times, has wandered through crowds and memorial events this week capturing images of a nation in shock.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil lawsuit against Goldman Sachs for securities fraud on Friday, charging the bank with creating and selling mortgage-backed securities that were intended to fail.

Remember "David After Dentist"? The video, recorded by his father, showed 7-year-old David DeVore in his car seat after minor oral surgery when he was still a bit loopy. The dad's original goal was just to forward the few minutes of footage to his wife, who was at work, to show her that their son was O.K. But then he posted it on YouTube because, well, it was just so darn adorable, launching a debate over whether it is exploitation to forever immortalize online your child  making a fool of himself.
On Media Decoder, Brian Stelter writes about a digital-age perk of winning a Pulitzer Prize: Apple might invite you to resubmit your formerly rejected iPhone application.
State Senator Pedro Espada Jr., the Bronx politician who staged a coup last summer and seized the Democratic majority leader's seat in Albany, will have some challengers of his own to fend off.

As The Lede explained on Thursday, polling after the first televised debate among the leaders of Britain's three largest parties revealed that the public was most impressed by Nick Clegg, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, who is extremely unlikely to become the country's next prime minister but may end up holding the balance of power if neither of the other parties wins a clear majority of seats on May 6.

Diversity is a catchword that's often used in fashion but pretty rarely employed. Since 1982, United Colors of Benetton has been putting its money where its mouth is through its award-winning if controversial ad campaigns. Now the Italian brand has taken the message a step further with a democratic online casting, "It's My Time." Candidates uploaded a profile with photos of themselves, and the community - yes, that's regular folks like you and me - voted on its favorites. The top 20, which included men and women from Iran, Belgium, Kazakhstan and India, were flown to New York City for a campaign shoot by the photographer Josh Olins. "It's the first time I've been here. I want to stay!" one winner, Lorenzo, a k a "Plastic is Fantastic," gushed last night at the a party in their honor at the Standard Hotel. (Plastic, he explained, "is the name of my favorite disco in Milano.")

Why do some hockey observers doubt the Washington Capitals, owners of the league's best regular-season record, can be Stanley Cup champions? For all their offensive flair and charisma, especially that of Alex Ovechkin (who was well profiled last week in The Times Sunday Magazine by Charles McGrath), they don't play a good defensive game.

Shares of Goldman Sachs fell as much as 15 percent on Friday, pulling down other financial stocks, after the Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil fraud charges against the firm, accusing it of creating subprime mortgage securities that were designed to fail. The banking sector declined as much as 2.6 percent on the news.

When is it ordinary unhappiness about the way you look, and when is it a psychological disorder? That's the question explored by Dr. Katharine A. Phillips in this week's Consults blog. Dr. Phillips, a professor of psychiatry at Brown Medical School, recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers' questions about body dysmorphic disorder, or B.D.D., an unusual condition in which people become obsessed about perceived body flaws. To learn more about B.D.D., see Personal Health columnist Jane Brody's story "When Your Looks Take Over Your Life." Dr. Phillips writes:

Back in December, I warned that Charles Schwab's generous 2 percent cash rebate credit card was in jeopardy. And sure enough, the company pulled the plug two weeks ago. It's not accepting new applications for the card, though the company isn't currently making any changes to the rewards structure for existing cardholders.

A few readers wondered whether I was referring to only a very small slice of the highest-income households when I said tax rates on the wealthy had fallen more than on any other group over the last three decades. The short answer is no.

It concluded that the project's construction and operation would have "limited adverse environmental impacts."

Airfares are expected to jump this summer, but for now, Lufthansa and Air France are having spring flight sales to Europe, good for departures through mid-May. And for lodging once you get there, Hotels.com is offering 30 percent off hundreds of European hotels.

It's impossible not to be charmed by the exhibition "Saved By Droog," for which the Dutch design brand scoured online liquidation auctions for caches of unwanted objects - like 720 soda glasses and 50 neon-orange safety vests - and then invited 14 designers to use them as raw materials. Nearly everyone here at the furniture fair did more with less this year, but few so overtly made an asset of the crisis, the business-killing tendencies of which inspired Droog to come to the aid of all those orphaned goods. Reclamation can also apparently benefit the bottom line, considering that 125 euros ($170) will net you one of 448 wallets stamped "Money does not make me happy" by the graphic designer Stefan Sagmeister. And silicone-coated wooden spoons by the Dutch food designer Marije Vogelzang are only 29.50 euros ($40). Everything is for sale on-site, and the designers get half the profits.

After a difficult winter, spring has finally arrived and Arnie, Bill, Charlie and Doug prepare for the first round of the year. At their home course, officials have marked a large area damaged by heavy snows as ground under repair (G.U.R.) in the fairway and rough. All four players play their tee shots and all four balls come to rest in the G.U.R.

Ballots were due this week for the N.B.A.'s postseason awards. Although The New York Times does not permit its reporters to vote, the N.B.A. reporters Howard Beck and Jonathan Abrams are making their picks in Off the Dribble. Today's debate is about the Executive of the Year Award.

Josh Hamilton will always have a connection with the original Yankee Stadium, where his flurry of majestic home runs was the highlight of the All-Star Game home run derby in 2008, the final year of the ballpark. Speaking in Cleveland on Wednesday, Hamilton said he was curious to see what was left of the old Yankee Stadium -- and the answer is: not much.

I'm on the road to a big conclave of college students, professors and administrators trying to build a better planet and society -- organized by former President Bill Clinton through his Clinton Global Initiative. I've moved to a university. My third book on the environment, a project of The New York Times, was for middle school kids. There's a pattern here. Youth matters.

LONDON -- Pastoral is a rare genre anywhere these days. Artists still celebrate nature but seldom the tranquil harmony between nature and civilized man. In dance, the two greatest extant pastoral masterpieces are Frederick Ashton's "La Fille mal gardée" and Mark Morris's "L'Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato." When Mr. Morris first made "L'Allegro" in Brussels in November 1988, it was just three months after Ashton had died. To some of us, connections between the two were immediately powerfully apparent: most obviously in the imagery in each work of horses, carriages and riders, of landscapes and people gazing into them, and of workers in the fields. In both, the world is young, its population innocent.

Every week, I write and star in a goofy 3-minute video about whatever I reviewed in The Times that week. It airs on CNBC at around 1:40 p.m. Thursday, and then it goes online-to nytimes.com, YouTube, iTunes, TiVo, JetBlue and so on.

New hotels continue to pop up in New York City.  Fashion 26-A Wyndham Hotel, opened this week in the city's garment district, a block away from the Fashion Institute of Technology on West 26th Street.

If the eyes are window to the soul, then the mouth is window to the gut, revealing anxieties, turmoil and hidden appetites. My partially deaf step-aunt lip-reads, and she understands me better than any other member of my family. The way a person smiles clues us into their disposition and emotional state, and whether painted, bitten or sealed, lips are constantly speaking volumes.

As long as his production doesn't go exorbitantly over budget, abruptly run out of funds, get ruined in a flash flood or drowned out by NATO aircraft drills -- all calamities that have befallen him in the past -- the director Terry Gilliam is scheduled to make his operatic debut with the English National Opera next year, The Guardian reported. Mr. Gilliam, the Monty Python alumnus whose films include "Brazil" and "The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus," and whose disaster-plagued shoot for an aborted film, "The Man Who Killed Don Quixote," was the subject of the documentary "Lost in La Mancha," will direct a production of Berlioz's "Damnation of Faust" that is planned for May 2011.

If any publicity is good publicity, then this has been an excellent week for Eliot Spitzer, the former governor of New York. In Friday's New York Times, Michiko Kakutani reviews Peter Elkind's "Rough Justice: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer," which chronicles the disgraced politician's trajectory from Sheriff of Wall Street to Client 9. Of the eight new books on the manga list on Friday, five are volumes of "One Piece." The series follows the adventures of Monkey D. Luffy, a 17-year-old adventurer and his ragtag crew on the search for One Piece, a pirate treasure. "One Piece" is incredibly popular in Japan: The Anime News Network reported that Volume 56 had a print run of 2.85 million copies. The publication schedule put forth by VIZ Media in the United States is an aggressive one. From January through June, the company plans to publish five installments a month, taking the series from volume 24 to 53. This week, Volumes 39-43 sit on the manga list. Previews of the first eight chapters are available here. The site also includes character bios and motion comics.

The issue of what you tell your employees when you're trying to sell your business is a tricky one that requires careful thought. Maintaining confidentiality surrounding the sale typically takes precedence over other concerns, yet it may be impractical -- or even impossible -- to keep employees in the dark.

Anyone out there remember soap? The Samurai Shopper does, and admits a sentimental affection for soap's plain-Jane properties. Soap may not be the most voluptuous product you've ever used, but it is efficient, disposable, a marvel of minimalism. I, like many others, traded up to fancy-pants facial gels, foams and creams that smell expensive - and are. But washing with emulsions of Meyer lemon or fig makes me think: what do figs smell like anyway, and should I smell like one?

10,000 Turn Out for Pleasanton Tea Party Rally | Political candidates like Carly Fiorina, the Republican who is trying to unseat Senator Barbara Boxer, went to the Alameda County Fair Grounds to rally Tea Party followers to their campaigns. But most of the talk during the five-hour rally focused on general discontent with the Obama administration's economic policies and the recently passed health care legislation. "This is great timing for us," said Bridget Melson, the president of the Pleasanton T.E.A. (Taxed Enough Already) Party and the event's organizer. "The passing of the health care bill has incensed and fired people up." Among the slogans visible at the event was: "Vote the traitors out in November." A New York Times poll shows that Tea Party supporters are wealthier than the general public, tend to be Republican and classify themselves as "angry." [The Contra Costa Times, The New York Times]

Many alternative-fuel companies are cash-poor, which means they spend a lot of their time chasing government loans and private capital. SunHydro, a start-up founded by Tom Sullivan to establish a solar-powered fuel-cell car refueling network on the East Coast, doesn't have that immediate challenge. For years, the Roman street artist was written off as a vandal who worked under the cover of night to prevent being apprehended by police. Slowly, this reputation has evolved and now many artists are featured in private galleries, awarded corporate sponsorships, and even granted public spaces by city authorities. This spring, three Roman neighborhoods will host street art exhibitions in which once anonymous artists will produce their work in public view for the first time.

ROOSEVELT--Emily. The extended Roosevelt and Foehl families mourn the death of our dear Emily who passed away suddenly and unexpectedly on April 11, 2010, at home in Park City, Utah. Born in White Plains, New York on August 13, 1969, Emily demonstrated to all who knew and loved her that she would live life to the fullest with no regrets. Empathy, inquisitiveness, courage, and determination defined her daily life. Emily graduated from Whitby School, The Millbrook School, the University of Virginia, and the University of Maine School of Law. She served with distinction as a law clerk for The Honorable Judge Monroe McKay of the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit in Salt Lake City from 1997 to 2000. In 2000, until her death, she worked in the Regional Solicitor's office of the United States Department of the Interior in Salt Lake City, Utah where she worked tirelessly on behalf of public land issues. In June 2008, Emily received the greatest gift of all a new heart. We want to thank the team at University of Utah Hospital for giving her the best care possible. We also extend our profound thanks to Emily's donor and family for giving her a new lease on life. Since receiving her new heart, Emily became an outspoken advocate for organ donation and patient care, helping to raise funds and awareness, supporting others going through the transplant process, and serving as the master of ceremonies for the ribbon cutting of the Patient Care Pavilion at the University of Utah Hospital in July 2009. Emily will be forever missed and celebrated by all her "stars and angels" including her husband, Peter Foehl; her sons Mason and Liam; her parents Chris and Roddy Roosevelt; her sister Kate and her partner Caroline; her brother Chris, his wife Christina, and their sons Noah and Wylie; her in-laws Allen and Sally Foehl; Pete's brother Chas, his wife Sara, and their children Walker and Reed; Pete's brother Dave and his wife Carol; her beloved grandmother Rosalind E. Havemeyer; many uncles, aunts, and cousins; and a huge community of friends and colleagues across the country. Emily would have wanted everyone to become an organ donor (organdonor.gov), rather than sending flowers. You may also honor her life by donating to Intermountain Donor Services (c/o Debbie Snider, IDS, 230 S. 500 E., Ste. 290, Salt Lake City, UT 84102) or the charity of your choice. A celebration of Emily's life will be held on Saturday, April 17 at 4pm at Park City Community Church, 4501 N. Highway 224, Park City, Utah. The family will be providing further information about a memorial service to be held in New England this summer.

DENVER - When Gary Matthews Jr. was growing up at his father's side in ballparks around the National League, he saw role models everywhere. There was his father, of course, and teammates and opponents such as Bobby Bonds, Joe Morgan, Dusty Baker and Willie McCovey. But in the current Mets clubhouse, Matthews is the only player who can fill that role for young African-American Mets fans. That's because he is the only black player on the team, a vivid example of the diminishing participation of African-Americans in baseball.

GRIBETZ--Donald, M.D. The Department of Pediatrics at the Kravis Children's Hospital of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine expresses our heartfelt sadness on the passing of Dr. Donald Gribetz. Dr. Gribetz joined our Department in 1953 as a newly minted and expertly trained pediatrician. Over the ensuing decades, he established himself as a pillar of intellectual achievement and integrity, a role model for future generations of doctors, and a giant in the field of Pediatrics. As a dedicated and talented teacher, he influenced the careers of countless students and residents during his lifetime. As a physician, Dr. Gribetz was unparalleled in his care and compassion for his patients. Dr. Gribetz was the recipient of many honors and awards for outstanding professionalism and service to Mount Sinai and to the field of Pediatrics. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Edith; his children, Beverly, Ed, Richard, Paula, Michael; and the entire family. We are honored to include Dr. Irwin Gribetz among our faculty and Judah Gribetz on our Board of Trustees at Mount Sinai. We extend our deepest sympathies to Irwin and Harriet, and to Judah and Jessica. Lisa M. Satlin, M.D., Chair, and the entire Department of Pediatrics.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the city's teachers union have agreed to do away with ''rubber rooms'' and speed up hearings for teachers accused of wrongdoing or incompetence, ending a disciplinary system that has made both City Hall and the teachers' union subjects of ridicule. Under the agreement, teachers the city is trying to fire will no longer be sent to the rubber rooms, known as reassignment centers, where the teachers show up every school day, sometimes for years, doing no work and drawing full salaries. Instead, these teachers will be assigned to administrative work or duties outside classrooms in their schools while their cases are pending.

Frank was elected to the BCNY Board of Trustees in 1964, served on the Education Committee for 23 years, eight as a Chairman. A recipient of "The Man Behind the Boy Award" in 1992, the "Frank Mansell Scholarship Fund" was established in 1989 in honor of his remarkable contribution to the lives of our boys. His generosity, good humor and commitment to the welfare of youth will be remembered by us all with deep affection. As friend, supporter and Trustee, Frank embodied The Boys' Club of New York's core principles of character, civility, community, and citizenship. The Boys Club of New York

PORTLAND, Ore. -- The regular season came to a bizarre end here Wednesday night, in a game between the league's two most injury-depleted teams. As the playoff-bound Trail Blazers mostly rested their key players in a game that had no consequence for their postseason positioning, the low-run Golden State Warriors brought just eight players. Two of them (Ronny Turiaf and Anthony Morrow) were declared unfit to play by the team's trainer during warmups. Midway through the first quarter, center Chris Hunter aggravated his knee. So Coach Don Nelson, who recently became the career victories leader, used five players for the rest of the game. Well, he tried. When Devean George fouled out in the fourth quarter, Nelson argued that he had no players left and that George could remain in the game while the Warriors were assessed a technical foul. Officials said that one of the other players on the bench must enter the game. The game stalled as the sides argued. Ultimately, Nelson lost the argument. He inserted Hunter for about a minute. Then he pulled him for Turiaf, who fouled seven seconds later. Nelson took Turiaf out and inserted Morrow, who played nine seconds. Finally George, with six fouls, came in to finish the final 3 minutes, 29 seconds, and the Warriors were assessed a technical foul. ''They made me put injured players in,'' Nelson said after the game. ''That's not right.'' Warriors players missed more than 500 combined games because of injuries this season. But with Stephen Curry (42 points, 9 rebounds, 8 assists), Monta Ellis (34 points), Anthony Tolliver and Reggie Williams each playing 48 minutes, they managed to beat the Blazers, 122-116. It was Nelson's 1,335th career victory. The Warriors finished 26-56, and the Blazers (50-32) head to a first-round matchup with Phoenix. ''What a bizarre game, huh?'' Nelson said. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

GINGOLD--Evelyn Block, passed away at the age of 90 on April 14, 2010. She was born in 1920 and graduated from Hunter College in 1941. She became the first Western Union messenger girl and later a cryptographer during g the war. She married Sol Gingold, a dentist and a school friend of her brother, in 1942. They raised three daughters, Arleen, Janet Marcus and Laurie Frankel. They lived in Great Neck amid a large family for over 45 years until Sol's death in 2003. Evelyn lived in Florida since 2004, although she returned to Great Neck in the summer for as long as she was able. She was the last one left in the family of her generation. As well as her daughters she leaves behind three grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

MANSELL--Frank L.,of Hobe Sound, Florida and East Hampton, New York, died peacefully on April 14 at his home in Florida. His wife for 42 years, Edmona Lyman Mansell, died in 1999. He is survived by his daughters, Devon Mansell Laycox, Sherborn, MA and Jessica Mansell Ambrose, East Hampton, NY, his step-sons, Robert L. Miller of Malibu, CA, Christian F. Miller of Missoula, MT, and Charles B. Miller of Virginia City, MT, 14 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. His sister, Mary Ross, of Omaha, Nebraska preceded him in death in March. A step-son, Gordon E. Miller of Santa Fe, NM died in 2006. Mr. Mansell was born in Omaha, Nebraska in 1922 and resided in Omaha until leaving for military service in 1943. Following service as a Naval Officer aboard an aircraft carrier in the Pacific Theatre in World War II, he graduated from the University of Nebraska at Omaha in 1944, and from Harvard Business School in 1948 where he was a Baker Scholar. He began a 40-year career in investment banking in 1948. Most of his years on Wall Street were spent with Blyth & Co., where he became President of the firm. He then was Vice Chairman and Chairman of the Executive Committee of Blyth Eastman Dillon Co., later, Chairman and CEO of the investment banking subsidiary of Paine Webber, Blyth Eastman Paine Webber. Mr. Mansell was a Trustee of Freedom Institute, an Honorary Trustee of the Boys Club of New York, a Trustee of the University of Nebraska Foundation, and a Trustee of the Jupiter Hospital Foundation. An avid golfer, Mr. Mansell was a member of golf clubs on both the East and West coasts, including The Maidstone Club, Seminole Golf Club, Cypress Point Club, Augusta National Golf Club and the Jupiter Island Club. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Freedom Institute, of New York City, and to The Frank Mansell Endowment Scholarship Fund of The Boys Club of New York. A Memorial service will be held on Monday, April 19th, 2010 at the Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island, FL at 11am.

My Sunday column is about the other Catholic Church, the one I have learned to admire for its work among the poorest people around the globe. It has tended to be the bishops and cardinals who have gotten the church in trouble, while it's the amazing priests, nuns and lay-workers who do extraordinary work at home and around the world. And as I note in the column, I've learned from meeting nuns in Africa, Asia and Latin America that the coolest and toughest people in the world are nuns. Their orphanages, hospitals and schools keep the world going.

INDIO, Calif. - Coachella's two head-to-head headliners on Friday night, blasting away simultaneously on adjacent stages, were opposites in some ways. Jay-Z was the triumphal capitalist, touting his business savvy and long-term success with a big band, a full stage production - complete with a video backdrop and an entrance via lift - and a glamorous cameo from Beyonce, his wife, that was topped with fireworks. Public Image Ltd. (PiL on its logo), playing John Lydon's pioneering post-punk songs for its first tour in 18 years, was the unglamorous naysayer, sneering at capitalism (in its opening tune, "This Is Not a Love Song") and singing about death, antisocial thoughts and lifelong trauma.

MANSELL--Frank. The Board of Trustees of Jupiter Medical Center Foundation extend their deepest sympathy to the family of Frank L. Mansell. Mr. Mansell served as a dedicated member of the Foundation Board since 1997. Recognized as a Distinguished Grand Founder, the Cardio-Pulmonary Suites are named in Edmona and Frank Mansell's honor. He served as a philanthropic catalyst for the Medical Center's most critical initiatives and his passing will leave an indelible void in our community. Peter O. Crisp, Chairman Richard L. Cosnotti President and CEO The Jupiter Medical Center Foundation.

The market wasted little time in rushing to a particularly harsh judgment against Goldman Sachs on Friday, slicing some $12.4 billion off the company's market value after the Securities and Exchange Commission filed a blockbuster civil suit against the firm and a vice president who works there. The commission says Goldman failed to disclose to investors how a complicated mortgage-backed security was made and the conflicts that resulted from it. What makes the market's pounding particularly painful is that early next week, Goldman's stock likely would have soared after it announced huge earnings for the first quarter; instead, the S.E.C.'s civil complaint has crushed it.

MANSELL--Frank L. The Board of Trustees, Staff and Alumni of Freedom Institute mourn the loss of Frank L. Mansell, and extend their deepest sympathies to his family. Mr. Mansell served on Freedom Institute's Board for eleven years, and helped the Institute continue to flourish after the passing of its founder, and his wife, Mona Mansell, in 1999. His support had tremendous impact on many families seeking recovery from alcoholism and substance abuse. Mr. Mansell was a generous benefactor, sound advisor, and loyal friend whose dedication served as an example to us all. He will be remembered fondly. Freedom Institute

(HBO) FOUR CHRISTMASES (2008) Reese Witherspoon and Vince Vaughn, above, star as Kate and Brad, an unmarried San Francisco couple who each Christmas invent a charity project as an excuse to take a hedonistic vacation and avoid festivities with their dysfunctional families. But when a news reporter points a camera their way just as their trip to Fiji is canceled, they have no choice but to make the rounds. Robert Duvall and Sissy Spacek play Brad's divorced parents; Mary Steenburgen and Jon Voight are Kate's. The cast includes Tim McGraw and Jon Favreau as Brad's feral, cage-fighting brothers, and Kristin Chenoweth as Kate's relentlessly fertile sister. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that, in a break from holiday movie tradition, the film, ''briskly directed by Seth Gordon from a snappy, many-authored script, is refreshingly tart and lean, forgoing the usual schmaltz and syrup.'' 10:30 A.M. OWENS--Bennett Lee, 83, of Pittsboro, North Carolina, died on Thursday, April 15, 2010 at his home in Fearrington Village, surrounded by loved ones. The cause of death was cancer. Bennett was born on July 25, 1926 in Cincinnati, Ohio to Burleigh and Esther Owens. He graduated from Denison University after serving in the United States Navy for two years. He met Elizabeth Richards at Denison and married her in July, 1948. Bennett went on to earn his Bachelor of Divinity from Yale Divinity School in 1952. Reverend Owens served as minister at the First Baptist Church of Sidney, Ohio and the New Mountview Baptist Church, and was Curate of St. Albans Church in Bexley, Ohio. In 1965 he was the interim Episcopal Chaplain at Brown University in Providence, Rhode Island. Mr. Owens and his family moved to Montclair, New Jersey in 1966, and for the next two years he was Coordinator of Voluntary Services for the National Episcopal Church. During this time he also ministered to jazz musicians in New York City and conducted the first ever jazz communion service in National Cathedral in Washington, DC, with Bishop Daniel T. Corrigan, a civil rights leader. He also worked as a writer for the Robert F. Kennedy presidential campaign. Bennett spent the majority of his career as Assistant to the Executive Director of the Ministers and Missionaries Benefit Board. He retired in 1988 and soon thereafter he and his wife moved to Vero Beach, Florida, where they resided from 1990-2004. Bennett is predeceased by his only brother, Lloyd, and his oldest son, Timothy. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth; son, Christopher and daughter-in-law, Suderat of Austin, Texas; daughter, Stephanie and son-in-law, Mark Lurie of Montclair, New Jersey; daughter, Cynthia and son-in-law, Phillip Bors of Pittsboro, North Carolina; daughter-in-law, Susan Owens of Naples, Florida; seven grandchildren: Kelsey Gale Owens, Bee and First Owens, Matthew and Jordan Lurie, Allory and Isabel Bors; brother-in-law, David O. Richards of Granville, Ohio; and sister-in-law, Louise Richards of Oberlin, Ohio. A private memorial service will be held in North Carolina at a later date. Those who wish may contribute to UNC Hospice, P.O. Box 1077, Pittsboro, NC 27312. Hall-Wynne Funeral Service is helping the family with the services.

KRINSLY--Charlotte. Born February 19, 1918 in New York City and died peacefully at home at age 92. Charlotte was the daughter of Joseph and Etta Wolf. For 58 years, she was married to Stuart Krinsly, who died in 2002. Together they traveled extensively for his business and their pleasure. Their fascination of the world took them to all continents, except Antarctica. Charlotte co-founded Art-on-Tour in 1955, a non-profit school exhibit service that received grants from the Museum Aid Program of the New York State Council of the Arts. She received a New York State Award in 1968 from the New York Council on the Arts, awarded by Nelson Rockefeller "for bringing the fine and folk arts of many regions and periods to children who might otherwise grow up in ignorance of a major part of their cultural heritage". She is survived by two daughters, Ellin (Arie van Duijn) Krinsly and Joan (Barry) Rosenthal, her brother Daniel Wolf and three grandchildren, Stephanie, Doug and Carolyn. Funeral services will take place at 11:30am on Sunday at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81st St). In lieu of flowers, donations to Westchester Medical Center, White Plains, NY.
RAEBURN--Robert A.,12/25/1929-4/17/2007. Deeply loved, sorely missed. Donna and Family

TAYLOR--Marvin, 81, passed away peacefully on April 15. Affectionately known as "Mr. Queens College," Marvin began his career in education teaching in a one room schoolhouse eventually earning a Professorship of Psychology at Queens College in 1955. He rose to become Dean of Education there, and retired as Provost in 1992 to pursue a career playing his beloved saxophone. His humor and wisdom will be sorely missed. Marvin Taylor is survived by his wife, Carol, his daughter, Michele, son David and grandchildren Justin and Carlee. Funeral Sunday at 1pm at Gutterman's in Woodbury, L.I.

MAYNARD--William Harrison, Jr. died Thursday at his home in Larchmont, NY with his family by his side. He was born to William H. and Charlotte (Wadlin) Maynard in Poughkeepsie, NY in 1929. He grew up in Highland, New York with his brother Frederick and sister Audrey (deceased). In 1954, Bill married Marilyn (Goewey) of Newburgh, New York. The couple spent their summers on Martha's Vineyard since 1980. Bill is survived by his loving wife Marilyn, his brother Fred (Venus), daughter Laurie and sons William H. Maynard III, Christopher and Mary (Devine), and Jeffrey, and grandchildren, William H. Maynard IV, Sarah Oommen, Elvis Maynard, James Wyatt Maynard, Hannah Maynard, Luke Maynard and Liam Maynard. Visiting Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 pm at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. Larchmont, NY.

Mathematical signs and symbols are often cryptic, but the best of them offer visual clues to their own meaning. The symbols for zero, one and infinity aptly resemble an empty hole, a single mark and an endless loop: 0, 1, ∞.  And the equals sign, =, is formed by two parallel lines because, in the words of its originator, Welsh mathematician Robert Recorde in 1557, "no two things can be more equal."

To the Sports Editor: Re ''The Dixie Walker She Knew,'' April 11: As a University of Kentucky basketball fan, because of the continuing mainstream condemnation of Coach Adolph Rupp, I can relate to the Walker family's quandary regarding the perception of Dixie Walker as a racist.

For years, only a simple sign indicated the location of what was once the Nazi secret police headquarters in Berlin. ''You are standing on the grounds of the former torture chambers of the Gestapo,'' it read. More recently, an outdoor exhibition, called ''The Topography of Terror,'' has marked the spot. On May 7, the exhibition is scheduled to get a new home: a glass and concrete museum and documentation center built on same site. The building (Niederkirchnerstrasse 8; 49-30-25-45-09-50; topographie.de), which cost just over 21 million euros, about $28 million, includes exhibition spaces, a multimedia research library, and seminar rooms. A main draw will be a permanent exhibition that examines Nazism and its victims. And there will be physical reminders of the city's past: The Berlin Wall once ran right through the area, and a section of the infamous barrier remains intact along the border of the new complex.

To the Editor: Re ''In Currency Games, the Prize May Be a Trade War'' (April 11), which saw a threat of Chinese retaliation against possible United States trade measures to counterbalance an undervalued Chinese currency:

THE Spanish police have stopped what appears to have been a daring strategy by an enterprising band of drug smugglers, who the police say tried to use the Dakar Rally in January to cover up their tracks. Agence France-Presse reported that the smugglers disguised a truck to look like a support vehicle for the rally, which was moved to South America from Africa last year. Photos from the police show a silver truck with logos for Red Bull and the Dakar Rally on its side panels and a graphic of a racecar on the rear doors.

(13, 49) SMALL ISLAND Two couples -- one Jamaican, one English -- find their lives tragically intertwined in postwar Britain in this ''Masterpiece Classic'' adaptation of the 2004 novel by Andrea Levy, which won the Orange and Whitbread prizes for fiction. Naomie Harris and David Oyelowo, above, play Hortense and Gilbert Joseph, recent immigrants from the West Indies in a marriage of convenience. Ruth Wilson is their landlady, the working-class Queenie Bligh, whose husband, Bernard (Benedict Cumberbatch), has been mysteriously absent for a couple of years -- and whose offer of friendship exacts a great price. Part 2 will be shown on April 25. Laura Linney hosts. 5:30 P.M. (HBO) MASTERCLASS For more than 25 years, YoungArts, a program of the National Foundation for Advancement in the Arts, has offered scholarships and mentoring to emerging high school artists. This new nine-part series follows several of these young musicians, dancers, writers, actors and visual artists as they meet with masters in their fields, starting with the tenor Plácido Domingo. Other luminaries are Edward Albee, Bill T. Jones, Liv Ullmann, Frank Gehry, Julian Schnabel, Michael Tilson Thomas, Jacques D'Amboise and Olafur Eliasson. Writing in The New York Times, Neil Genzlinger said, ''The program is must viewing for all those high school students with dreams of stardom of one sort or another, and for their teachers.''

In an article in The Times and a post on The Choice blog last week, Jacques Steinberg described how Duke University had offered places on its waiting list to 3,383 freshman applicants -- 856 more than a year ago. Here are excerpts from the reader comments on The Choice: It's all about the usual niceties of the makeup of the class, and who can blame them? They want the same exact makeup for their class, regardless of which admitted applicant chooses to go elsewhere, and who can blame these admissions officers? It is like casting a play.

PEARLMAN--Hubert S.,M.D. F.A.C.S., age 83. A father who relished his sons, Fred, Henry, and George, and adored his deceased wife Lucy, passed away on April 16, 2010, in his sleep. He was married 53 years. His grandchildren Lindsey, Samantha and Max were his special joy. He is survived by his sister Eleanor Kostant. He graduated from the University of Illinois, College of Medicine in 1950. He was an undergraduate at Northwestern University, and served in the U.S. Navy in WWII. He trained in general surgery at Maimonides Hospital and volunteered for the Korean Conflict, serving in the U.S. Army as a captain. He trained in orthopedic surgery at Kings County/Downstate, where he has remained on the faculty, going through the ranks to full clinical professor. He served on the staffs of several hospitals in Brooklyn. He organized and ran a fully accredited training program in orthopedic surgery at Maimonides from 1965 to 1993. He had served as chief at Lutheran Medical Center and consultant at Methodist Hospital. He was the author of over thirty scientific articles in his field, portions of two text books, received grants for a number of fundamental orthopedic research projects. He coauthored two scientific motion pictures, and made numerous presentations. He described an entity known as Nivergelt-Pearlman syndrome. He served as President of the Kings County Medical Society, was a councilor to the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons,, a delegate to the New York State Medical Society, a founder member of the Eastern Orthopedic Association, serving on its first executive committee. He was also a cofounder of the Brooklyn Orthopedic Society, He served as chairman of the orthopedic section of the New York Academy of Medicine. He was a member of the Academic Orthopedic Association.. His special qualities for poetry, wit and loyalty will be missed. Services will be held Monday, April 19, 2010, at the Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, (near Avenue V), at 9:15am.

BERNSTEIN--Howard, CPA, 91. Husband of Muriel, daughter Susan and husband Bruce, sons Harvey Bruce and Robert Marc, grandfather, great-grandfather. Graduate of University of Pennsylvania Wharton School, veteran of WWII. Graveside service Monday at 3pm in Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY.

JOHNSON--Deirdre Jones, of Greenwich, CT and Charlottesville, VA died peacefully at her home in Charlottesville on April 12, 2010 with two children by her side. Deirdre was born on February 15, 1930 in New York to Lillian Hartigan Gibbs and Douglas Seymour Gibbs. When her father died in 1941, Deirdre went to live with Dr. Edward Hallaran Jones and Margaret Stuart Jones of San Angelo, TX, Hendersonville, NC, Nokomis, FL and New York City. She was a graduate of The Spence School and Vassar College. Deirdre served as a volunteer with the Greenwich Hospital Auxiliary. She helped organize the Decorator Show House to benefit Vassar College and she served as a Trustee for the Taft School. Deirdre was a member of the Round Hill Club and the Field Club in Greenwich, CT, the Colony Club in New York, The Onteora Club in Tannersville, NY, Farmington Country Club in Charlottesville, VA, and the Mill Reef Club in Antigua, West Indies. A memorial service will be held on May 14, 2010 at Saint Barnabas Church in Greenwich followed by a reception at the Round Hill Club. She is survived by her four children; Deirdre and Megan LeBoutillier, Katharine Lagedrost, and Henry Fairfax Ayres III, and six grandchildren; Elizabeth, Jennifer and Christopher Lagedrost, Brennan, Andrew James and Molly Ayres. She will be remembered for her beauty, her impeccable sense of style and her sense of humor.

Each week on the City Room blog, editors select a New Yorker to answer readers' questions. Here are excerpts from last week's Q. and A. with Alison Lowenstein, the author of ''City Kid New York: The Ultimate Guide for NYC Parents With Kids Ages 4-12'' (Rizzoli/Universe 2010).This week Dr. Laura Erickson-Schroth, who is currently working on ''Trans Bodies, Trans Selves,'' a resource guide for transgender and other gender-variant people, is responding to readers' questions about transgender life. Q. I would like to begin to take my 4-year-old son to Broadway shows now that he is old enough to enjoy them and can sit through them. We have seen ''The Gazillion Bubble Show,'' and we are going to see ''Imaginocean'' soon. ''Stomp'' will be on the list, too. I know there are often minimum ages posted on the shows' Web sites, with 4 or 5 usually being it -- but do you have any opinion about ''Fela!''? I heard it is great fun with music and dancing in the aisles. Although the theme will likely go way over his head, I think he would love it. Please let me know what you think!

KRINSLY--Charlotte. Born February 19, 1918 in New York City and died peacefully at home at age 92. Charlotte was the daughter of Joseph and Etta Wolf. For 58 years, she was married to Stuart Krinsly, who died in 2002. Together they traveled extensively for his business and their pleasure. Their fascination of the world took them to all continents, except Antarctica. Charlotte co-founded Art-on-Tour in 1955, a non-profit school exhibit service that received grants from the Museum Aid Program of the New York State Council of the Arts. She received a New York State Award in 1968 from the New York Council on the Arts, awarded by Nelson Rockefeller "for bringing the fine and folk arts of many regions and periods to children who might otherwise grow up in ignorance of a major part of their cultural heritage". She is survived by two daughters, Ellin (Arie van Duijn) Krinsly and Joan (Barry) Rosenthal, her brother Daniel Wolf and three grandchildren, Stephanie, Doug and Carolyn. Funeral services will take place at 11:30am on Sunday at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81st St). In lieu of flowers, donations to Westchester Medical Center, White Plains, NY.

In January 2009, Michael Najjar of Berlin was part of a team that ascended and took photographs of Mount Aconcagua in Argentina, and he was struck by how much the silhouette of the mountain--the Western Hemisphere's highest, at more than 22,800 feet--resembled a stock-price chart. Using Photoshop, he digitally altered the mountain's outlines so that they traced trajectories of nine market movements over time, in a series he calls ''High Altitude.'' (There is some artistic license: the chart lines of the Dow, Russian Trading System and Nasdaq composite run from the far left of the corresponding images to about two-thirds of the way across. The Lehman ''mountain'' is at an angle.) On the mountainside as with investing, Mr. Najjar notes, if you focus solely on the summit's glory you might ignore the risks and fall. These photographs, he says, are an effort to ''rematerialize'' market data so it is more understandable.

The Town Hall Hotel & Apartments, a 98-room boutique hotel set to open this month in the gritty surrounds of London's Bethnal Green, is being hailed as further proof that the city's east end is firmly on the road to chicness. Built a century ago, the imposing Edwardian building was reimagined by Loh Lik Peng, a hotelier with history of developing cool design hotels in Singapore. Much of the grand interior remains, with swaths of oak paneling and marble floors, a soaring glazed dome and vast mahogany-walled suites.

THE EYJAFJALLAJOKULL VOLCANO, Iceland's largest, had slept for nearly 200 years before awakening on the night of March 20. The first visible sign was a red cloud glowing above the vast glacier that covers it. Over the next few days, fire fountains began spewing hot magma as high as 300 feet into sky; lava flowed in molten rivers 60 feet thick. The mountain then seemed to return to its slumber before a spectacular explosion on Wednesday sent a plume of ash more than 30,000 feet into the atmosphere.

HOWARTH--Dushka, Gurdjieff's Daughter Dies. 1924-2010. Dushka Howarth died on March 28th at the age of 85. The daughter of George Ivanovich Gurdjieff and Jessmin Howarth, Dushka was a multifaceted and highly creative woman: in early life, a publicist for such renown entertainers in the Harlem jazz scene as Nat King Cole and Dick Hymen; later, a talented popular singer with a huge multicultural repertory; still later, returning to her roots, a dedicated teacher and advisor for the Gurdjieff Sacred Dances. She devoted her last years to preserving the heritage of her father and mother, in part by founding the Gurdjieff Heritage Society. Her archival efforts resulted in the publication of a complete set of Gurdjieff's harmonium music in 2005, and soon after recordings of the original orchestral scores for Gurdjieff's Oriental Suite. In 2009, she published a 500 page memoir and family photo album, "It's Up To Ourselves": A Mother, A Daughter, and Gurdjieff. Dushka was truly unique. She will be remembered. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made at: Gurdjieff-Heritage-Society.org. A Celebration of Dushka Howarth's Life will be held on May 21 at 6:30pm at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Ave. Visit website and RSVP to: celebration@gurdjieff- heritage-society.org.

KELLEY--Didi, on April 13, 2010. Born Deirdre Sharon Kelley to Hortense and Gordon P. Kelley December 28, 1932. Sister to Lynne Poole and Gordon P. Kelley, Jr. Partner and best friend to Mary Ann (M.A.) Knoke. Beloved mother to Hope, Juli, Hunter, Brooke, and Steve. Grandmother to Antonia, Camille, G. Hopper, Kyle, Max, Miles, Stefan, and Zephyr. Didi was a journalist, an activist, an unyielding champion of civil rights, the women's movement, AIDS awareness and numerous humanitarian efforts. Born in Chicago, Didi traveled the world, living in Thailand, Italy, and Nicaragua. An outspoken critic of American imperialism, she marched against the war in Vietnam, wars in Latin America and the Middle East. She worked in New York City at the "God Box," with the Methodist Church, and traveled to Haiti to help deliver humanitarian aid there. She lived and worked in Bangkok where she wrote for the Bangkok World newspaper and later co-owned and worked as a journalist for Chaturat Magazine - a radical, left wing monthly. Later, she lived in Managua where she worked with the humanitarian organization C.E.P.A.D. to help create an independent Nicaragua. In New York, she became a spokesperson for New York's Suffolk County Chapter of ACT-UP and founded Thursday's Child, an organization in Long Island that provided housing for families with AIDS. Didi dedicated herself to advocating for, writing about, and giving voice to society's oppressed, ignored, and forgotten. Her passions were her five children and her partner, Mary Ann Knoke. Didi was a great listener and a tireless source of encouragement, advice, and support. She died from ailments too numerous to mention, most of which were related to cigarette smoking. She leaves a legacy of perseverance, compassion, generosity, and strength. She was a diligent warrior, a devoted humanitarian, and a beautiful soul. She was a true giver and we will all miss her deeply.

EXPLORING THE RING OF KERRY, IRELAND, APRIL 3, 2010. Mathilde Varenne, 22, right, an au pair from Paris working in Dublin, points across the River Laune, near the town of Killorglin, during a trip around western Ireland with her friends Ana Marin Lopezosa, center, and Sonia Ferrer Cuni. ''I wanted to learn English, but I wanted to stay in Europe because the States or Australia were so far from my family. I'm half Spanish, and I think the people, the way of life in Ireland are quite similar to Spain's, which is what attracted me there. This trip west was my best trip since I've been here. We did the Ring of Kerry, and then the Dingle Peninsula and Cork. I'm leaving soon, but I feel like I can leave now after this trip. The color is amazing -- green everywhere. We rented these bikes and did, like, 20 kilometers in strong winds and pouring rain, but it was really fun. Ireland wouldn't be the same with sunshine.'' As told to Austin Considine

Rail Europe, in partnership with Switzerland Tourism, is offering 50 percent off Swiss Passes for adults, while children 16 and younger ride for free. The Switzerland Family Rail Sale takes place April 21 to 27, and is valid for travel within six months of purchase. The sale covers two types of tickets: The 8-day consecutive pass, which will start at $193, and the three-day Flexipass, which will start at $128 and can be used for consecutive or non-consecutive travel over the course of one month. The tickets grant unlimited travel on all Swiss trains, boats and postal buses, and free admission to more than 400 of the country's museums.

COHEN--Rosalie Palter, 99, of New Orleans and Cincinnati, died peacefully on April 7. Predeceased by husband Joseph Cohen M.D., and sister Mildred Brown. Mother of Carmel J. Cohen (Babette) and Sharon Leviton (Jim); grandmother of Lisa Cohen Liman (Lewis); Jonathan Cohen (Mariza); and David Leviton. Great-grandmother of five. Inspired by her mentor, the eminent poet and scholar Ephraim Lisitsky, Rosalie became a scholar of Jewish learning and philosophy. She embraced the concept of Tikkun Olam, and created programs and institutions that became the bedrock of the New Orleans Jewish Community. She was the first female president of the Jewish Federation of New Orleans from 1959 to 1961; a cofounder in 1960 of the New Orleans Lemann Stern Young Leadership Group, which educates young Jewish women and men in leadership skills and philanthropy; and, in 1962, of the Home for the Jewish Aged, now Woldenberg Village. She developed educational programs for New Orleans's Jewish women: the New Orleans Enduring Heritage Institute, 19651972; a forum for presidents of Jewish women's organizations, 1980s; and a Torah study group, 19851993. At the national level, she was the first elected female vice president of the American Council of Jewish Federations, 19631965, and she was in the leadership of Hadassah. She was a founding member of the National Foundation for Jewish Culture (NFJC) in 1960. Possessing physical beauty, charm, idealism, and determination, she was just 19 when she and husband Joe honeymooned at the 1929 World Zionist Congress in Zurich, at which the Jewish Agency was born. They were soon (erroneously) reported killed in Arab-Jewish skirmishes in Palestine. 75 years later she became a refugee of Hurricane Katrina. In the years between, she built a family and was a cherished friend and mentor. New Orleans was her home, but the institutions that she inspired extend nationally and internationally. She once said, simply, "I have had a vision of what a Jewish community ought to be, and I felt I had a responsibility." Funeral services were held in New Orleans on Sunday, April 11 at Congregation Shir Chadash.

NOY--Max, passed away Friday night at 4:14 pm. He also was a generous supporter of three hospitals in Israel. Max Noy was a man who will be fondly remembered by all who knew him. He is survived by his daughter Ruth, his grandsons Bob and Gary and his two great-grandchildren, Lisa and Alec/ Services Monday 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

After an 82-game season of teams grinding it out for position, the N.B.A. playoffs can seem like an entirely different game. A team can get away with an undersize player in the middle during the regular season, the way the 2006-7 Warriors did with Al Harrington, but that weakness is often highlighted in the playoffs, as when Harrington had to face the much larger Carlos Boozer in the second round. The Dallas Mavericks, who coasted into this season's playoffs as the No. 2 seed in the Western Conference, will be hoping that Jason Kidd, the team's veteran point guard and potential Hall of Famer, does not have a drop-off in production as he had in the playoffs the last two seasons, a trend often attributed to a lack of quickness.

Last Thursday's televised party leaders' debate--the first in British history--injected new energy into a lackluster election campaign. The incumbent prime minister, Gordon Brown of the Labour Party, still faces a tough fight from his Conservative opponent, David Cameron--though with the polls swinging toward the third-party Liberal Democrats there is the real possibility of a ''hung Parliament.'' If Americans sometimes find their electoral-college math baffling, the vagaries of Britain's unwritten constitution are even more rococo. Below are some oddities of British electoral tradition.

MILLER--Duncan, 85, of Ocean Reef, FL and Black Butte, OR, died at his Florida home on April 1, 2010. He was born in Scarsdale, NY to Clifton Miller and Emily Thompson Miller. He served in the US Army stationed in Puerto Rico. He met his bride 41 years ago and married her in 1976. They have been winter residents of Ocean Reef for the past 40 years, and enjoyed spending the summers in Black Butte, OR. He was an investment advisor on Wall Street and in Connecticut. He was an outdoorsman and an avid fisherman and golfer but his passion was bonefishing. Duncan was predeceased by his parents and a step brother E. Carroll "Stony" Stollenwerck. Duncan is survived by his loving wife Margaret "Peg" and a brother Clifton (Carole) Miller, Jr. of Florida and several nieces and nephews. He will be greatly missed. A private service was held. Beyer Funeral Home was entrusted with the funeral services.

MANSELL--Frank L. The Board of Trustees, Staff and Alumni of Freedom Institute mourn the loss of Frank L. Mansell, and extend their deepest sympathies to his family. Mr. Mansell served on Freedom Institute's Board for eleven years, and helped the Institute continue to flourish after the passing of its founder, and his wife, Mona Mansell, in 1999. His support had tremendous impact on many families seeking recovery from alcoholism and substance abuse. Mr. Mansell was a generous benefactor, sound advisor, and loyal friend whose dedication served as an example to us all. He will be remembered fondly. Freedom Institute

THERE is a scene in the new documentary ''Vidal Sassoon: The Movie'' in which the legendary hairstylist is having a candid conversation with the designer Mary Quant. He tells her how she changed fashion in the 1960s. ''You put the top on it,'' is her response. Indeed, with his modernist wash-and-wear cuts that freed women of their fussy, salon-crafted coifs, Vidal Sassoon, still sprightly at 82, had an incredible impact on both pop culture and social conventions. And his life beyond the Five-Point Bob -- living in an orphanage in London; working as a bike messenger during the blitzkrieg -- is pretty remarkable as well. Using archival footage and present-day interviews with family, colleagues and the man himself, the film's director, Craig Teper, explores it all. And as Mr. Sassoon, standing on the stage at the Royal Albert Hall, in front of thousands of hairdressers who have just given him a lengthy ovation, saw it, ''In the final analysis, my heart was in hair.''

KUNIKOFF--Gilbert. Beloved husband of Helane Nee Kahn. Loving father of Robert and Jane Kunikoff, and Mitchell and Eileen Kunikoff. Adored grandfather of Jessica, Paige, Brooke, Alexandra Kunikoff. You will always be in our hearts. We miss you already. Services for Sunday 11:30am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 91st Amsterdam Avenue.

PEARLMAN--Hubert, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Hubert Pearlman. He was a member of the staff at Maimonides Medical Center for 50 years. He was President of the Medical Staff in 1964-1965. He was the founder of the Orthopedic surgical residency in 1966 and chairman for 30 years. He passed away at age 82. His life was devoted to service to patients and the residents that trained with him. He was the author of over 30 scientific publications and sections of two text books. He was Clinical Professor of Orthopedic Surgery at Downstate Medical School and voluntary attending at Kings County Hospital since his retirement from clinical practice in 2002. He was a President of the Kings County Medical Society, a councilor of the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons and Chairman of the Orthopedic section of the New York Academy of Medicine, member of the American College of Surgeons and numerous societies devoted to orthopedic surgery. He served in the US Navy in World War II and was a captain in the Army Medical Corps during the Korean Conflict. His sense of humor and poetry will be missed. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. W. Wexelman, M.D., Pres H. Wasserman, M.D., Pres-Elect E. Fitzpatrick, M.D., Sec. G. Neiderman, M.D., Treas.

An article last Sunday about cellphone usage in the developing world characterized the International Telecommunication Union incorrectly. The union is a public-private arm of the United Nations whose members include governments and private companies. It is not a trade group.

ST. LOUIS -- In search of a solitary run, the Mets and the Cardinals played nearly seven hours of baseball Saturday, beginning on a warm, sunny afternoon and continuing into a chilly evening until finally the matter was resolved. Each team waited until the 19th inning to touch home plate, each scoring once to send one of the more bizarre games in years into another extra frame. Then Angel Pagan scored on a sacrifice fly by Jose Reyes, and the Mets went on to win, 2-1, in their longest game in 36 years.

At a time when it can be difficult to find that rare quality known as class, it is refreshing to see Grace Kelly back in the limelight. The late actress and her inimitable fashion sense are the focus of ''Grace Kelly: Style Icon,'' an exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum (Cromwell Road; 44-20-7942-2000; vam.ac.uk; free admission) through Sept. 26. The show traces her life from Philadelphia socialite to Hollywood star to Oscar winner, and finally to her fairy-tale role as Princess Grace of Monaco. Though classically beautiful, she achieved her status not simply by virtue of her features but with her sense of style. It helped, of course, that her outfits were designed by the likes of Dior, Balenciaga and Givenchy.
Film Mike Hale

AMSTERDAM HIGH Bridges is a pretty obvious name for a fish restaurant in Amsterdam. The Dutch city has hundreds of them spanning its famous canals. But Bridges, a dining spot that opened in Sofitel's Amsterdam the Grand hotel last November, is appropriately named in another respect: the chef, Aurélien Poirot, creates dishes that bridge cultures. That's obvious from the start. One amuse-bouche of tiny curried shrimp is followed by another of sashimi with wasabi cream. The fusion also worked well in the halibut saté, served with bok choy and fingerling potatoes. The spicy sauce, incorporating crunchy bits of peanuts, gave a tangy kick to the mild, perfectly roasted fillet.

Soon after Ericka Hamburg's Complaint Box essay was posted online Friday morning, comments started coming in. Excerpts from a few are below. Add yours at nytimes.com/cityroom. You are right on the mark. Years ago I learned Starbucks had come to Paris by the overflowing trash bins filled with empty paper cups.

PERHAPS it has something to do with the New Minimalism in fashion, or maybe it's just a severe case of spring fever, but not since Bianca Jagger was captured strutting around Heathrow in 1972 in a cream-colored YSL jacket and matching trousers has the idea of a white pantsuit seemed so chic. Recent images of women like the actress Elisa Sednaoui in a Chloé one-piece (left, second from top) and the model Ajak Deng in a Todd Lynn ensemble (bottom) have made the look only more coveted. Thankfully, there were a slew of options on the spring runways, from a lean-and-mean style at Jil Sander to a more classic cut at Tommy Hilfiger (third from top) and a slouchy borrowed-from-the-boys version at Etro (top). For a particularly white-hot outfit, push up the sleeves and pair it with fantastic heels. You think Bianca ever worried about the dry-cleaning bill?

JEWISH KAIFENG, CHINA To the Editor: Matthew Fishbane's article ''China's Ancient Jewish Enclave'' (April 4), about the Jews of Kaifeng, brought back memories of a religious-school class I attended in Brookline, Mass., in the mid-1950s. We read a book called ''Michael Turns the Globe,'' by Deborah Pessin, published in 1946. Each chapter described the travels of the fictional narrator to a little-known Jewish community in some exotic corner of the world.

I work in the financial district, and when it's lunchtime, the decision to be made is: polystyrene, No. 6 plastic or real plates? The use of china and cutlery is relegated to actual restaurants, for special occasions or business lunches. Most workers (and tourists) head for fast-food chains, lunch trucks or one of the many self-service places, indistinguishable in their offerings of salad bars, soups, sushi and sandwiches. My rant is not with the sameness of their culinary offerings, but with the mountains of unrecyclable and unrecycled trash they generate.

D'AQUINO--Josephine. Predeceased by husband, Carl. Beloved mother of Carl, Roger and Victor. Grandmother of Josephine and Stephanie. Services at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, Sunday 2-6pm.

THE WALL Come May, seniors at Scripps College in Claremont, Calif., will sign their names to Graffiti Wall, just as every graduating class has done since 1931, filling corners and columns, edges and eaves. The class votes on a theme that best captures its mood. The final act of putting paint on wall seems to inspire raw emotion. Says Ashley Peters, an alumna of the women's college: ''It really signifies the end of the Scripps College experience.'' THE FENCE The class of 1924 donated a fence to Carnegie Mellon as a place for seniors to meet and greet, and it soon became a campus billboard. The Guinness Book of World Records named it the most painted object in the world. Flash forward to 1993, when it collapsed under the weight of so much paint and had to be rebuilt, in concrete. Student groups apply a message every day or so. There are rules: The fence can be painted only between midnight and sunrise, and only with a brush (students stand guard overnight to make sure no one paints over their work). Should someone break a rule, says Damien Valdes, a senior, ''they'd be ostracized from their peer group immediately.''
In a Foreclosure, Who Gets the Rent?

The Fifth Avenue Easter Parade, a century-old tradition, only gets better. The event, which took place two weeks ago, attracts visitors from around the world, eager to see the still-stylish stroll. This year, a swing band and dancers entertained churchgoers in their holiday best and gents in top hats, once an Easter signature. Parade highlights: men mixing vibrant primary colors, young women in Little Bo Peep crinolines and panniers, and plumed vamps from another era. The low-riding jeans of a photographer contrasted sharply with the attire of her subjects, above. The cleverest of the silly hats: two giant cupcakes.

WALL STREET analysts, commenting on positive retail sales numbers, have lately used the term that they've ''beat expectations.'' This is a little like a mother saying of her new son-in-law, ''He's not the handsomest, but he's nice.'' Yes, most department stores and specialty retailers like H & M saw decent sales gains for March. In Paris, LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton reported an 11 percent quarterly increase. But this was after a not-so-pretty 2009. And several luxury companies, including LVMH, continue to express caution about the rest of the year. Many people are still out of work, or finding work that pays less.

Historically, students have enjoyed two eras of significant grade inflation, during the Vietnam War and now. ''Since about 1986 it's been a straight line ascending,'' says Christopher A. Healy, co-author of an analysis of grading patterns published last month in The Teachers College Record of Columbia University and an associate professor of computer science at Furman University. Why this should be - easier teachers? better students? - is a matter of debate. What follows are undergraduate grades at a cross-section of colleges (note the decline in A's at Princeton, which in 2004 set a goal of capping them at 35 percent of grades awarded). More details on many of the institutions are available at Dr. Healy's database, at cs.furman.edu/chealy/stats/.

Coming from Berlin's Hackescher Markt and heading northwest, the initial stretch of Rosenthaler Strasse has been a shopper's heaven at least since the first wave of post-Communist Berlin's urban renewal in the mid-1990s. But beyond the street's second block or so, the pickings got pretty thin. Empty lots alternated with gray, Communist-era housing and a few surviving old buildings to create an uneven and unappealing streetscape. That is, until recently. Just last year, several attractive, affordable hotels opened, and they have now been joined by some promising new shops. A number are foreign-born. From Britain, there's AllSaints Spitalfields (No. 52; allsaints.com), a three-story spot where dark cloaks with a decidedly early-'80s feel are for sale in an industrial interior, and, in another recently renovated building nearby, an outpost of the popular Ben Sherman label (No. 31; bensherman.de).

SUTPHEN--Martha Rusk, 79, died peacefully of cancer in Sag Harbor, NY, on April 12, 2010. A New York City public school teacher, she leaves her husband, Dr. Richard Stock, her daughters Susan Slowinski, Lucy, Molly, and Ann Sutphen and grandchildren Sam, Simon, Ellie, Nina, and Kara. She was the daughter of the late Dr. Howard and Gladys Rusk. Her first husband, Preston Sutphen, died in 1986. Brothers Howard Rusk and John Rusk also survived. Her family is humbled by the love of her many friends. A Memorial Service will be held at the Century Association (7 West 43rd) on April 19th at 3pm. Memorial contributions can be sent to Doctors Without Borders USA, P.O. Box 5030 Hagerstown, MD 21741 or Peconic Land Trust, PO Box 1776, Southampton NY 11969.

ALESI--Gladys Eckman, age 93, on April 6, 2010. She was born in Jamestown, NY, and graduated from Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn. She earned a B.A., magna cum laude, from Hunter College and an M.B.A. from NYU. Her career with the NYC Board of Education began as a teacher of English and citizenship to refugees of the Holocaust; she retired as the director of the Board's English and Citizenship Program. She also served as Executive Director of the American Immigration and Citizenship Conference and as a consultant to the Department of Justice, Immigration and Naturalization Service. Following her retirement from the Board of Education, she volunteered at the United Nations, the Metropolitan Museum, and New York Hospital. She was a member of the New York Hospital Auxiliary and the Park River Independent Democrats. She authored 11 books, including Barron's U.S. Citizenship Test, which is now in its seventh edition. She is survived by daughter, Catherine McCollum of Long Branch, NJ; son and daughter-in-law, Charles and Rita Alesi of Winchester, MA; granddaughters, Ineke and Kara; and great-grandson, Thomas. Memorial donations may be made to VNSNY Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10001.

SINCE opening on Lafayette Street in 1994, Supreme, the influential skateboard and street-wear brand, has made it its business to create the best product possible, whether that's a well-cut T-shirt or a well-cast ad campaign. (Past ones have starred Lou Reed, far right; Mike Tyson; and Kermit the Frog.) Even its skateboard decks, which have featured the work of Jeff Koons (shown here), Damien Hirst, Richard Prince and Christopher Wool, are considered blue chip, and as feverishly collected by art-world folk as they are by 15-year-olds. ''My approach has always been to make things we were proud of,'' said James Jebbia, the brand's founder. ''I don't want to dumb anything down, and I think people appreciate that. Even if it's not their cup of tea.''
