LYON--Dorothy, passed away April 10, 2010. She was a woman of extreme will, loving heart and compassion. She will be terribly missed by her nephews Timothy (Nancy) Galyon of Pleasantville, NY; George Tipton (Roxanne) Galyon, Wappinger Falls, NY; Howard Brown, Manhattan Beach, CA; nieces Kay Trerice (Nelson), Shelly Bay, Bermuda, Francis England, Devonshire Parrish, Bermuda and Shirley Sevigny (Tom) of Roanoke, VA. Dorothy was born in Bermuda on July 4, 1915. Beloved sister of the late Ruth Galyon of Shelly Bay, Bermuda along with five other predeceased brothers and sisters. Dorothy moved to the US in 1937, wed Alfred E. Lyon, former President and Chairman of Philip Morris in 1944 and enjoyed a wonderful life which included travels around the world together. She enjoyed gardening at their country home in Bedford Village, NY; volunteering at Stamford Hospital and a deep appreciation of the arts. She was also a generous contributor to various charities. She will be missed by those whose lives she touched. A Memorial Service will be held on April 24, 2010 at 3:30 at The Frank E Campbell Home, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Mianus River Gorge Preserve, 167 Mianus River Rd., Bedford, NY 10506.

MALMGREN--Lois C.,85, of Manhattan, passed away April 8, 2010. Beautiful and talented, Loys, as she was known, began her career at WNHC-TV of New Haven. In New York, she held professional positions at NW Ayer, General Foods and Bloomingdale's, and volunteered at New York City Ballet. Memorial service at 1:30pm, Sunday, April 25, at Christ Church United Methodist, 520 Park Avenue; contributions in her name may be made to the Church.

OWENS--George French Bowie Jr. Retired Partner and Director of Johnson & Higgins, 82, died peacefully at home April 14, 2010. He was born in Boston, son of Muriel Cuzner Owens and George F. B. Owens. He grew up in Rockville Centre, NY and graduated from Westtown Friends School, Wilmington College and received his MBA from New York University. During the Korean War he served as a supply officer aboard the USS Passumpsic AO 107. In 1953, after leaving the Navy, George joined Johnson & Higgins in New York City as a member of their Marine department. George went on to run the Marine department of the Los Angeles office for six years before being elected Partner in 1978 and relocating to Pittsburgh to become Managing Director of the office until his retirement in 1990. After spending many years visiting family in Vero Beach he became a resident in 1994 leaving only to continue a lifelong tradition of spending summer months in his family's home on West Hill in Wallingford, VT. George is survived by his beloved wife of 58 years; Marjorie Weeks Owens, his adored children; Janet Owens Floor (Greg) of Salt Lake City, UT, William French Owens of Wallingford, VT and Julie Owens Ream (Craig) of Pittsburgh, PA and his cherished grandchildren; William and Steven Floor and Christopher, Andrew, Benjamin and Lucy Ream. George was a member of The Sons of The Revolution in the State of New York and the Navy League of the United States. George's passions included sailing his catboats and golfing with family and friends. He could regularly be found on the course at Rutland, Ekwanok, Riomar, and Bent Pine Country Clubs. He always had a ready smile, twinkle in his eye, and a hearty laugh. He will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved him. Services: Prayer Service at the Trinity Church, 2365 Pine Avenue, Vero Beach, Florida at 11am Monday, April 19, 2010. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in George's memory to: The Humane Society of Vero Beach & Indian River County, P.O. Box 644, Vero Beach, FL 32961 or Wallingford Historical Society, c/o Joyce Barbieri, 75 School Street, Wallingford, VT 05773. A guestbook may be signed at www.strunkfuneralhome.com. Services by Strunk Funeral Home in Vero Beach.

Despite his best efforts, Cliff, 28, could not get to sleep until about 7 a.m. It had been this way since he was a teenager. He was a healthy and successful young scientist - except that he didn't arrive at the lab until 5 p.m., just as his co-workers were preparing to leave. Although he got his work done by pulling all-nighters, he became isolated from the group. Sleeping pills didn't work. Nighttime alcohol bouts got him to sleep sooner, but only by two to three hours - a bummer on many levels. Significantly, Cliff was not depressed.

"This kerfuffle [over whether to allow streetcar wires in Washington D.C.] is about more than just ugly wires ... It gets to the heart of an old and familiar conflict over how Washingtonians and Americans at large envision the city. In its coverage, The Post has referred to opponents of wires as 'preservationists,' but I think 'D.C. monumentalists' better describes their stance. For the monumentalist, Washington, D.C., the city comes second to Washington, D.C., the sanitized and photogenic capital. The monumentalist vision of Washington has choked nearly all urban life from the Mall and its environs. It has fashioned large sections of our city into pleasing vistas for tourists but has given the rest of us lifeless wastelands (if you've ever stepped foot outside at L'Enfant Plaza, you know what I'm talking about). Streetcar wires aren't pretty, but urbanity isn't always pretty. In fact, a vibrant, organic city is unabashedly messy, as exemplified by the hodgepodge of architectural styles, the variety of uses and the diversity of people in the District's thriving historic neighborhoods. It is hardly a victory for historic preservation if struggling areas of the city are cut off from an avenue to rejuvenation simply to preserve an unfettered view or two of the Capitol dome. The monumental core should be the city's heart, not its parasite."

Jeff Burton was smitten with Stella Stevens the instant he saw "The Poseidon Adventure." That was in 1972. He was 9. In the movie, Stevens played an ultrachic former call girl who had married a burly cop, Ernest Borgnine, and fell to her death shod in silver platform shoes. The young Burton developed a raging obsession with both Stevens and the film. Thirty-five years later, after working as a still photographer on porn movie shoots in Los Angeles, where he lives, Burton got to direct her himself - for a portrait now hanging in his seventh solo show at the Casey Kaplan Gallery.

Attorney General Jerry Brown of California is taking Moody's Investors Service to court. Mr. Brown contends that the credit rating agency is "blowing off the state of California" in its seven-month investigation into whether Moody's and the two other leading credit-rating agencies, Standard & Poor's and Fitch Ratings, acted improperly during the credit boom by assigning super-safe, triple-A ratings to mortgage-backed securities that later turned out to be extremely risky and in some cases worthless.

"Kick-Ass" slew the dragon after all. Lionsgate executives are doing cartwheels over final box office figures that show their R-rated superhero comedy was the No. 1 movie over the weekend after all, beating DreamWorks Animation's "How to Train Your Dragon" by a whisker. "Kick-Ass" ended up selling $19.83 million in tickets; "Dragon" moved into second place, with $19.63 million. What does it mean? For "Dragon," not much. The animated movie, propped up by sky-high 3-D ticket prices, continues to do solid business in its fourth week in theaters. So it fell to second place - it already got a boatload of free press out of appearing to take the top slot. As for "Kick-Ass," the No. 1 crown is psychologically important to embattled Lionsgate, which promoted the movie heavily with hopes of discovering a franchise. Joe Drake, Lionsgate's co-chief operating officer, appears to still have hope. "Our marketing and distribution teams have brilliantly positioned it for a long and successful run," he said in a news release on Monday.

Maybe your mother told you that you should always put clean underwear on in the morning in case you were ever to get hit by a bus. But what if every time you changed your skivvies, 20 trees would be planted in Africa? It could happen. PACT underwear [www.wearPACT.com], the pet project from the design celeb Yves Behar, donates 10 percent of its sales to an ever- increasing roster of nonprofits like Dave Eggers's writing program, 826 Valencia, and Oceana. Each organization gets its own print so you can wear your cause on your, er, oh never mind. The newest collaboration is with the architect David Adjaye and Wangari Maathai, whose Green Belt Movement works to empower women and fight deforestation, soil erosion and water scarcity in Kenya. For Earth Week only, 100 percent of the proceeds of Adjaye's specially designed Green Belt print underwear will contribute to the planting of 10,000 trees. (After April 25, it reverts to 10 percent.) See? Change is good!

The Partner and I both realized that it would be hard to build the business (you can see my previous posts here) selling only dining furniture. For weeks, the pseudonymous reviewer known only as Historian had been using the British book site amazon.co.uk as his or her personal shooting gallery, taking aim at the authors of works on Russian culture and history: Rachel Polonsky's book "Molotov's Magic Lantern" was dismissed as "dense," "pretentious" and "the sort of book that makes you wonder why it was ever published"; and Robert Service's work was skewered as a "dull read" (for a book about Trotsky) and "rubbish" and "an awful book" (for a history of communism). Perhaps the only author to be spared the point pen of Historian was Orlando Figes, whose book "The Whisperers" was described as a "beautiful and necessary" account of Soviet history, written by someone with "superb storytelling skills" and of whom Historian said, "I hope he writes forever."

If the voters of any country know that wars fought in foreign fields rarely win or lose elections, the British do; the most stunning election upset in modern British history came in 1945, when soldiers returning from World War II, or awaiting transportation from distant battlefields, combined with restive families at home to boot Winston Churchill and his Conservatives out of office less than three months after he led the country to victory over Nazi Germany. Then, as now, voters made their choices primarily on domestic issues, and they judged Labour's Clement Attlee better equipped for the social and economic renewal the country needed than the man widely regarded, even then, as one of the greatest Englishmen who ever lived.

Today's column on David Cameron's Tories has been half-overtaken by events: I was writing as if the Tories were still clinging to a slight edge in the polls, but as of this morning that may no longer be the case. The Liberal Democrats have been surging since their leader's strong performance in last week's debate; now they've surged into a narrow lead. Thanks to the way the U.K.'s Parliament apportions seats, a Lib Dem victory in the popular vote would leave either Labour or the Tories with a slight plurality in the House of Commons (not coincidentally, electoral reform is a major Lib Dem issue), but well short of the majority required to govern. For political observers, this would be a fascinating outcome: Think Florida in 2000 crossed with a brokered convention. For Britain, misgoverned and indebted and desperate for strong leadership, it would probably be a disaster.

By 2008, 79 men and boys from San Pedro de Macorís, a small sugar mill town in the Dominican Republic, had gone on to play major league baseball. Of the 471 Dominicans who had played in at least one major league game, 1 in 6 came from San Pedro: Ozzie Virgil, Joaquin Andujar, Alfredo Griffin, George Bell, Sammy Sosa, Robinson Cano. Mark Kurlansky, who has written histories revolving around cod and salt, puts San Pedro under the microscope in his new book, "The Eastern Stars: How Baseball Changed the Dominican Town of San Pedro de Macorís" (Riverhead).

Nursing Homes Cashed In While Cutting Staff | California's nursing homes reaped $880 million from a 2004 state law designed to help hire more caregivers and boost wages. But that's not what all of them did, an investigation found. Some 232 homes took the money while cutting staff or wages. Cloverdale Healthcare Center in Sonoma County received a $1 million increase in state money, but staffing dropped 8 percent in 2008 compared with 2004. Regulators uncovered problems at the center, including a patient who had been left in a soiled diaper for five hours. [California Watch]

Shazam, the mobile application that can identify the songs you hear, has enjoyed tremendous success on the iPhone and iPod Touch. More than 15 million users have downloaded the application since it first became available in 2008, and the company that created it recently secured more money from investors. It's hard to imagine whipping out Apple's tablet computer in a nightclub to figure out whether the Jay-Z song that's playing was remixed by the XX or Diplo, a process known as ''tagging.''

After a difficult winter, spring has finally arrived and Arnie, Bill, Charlie and Doug prepare for the first round of the year. At their home course, officials have marked a large area damaged by heavy snows as ground under repair (G.U.R.) in the fairway and rough. All four players play their tee shots and all four balls come to rest in the G.U.R. Arnie discovers his ball in the G.U.R. in the rough. He determines his nearest point of relief to be in the fairway and drops his ball in the fairway.

JIEGU, China -- Long after the bulldozers have gone silent and the rescue workers have retired to their tents, the only sound in this earthquake-battered city is the plaintive barking of dogs that have lost their homes, and in many cases, their owners. As the smoke from a thousand campfires filled the air early Sunday morning, solitary figures shuffled through the darkness, heading to no place in particular. Some, like Tsai Ba Mao, 63, were drawn to a tent off the city's main square, where Buddhist monks had created a makeshift temple filled with rows of yak-butter lamps. A cardboard sign above the entrance read ''Pray for the dead,'' written in Chinese and Tibetan.

Ever been out playing with your buddies and thought it would be fun to try a Happy Gilmore swing on the tee? Come on, be honest. OK, it's fun. Last year, I wrote about scientific testing that showed that the running start, hockey-inspired swing may even be productive, if hard to achieve consistently. Turns out the golf community is not done with Happy Gilmore swing news.

WEINSTOCK--Arthur S.,of White Plains, NY, died peacefully on April 17, 2010, after a brief illness. He was the son of the late George J. and Frances K. Weinstock and the brother of the late Rita Weinstock and the late Blossom Landsman. He was predeceased by his wife of 52 years, Marion (Betty) E. Weinstock. They loved each other dearly. He is survived by his loving nieces Margaret (Peggy) Kerner (Jonathan) of Pound Ridge, NY, and Carol Landsman Hassett (Steve) of Portland, OR. Arthur worked for Exquisite Form and was the general manager of manufacturing in Puerto Rico. Arthur was a graduate of Columbia College, class of 41, and a member of Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity (ZBT) and stayed active in both. He served as president of the Society of Columbia Graduates and was on the Board of Columbia/Barnard Hillel. He and his wife Betty endowed the Arthur S. and Marian E. Weinstock Scholarship for needy students at Columbia College. He served on the Supreme Council of ZBT and endowed the Arthur S. Weinstock Recognition Award for participation in intercollegiate Athletics. He was Treasurer of the Columbia Club of Westchester. He was an active member of the congregation at Temple Israel Center, White Plains, NY, where he dedicated a classroom in the Hebrew School. We will miss his humor, kindness and great stories. The world will be a little less caring without Arthur in it. The funeral will be held at Temple Israel Center in White Plains on Monday, April 19, 2010 at 12:30pm. Contributions in Arthur's memory may be sent to the Arthur S. and Marian E. Weinstock Scholarship for needy students at Columbia College or Temple Israel Center, White Plains, NY.

WHITSELL--Rosemarie, 79, of Sharon, CT, died April 13 at Noble Horizons. She was the wife of Dr. John C. Whitsell II. Mrs. Whitsell was born in Mckeesport, PA on October 1, 1930. She was a graduate of Western Pennsylvania Nursing School and did graduate work at the University of Pennsylvania. From 1953 to 1966 she was a head OR nurse at New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center. She was president of New York Hospital Auxiliary and vice president of The Drama League. She was also a member of the Millbrook Garden Club, the Sharon Country Club, the Colony Club and the Mill Reef Club of Antigua, She is survived by her husband of 44 years. A memorial service will be celebrated on Friday May 28 at 11am at the Sharon Episcopal Church. Memorial contributions may be made to the Sharon Volunteer Ambulance, P.O. Box 357, Sharon, CT. 06069.

As President Obama approaches the end of his administration's opening chapter, his advisers have begun a backstage debate over Chapter 2, which will be fundamentally different in tone, aspiration and political complexity. For his first 15 months, Mr. Obama has pounded away at four domestic initiatives. All four - economic stimulus, health care, Wall Street regulations and energy policy - reflected priorities of important Democratic constituencies. The next phase, which Mr. Obama set in motion by appointing a bipartisan panel on reducing the nation's debt, will not.

(BBC America) TOP GEAR After buying used cars -- an FJ40 Toyota Land Cruiser, a Range Rover Classic, above, and a Suzuki Jimny -- over the Internet from dealers in Bolivia, James May, Jeremy Clarkson and Richard Hammond embark on a 1,000-mile drive from the middle of the Amazon rain forest to the Pacific coast of Chile through the treacherous terrain in the altiplano region, the Andes and the Atacama Desert. The ascent to La Paz along the steep North Yungas Road, popularly known as El Camino de la Muerte (''The Road of Death''), so terrifies the acrophobic Mr. May that he humorously threatens to cut off the head of anyone who bumps him. But he seems to be only half-kidding when he pulls a machete on Mr. Clarkson after a small accident. The two men leave their weapons behind when they appear on a special episode of ''Friday Night With Jonathan Ross'' at 9:40. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY The guests include former President Bill Clinton and Jennifer Lopez. Here and on ''The View,'' at 11 a.m. on ABC, Alyssa Milano also promotes her new series, ''Romantically Challenged'' (Monday night at 9:30 on ABC), in which she plays a divorcée about to start dating for the first time since the Clinton administration.

Look! Up on the wall! It's a painting! Of that strange visitor from another planet who came to Earth - well, you know how that goes. Figuring out how that particular painting of the guy in a red cape and blue tights came to be hanging in the Lehman College library, just past the card catalog, high above tall shelves of books, took longer than it takes a speeding bullet to go almost anywhere. But for one Superman fan, it was a mystery worth solving, even though it is not a really important mystery, like why it took Superman so long to kiss Lois or whether The Daily Planet would survive in the Internet age.

RADZIEWICZ--Karen A.,passed away Sunday April 18 after a long and valiant fight. Born, raised and lived in New York City. She spent many years as an Associate Director WABC-TV on many shows and projects such as Eyewitness News and Live With Regis and Kathie Lee. She later moved on for the next 19 years to ABC News to serve World News Tonight, Nightline and World News Now. An active parent at PS24 in the Bronx and Manhattan East Middle School. This week's restaurant review is of SHO Shaun Hergatt, down in the financial district. Pete Wells gave it a short review in the summer of 2009, a few months after it opened, before I'd strapped on the feed bag to become the newspaper's restaurant critic. I made my way over to the dining room a few months later, and started returning again. It's very good. It's also weird, anachronistic at its core, and the food's extremely fussy. It doesn't hew to the locavore esthetic but to the notion that you ought to be able to get any ingredient you want, from anywhere in the world, at any time.

As macarons make their way across the pond from France to New York, there has been a twee treats exchange: in various branché districts of Paris, le cupcake est arrivé. It's not unlike New York City's cakelet rush of the early aughts, though here, "Sex and the City" is only partly to blame. (Since the show came to French TV in 1999 and has run almost ever since, les filles have loved their Carrie, but many of the new bakers have come through the United Kingdom.) Last year, Synie's Cupcakes opened in tony Saint-Germain, and in Abbesses, the Paris neighborhood that most resembles Magnolia Bakery's West Village, there are not one but two new spots peddling the goods: Miss Cupcake, run by the 30-something ex-London-dweller Laurence Kreitmann, situated in the crook of the tiny rue Vieuville; and on the rue Lepic, the second outpost of Berko, a bakery destined to miff any New Yorker for its epitaph ("Original Cupcake") and its prices - two euros for a cake about one-fourth the size of your average Buttercup Bakery wares.

While the rest of the world concerns itself with the airborne residue of Iceland's volcano, farmers there are trying to cope with the ground-level aftermath. When we talk about autism (which we are doing often during Autism Awareness Month), we tend to talk about children and ways that their parents can help. Overview | How can some local events have global consequences? What lessons can we learn from the eruption of the Eyjafjallajokull volcano in Iceland about the fragility of our interconnected world? In this lesson, students examine how the eruption has illuminated how connected we are and how fragile our global web may be. By collating stories of people, businesses and organizations affected by the eruption on a world map, students create a visual representation of the wide-reaching effects of the eruption.

The problem with popular apps that tell your friends where you are, like Foursquare, Brightkite and Latitude, is they also inform people who are not your friends where you are -- or aren't. A  Web site called "Please Rob Me" republished such alerts to point out that telling a network of people where you are, tells burglars where you are not - protecting your home.

A video and a blog post here on Monday presented a closer look at Taliban snipers, who were an unusual factor in the fighting in Marja this year. To understand the role that Taliban snipers have - or have not - played in the larger Afghan war, a look with more sweep is necessary. Afghanistan is a sprawling place, and the insurgency operates in some ways like a complicated syndicate, with varied groups and leaders in different parts of the country loosely collaborating with one another on some matters but not at all on others. So how significant have Taliban snipers been over all in the larger war? How much of a threat have they posed?

Inter Milan counter attacked with great effect Tuesday against Barcelona, coming back from a goal down to win the first leg of the UEFA Champions League semifinal, 3-1. Barca went up early, scoring a crucial away goal by way of Pedro Rodriguez. He tucked away an angled pass from Maxwell, whose run down the left flank past Cambiasso to the goal line was unchecked by Maicon and Lucio, who both stopped dead in their tracks. But Inter responded with determined counter-attacking play, as per Manager Jose Mourinho's instructions. Wesley Snjeder, Maicon and Diego Milito all scored for Inter, who will travel to Barcelona for the second leg on April 28.

Corporal punishment was banned in New York State public schools later than one might expect -- in 1985. But there is still one vestige of that old policy that remains. Every year, each of the state's 700 school districts must spend five minutes filling out a report recording whether there were any cases of physical punishment, and send it off to Albany.

When a family friend recently made her first hole in one, she mentioned how she had hole-in-one insurance. For what exactly? Tradition calls for the ace golfer to treat everyone at the club to a round of drinks after the shot. Her insurance, however, didn't cover her because the shot didn't happen at her own golf club.

"A Barneys girl likes a sexy tee, so we wanted to give her an organic option," says the store's fashion director and eco-crusader, Julie Gilhart, of Barneys' Earth Day collaboration with Loomstate. "We wanted to do a blank T-shirt with a sexy fit like Alexander Wang or the Row, and we wanted to make it all organic but affordable, too." The deep-V design, which sells for $40 (for the 40th Anniversary of Earth Day), comes in your usual New Yorker hues - namely, black, white and gray - but also in the colors of the NBC peacock. Gilhart, it turns out, is also one of the headliners for Christie's' first ever "green" auction, A Bid to Save the Earth, and NBC has signed on as a media sponsor. The live auction on April 22, which benefits the N.R.D.C., the Central Park Conservancy, Oceana and Conservation International, includes such fashionable prizes as lunch with Vera Wang - plus a $10,000 shopping spree at her flagship store - and a fitting with Stella McCartney for bespoke his and hers suits. For Gilhart, creating such fashion synergy is all in a day's work: "We just thought, Hey we're all on the same page, so let's get together."

One of the books on my bedside table is "The Favorite Child" by the psychologist Ellen Weber Libby; an examination of the taboo subject. 12:40 p.m. | Updated The rumblings of an Icelandic volcano continue to be felt as far away as New York, as the travel restrictions in Europe forced by volcanic ash have required the New York Philharmonic to make changes to its Stravinsky-themed programming that starts this week. The Philharmonic said on Tuesday that the Mariinsky Theater Chorus of St. Petersburg would be unable to perform in the "Russian Stravinsky" festival concerts planned for Wednesday and Thursday. As a result, the Philharmonic will offer all-orchestral programs on those nights, which will still be conducted by Valery Gergiev; "Jeu de Cartes" will be performed in place of "Les Noces." The rest of the programs on those nights, including Symphonies of Wind Instruments and "The Firebird," are not affected. The "Russian Stravinsky" festival runs through May 8.

When we last saw the scheming, self-loathing advertising executives of "Mad Men" they had just orchestrated a Christmas coup, as Don Draper, Bertram Cooper, Roger Sterling and their newfound frenemy, Lane Pryce, bailed on their former agency to start their own shop. So what's in store for Season 4? Did Don and Betty pull the plug on their marriage? Have we seen the last of Sal Romano, and has little Sally Draper conquered her lisp? Will Pete and Trudy Campbell dance again?

Hackers Breached Google's Password System | Google disclosed in January that Internet intruders had stolen information from its computers. Now, a person with direct knowledge of the investigation has told John Markoff of The New York Times that the company's password system was breached. The program, known as Gaia for the Greek goddess of the earth, allows users to sign in once to operate a range of services. It was attacked last December. The hackers do not appear to have stolen Gmail users' passwords, and the company quickly beefed up security. But the theft leaves open the possibility that hackers can find other weaknesses, according to independent computer experts. [The New York Times]

Goldman Sachs is staying on message in the first part of its conference call to discuss its first-quarter financial results, despite the Securities and Exchange Commission's fraud case against it. "Investment banking produced net revenues of $1.2 billion, down 28 percent from the fourth quarter," said David A. Viniar, the firm's chief financial officer. ADAMS--Sheila K.,actress played in the original Broadway production of "A Little Night Music" and William Inge's "Summer Brave." Her own published plays showed Midwestern frankness and a black sense of humor. She leaves behind many friends and a few mortal enemies. We will all miss her.

FORT WORTH (AP) -- Denny Hamlin went ahead in the closing 12-lap shootout, earning a victory at Texas Motor Speedway on Monday as he held off Jimmie Johnson at the end to win another rain-delayed race. Hamlin won for the second time in three races, each victory coming in races that were postponed by rain before being run on a Monday. It was the 10th career Nascar Sprint Cup victory for Hamlin, who won a Monday race at Martinsville three weeks ago, then had surgery two days later for a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee. He ran every lap at Phoenix last week and was still hurting in Texas.

When you are seriously ill, many of the transactions you make are rendered in blood. Blood flowing in, blood flowing out: transfusions and the endless freight train of tests, feral clots afloat in the catheter tube, suspect seepage around sutures.

ZUCKERT--Robert Perry. 1969-2010. Robert Perry Zuckert was the beloved son of Sandy Culbertson Zuckert of Los Angeles, CA and Robert Barnes Zuckert of Brandon, VT. Robert was a graduate of the Allen Stevenson School in New York, attended Phillips Andover Academy in Massachusetts, Alliance Francaise in Paris and the University of California-Irvine. He was injured in 1994 while playing rugby for the University of California-Irvine, and at the young age of 24 became quadriplegic and lived with that disability for the rest of his short life. His triumph was what one doctor described as "carving a life of dignity, creativity and adventure" in the face of physically limited circumstance. He cast a wide net of inspiration over all who witnessed or shared his daily attack for life. His life was defined by courage and tenacity. He is survived by his brothers Gregory Zuckert of Whitefish, MT and Christopher Zuckert of Los Angeles, CA and his devoted friend John Ziegler of New York City. A service honoring Robert's life will be held at 4pm, Saturday April 24, 2010 at First Congregational Church, 900 High St, Santa Cruz, CA.

WASHINGTON -- Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida, facing pressure from fellow Republicans to abandon his Senate campaign, said Monday that he would not allow party leaders in Washington to push him from the race and declared that he was considering running for the seat as an independent. Mr. Crist spoke after the disclosure of a memorandum to fund-raisers and party officials from the National Republican Senatorial Committee that said Mr. Crist had ''zero chance'' of winning the nomination in his primary fight against Marco Rubio, whose candidacy has been fueled by backing from Tea Party supporters.

10:18 p.m. | Updated President Obama flew to Los Angeles on Monday for a political cash run to help out one of his most embattled Democratic allies, Senator Barbara Boxer of California, and warned that she was in danger of losing her seat after 18 years. As he shared the spotlight with Mrs. Boxer at the first of three evening fund-raising events, the president said that without help and money from Democratic activists, ''she might not win this thing, and I don't think that's an acceptable outcome.''

9 P.M. (13) THE DANCING BOYS OF AFGHANISTAN They call it Bacha Bazi, or ''boy play'': an ancient tradition, banned when the Taliban were in power, in which street orphans or sons from poor families are bought by businessmen. The boys, sometimes dressed in women's clothes, are taught to sing and dance for the entertainment of male audiences, above -- and then traded or sold among the men for sex. The result can be murder, and even the Afghan authorities responsible for stopping these crimes have been accused of participation. Drawing on interviews with boys, their families and their masters, Najibullah Quraishi exposes this practice, prohibited by Afghan law, for ''Frontline.'' 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW Cameras follow 24 hours in the life of Nadya Suleman, a k a Octomom.

GRIBETZ--Donald, M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni Association and all of its members mourn the passing of Dr. Donald Gribetz on April 10, 2010. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Dr. Gribetz came to Mount Sinai Hospital as a research assistant in Pediatrics in 1953. Dr. Gribetz was a recipient of the Jacobi Medallion in 1993, for his distinguished achievement in the field of medicine and his extraordinary service to the Hospital, the School, and the Alumni Association, the most prestigious honor the Alumni Association bestows. He was also a holder of the Golden Headed Cane in 2000. The Gold-Headed Cane Award is the pinnacle to which a Mount Sinai physician may aspire. This award is rarely presented, and only then to the physician who best represents the professional and personal traditions of Mount Sinai. The Alumni Association and its Executive Board, Martin S. Goldstein, Jeffrey Laitman, Lyris Schonholz, Jonathan Schiff, and Elliot Rayfield, extend its sincere condolences to his wife, Edith, and his long surviving legacy of children and grandchildren.

Here at City Room we do our best to help New Yorkers in need. Lately we've been reading that more than 30,000 workers in the city's residential buildings -- many of them doormen -- are threatening to strike at 12:01 a.m. Wednesday. Doormen provide many valuable services: they sign for packages, keep out intruders, act as de facto baby sitters and keep their eyes on the block. Many apartment dwellers will feel their absence if they walk off. But there is one service doormen provide that residents may be able to master themselves. Therefore, we offer the following guide.

For nearly a quarter-century, they have sat in sinister silence, concrete tombs of the city's transit system, choking off traffic and delaying thousands on their commutes. They are the scourge of Staten Island, the bane of the fifth borough. We speak, of course, of the 11 unused tollbooths on the Staten Island side of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, a frustrating phalanx of transportation planning gone batty. Since the spring of 1986, not a single driver on the bridge has had to pay a toll to reach Brooklyn. Yet the booths, installed at the bridge's opening in 1964, never went away.

For people in same-sex relationships, aging carries an added burden of anxiety: the fear that in a health crisis their partner might be excluded from making medical decisions, even visiting their bedside. Consider Tim Hare, 63, a retired architect in Easton, Pa., with a history of heart problems. He and his partner of 34 years, Earl Ball, were legally married in Canada in 2003. But whether hospitals and health care authorities in this country would recognize them as family members is an open question, even with President Obama's order last week extending hospital visiting rights and decision-making authority to same-sex partners.

In a 1964 concurring opinion deciding Jacobellis v. Ohio, Associate Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart wrote about ''hard-core pornography'' and his struggle to define it: ''Perhaps I could never succeed in intelligibly doing so. But I know it when I see it.'' Using Potter's indisputable logic, it's hard not to see something obscene in how Wall Street reaped massive profits and bonuses in 2009 -- and continues to do so, as is clear from Monday's announcement by Citigroup that it had earned $4.4 billion in the first quarter of 2010, which was even more than earned by Bank of America ($3.2 billion) and JPMorgan Chase ($3.3 billion) in the same period -- merely 18 months after trillions of dollars of American taxpayers' treasure was used to save a financial system brought to the precipice by Wall Street's greed and irresponsible risk-taking. Goldman Sachs, which is facing a civil fraud suit filed by Washington regulators, is expected to report robust earnings Tuesday morning as well.

ORKIN--Louis R.,M.D. 94 years young, passed away suddenly on April 16, 2010 with his family by his side. Devoted, loving and cherished husband of 70 years to Florence Orkin. Loving father to his daughter Rita Orkin and son-in-law Sinan Akdeniz. Loving brother to Irving and brother-in-law to Ruth Feinberg, Evelyn Fine and Beatrice Fine. Loving uncle to Susan Clark, Robert Orkin, Barbara Zingler, Richard and Nena Feinberg, John Auerbach and Cobry Kummer. Dedicated in his professional life to the practice of medicine and medical education. Graduated NYU School of Medicine 1941: Captain US Army Medical Corp. 1942-1945, awarded Bronze Star; 1950-55 Assistant Professor Anesthesiology NYU; 1955-82 Professor and Chairman Department of Anesthesiology, Albert Einstein College of Medicine; 1986 - Distinguished University Professor Emeritus Anesthesiology AECOM. He was a wonderful storyteller, especially of the many interesting events of his long life; a kind and gentle man who will be remembered by all who were fortunate to have met him. Memorial service will be held May 3, 2010 at 12 noon at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave, New York City. For further information call 212-873-3500.

TZALL--Helene, 91, beloved wife of the late Bernard for 64 years. Loving mother of Justine Wesley and Stephanie. Adored grandmother of Alexa, Gillian, Andree and Madeline. Graveside service at Old Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Gardens, Queens, 1pm, Wednesday, April 21.

Bill McCollum, Florida's attorney general, has been crowing for months about the lawsuit he filed challenging the federal health care overhaul. His calculus, as the Republican candidate for governor, has been broadcast at every turn: Voters will love it! But apparently most do not. A new Quinnipiac poll shows that 54 percent of Florida voters believe it was a ''bad idea'' for him to sue, compared with 40 percent who said it was a ''good idea.'' In another surprise for the McCollum campaign, 41 percent of independents said it made them less likely to vote for him, compared with 27 percent who said it would sway their vote in his favor.

Thursday is the 40th anniversary of the original Earth Day. Over the years, the impact of this once seminal day has lessened. Earth Day brings people together for nice gatherings and noble efforts but has, for the most part, made sustainable action more of an annual event than a daily habit. We've got to change that.

I am convinced that during bouts of insomnia I have sometimes slept without knowing it. The thoughts of waking seem to mingle with thoughts that may be part of sleep. Has the clock moved too quickly? Did I doze off? Some years ago in a rented house in Vermont, I couldn't sleep and lay awake listening to the sounds of mice in the walls, bears that sounded like owls calling to each other in the woods and the wind in the trees. I then dreamed I was lying awake on the very bed where in fact I was sleeping, but someone had broken into the house. Because the room where I actually was and the room I dreamed were identical, the threshold between waking and sleeping had blurred and, when I woke up, I thought I heard the burglar moving around downstairs. It was a frightening experience, a temporary loss of the boundaries between waking experience and the illusions of dreams.

This past Saturday at Webster Hall's grand ballroom, it all came down to two very different but equally impressive New York City "shredders": Dylan Brenner, a 15-year old Les Paul-wielding prodigy from Long Island, and Lily Maase, a 27-year old guitarist who splits her time between Bushwick, Brooklyn, and Spanish Harlem. For anyone raised on Madonna or Rihanna, it's hard to fathom how a rich girl with a wardrobe full of shirtdresses, twin sets and pearls  and a firm disbeliever in women wearing trousers  could become the fashion idol of her generation. But Grace Kelly epitomized a time before rebellion was a virtue, and the forthcoming "Grace Kelly: Style Icon" exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London pays homage to the actress-turned-princess's sartorial legacy, from her rise to stardom in the '50s to her untimely death in 1982. "She certainly didn't see herself as a style leader, liking such conservative clothes," says the show¹s curator, Jenny Lister. "But audiences loved her kind of uncontrived, natural beauty." Highlights of the show include Kelly's namesake Hermès bag, dresses from her films "High Society" and "Rear Window," and items from among the 80 pieces of luggage she carried to Monaco for her wedding to Prince Rainier in 1956. But perhaps more intriguing is what happened in the decades that followed, when Kelly found herself outside her comfort zone  amid all the tiaras and Dior ballgowns are the odd nods to rising hemlines and changing times, like her YSL Mondrian dress. In the end though, says Lister, "she was always happier in a Chanel suit."

It is a universal truism, not to mention a bedrock commercial ploy, that when you tell someone they can't have something, they'll likely become obsessed with obtaining it. This is readily demonstrated by liquor fanatics, who will cross the globe for a bottle of the most obscure and often pointless spirits, just to say they've tasted them. I am as guilty of this as anyone, and need only point to my several-year hunt for the elusive Cocchi Aperitivo Americano (pronounced co-key), for which I've buttonholed friends heading to Italy and Oakland, Calif., where it was once rumored to have an importer, all in vain.

Susanna Phillips, a 28-year-old soprano from Huntsville, Ala., was named the winner of the Beverly Sills Artist Award, the Metropolitan Opera said on Wednesday. The award, for singers age 25 to  40 who have appeared in featured solo roles at the Met, has been given annually since 2006 and comes with a prize of $50,000. Its previous winners include the baritone Nathan Gunn, the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato, the tenor Matthew Polenzani and the bass John Relyea. Ms. Phillips made her Met debut last season in the role of Musetta in "La Bohème"; she has also sung Pamina in "Die Zauberflöte" and will reprise the role in the Met's 2010-2011 season. The award was to be officially presented to Ms. Phillips at the Met by Dr. Agnes Varis, a managing director on the Met board who with her husband, Karl Leichtman, endowed the award, and Muffy Greenough, Ms. Sills's daughter.

U2 and Lady Gaga videos notwithstanding, the lure of lonesome Joshua Tree has always been the desolation. There's nothing like 25,000 square miles of Mojave wasteland to put things in perspective. But in those arid badlands of Southern California, accommodations - when you can find them - tend to be either motel-dismal or perfunctorily kitschy. Except for these two recent discoveries. Sacred Sands is a wisp of high-desert chic just one mile from the west entrance to Joshua Tree National Park. Here, at the base of a rocky ridge, Steve Pratt and Scott Cutler have fashioned a luxe eco-friendly retreat that's unapologetically open to the barrens. It has just two suites ($269 and $299 a night) - though two more are in the works - both with wraparound terraces. Each has an outdoor hot tub spiked with Dead Sea salts and tea tree oil along with a meditation platform, essentially a full-size bed where guests can sleep al fresco. And many do: "For city dwellers, it might be a little frightening at first," Cutler says, "but most people who doze off under the stars say it's the best sleep they've ever had." In the morning, fresh chilaquiles with homemade mole sauce, oven-baked pancakes and yam hash give incentive to rise.

"In Jaipur, capital of the desert state of Rajasthan, I spent time with Mohan Bhopa, a local goatherd and bard, who keeps alive a four-thousand-line sacred epic that he, now virtually alone, still knows by heart. Though completely illiterate, Mohan is one of the last hereditary singers of a great Rajasthani medieval poem, the 'Epic of Pabuji.' This six-hundred-year-old text is a fabulous tale of heroism and honor, struggle and loss, and, finally, martyrdom and vengeance. Over time, it seems to have grown from a local saga about the heroic doings of a raiding chieftain protecting his cattle to the legendary story of a semidivine warrior and incarnate god. When these four thousand courtly lines are recited from beginning to end-which rarely happens these days-it takes no less than five nights of eight-hour, dusk-till-dawn performances to unfold. Mohan's caste of wandering bhopas (shamans and bards) travels from village to village, staging performances. How long this will continue, no one knows ... his ancient recitative art is now threatened by the lure of Bollywood and televised Hindu epics shown in India. While watching one of Mohan's night-long performances, one of the village Brahmans explained that villagers no longer had the attention spans to listen to the whole epic. 'Now that we have TV, our children don't like to listen so much. The younger generation prefers the CD with the main points of the story. It takes only three to four hours maximum.'"

Running a small business requires some level of expertise in many areas. There are management issues, marketing questions and financial realities. Trying to master all areas, or at least sort them all out, can be frustrating, exhausting and scary. Entrepreneurship differs from many other "professions" in that by definition you are on your own: no colleagues back at the office, no mentor or boss to show you the way. The Sports Illustrated model is bent in downward-dog position, feet planted in a wide V. Each Asics resting on a gliding disc, she slides first her right foot across and beneath her torso, then repeats the motion with her left foot. Someone who did not know better might imagine Irina Shayk was playing Twister, that goofy '60s game involving a spinner and a vinyl polka-dot floor mat. But working out is no more a game for someone in Shayk's line of work than it would be for a professional athlete. In a business where a pert behind and firm inner thighs are career requisites, more models are moving away from body-shaping routines built on a diet of Moët & Chandon and Marlboro Reds and doing something their predecessors assiduously avoided: hitting the gym.

Is it better to rent or buy? In his column today David Leonhardt takes a fresh look at the issue. According to Mr. Leonhardt, the decision depends on where you live. In some areas, like South Florida, Phoenix and Las Vegas, buying has become more attractive since home prices have declined so much relative to rents. In others, like Manhattan or San Francisco, it still may make financial sense to rent.

Six days after volcanic ash virtually shut down European airspace, the airlines slowly resumed flights there on Tuesday. The last time my wife, Jackie, and I ate in a restaurant operated by the French chef-restaurateur Joël Robuchon was at his place on rue de Longchamp, in Paris, which closed in 1993. We were probably there in 1980s. What I remember best about that dinner, apart from an overall impression of excellence and a stunning tomato tart, was a snatch of overheard conversation: Older man leans across the table and purrrrrrs to (much) younger woman, "Un dîner digne de madame" - "A dinner worthy of the lady." You can't say these things in English, and probably not even in French nowadays, but it has become one of our catchphrases, often applied to meals like the leftover pizza we had the other night.

10 Percent Cut in Muni Service Proposed | You can expect your ride on Muni over the next year to get more uncomfortable and your wait for buses and trolleys longer, if  San Francisco's Board of Supervisors approves the lean budget adopted Tuesday by the Municipal Transportation Authority. A 10 percent service cut would take effect on May 8, according to the new $750 million budget. Transit officials had hoped an infusion of cash from the state would prevent service reductions, but now say that won't be possible until July 2011. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

Last week, Knopf published a new translation of "The Second Sex," Simone de Beauvoir's feminist masterpiece. The original English translation, in print for over 60 years, was widely considered to be a botched job, done by a zoology professor with imperfect French and significantly abridged by the publisher. This latest translation got us thinking about de Beauvoir's accidental style statements - about her whole amazing, intellectual frump thing. Digging into the New York Times photo morgue, we've come up with what must be the world's first "Simone de Beauvoir Look-Book." Which is nothing if not reductionist and superficial. But hey, we've graded dictators and literary lions before, so why should existentialists be exempt?

(Fox) AMERICAN IDOL: IDOL GIVES BACK 2010 Alicia Keys, Carrie Underwood, the Black Eyed Peas, Annie Lennox, Jeff Beck and Elton John, as well as a few celebrities not yet revealed, use their star wattage to raise awareness and money for charities around the globe. The special, now in its third installment, has raised more than $140 million to date; this year's show is dedicated to programs like Feeding America, Malaria No More, the American branch of Save the Children and the United Nations Foundation. (Above, LaKisha Jones, left, a Season 6 ''Idol'' finalist, and Stacy Laster of the Houston Food Bank.) Ryan Seacrest will host from the ''American Idol'' stage in Los Angeles. Queen Latifah will hold court at the Pasadena Civic Auditorium. 8 P.M. (13) THROUGH A DOG'S EYES For thousands of disabled Americans, dogs really are man's best friend. In this documentary, Jennifer Arnold, the founder of Canine Assistants, one of the nation's largest service-dog organizations, takes viewers through the process of being matched with, and becoming acclimated to, a dog, while inspirational stories show the transformation of seemingly ordinary dogs into full-blown heroes. Neil Patrick Harris narrates.

Funeral Thursday, April 22 at 11:15am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., New York. Private burial to follow. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The GO Project, 86 Fourth Ave, New York, NY 10003.

ZERMAN--Melvyn B.,79, died peacefully at his home in Manhattan on April 19, 2010. He is survived by his sons, Andrew, of Manhattan and Jared (Amy), of Irvington, NY, his daughter, Lenore (David Balk) of Los Angeles, four grandchildren, Mitchell, Gemma, Adam and Gillian, and sisters Ruth Beleson and Renee Langsam. Predeceased by his wife, Miriam. Born in the Bronx, he received a BA from the University of Michigan and an MA from Columbia. After many years as a successful publishing sales executive, in 1977 Mel recounted his experiences as a murder trial juror in the much-acclaimed Call "The Final Witness" (Harper & Row, 1977). He followed this up with two non-fiction books for young adults. In 1984 he founded Limelight Editions, publishing reprints and, later, original titles, of books on the performing arts. By time he retired in 2003, the company had elegantly and lovingly published over 200 titles. Mel was also an avid art collector, traveler and inveterate theatre goer. He will be remembered for his humor, his intelligence, his loyalty, his wisdom and, most of all, his kindness. A funeral will be held on April 21 at 2pm at the Riverside, Amsterdam at 76th. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be sent to the Alzheimer's Association/New York Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave, 4th floor, New York City, NY 10017. www.alz.org/nyc.

KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. -- The space shuttle Discovery returned to Earth on Tuesday with a fiery dawn plunge across the heartland of America, closing out a complex space station resupply mission with a smooth Florida landing. Running a day late because of cloudy weather, Capt. Alan G. Poindexter of the Navy took over manual control at an altitude of about 50,000 feet above the spaceport, guiding the shuttle through a sweeping right overhead turn to line up on Runway 33.

Alan Cumming, right, has withdrawn from the long-delayed Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' because of a scheduling conflict, a spokesman for the show said on Monday night. Mr. Cumming, who won the Tony Award for best actor in a musical in 1998 for his role as the M.C. in ''Cabaret,'' was to play the villain Green Goblin in ''Spider-Man'' for Julie Taymor, the director and one of the book writers. Ms. Taymor and Mr. Cumming worked together on the movies ''Titus'' and most recently ''The Tempest,'' which is expected to be released later this year. ''Spider-Man'' was originally scheduled to begin performances on Broadway in February, but endured production delays because its first group of producers had difficulty raising money to mount the musical, which at that time was expected to cost $50 million. A new lead producer came on board in November and has said that the musical will go forward at the Hilton Theater sometime this year.

KAPLAN--Roberta Wennik. Born March 9, 1930 in New York City she died peacefully at home in South Orange, New Jersey on Sunday, April 18th, surrounded by her family and her tireless and beautiful nurse's aide Catherine Marquis. She loved Mozart, Bach, Handel, Sinatra, Rodgers and Hammerstein, Kaufman and Hart, Larry David, and Freud; she loved flowers, colors, dachshunds, coffee ice cream, her friends, silly laughter and the Upper East Side of Manhattan; most of all she loved her family: her late husband Robert Edward Kaplan; Rob, Maria, Bob and Will; Peter, Lisa, Caroline, Charlie, Peter Walker and Davey; Jim, Karen, Jacob, Aaron and Avery. She will be missed forever by every one of us.

Ike Davis's major league career has only just begun, but already his name is resonating, in part because it evokes one of the great artifacts of American political history - the ''I Like Ike'' campaign slogan used on behalf of Dwight D. Eisenhower in the 1950s, when he was twice elected president. During Davis's major league debut with the Mets on Monday, fans went to Citi Field armed with ''I Like Ike'' banners. Mets television announcers had fun referring to Adlai Stevenson, the losing candidate in each of Eisenhower's victories. Playing along, The New York Post ran a back-page headline Tuesday that read, ''Ike Takes Office.''

The expressive footwork of Kate Gosselin -- and her expressionless mien -- continued to captivate and baffle viewers as ''Dancing With the Stars'' led the ratings on Monday night. That ABC reality competition averaged 20.8 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, followed by the premiere of the comedy ''Romantically Challenged'' (11.6 million), starring Alyssa Milano. CBS was runner-up on the night as a new episode of ''CSI: Miami'' (11.7 million) surpassed the rival crime series ''Castle'' (10.5 million) on ABC. Fox ranked third with ''House'' (10.6 million) and ''24'' (8.9 million). NBC placed fourth.

When ESPN contracted Jeff and Michael Zimbalist about making a documentary about the infiltration of drug money into professional soccer in Colombia during the 1980s and ’90s, the brothers’ original plan was to make a 50-minute film. The finished product, called “The Two Escobars,” came in at twice that length, and in addition to its showing on ESPN in June,  made the line-up at the Tribeca Film Festival. Its world premiere on Thursday night is to be followed by three other showings.

My nine-month old son engages with music in a variety of ways as he moves through his daily life. He listens to music in the background while he focuses on other activities. He moves to music as my wife or I clap his hands and bounce him up and down in time to a song. And he creates music, banging his fists on a piano keyboard to play clusters of high and low notes. As judged by laughs and smiles, he likes all of these activities, but he enjoys creating music the most.

Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck are making a comeback in "The Looney Tunes Show," a new series that situates the characters in the suburbs with wacky neighbors like Yosemite Sam, Tweety and Sylvester. The series was announced by the Cartoon Network during a presentation to advertisers of its coming season. Other series include "Mad Magazine," an animated sketch-comedy series based on the long-running print publication that will include the Spy vs. Spy characters, and "Young Justice," about a group of teenage super heroes who must deal with teachers, parents, crime-fighting mentors and power-crazed super villains. A restaurant three years in the making, Viajante opened on April 18 in the Town Hall Hotel in east London's Bethnal Green neighborhood. The Portuguese chef Nuno Mendes, who once worked under Ferran Adrià at El Bulli, signed on back in 2007. In the years since, he has developed menus and recipes at the Loft, the supper club and test kitchen he ran out of his own home, serving multi-course tasting menus to those lucky enough to get a reservation.

"Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson," the rock musical at the Public Theater, is being extended once again, for three weeks through May 30. Blending emo-rock with populism, the widely praised show presents Jackson as a rock star. The Public is turning three Saturday nights into beer night -- or wine, soda or liquor night -- with audience members receiving a free drink coupon with a ticket for the 9:30 p.m. shows on May 15, 22 and 29 for $49. Benjamin Walker stars as Jackson. The musical is written and directed by Alex Timbers, with music and lyrics by Michael Friedman.

Long Island City, Queens, is dotted with former industrial buildings, but it is also rich in artistic endeavors, like the transformation of a warehouse and a landfill into public art spaces. Socrates Sculpture Park, the former landfill, is a huge green canvas for large artworks; recent displays include a bright yellow walkway made of inner tubes, and a concrete rat and pigeon on a podium. And some of the local art is accidental. At 49th Avenue and Vernon Boulevard, a passer-by will see at dusk the nearby Gothic spires of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church and, above the rooftops and across the river, the twinkling lights of the Empire State and Chrysler Buildings.

NASA has released spectacular, new images of the sun, taken from a spacecraft called the Solar Dynamics Observatory, which was launched into space in February. Given the durability and predictability of the arguments involved, and the amount of ink spilled on them over the years (and centuries, and millennia), it's hard to come up with something interesting to say on the question of Christianity versus the "new" atheists. But the Orthodox theologian David Bentley Hart has now managed the trick twice: Once in his slim book "Atheist Delusions: The Christian Revolution and Its Fashionable Enemies," which came out last year, and now in a fine essay for the latest First Things. Here's his concluding reflection - but do read the whole thing:

"Recently I was re-reading The Lord of the Rings and began to wonder how it might be read fifty years from now, assuming that our scientists are able to extend the human lifespan significantly. Might it not be that Bilbo and Gollum will become more significant figures in the minds of future readers? And might not the Ring itself take on a different aura of meanings? Think of Bilbo, in appearance "unchanged" in his eleventy-first year, who nevertheless confesses, 'I am old, Gandalf. I don't look it, but I am beginning to feel it in my heart of hearts. . . Why, I feel all thin, sort of stretched, if you know what I mean: like butter that has been scraped over too much bread. That can't be right.' And think of Gollum, to whom the Ring has given 'unnaturally long life': in the end, 'He hated it and he loved it, as he hated and loved himself.' In the lives of these two characters the One Ring does not appear as a Ring of Power so much as a Ring of Immortality, a ring that gives biological life without the means to enjoy it or profit from it. How many people in the future will identify in a particularly strong way with Bilbo and Gollum in this respect? ... Similarly, what will future generations make of that terrifying epigraph to Eliot's poem The Waste Land, taken from Petronius's Satyricon? The epigraph concerns the Cumaean Sybil, who made the mistake of asking the gods for extraordinarily long life without also asking for youth, so that her body wthered and shrank almost to nothingness. One of the main characters of the Satyricon, the ludicrous Trimalchio, says, 'For I myself once saw with my own eyes the Sibyl hanging in a cage, and when the boys asked her, 'Sibyl, what do you want?' she answered "I want to die.''"

Eastport, a city of about 1,600 people that is about as down east in Maine as you can get, has seen better days. At one point in its history it was the sardine capital of the East, but overfishing and resulting catch restrictions led to that industry's long slow death. The old canneries along the shore are shuttered and decaying, and the last one in the region -- indeed, in the country -- about 50 miles to the southeast in Prospect Harbor, closed just last week.

What is it about music festival photography that is so transfixing? Iconic crowd shots from Newport, Woodstock, Live Aid or Glastonbury can do more to explain an era's zeitgeist than shelves of sociological studies. Music's liberating power combined with the absence of authority can make for mesmerizing glimpses of youth culture - its tribes, rituals, uniforms, couplings, body adornment, accouterments - in all its uninhibited glory.

Three American authors have been named to the shortlist for the  Orange Prize for fiction, the British honor awarded annually for a novel written by a woman in English.  The finalists this year include Barbara Kingsolver for "The Lacuna," Attica Locke for "Black Water Rising" and Lorrie Moore for "A Gate at the Stairs." Ms. Locke is a first-time novelist. The list also includes the much-garlanded Hilary Mantel, for "Wolf Hall," which has already won the Man Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction. Rounding out the list of finalists are the British writer Rosie Alison for "The Very Thought of You," and Monique Roffey, who was born in Trinidad, for "The White Woman on the Green Bicycle."  The winner will be announced on June 9 in London. The prize comes with a check for about $46,000 and a bronze statue called a Bessie.

"We make clothes because it makes us happy," says David Gensler, the designer, branding guru, business innovator and main brain behind the KDU, a Brooklyn-based consultancy and design collective. The multifaceted branding department (with clients like LVMH and Diesel) is the collective's breadwinner, but Volkcraft, its meticulous men's clothing line, is the love child. The jacket-focused collection, designed by Gensler, the creative director Aerosyn-Lex Mestrovic and the senior designer Portia Wells, consists of made-to-measure garments that combine Savile Row luxury, avant-garde fashion and high-tech sportswear; it is meant to evoke a jet-setting, high-performing lifestyle similar to their own. "One week we'll be standing by an erupting volcano in Iceland and the next we'll be walking the Great Wall of China," Gensler says.

There is something very elementary that recreational players can do to improve their games in a highly sophisticated way. First, when you get to the range, pick a target in the distance to aim at -- a specific flag or a cluster of small trees. Then, lay a club on the ground parallel with your shoulders so that it is pointing in the direction of the target. Before you hit your first ball, it is essential that you use an alignment aid to train your eyes to aim properly.

Millions of people suffer from the common but mysterious ailment known as "essential tremor" -- the uncontrollable shaking of the hands, head or other body parts that occurs during voluntary movement. Here, one reader asks whether Botox is a good option for somebody with shaking in the hand.

The day after laying off half of my workers, I sat with the others in my office. They knew we were in trouble, but The Partner's policy of silence had kept me from revealing just how bad it was. They were angry about being kept in the dark, and many were ready to quit. So I made a promise that from that day forward I would answer any question, any time, as completely and honestly as possible. I laid out for them what the near-term future would look like: we had work, but not much. More might be coming, but maybe not.

Big Bambu, the massive installation by the artists Mike and Doug Starn, is green is every sense of the word. It's green, literally. It's made from one of the most sustainable materials around. And it's even recyclable. The original 50 foot tall sculpture, which was assembled from a network of 2000 bamboo poles at the former Talix Foundry in Beacon, New York, was reconfigured into a T for the cover of our 5th anniversary issue. And it recently moved to the roof of the Metropolitan Museum where it will be on view from April 27 through October 31.

Handing Out Cash to Stave Off Homelessness | In the past two years, Antonio Moore, 30, has gone from a $75,000-a-year job as a mortgage consultant to working part-time for $10-an-hour as a line cook at a fast-food restaurant. He lost his three-bedroom house and his Lexus. Mr. Moore, who lives in San Mateo, is now in danger of becoming homeless because he cannot pay the rent on his studio apartment. The fountain of youth is legendary in myth and history; some scientists and skin-care experts think it still exists, thanks to an enzyme called telomerase. Dr. Gregory Bays Brown of RéVive has created a $1,500 skin cream, Peau Magnifique, containing telomerase. In fact, the 2009 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine went to three scientists who discovered how chromosomes are protected by the enzyme, and further research could prove telomerase to be a key factor in infinite cell proliferation. No one's promising the death of funerals yet, but hope springs eternal. Here's the CliffsNote: As cells divide, they send copies of themselves to new cells. But that copying process chops off bits of the originals' protective tips. As we age, the tips, known as telomeres, get shorter and shorter till the original cells die, and we do too. Cancer cells, stem cells and some rogue cells produce a substance that blocks the snipping process - telomerase. How it can be deconstructed, harnessed and activated remains to be seen: lab-made telomerase would have to penetrate skin, pass through tissue and cell walls, and hook into chromosomal activity in order to be effective. But RéVive's Brown claims that telomerase can recruit the skin's resting stem cells - which exist in case of injury - to manufacture new skin. So far, there are no major peer-review studies or clinical trials. And animal testing isn't possible since only humans produce it. Nevertheless, the party has definitely begun; in addition to RéVive, Jan Marini's Age Intervention Regeneration Booster and Goldfaden's DNA Telomere Cream boast telomere science. Other beauty products are sure to follow.

WASHINGTON -- There were few liberals and just one woman on the federal appeals court in Chicago when Diane P. Wood, an antitrust expert with a flair for foreign language and an ear for playing the oboe, showed up in the summer of 1995. The chief judge, a scholarly conservative named Richard A. Posner, promptly gave her some advice. The appeals bench, Judge Posner warned, was like ''a system of arranged marriage with no divorce.'' His message to his junior colleague was clear: Pick your battles carefully. Compromise when you can.

SUPAI, Ariz. -- Seven years ago, the Havasupai Indians, who live amid the turquoise waterfalls and red cliffs miles deep in the Grand Canyon, issued a ''banishment order'' to keep Arizona State University employees from setting foot on their reservation -- an ancient punishment for what they regarded as a genetic-era betrayal. Members of the tiny, isolated tribe had given DNA samples to university researchers starting in 1990, in the hope that they might provide genetic clues to the tribe's devastating rate of diabetes. But they learned that their blood samples had been used to study many other things, including mental illness and theories of the tribe's geographical origins that contradict their traditional stories.

FOR the first time since the 1970s, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has announced a step that it once took routinely: appointing an inspector for a new reactor construction project. With 17 applications in hand from companies that want to build 26 reactors, the agency is likely to name a lot more inspectors; it also expects five more applicants in the next few years.

10 P.M. (National Geographic) AMERICAN SERENGETI ''Nature Untamed'' follows scientists at the American Prairie Foundation as they embark on a quest to rebuild three million acres of the Great Plains in Montana, where land and wildlife have been eroded by human settlement for more than 200 years. The mission, covering an area larger than Yellowstone, includes reintroducing species long associated with the West, like the bison, the pallid sturgeon and the prairie dog, and charting the resurgence of pronghorn antelope, cougars, rattlesnakes and big-horned sheep. 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEW The women chat with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

Livescribe's Pulse smartpen is a standard writing instrument combined with a digital audio recorder. By using special dot-embedded paper, notes you take at a lecture, for instance, are synched with a recording of that talk. Touch the pen to a scribbled word and you'll hear the recording. With the Pulse smartpen, students, lawyers doing depositions and harried reporters don't have to worry about capturing every word.

Bill Wisleski earned himself the nickname the Human Magnet over in Vietnam, for the way flying objects found their way to him, twice when his vehicles hit land mines, once from direct rifle fire. In between, he tried to keep track of his hometown team, the Amazing Mets. It was not easy in those days before the Internet. Soldiers would ask each other for the latest scores, the current standings, but they were all a week or two behind.

FOR companies that specialize in the business of saving energy, these ought to be flush times. Last year's stimulus package devoted at least $20 billion to efficiency measures, more than any other single law. President Obama regularly preaches the virtues of better insulation and weatherizing homes. Yet the efficiency business has not reaped the benefit that it had hoped to receive. The stimulus dollars -- enough to increase the amount of federal money some state energy offices receive by a factor of 100 -- are still being distributed. Money being doled out by different government agencies has been delayed by problems like insufficient staff in the Energy Department and pay requirements for contractors in the stimulus law.

Q.Is there a way to schedule sending a message in Outlook instead of right when I write it?A.Outlook 2007 includes a feature to easily delay the delivery of a single message or all of them. If your Internet service provider uses a POP3 mail system, however, you do need to keep the Outlook program open until the messages are actually sent off. When you have finished writing the message you want to delay, select the Options tab. In the More Options area in the Outlook toolbar ribbon, click on the Delay Delivery icon. When the Message Options box appears, go to the Delivery Options area and put a check in the box next to ''Do not deliver before.'' Select the time and date you want the message to leave. Once you have your delivery time set, click the Close button.

IT'S an age-old problem that has vexed truckers and shippers for as long as there have been truckers and shippers: how to find cargo for their return trip home after they've made their initial delivery. Now truckers are trying to address it in a systematic way. Deadhead trips, as they are known, are a waste of fuel, money and time, and a producer of greenhouse gases. Yet more than a quarter of the trucks on the road in the United States drive empty, according to industry estimates.

These are photographs of plastic bags that I pulled from trees and shrubs in the woods near my home in New Jersey. To make these pictures -- photograms -- I took the bags into my darkroom and gently dropped them between my enlarger's lens and a piece of light-sensitive paper. I then illuminated the scene with a flash of light for less than a second. The resulting images trace the objects gliding in the air moments before they come to rest. Like Earth Day, they are for me a prompt to reflect on

HTC has designed a phone for people who like to take pictures with a phone. It has just announced the modestly named Droid Incredible, which pairs an 8 megapixel camera with a bright 3.7-inch AMOLED screen. AMOLED screens - for Active Matrix Organic Light-Emitting Diode -- are known for their bright colors and fine detail, as well as for low power consumption.

MANUFACTURING, long in decline in the United States, might rise again if the green economy were 100 percent homemade. But that big ''if'' is not what's happening and seems unlikely. Rather than ''made in America,'' much of the green manufacturing to date is ''assembled in America'' from parts made overseas. The Obama administration is trying to change that, offering generous tax credits to generate domestic production. But the impact has been modest, because assembly plants qualify for the credits.

Werner Schroeter, a German film and stage director whose flair for lush visuals and heightened emotions introduced an operatic sensibility to the New German Cinema movement of the 1970s, died on April 12 in Kassel, Germany. He was 65. His death was announced by the Schwules Museum in Berlin, where an exhibition devoted to Mr. Schroeter's work has been running since March. A museum spokeswoman, Anne Jung, told Agence France-Presse that Mr. Schroeter died after an operation for cancer, which he had been fighting for three years.

''He's the Rembrandt of 72nd Street!'' a yellow cab driver yelled at a man on the sidewalk sketching the 72nd Street subway station last Wednesday on the Upper West Side. Not quite: Rembrandt did not use city subway maps as his canvases. But the Rembrandt of 72nd Street does: Enrico Miguel Thomas, who can be found nearly every day outside the station.

OPENINGS FREEMANS SPORTING CLUB has a new store at 327 Bleecker Street (Christopher Street), (212) 255-5509, which will carry its men's-wear line, designed by a co-owner, Taavo Somer; Brooks bike saddles; and sneakers. ''The design is general hardware store in the 1950s,'' said Mr. Somer, who is an architect. There won't be a barbershop, as there is at the original Rivington Street location, but there will be a tailor on site, as well as a newsstand with magazines. ... Bondi Beach comes to New York via the Australian swimwear label ZIMMERMANN, which opened a 2,500-square-foot pop-up shop last week in SoHo, at 112 Greene Street; (212) 925-5405. Besides swimwear ($160 to $300), there are dresses ($250 to $675), caftans and jumpsuits ($150 to $420). The pop-up is scheduled to close June 30, although the plan is to find a permanent SoHo beachhead.

Children love your shiny new iPad, and it has the fingerprints to prove it. What's the best way to keep it looking new? MININGHAM--Robert Darcy of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, died April 15th at Calvary Hospital after battling bladder cancer for more than three years. Robert was born April 4, 1942 in Yonkers, son of George W Miningham and Lillyann Wegener Miningham. Robert graduated from Halstead School and Davis and Elkins College. He enjoyed sports, photography, and travel and had a passion for computers. Robert worked for Columbia University's Hudson Labs as an oceanographer, using computer systems to map the ocean floor. He married Barbara Ann Haas in 1965. In 1977 Robert became co-owner of the highly respected computer software firm, Miningham & Oellerich, Inc, (M&O), 40 Fulton St, New York, which specializes in front and back office solutions (data management) for broker-dealers using "Serve me! Suite." Robert is survived by his loving wife; two of his three beloved daughters, Elisabeth Miningham Monsour (Roy), Katherine Darcy Miningham (deceased 1997), and Victoria Chas Miningham; his Goddaughter, Kristen Blakely; his four beloved grandchildren; his nephew George Miningham; his niece Monica Widing; and his sister Karen Ives. Celebration of Robert's Life will be held at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home in Dobbs Ferry, April 23, 7-9pm. Robert's daughters have created a website, www.seizetheribbon.com, to raise money for research to fight bladder cancer.

Is it really a film festival if Edward Burns isn’t there? Since his debut feature, “The Brothers McMullen,” broke through at the Sundance Film Festival in 1995, Mr. Burns has become a frequent presence at the Tribeca Film Festival, where his directorial efforts like “Ash Wednesday,” “Looking For Kitty” and “Purple Violets” have made their debuts. In the years between, he’s also acted in films like “Saving Private Ryan” and as a fictional version of himself on the HBO comedy “Entourage.” This year he’s back at Tribeca with “Nice Guy Johnny,” about a young man (Matt Bush) pulled between two paths in life and two women, and his miscreant uncle (Mr. Burns) trying to help his decision-making process.

The name Fatih Akin is not likely the first that comes to mind when thinking of jovial movie comedies. His 2004 film “Head On” dealt with two strangers with suicidal tendencies, and 2007’s “The Edge of Heaven” was a serious exploration of the generational and geographical distances between parents and children. Mr. Akin goes in a different direction with “Soul Kitchen,” a lighter look at the frenetic life of a restaurant owner in Hamburg, Germany.

As befits an actor-rapper multi-hyphenate like Ice Cube, his documentary “Straight Outta L.A.” is two stories in one: it’s the tale of how the Oakland Raiders owner Al Davis moved the team to Los Angeles in the 1980s, and how it helped inspire the city and bring it together, before the Raiders returned to Oakland in 1995. It’s also the story of N.W.A., the gangsta rap group that included Ice Cube, Dr. Dre and Eazy-E, and how it made the Raiders’ clothing and sometimes ruthless spirit an essential part of its act. “Straight Outta L.A.” will have its premiere Friday at the Tribeca Film Festival, as part of the Tribeca/ESPN Sports Film Festival, and will be shown on ESPN as part of its “30 for 30″ film series next month.
