Goldman Sachs is in the federal dock, President Obama is in New York talking tough to Wall Street, regulatory packages are flying through Congress -- what could possibly get in the way of the financial reform juggernaut? "The Securities and Exchange Commission is the sheriff of the financial industry," reports Jonathan Karl of ABC News, "but a new government report obtained by ABC News has concluded that some senior employees spent hours on the agency's computers looking at sites such as naughty.com, skankwire and youporn as the financial crisis was unfolding."
The first episode in the live-action prequel for the video game "Alan Wake."

The Securities and Exchange Commission's inspector general said Friday that he would investigate why the agency filed securities fraud charges against Goldman Sachs on April 16 after several House Republicans questioned whether the timing of the case was aimed at swaying the Senate's debate on the financial regulatory bill.
In this week's Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan writes about an emerging hybrid of philanthropy and private equity called "impact investing."
This week's Your Money column discusses how women fare when it comes to money matters.

3:47 p.m. | Updated After many flights to New York were delayed because of the volcanic ash clouds over Europe, the Chorus of the Mariinsky Theater finally arrived at Avery Fisher Hall in time for the second concert of "The Russian Stravinsky: A Philharmonic Festival" on Thursday night. The chorus was missed in Wednesday's opening-night program, conducted (as is the entire festival) by Valery Gergiev, which was to have included "Les Noces," not heard at the Philharmonic since 1982.

This week's Minimalist column uses escarole, one of the first spring greens and more affordable than other early offerings like radicchio. Its flavor is better cooked than raw, especially when mixed with creamy rice and the sweet mellow bite of garlic.
On Dec. 16, 2009, I boarded a plane to Kabul, where I would spend five weeks as a research assistant.
Alaïa, AzzedineClaims he would love to design for H&M. Chic!
A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.
Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York region. Subjects include showers for stranded travelers, the bar car on the Metro-North, and a party at the Hudson Hotel.

Former executives at Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's offered damaging critiques on Friday of the practices at the two credit-rating agencies during the run-up to the financial crisis, The New York Times's Sewell Chan reports from Washington.
Bettors at Aqueduct racetrack, in Queens, N.Y., are devoted to their no-frills track, which is in for another lean season.

My colleagues on the news side of The Times have expanded the focus of the great Green Inc. blog, which was reborn this week simply as Green. I hope you'll track their work on environmental commerce, science, energy policy and related issues. You can contact the Green team with tips or feedback at greenblog@nytimes.com.
Mark Bittman prepares a pot of Italian spring soup.

Updated, 7:07 p.m. | The crowds that lined East Houston Street on Thursday morning to watch Barack Obama's motorcade speed toward Cooper Union got a glimpse of the pomp and protection that accompanies the president. There were black sedans with tinted windows, S.U.V.'s full of Secret Service agents and a brigade of motorcycle officers from the New York Police Department led by a high-ranking officer wearing a white shirt.
Last night I gave some bum advice to Rachel Feinstein.

Everyone's having fun with the chickens for checkups story, in which Sue Lowden, the leading Republican Senate candidate in Nevada, expressed a desire to return to the good old days in which people who wanted a checkup from their doctor would offer a chicken in exchange. And she's not backing down!
Even though the job market appears to be turning around, more than one in five American workers still thinks the axe may be coming for them in the next year.
The pastel spring coat disappeared decades ago, replaced by variations of the between-season trench coat.

Luxury resorts at motel prices. Sugary beaches without crowds. In the weeks between spring break and the summer crush, travelers are few and deals abound. Lionel Beehner offers eight places to enjoy the off-season.
Things are picking up for Carl C. Icahn in his takeover battle for Lions Gate Entertainment.
A new amusement park on Coney Island will feature 22 new rides manufactured by Italy's Zamperla Group.

There's been an interesting exchange over my suggestion -- which is by no means original -- that the stability of banks between 1935 and 1980 or so had a lot to do with lack of competition, which gave banks a franchise value that executives didn't want to endanger with risky strategies.

Good news for the Robins family and everyone who has been praying for the safe return of 14-year-old Matt: he is back home in Maplewood. According to the family's Facebook page, all is well. A friend of the family said the family is asking for privacy. -- The Local

Ecologically correct fashion can be more than hemp totes and Veja sneakers - even more than vegan platforms from Stella McCartney. In the hands of the Franco-Brazilian designer Jean-Philippe Gawronski, it's something you want to wear well beyond the yoga studio. The handsome 30-year-old designer, who honed his skills at Lanvin for a year, realized that there was something missing at the high end of the green market. In 2007, he launched Imitation and Disguise, a focused collection of luxurious clothing and accessories made with ecologically certified materials. "I wanted to create clothes that make a woman look elegant, sexy and of the moment," he said from Paris.

New York Times reporters will be providing updates and analysis of the second and third rounds of the N.F.L. draft. Paul Myerberg of The Times will be hosting the festivities, and Judy Battista is at Radio City Music Hall, Greg Bishop is with the Jets and Dave Caldwell with the Giants. You can also follow Judy on Twitter. You can catch up on last night's coverage here.

The setting was the sun-dappled campus of Columbia University, so perhaps it wasn't surprising that today's forum on "New York and the Electric Car," sponsored by the university and General Motors, took on a somewhat elevated tone.

Given the commotion outside his office in the West Bank one day in 2006 - armed protesters, some of them firing into the air, were marching through the streets of Ramallah - Osama Silwadi, a well-known Palestinian photojournalist, naturally, went to the window to see what was going on.

Sher Bano is a 17-year-old Pashtun girl from Pakistan who spent last year as an exchange student in Evanston, Illinois, as part of the Youth Exchange and Study (YES) Program. She is now back in the city of Peshawar in the northwest of Pakistan. As a guest blogger, she'll be writing about life in Pakistan from the perspective of a teenage girl who has spent time in the West. This is her second post.

It has been five years since Microsoft and Remedy Entertainment of Finland announced that they were developing a mature psychological action thriller for the Xbox 360 called Alan Wake. The game isn't scheduled to hit stores until May 18, but its milieu -- the disturbing, mist-shrouded Northwestern town known as Bright Falls -- is first coming to life in a live-action suspense series.
The first episode in the live-action prequel for the video game Alan Wake.
The Ravenswood City School District board voted on Thursday night to end grades K-4 at a charter school run by Stanford University's School of Education.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. - Well, President Obama can check this campaign promise off the list at least. While running for president, he camped out in this scenic small city surrounded by the Blue Ridge Mountains in October 2008 to prepare for a debate, and the candidate liked it so much he vowed to come back.

Halston was the party monster's party monster, the "Emperor of Studio 54," until the excesses of his life finally did him in. And now he is the subject of a new documentary, "Ultrasuede: In Search of Halston," one of the most anticipated films at this year's Tribeca Film Festival.

Religious violence erupted in numerous places around the world on Friday, most grievously in Baghdad. Karim Kadim - a member of the Associated Press team that won the 2005 Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography - was on the scene and took the first three pictures in today's report; an unusual presence for a single photographer on any given day.

Following is the third and final set of responses from Dr. Laura Erickson-Schroth, who is working on "Trans Bodies, Trans Selves," a resource guide for transgender and other gender-variant people, covering health, legal issues, cultural and social questions, history and theory.

In this article, adapted from "Sexy and Good: Sustainable Product Design," which appeared in the Fall/Winter 2009/2010 issue of the Harvard Design Magazine, the T columnist and International Herald Tribune design critic Alice Rawsthorn discusses the design and ecological pros and cons of nine products.

Last year, the French culinary organization Omnivore held its first festival in New York. On Friday, the group released details of an expanded and more ambitious event to be held June 4 and 5. This one is to be split between Manhattan and Brooklyn.
Zipcar members will soon be able to cross the Atlantic and unlock a fleet of cars parked throughout London and other cities in England.
Manager Jerry Manuel unveiled his promised new lineup on Friday afternoon, and it has Jose Reyes batting third, the first time Reyes has not been in the leadoff spot since July 5, 2005.
The Moviegoer is a regular column on new and noteworthy films, actors and directors by John Anderson.

As the week comes to a close iPhonegate continues to captivate the country; stores remain closed, truckers can't buy gasoline, life is essentially at a standstill ... O.K., it didn't really captivate the country, but the missing iPhone did make it onto almost every major media outlet, including "Good Morning America" and "Late Show With David Letterman." Still, in the nerdosphere, the debate continues among technologist and gadget blogs. But what did commenters on The Times Web site think? Many believed that the entire production was just another Apple publicity stunt.

Rejection letters are impossibly thin. For such small missives they settle on the kitchen counter laden in the emotional weight of 18 years of child-rearing: hand-wringing hopes, pushed-aside problems (like cars and trees) and the crazy optimism that comes with mothering - like the possibility of full-ride scholarships and the Ivy League.

If you can't stop them, link to them. That is the approach Ford is taking to the use of smartphones in the car. Later this year, the automaker will introduce software that allows applications, like Pandora and Twitter, to be used with  cellphones connected to its in-car Sync systems (a topic that is covered in an article in Sunday's Automobiles section).

Two topics buzzing through the blogs today concern the Army's decision to "disinvite'' the Rev. Franklin Graham, son of the evangelist Billy Graham, to lead the services at the National Day of Prayer event at the Pentagon next month, and President Obama criticizing Arizona's pending immigration legislation.

The photographers Coppi Barbieri made this video, "Nude," to coincide with the T Women's Fashion Summer 2010 issue, the theme of which is undone beauty. As you'll see, model Adela Capova comes undone beautifully.

British newspapers are known for many things, but the impulse to hide their political views under a bushel of subtlety is not among them. For Americans taught that newspapers are supposed to be impartial in their news pages, a headline like "The Cam Back Kid," which adorned the front page of The Sun on Friday -- hailing the Conservative leader David Cameron's "victory" in the tabloid's own poll of viewers of Thursday's televised debate -- might seem to err on the side of editorializing. On the newspaper's Web site, readers were shown a huge photograph of Mr. Cameron downing a celebratory pint of beer, "to celebrate bouncing back in style to win the second party leaders' debate."
An 18-minute film chronicling the life of a plastic bag has gone viral on the Internet.

There is much talk around the Devils today of how disappointed players are (Rich Chere in The Star-Ledger quotes many of them), and how equally disappointed many of the fans are (like blogger John Fischer of In Lou We Trust), how much more everyone expected from a team whose cornerstones are Hall of Famers Lou Lamoriello and Jacques Lemaire and future Hall of Fame goalie Martin Brodeur.
Senator Richard J. Durbin told reporters on Friday that he has been subpoenaed to testify in former Illinois Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich's upcoming corruption trial, according to news media reports.
The drawing is nearly devoid of detail. It shows a vague-faced man in a suit, ripped from context, leaning his hand up against nothing.
Jazz returns to Millburn High School next Thursday, when students will perform their annual "Night of Jazz XI" concert at 7:30 p.m.

The great Marisa Silver, guest-blogging last week at The Elegant Variation, offered a short but valuable list of "Advice for the Lovelorn ... I Mean Writers," in which she applied relationship lessons to literature. Among her tips: "Get lost. Be scared. Have no idea where you're headed."
Coal mining carries inherent risks. But the TECO Coal Corporation, operator of the E3-1 mine in Hazard, Ky., places a high priority on mine safety.

A surprising number of teams spent their first-round pick on a position that, going into the draft, seemed already to be filled. These moves are always intriguing. Sometimes they're a result of a team following the "best player available" drafting model. But usually, it's a team saying, "Fans might like the players we already have at this position, but we sure don't."

One of the longest relationships between an advertiser and an agency is ending after 96 years as the Chevrolet division of General Motors cuts its remaining ties with Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

It's all about ... undone beauty, starring our cover girl, the actress Rebecca Hall, who channels 'Horses'-era Patti Smith to capture the season's effortless style. Speaking of undone, we present a portfolio of beauties  from Karen O to Greta Gerwig  for whom messy is more, revisit Bettina Rheims's bare beauties, explore the history of nude fashion and bring you up to date on the latest in dry shampoos and wispy fragrances. Chanel makeup artist Peter Philips performs a surreal reveal, hair star Guido Palau picks his favorite products and Anjelica Huston talks about her favorite scent (hint: it isn't Joy). Susan Campos combs through Hollywood's secret hair-restoration club, Daphne Merkin dreams of life as a Real Housewife  complacent husband and all, and Guy Trebay reveals the naked truth about today's models.

Nearly 20,000 sixth graders who attend low-income schools will receive free computers beginning in September, thanks to a $22 million federal grant meant to increase broadband access in New York City.
Our virtual refrigerator is bare. Thanks to Grace, its spot in the right-hand column of The Local has been beautifully held for several weeks. But now it's time for something new.

This week, Facebook introduced the "open graph," a giant expansion of the "social graph" concept on which Facebook is built. The word "open" alone should be a tip-off that there are significant new privacy issues to weigh.

Lehman Brothers Holdings, the bankruptcy estate of the failed investment bank, moved to dismiss more than $1 billion worth of creditor claims by Nomura of Japan, arguing that they are vastly overstated.

Something borrowed, something old, something new - the only thing missing from this one-off necklace ($2,900) by Marsha Chun-Matsubara (her fledgling label is called Abakus) is something blue. Unicorn Disco, inspired by a client's old necklace, is made of vintage aluminum disks from Germany, bubble pearls, antique copper mesh, fake coral, rhinestone buttons and snakeskin printed beads. "It reminds me of something by Miriam Haskell," Chun-Matsubara says, "but turbocharged." Go to abakuscollection.com for information.

This week: Alan Brinkley discusses the life of Henry Luce, creator of the Time-Life magazine empire; Charles McGrath talks about a biography of the author Muriel Spark; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

Mike Tanier, an analyst for footballoutsiders.com and a contributor to the Fifth Down, answered readers' questions Friday afternoon about the N.F.L. draft. Look for his insight and analysis on Rounds 2 and 3 of the draft, delivered with a joke or two, Friday night on the Fifth Down.

A new five-year forecast by J.D. Power and Associates anticipates a 55 percent growth for the automotive market in China by 2015, with sales of passenger vehicles -- defined as cars, sport utility vehicles and minivans -- expected to increase from 8.7 million in 2009 to 13.5 million in 2015.
Think the real estate bust has been tough for everyone? Just ask Jamie Dimon.

As investigators continue looking into the business and political dealings of Pedro Espada Jr., the Senate majority leader, a top Democratic donor announced Friday that he planned to direct as much as $250,000 toward defeating Mr. Espada in this year's election.

Sister Helen Prejean, the author of the best-selling book and Hollywood film "Dead Man Walking" and an outspoken opponent of the death penalty, is the next speaker in the Catholic Perspectives Lecture Series at Seton Hall University. Want to cover it for The Local?
The Icelandic volcano that disrupted global air travel last week raised a concern: should we be thinking of alternative ways to move masses of people and goods? Read more.
All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we've created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

You've probably read a lot about Jason Pierre-Paul and his amazing athletic ability. But if you've yet to witness it, here's the YouTube video everyone has been talking about.

When my wife and I decided to move out of New York about a year and a half ago, we would begrudgingly wake up early every weekend, leave our cramped, fourth-floor corner, pocket walk-up and shuffle ourselves onto a groggy train to meet our real estate agent in downtown Maplewood.

Overview | What if hundreds of people around the world took pictures at the same moment and uploaded them to one digital album? The New York Times's Lens blog has invited people to submit photos taken at the same time on Sunday, May 2, 2010. In this lesson, students look at and critique Times reader-submitted photos that capture a moment and/or express a theme. They then do a "trial run" for "A Moment in Time," create a presentation of their images and prepare to participate in and/or view and assess the May 2 event.

The Cleveland Play House, the Cleveland Orchestra, and GroundWorks DanceTheater have undertaken an unusual collaboration this weekend to present a new production of Stravinsky's "Soldier's Tale," which includes a libretto by Kurt Vonnegut Jr. that sets the work during World War II.

Last week, in spite of the volcanic ash cloud, Milan was abuzz with design, both at the furniture fair and at the many exhibitions outside it. There was plenty to see, and to sit on. Chairs were somewhat more restrained than in recent years, and there was a strong bent toward practicality, with a liberal sprinkling of eco-friendliness. But beauty, and even whimsy, was also on the menu. Here are a few of The Moment's favorites.
Former N.B.A. star center Vlade Divac has had many titles in his career: All-star, two-time Olympic silver medalist, two-time world champion, savvy flopper, basketball ambassador.

The fate of the big financial regulation legislation is largely in the hands of two chief negotiators: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, the chairman of the banking committee, and Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, the panel's senior Republican.

One day after President Obama addressed some of the nation's most influential bankers on the need for a new financial regulatory structure, lawmakers in Congress are battling over the details of the overhaul bill.

BMW introduced a new 'tweener sedan concept at this week's auto show in Beijing, a design study that hints at how far the brand thinks it can push its styling without giving up its signature elements. Called the Gran Coupé, it would slot into BMW's lineup between the 5 Series and 7 Series.

On Earth Day, the leadership of the International Whaling Commission issued a long-discussed proposal for a "peace plan" aimed at reining in expanding whale hunts by Japan, Norway and Iceland that have, in various ways, skirted the longstanding moratorium on commercial whaling.

We are easily amused. Thus, titles like James Schuyler's "Other Flowers: Uncollected Poems," reviewed this weekend in the Book Review, elicit chuckles. (Which is not to say anything bad about the book itself; Stephen Burt, our reviewer, has only high praise.)

The Broadway production of David Mamet's play "Race" has earned back its initial investment of about $2.5 million after five months of performances this season, the producers announced this week. It is one of a handful of commercial plays this season to have recouped the investment spent on mounting the productions on Broadway.
The tennis bubble at Queensboro Ovalwill be removed in May, paving the way for a return of the softball and baseball leagues that nearly lost their summertime fields.

I recently received a copy of "Wellbeing: The Five Essential Elements" in the mail. The book, published by Gallup Press, is a readable digest of survey data and academic research on what makes people happy and what makes them unhappy. To the uninitiated in this subject, you may find that the things you think make people happy are, in the words of the book's authors, "misguided or just plain wrong."
Monologue | Thursday night on "The Tonight Show With Jay Leno" on NBC: Happy Earth Day. To demonstrate their commitment, environmentalists all across the country risked their lives driving Priuses.
Officials said 12 bombs killed dozens of people in a series of attacks in Baghdad and western Iraq that came days after two top insurgents were killed.

Monologue | Thursday night on "The Late Show With David Letterman" on CBS: You know, a lot of people were flying and got delayed by the Icelandic volcano, and everybody is upset. They lost billions of dollars in revenue. And I said, "O.K., it's kind of their fault. I mean to be flying during the volcano season, come on! Are you nuts? Really? Your own fault."

James Levine's manager, Ronald Wilford, said his client was released from the hospital on Wednesday after lower back surgery and "never looked better." He said the operation had been "enormously successful" and that despite a series of canceled performances recently, Mr. Levine still hoped to conduct at the Tanglewood Festival this summer. "He wants to come back to conducting as quickly as possible, but he doesn't want to screw it up," Mr. Wilford said in a telephone interview. "He's really frustrated."

There's something comforting and delightful about a classic soda fountain. That's what Anton Nocito thinks, and his dream is to open one in New York City. He's starting small with homemade soda.
Images from two exhibitions of King Tut artifacts.
Two articles in the current American Journal of Public Health (links via Marion Nestle's piece here) discuss the potentially constructive role of Big Food in improving global diet.
A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Friday.  Topics include finding the votes for financial regulation, Jon Stewart takes on Fox and Hollywood wants a natural look.

Those of you who stumbled on The Choice soon after its inception last spring may remember Nicholas Geiser. He was a high school senior from San Francisco who wrote for our blog about a perfect batting average: he was accepted to all 12 colleges to which he applied, and ultimately chose Yale over Harvard and a prestigious Morehead-Cain Scholarship at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill.

After the Securities and Exchange Commission accused Stephen J. Czarnik, a securities lawyer, of facilitating an illegal pump-and-dump investment scheme, Mr. Czarnik's lawyer filed a vigorous defense brief in Manhattan federal court two weeks ago.

Esther Duflo, a development economist at M.I.T., has been awarded the John Bates Clark Medal. The award is given to "that American economist under the age of 40 who is judged to have made the most significant contribution to economic thought and knowledge."

Ford introduced its Start Concept urban car Friday morning at the Beijing auto show. With China emerging as the world's hottest and most congested automotive market, Beijing seems an obvious choice for the automaker to show off a vehicle that features its lightweight materials and EcoBoost engine technology.

For years Orli Cotel, a spokeswoman for the Sierra Club and host of the nationally syndicated show "Sierra Club Radio,"  hosted clothing swaps as a way to freshen up her wardrobe for free and recycle clothes among her friends.

Yesterday, in my weekly e-mail column (sign up here: nytimes.com/email), and in this blog, I wrote about the explosion of free WiFi hot spots for home cable-Internet customers. I wrote that I love these developments, but just can't figure out why the cable companies are going to all this expense. Surely, I wrote, this must be a big preemptive move to ward off something.

In 2007, Josh McDaniels was the prepubescent looking offensive coordinator who steered the New England Patriots' offense, the most explosive the N.F.L. had ever seen. The Patriots dragged the spread into the N.F.L. spotlight, a scheme that McDaniels admitted he stole largely from the University of Florida, where his long-time friend Urban Meyer has dominated the college game.
On Saturday, fleas come to Manhattan.

The day after the 40th Earth Day is a good moment to revisit music of this sphere and ponder whether humans should start singing a new tune about forging a more durable relationship with their home planet. I love the music of the 20th-century environmental movement. No song captures the spirit of that era better than Tom Paxton's "Whose Garden Was this?"

Car-sharing companies, which sign up members who pay fees for access to strategically located fleets, are clearly on a roll.
These style-conscious pieces will make you feel pretty on the inside.
President Obama on Friday strongly criticized restrictive immigration legislation pending in Arizona, calling for a federal overhaul of the nation's laws instead.

One of the many complicated questions raised by Abbie Dorn's haunting story yesterday was what rights her parents have under the law. They are the grandparents in this case, asking for visitation on their daughter's behalf. Lawyers for their former son-in-law argued that they had no legal standing, but a judge ruled otherwise.

I have a burning question for those clueless, self-absorbed troglodytes who honk their horns in residential neighborhoods. Why, because the person in front of you doesn't move within a millisecond of a green light, do you feel that slamming your jarring, piercing horn does anything other than upset everyone else in the vicinity - particularly those whose right to the quiet enjoyment of their residential premises is being violated?
A few years ago the satirical newspaper "The Onion'' ran an open letter from a father to son, chiding him for making a mockery out of "Taco Night.''

New York state environmental officials have decided that new regulations governing a controversial method of natural gas drilling will not apply to the state's only two unfiltered water supplies. Instead, far stricter ones will be in force.

With two runners on in the third inning of Thursday afternoon's game between  Milwaukee and Pittsburgh, Pirates pitcher Daniel McCutchen seemed determined to pitch around Brewers slugger Ryan Braun. Unfortunately for McCutchen, no matter how hard you try to pitch around Braun, he just keeps swinging.

Video from Zimbabwe on Thursday showed Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and Robert Mugabe, two presidents who remain in office despite claims from opponents that they engaged in electoral fraud, enter a news conference hand in hand at the start of a state visit by Iranian officials to a country with untapped uranium deposits.

My father recently sent me a New York State Office of Unclaimed Funds claim form in the mail that he had stapled to a partial list of names of people with unclaimed funds in New York. Among the names was mine (just a couple names down from a Susan A. Sarandon).

According to Bloomberg, Lufthansa, Europe's second-biggest airline, has opened a German beer garden at its business class lounge in Munich, the city that holds the annual Oktoberfest, as it seeks to lure full-fare customers.

A new man is moving into Riverdale, the home of comics' perennial teenager Archie Andrews and his gang. His name is Kevin Keller and he's blond-haired, blue-eyed and gay. The property values in the fictional town will be sure to skyrocket. Kevin will be introduced in Veronica No. 202 in a story titled, "Isn't it Bromantic?" The inclusion of the character meets twin goals, one real world and one in-story.

Millions take prescription and over-the-counter medicines to relieve arthritis pain, and all carry a long list of side effects. But how dangerous are these pain relievers? Dr. Neena S. Abraham, a gastroenterologist at the Michael E. DeBakey V.A. Medical Center and associate professor of medicine at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, recently took readers' questions about ulcers, a potentially life-threatening condition increasingly tied to Nsaid pain relievers. Here, Dr. Abraham responds to a reader concerned about pain relievers and bleeding.

In today's Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman explores the steps men and women can take to protect their joints and keep arthritis at bay.

The plot continues to thicken in the most exciting scandal to emerge from Britain's historian community since -- well, ever. Last week, a lawyer for Orlando Figes, an author and history professor at Birkbeck College in London, said Mr. Figes's wife, Stephanie Palmer, a lawyer and lecturer at Cambridge University, was Historian, a pseudonymous commenter on the amazon.co.uk Web site who had been harshly criticizing books by Mr. Figes's rivals while praising her husband's work.

Updated, 4:13 p.m. | The failed Qaeda plan to bomb three New York City subway stations during the morning rush was ordered by two senior Qaeda leaders in Waziristan, who met personally with the admitted plotter Najibullah Zazi and his two co-defendants and urged them to conduct a suicide attack, a federal prosecutor said in court on Friday.
Twice a week, Nocturnalist, our newest City Room feature, goes out at night so you don't have to.

There is roughly a week left in an April promotion offering golfers a free 15-minute club fitting and the opportunity to trade in their old clubs toward new properly fit equipment. The promotion is being sponsored by PGA teaching professionals nationwide.

"An epic of epic epicness" is the tag line for "Scott Pilgrim vs. the World," a live-action film adaptation of the "Scott Pilgrim" comic book series published by Oni Press. The fourth volume of the series lands at No. 4 on the paperback list this week. In it, the slacker title character gets a job and battles another of his girlfriend's exes. Her name is Roxie and she's a ninja. The final volume in the comic book series will be released on July 20, and the film opens in theaters on Aug. 13.
Highlights from today's New York Times:

Champagne flowed at the opening-night party for one of the most highly anticipated Broadway musicals in history. The notices were even better than expected, and everyone knew the show would run forever. Worldwide domination was in the offing -- CDs, DVDs, movies, road companies, the whole megillah. Boffo, baby!

On April 15, the European Environment Agency in Copenhagen convened a two-day workshop on how to move toward a more sustainable transport system on the Continent by 2050. Since flying is by far the most highly emitting form of transportation, the central question was "How would Europe look and function without aviation or with much less aviation than we have now?" as Peder Jensen, the agency's transportation expert and the event's organizer, put it.

Most beauty stories are about the latest makeup trends. For "Surreal Reveal," the makeup artist Peter Philips and the photographer Richard Burbridge took a decidedly reductive, and ultimately seductive, route. Using photographs by Man Ray as a springboard, Philips, who is Chanel's global creative director of makeup, stripped down the idea of a beauty image to its naked core. He didn't even use foundation on the model's skin. "After all, great skin is the ultimate luxury," he says. But bare doesn't mean you don't use any makeup at all, he stresses. "When you pare it down to such an extent, every element you do wear has to be perfect - the perfect lipstick, the perfect eyeliner, the perfect nail polish." For Philips, the new bare lies somewhere between the overdone maquillage of the late '80s and the raw, unkempt look of the early '90s. "I don't think women today feel the need to be so extreme," he says. Working on the shoot, Philips found the contradictions inherent in creating deconstructed beauty images to be both intriguing and modern. "The iconic, formal poses in the photos are a reference to old fashion photography, and are completely at odds with how we played with the pristine, expensive objects in the shots," he says. (It's true that a lot of women might shudder at the idea of drawing on a quilted Chanel bag with eyeliner.) "I love the fact that you can never see the model's eyes," Philips continues. "Makeup can be a mask that a woman hides behind. I compare it to a woman who overaccessorizes or wears over-the-top fashion - the accessories and clothes almost act as armor." Whether a woman decides to get away with a mere swipe of mascara or puts on a full face, Philips supports the idea that less can truly be more: "You can wear the most dramatic red lipstick, but if you wear it with confidence, as if you own it, it will look completely natural."

Officer Pirone, who had been on paid leave since Mr. Grant's death, has never been charged with a crime but has been a focus of community outrage since the shooting. The Wages of Debt | About $100 billion in credit card debt is sold annually in the United States, and debt collectors are increasingly turning to the courts to enforce payment of uncollected debts, which are sold and resold among debt collectors. Critics say the practice clogs the courts and turns corporate lists of debtors into free-fire zones that sometimes target the innocent. In the Bay Area, a loose-knit group of public-interest lawyers pools resources to fight what they see as a misuse of the court system. "We found that these law firms count on a huge percentage of the people that they sue defaulting," or not responding to the legal actions, said Osha Neumann, a lawyer with the East Bay Community Law Center. "That's how the debt buyers make their money."

An article on Thursday about Judge Diane P. Wood, a possible Supreme Court nominee, misidentified the town where she spent her early years. CAIOLA--Benny, beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother and so much to so many, passed away peacefully on Thursday, April 22nd 2010 in New York, NY. He is survived by his wife Bettina Caiola, and his children Benny Caiola III, Luigi Caiola, Alfred Caiola and Rose Caiola. Mr. Caiola was deeply loved by his family and all who knew him. His charismatic and gracious personality made him a giant among men. He leaves behind a legacy which will keep his spirit alive for generations to come. He came to America at the age of 17 from San Fratello, Italy. Mr. Caiola founded B & L Management, LLC, which owns and manages buildings all over Manhattan. He worked his way up from plasterer to general contractor finally building a Real Estate Empire of his own throughout Manhattan. The joy of providing for his family was what drove him. In addition to being well known as a real estate developer and owner Mr. Caiola was known for his wit and his generous and caring ways. His passion included owning the largest and most extensive Ferrari collection in the world. Having worked his way up he never forgot what it was like for the average working person. He was always there to offer advice and assistance in any way possible. Services will be held Saturday, April 24, and Sunday April 25 at the Frank Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue (81st) from 2-4:30 and 7-9pm. He will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved him. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to: The American Cancer Society.

Blagojevich, the indicted former governor of Illinois, want to subpoena President Obama to testify at Mr. Blagojevich's corruption trial, set to start in June. In their motion filed Thursday asking a judge to issue a subpoena, the lawyers argue that President Obama, alone, can provide insight into a central accusation against the former governor - namely, that he tried to get money or a high-paying job in exchange for making an appointment to the United States Senate seat Mr. Obama left when he was elected president.

OAKLAND, Calif. -- Alex Rodriguez had a busy sixth inning Thursday. Before initiating the Yankees' first triple play in 42 years, Rodriguez may or may not have violated a code in the unwritten rules of baseball. Either way, when he wandered across the pitching mound on his way back to first base, Rodriguez infuriated Oakland starter Dallas Braden and ignited a storm of verbal jousting after the Yankees' 4-2 loss to the Athletics at Oakland Coliseum. The play in question occurred with one out, after Rodriguez had lashed a single to left. The next hitter, Robinson Cano, fouled a pitch down the left-field line, and on his way back to first Rodriguez cut across the diamond and the mound, touching the pitching rubber. Braden barked at Rodriguez, telling him to get off the mound.

Sean Forman is the creator of Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues. The Mets' 20-inning game against the St. Louis Cardinals on Saturday, which was decided by Jose Reyes's sacrifice fly in the top of the 20th, was just the latest marathon between the two teams. They played a 25-inning game on Sept. 11, 1974, and two 17-inning games, one in 1976 and another in 1993. Saturday's game tied for the second-longest game in the major leagues since 1993.

President Obama took his rhetoric of reform on Thursday to the nation's financial capital in a high-profile foray to chide Wall Street bankers for their ''reckless practices'' and to press for tighter regulations meant to avert another financial crisis. Addressing leaders of New York's financial giants, including Goldman Sachs, Mr. Obama described himself as a champion of change battling ''battalions of financial industry lobbyists'' and the ''withering forces'' of the economic elite. With his poll numbers sagging, the choreographed confrontation seemed aimed at tapping the nation's antiestablishment mood as well as muscling financial regulation legislation through Congress.

CROWTHER--Paulette Isabel 53, vivacious and devoted mother, sister, daughter, partner and friend, landscape designer and public relations director, passed away at her home in New York on April 5, 2010, in the arms of her loved ones, after a two-year battle with cancer. Born in 1956 to John and Ginette Crowther, Paulette spent her formative years in Montclair, NJ, as the eldest girl and second of seven children. She spent her summers in Westhampton and Rhode Island, where she cultivated her love of nature and passion for the ocean. She graduated from Barnard College in 1978 with a B.A. in English Literature. The artistic and cultural vibrancy of New York City immediately captured her; she lived there the rest of her life. She applied her gifts for language and communication to a career in public relations and graphic design at Rockefeller University, the YWCA and Cardozo Law School. In 1983, Paulette married Carlos Almada, with whom she had three children, Justine, Tristan, and Camille. She nurtured them selflessly, ensuring that they were enriched by fine education, joy and boundless love. They always will be inspired by her kindness, curiosity and lust for life, no matter the circumstance. She enjoyed many wonderful years with her fiance, Bill Wunder, who shared her passions for nature, cooking, music and travel. Her wanderlust led her to many exotic lands, where she indulged her fascination with history, culture and natural beauty. Paulette was diagnosed with advanced cancer in March 2008. Graced with incredible tenacity in the face of extreme adversity, she endured months of arduous treatments while retaining her signature smile, flare and zeal. During the last year of her life, she fulfilled a longtime dream and enrolled in the Master of Science in Landscape Design program at Columbia University. She immersed herself in her projects, often studying into the night, even while working full-time, adhering to a disciplined regimen of exercise, healthful eating and meditation, and never missing a beat as a stellar mother and committed friend. Our lives are and will always be enriched by Paulette's bright light.

Documents released in a lawsuit filed Thursday against Pope Benedict XVI show that the Vatican was informed more than a year earlier than previously thought about the case of a priest who molested deaf boys for two decades at a boarding school in Wisconsin. One victim of the priest wrote two letters to the Vatican's secretary of state in 1995 asking Pope John Paul II himself to read his anguished letters and ''excommunicate'' the priest, the Rev. Lawrence Murphy.

CROWTHER--Paulette. Cardozo Law School mourns the loss of Paulette Crowther, a vibrant member of our community who passed away on April 5. Our hearts go out to her children, Justine, Tristan, and Camille, her mother, Ginette Crowther, her siblings, and her fiance, Bill Wunder. Paulette will be remembered for her dedication, loyalty, kindness, and good humor. Since arriving at the Communications Office in 1995, she helped craft the image and spirit of Cardozo and helped it achieve a high level of recognition and respect in the legal profession and academia. Through her commitment to intellectual rigor, energy, and boundless creativity, she became a beloved and much admired member of the Cardozo family. An inspiration to her colleagues, Paulette will be greatly missed. Kathryn O. Greenberg, Co-Chair, Cardozo Board of Overseers Leslie E. VOS--Frank, 90, died on April 19. Resident of Stamford, Connecticut. Graduated from New Rochelle High School in 1936, attended the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In World War II he served in the U.S. Army as an Infantry First Lieutenant, earning a Bronze Star. In 1951 he married Mary Catherine Dempsey of Philadelphia. A pioneer in the direct marketing industry and one of its most effective innovators, he founded Frank Vos & Co. in 1957, a direct marketing advertising agency in New York City. He sold it in 1986 to The Interpublic Group and enrolled in Columbia University, where he earned a B.A and an M.A. in American History. He was inducted into the Phi Beta Kappa Society. Avid skier and sailboat racer, he was also a licensed pilot for twin engine aircraft and held his instrument rating. Member of The Lotos Club in New York City since 1958. He is survived by his wife Mary Catherine Vos of Stamford, Connecticut, his brother Eugene Vos of Tivoli, New York, his son George Vos of Stamford, his daughter Julie Lindsey of New York City and five grandchildren: Ellis and Mary Lindsey of New York City, and Kate, Julia and Connor Vos of Stamford. Contributions may be made to The Friends of Nathaniel Witherell, Inc., 70 Parsonage Road, Greenwich, CT 06830.

Monologue | Friday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: That volcano in Iceland is still causing problems! Planes are flying again, but thousands of people are stranded. I didn't think it would affect me, but now it has. Last night, I was supposed to go to a concert by my musical hero, Gary Numan, who couldn't get a flight here because of that volcano. Numan is well known in Britain, but only has one hit here. It was "Cars." It was a hit in America. "Here in my car, I feel safest of all." This was before Toyotas.

The Reuters headline on Thursday was alarming: "Weakness rife in US small business loans." The article reported on testimony at a hearing held by the House Small Business Committee. "The U.S. Small Business Administration's inspector general found weakness in more than two-thirds of loans it examined in a program aimed at encouraging construction projects," Reuters reported. "Some $255 million worth of these so-called 504 loans were made to borrowers who might not be eligible or might not be able to repay them."

City Room has always had a soft spot in its heart for Soupy Sales while growing up, even if we never quite got him the way we did, say, "Magic Garden." The puppets, the pies, the Dean-Martin-esque faux(?)-drunk diction -- what was up with that? And what were we youngsters supposed to make of it? Even watching clips now, the main impression we get is that the 1960s were a very long time ago indeed. But Saturday at 6 p.m. on WLIW-TV (Channel 21 on all city cable providers), all will become clear, over the course of "Soupy Sales: The Gang's All Here" a one-hour survey of the man's oeuvre. It will be shown again Sunday at 4:30 p.m.

HESS--Norma W. Closest friend of 50 years. Wise and discerning, elegant and unpretentious, she will live on in my conscience, my fondest memories, my sense of humor and my gratitude for all we shared. KLINEMAN--Robert (Bob) David, died on April 20, 2010 at home in Aspen, CO after a battle with Cancer. Bob was a long time resident of New York City as well as East Hampton, NY and was born in Cleveland, OH on October 19, 1927. He is the son of the late Julia and Emery Klineman. Bob graduated from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania in 1948. He worked for Marshall Field in Chicago before joining the family business, Majestic Specialties, a ladies sportswear company, in New York where he was until the mid 1960's. His work at Majestic was interrupted by a tour with the United States Army where he was stationed in Germany in the early 1950's. After leaving Majestic Specialties, he taught at the Fashion Institute of Technology before moving to Aspen, CO in the mid 1970's where he pursued his love of the American Musical Theatre. Among other pleasures, he created and taught a college accredited course on the subject and was involved in virtually every theater and dance venue in Aspen. He assisted with the formation of the Aspen Community and Institute Committee and participated in the Wheeler Film Series at the Wheeler Opera House where he conducted programs on his most beloved topic "Fred Astaire." Bob made a name for himself by pursuing the Astaire legacy. In the early 1990's, he conducted a weekend presentation on Astaire at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, DC. He is survived by three daughters, Melissa and husband Stephen, Mary Elizabeth, Suzanne and husband William, three grandchildren William Jr., Alexandra and Annie and his son, Robert Jr. Additionally, he is survived by his brother, William and wife Barbara, a niece, Andrea, a nephew, Jeffrey, many cousins and countless friends of all ages whose relationship he cherished. Donations may be made in his memory to the Aspen Music Festival and School, 2 Music School Road, Aspen, CO, 81611, Attn: Kat Berg.

An article on Friday about a lawsuit against Pope Benedict XVI regarding a priest who sexually abused children quoted incorrectly from a comment by Jeffrey Lena, a lawyer for the Holy See. In noting that the case was ''really without merit,'' Mr. Lena said, ''When you're claiming intentional infliction of emotional distress because you got no response to a letter from a private individual to a prime minister, that is going off the deep end.'' He did not say that the letter was to a private individual ''who is like a prime minister.''

HESS--Norma W. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sorrow the passing of Norma W. Hess, beloved mother of John B. Hess and mother-in-law of Whitney Vice Chairman Susan K. Hess. A dedicated and thoughtful philanthropist, Norma was a lover of the arts, both performing and visual, and a devoted supporter of many causes, from education to healthcare and public policy. As President of the Hess Foundation, she was responsible for a remarkable breadth of gifts to City institutions and beyond, quietly bettering the lives of so many. She will be truly missed. Our most heartfelt sympathies go out to John and Susan, her daughter Marlene and husband James, her daughter Constance, and to her many grandchildren, friends, and loved ones. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director

HESS--Norma W. The Rockefeller University deeply mourns the loss of Norma W. Hess, beloved mother of our trustee Marlene Hess and widow of late Rockefeller University Council member Leon Hess. Mrs. Hess's spirit of generosity and volunteerism has left an indelible imprint on New York City. She served on the boards of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, the American Museum of Natural History, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She was also president of the Hess Foundation, which has supported many cultural, scientific, and educational institutions in New York City and beyond. We are deeply grateful that Mrs. Hess and her husband embraced The Rockefeller University, and that the Hess Foundation has created two distinguished professorships on our campus. The Hess family's longstanding involvement at Rockefeller is continued today by Marlene, who is a cherished member of the University community. Mrs. Hess will be greatly missed, and we extend our deepest condolences to Marlene, her sister Connie, her brother John, and their families. Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Paul Nurse, President Titia de Lange, Leon Hess Professor Sohail Tavazoie, Leon Hess Assistant Professor

EVERY architectural style falls out of fashion -- Art Deco was dated by the 1950s, mid-century Modernism looked shabby by the 1980s -- but after spending a generation in exile, it's usually welcomed back. Twenty years ago a weekend house by Richard Neutra might have been dismissed as too expensive to heat; now it's almost as sacred as a Palladian villa. A similar reconsideration is under way for Brutalism, that brawny mix of concrete walls and soaring cantilevers that first appeared in postwar Europe.

FEDER--Judith D. Beautiful and beloved wife of her devoted husband, Tapani Talo, adoring mother of Eliel and Eero, cherished daughter of Bob and Marge, loving sister to Susan, Ben, Jessica and Abigail, doting aunt of Sam, Basia, Brent, Danya, Seth, Zachariah and the late Maximillian, wonderful friend. Judy was a brilliant scholar (summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa, Princeton '78), talented singer and musician, linguist, and valued manager of the New York office of Brodeur International. Initially diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer in 2001, she fought an unceasing battle (never in remission), unwilling to cede an iota to the disease. Her own long struggle and experiences led her to conceive Patient Wisdom, a forthcoming product for the next generation of online patient communities. Her meditations on simple joys over the past nine years inspired all who knew her. Funeral Sunday 1pm. Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, 295 Soundview Ave, White Plains. Contributions may be made to the Princeton University Class of 1978 Foundation, 102 Tanglewood Lane, Newtown Square, PA 19073.

Americans are justifiably proud of having given the world a model for the architecture of democratic self-government. Democracies old and new have emulated the separation of powers and the idea of a constitutional court with the authority to review and invalidate actions of the other branches. But it is both instructive and humbling to dig a little deeper into how other countries' constitutional courts actually work -- instructive because the surface similarities obscure meaningful differences, and humbling because it just might be that the best of all possible worlds is not to be found in Washington.
I would like the firing squad, please. RONNIE LEE GARDNER, a condemned murderer in Utah, picking his method of execution. [A8]

HESS--Norma. The Trustees and the entire community of the American Museum of Natural History are deeply saddened by the death of our beloved Trustee Norma W. Hess. Serving on the Board since 2000, Norma was a devoted champion of the Museum's work in science and education. Quickly recognizing the importance of the Museum's new Richard Gilder Graduate School, and immensely proud of the Museum being the first museum in the country to grant Ph.D.s, she became one of its earliest and most generous supporters. She established the Hess Graduate Fellowships in Comparative Biology to enable the most promising doctoral students to attend. With wide-ranging interests, she was generous of time and support to so many institutions in our community. At the Museum, we will remember her fondly as a bright, insightful, committed woman who blended keen intellect, engagement, and conviction with a quick wit and a fun-loving nature. With her signature grace and integrity, she was a wonderful colleague, and we will miss her terribly. Our heartfelt sympathies go to her children, Connie, Marlene, and John, and the entire Hess family. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President

ANGELE--Homer, 96, died peacefully in his sleep on April 17, 2010 in Limassol, Cyprus. Born in Leonarrisso, Cyprus on May 13, 1913, he emigrated to England in 1939, where he met Fanny Alexandra Myefsky during the Blitz. Homer and Fanny married, and after the second world war he opened Homer Models, a couture and bespoke establishment in London. He continued working as a Savile Row tailor until his retirement in 1976. Fanny died in 1990. Homer is survived by his second wife Demetra, his only child Alan Peter Angele, his daughter-in-law Susan Meryl Angele, his grandchildren Elizabeth Colette Angele and Caroline Ming Angele and numerous nieces and nephews. Homer was a person of compassion, sensitivity, generosity, elegance and strength, and he will remain in our hearts forever.

MORGAN--Julia Harmon. Beloved mother to Jeffrey, Catherine, Leslie, Tim and Perri. Sister, aunt, grandmother, teacher, friend. Avid tennis player in Naples FL, Washington, DC and Bristol, NH. Radcliffe '56. We will all miss her terribly.

WAITE--Liane Fenelon, 86, died April 4, 2010 of cancer. Born in Yonkers to Earl and Mary Blanchard Fenelon, raised in Pittsburgh and for years a resident of Bronxville, she had a colorful career. Receiving her BS at Syracuse University in Food Science in 1945, she started work in the test kitchens of General Foods in New York City. There, she developed special flours for cakes, pies and breads. She then became food editor at the Ladies Home Journal, overseeing the publication of the Ladies Home Journal Cookbook in 1963, edited by Carol Truax, In which 75 years of the Journal's food recipes were brought up to date. Ahead of her time as a woman professional, from 1968 until she retired she held a senior management position in the Diamond International Corporation as Communications/Government Relations Specialist (i.e., Lobbyist). Upon her death she was serving as Board Vice-President of her Rockledge Manor Condominium. Her hobbies and interests included ham radio, baseball, opera (attending Wagner festivals throughout the world), needlework, collecting art of the Southwest, and hosting elegant dinner parties. Later, in defiance of her advancing years she became skilled in using the computer for email, creating her own holiday cards, and surfing the web. In personality she was tart, crisp but fun. She cared deeply for many friends from all walks of life. How can one NOT miss such a person dearly?! She is survived by several Fenelons (a nephew Curt and wife Betty, two nieces Christine and Carol, and a grandnephew Will) and her long-time companion, Edgar (Ted) Coons, a professor at NYU.

(HBO) YOU DON'T KNOW JACK: THE LIFE AND DEATHS OF JACK KEVORKIAN (2010) Al Pacino, left, dons a shock of puffy white hair and oversize glasses to play Dr. Kevorkian, the Michigan pathologist and right-to-die advocate sometimes known as Dr. Death. Susan Sarandon is Janet Good, a local Hemlock Society leader in whom he finds a kindred spirit; Brenda Vaccaro is his sister Margo; and John Goodman is his friend and helper Neal Nicol. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley called this Barry Levinson film about euthanasia ''a compelling, at times thrilling, tale that can absorb even those with little interest or feeling for the subject.'' She added, ''This is one of the saddest, dreariest subjects imaginable, but 'You Don't Know Jack' is anything but.'' 10:30 A.M. Kim Lawton looks at the impact of the earthquake in Haiti on the church, clinic and school that were established by her missionary grandparents. And Bob Faw visits with Muslim parents who home school.

HESS--Norma W. Our entire Lenox Hill Hospital family profoundly mourns the death of Norma Hess, beloved mother of our esteemed Trustee Marlene Hess. Norma's keen intelligence, sharp wit, and panache will long be remembered. Norma and her devoted husband Leon were extraordinary benefactors, vital champions and special friends of Lenox Hill Hospital for many decades. Their support of numerous Lenox Hill Hospital programs, particularly in cardiac care and orthopedic surgery, has left an enduring legacy that has impacted the lives of countless individuals. We celebrate the life and honor the memory of Norma Hess, an exceptional woman, and extend our deepest sympathies to Marlene, John, Connie, and to her entire family. William O. Hiltz, Chairman, Board of Trustees Gladys George, President and Chief Executive Officer

HESS--Norma W. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. deeply mourn the passing of Norma W. Hess, long-time supporter and member of the Board of Directors of Lincoln Center, and beloved member of our Directors Emeriti Council. She was a dedicated member of the Nominating and Governance Committee and valued member of the Lincoln Center Institute Board. Her elegance and wisdom will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to our Board member, her son, John B., her daughters Constance and Marlene, and their families and friends. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman Reynold Levy, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc.

The N.F.L.'s decision to move the draft from Saturday afternoon to Thursday evening paid off with an average of 7.3 million viewers, making it the sixth-most-watched program of the night. It beat every program on NBC's lineup, including two episodes of ''30 Rock'' and ''The Office,'' Fox's ''Fringe,'' and ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy'' and ''FlashForward.'' But the CBS lineup - ''The Mentalist,'' with 14.9 million viewers, ''CSI,'' with 13.4 million, and ''Survivor,'' with 11.9 million - overwhelmed the draft.

When a family friend recently made her first hole in one, she mentioned how she had hole-in-one insurance. For what exactly? Tradition calls for the ace golfer to treat everyone at the club to a round of drinks after the shot. Her insurance, however, didn't cover her because the shot didn't happen at her own golf club. Because I had never heard of such hole-in-one insurance before (I'm obviously not an avid golfer), I set out to research what kind of insurance policy it was exactly (or if it was truly insurance at all) and if it's something people might actually want.

An article on Friday about the Yankees' 4-2 loss on Thursday to the Oakland Athletics, which featured a triple play by the Yankees, described the team's previous such play, in 1968, incorrectly. John Roseboro of the Minnesota Twins lined into it; he did not ground into it.

PITTARI--Lydia Valle, was born on August 14, 1912 and passed away April 6, 2010. Lydia was born to Frank and Angela Valle in New York City. She grew up in the City with her brother Mario and after she graduated high school she studied opera and performed in many operas at "The Met" and in radio musicals. Lydia and her family traveled frequently to Italy and on one the trips she met and fell in love with an Italian Pediatrician, Giuseppe (Joe) Pittari. Lydia and Joe were married in Italy and lived in Milan throughout the War. After World War II, Lydia and Joe frequently traveled to the United States. In 1979 Joe passed away and after burying him in his native Sicily, Lydia returned permanently to the United States. She resided in Miami in the Marjorca Towers and then moved to the Palace of Kendall where she resided until the time of her death. The family would like to thank the owners and staff of The Palace for making Lydia's final journey extremely comfortable and care free. The family would also like to especially thank her primary care giver, Nivian Rodriguez, for her timeless hours and efforts to maintain Lydia's lifestyle and comfort level to maximum degree. Lydia leaves countless friends and children of friends in New York City and Miami. She is survived by her loving family, nephew Larry (Carole) Valle, Chris (Debbie) Valle, Stacia (Christopher) Cannon and Bryce and Vincent Valle. The family will celebrate Lydia's full life in a private memorial and requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the charity of your choice.

MONDAY'S PUZZLE - Are you a crossword fan or, more generally, a puzzle aficionado? The former probably knows or at least might be pleased to learn that the word "aficionado" implies not just a devotee, but an enthusiastic amateur. The latter might then view that as the start of a logic puzzle. Will Shortz can't be an aficionado because he's a professional, therefore the man in the blue house must smoke Lucky Strikes, or however that old syllogism goes. We're going to do something a little risky, perhaps, by expanding the scope of Wordplay just a little. More on that further down.

At first glance, Vincent Olinet's mixed-media sculptures of pretty, frilly things like pastel layer cakes, four-poster fairy beds and glossy lipsticks are seductive, but upon closer inspection they reveal a subversive side. The cakes have collapsed in a gooey mess on their plates, the beds have been left outside to rot in the rain, and the lipsticks have rough edges and are sloppily varnished. ''I like to make shiny, colorful art pieces that appeal to our dreams and urges but actually deal with decay or disillusion,'' says the Brussels-based Olinet. Apply with caution. An exhibit of his work is at Galerie Laurent Godin in Paris through May 15. Go to laurentgodin.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE (PHOTOGRAPHS BY GALERIE LAURENT GODIN, PARIS)

AS they came and went -- major dignitaries and minor deities, old friends and pint-size new ones, people who left too soon and people who showed up unannounced -- Mark Twain recorded it all in a handsome brown guest book. Together, these turn-of-the-century tweets provide vivid snapshots of the final two years of a great writer's life, 1908 to 1910, a time when Twain traded in his Manhattan town house for a Connecticut estate he called Stormfield.

KAREN O: ''I'm really attached to my battle paint. It's my buffer,'' said Karen O of her Russian Red lips and graphically painted eyes, which, along with her mussy bowl cut, define her stage look as the electrifying singer of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs. ''I'm definitely going for something that people in the back row can see.'' Now 31, she's redefining her beauty ideal, shifting into being ''more of a woman than a 20-something rock chick.'' Her current style icons? Her mother (whose Jean Paul Gaultier top she's wearing here) and Anjelica Huston, circa Jack Nicholson. Top, her own. Céline pants, $1,200. At Kirna Zabête. Go to kirnazabete.com. LÉA SEYDOUX : Her grandfather runs the film-production-and-distribution giant Pathé and her great-uncle the film company Gaumont, but the cherubic 24-year-old has found her place on the other side of the camera. Sweetly soft-spoken, she earned a nomination for most promising actress at last year's César awards. Next, in Ridley Scott's ''Robin Hood,'' she's a French princess who becomes the queen of England. Seydoux marvels at the ''clean perfection'' of American actresses. But even after appearing in such Yankee campaigns as Levi's and American Apparel, her own rumpled, fresh-faced style is ''not very polished'' in comparison, she said, adding, ''Sometimes it makes me shy.'' Crewcuts sweater, $125. Go to jcrew.com.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, April 10th 2010, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. HESS--Norma W. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sorrow the passing of Norma W. Hess, beloved mother of John B. Hess and mother-in-law of Whitney Vice Chairman Susan K. Hess. A dedicated and thoughtful philanthropist, Norma was a lover of the arts, both performing and visual, and a devoted supporter of many causes, from education to healthcare and public policy. As President of the Hess Foundation, she was responsible for a remarkable breadth of gifts to City institutions and beyond, quietly bettering the lives of so many. She will be truly missed. Our most heartfelt sympathies go out to John and Susan, her daughter Marlene and husband James, her daughter Constance, and to her many grandchildren, friends, and loved ones. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director

Among the clognoscenti, a visit with the Portland, Ore.-based Clogmaster, a k a Cecilia Tidlund, is the stuff of legend. Not only can you custom-design clogs from candy-colored, patent and metallic leathers, you'll also receive a custom fitting -- maybe even a customized dressing-down about your appalling footwear habits. (Silly me, I wore flip-flops.) Tidlund, a native of Sweden and the founder, in 1976, of one of America's first bespoke clog companies, is an orthopedic-wellness militant à la the Soup Nazi. Which is why, when I phoned Tidlund to solicit her (withering, I was certain) take on one of spring's big trends -- the befeathered, begrommeted, open-toed, high-heeled clog (see Miu Miu, below left; Louis Vuitton, below right; and Chanel) -- I was surprised that she wasn't entirely negative. First she reminded me that ''we've seen them before.'' Then she added, ''I'd rather people get into a bad fashion clog than a ballet flat or flip-flop. Flimsy shoes are ruining people's feet. I've seen 12-year-olds with bunions.' HEIDI JULAVITS

9 P.M. (TV Land) THE 8TH ANNUAL TV LAND AWARDS Tom Hanks will hark back to his roots as just another struggling actor -- albeit one with a rather unusual work wardrobe -- when he reunites with Peter Scolari, above right with Mr. Hanks, to accept the Anniversary Award 30 years after the debut of their drag comedy, ''Bosom Buddies.'' Billy Crystal, Jane Leeves, Jay Leno, Wendie Malick, Bob Newhart and Betty White will bestow honors to some other blasts from the past, including giving the Impact Award to the cast of ''Everybody Loves Raymond''; the Fan Favorite Award to the crew of ''The Love Boat''; and the Legend Award to both Mel Brooks and Carl Reiner. Cheryl Ladd and Jaclyn Smith of ''Charlie's Angels'' will pay tribute to Farrah Fawcett, who died in June 2009. And Jane Lynch will accept the Future Classic Award on behalf of ''Glee.'' There is even a rendition of Journey's ''Don't Stop Believin' '' by a group of older choristers, including Shirley Jones and Marion Ross, with solos by David Hasselhoff and Marilu Henner. Tim Allen hosts. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Chris Wallace speaks with Alan K. Simpson, the retired Republican senator from Wyoming, and Erskine B. Bowles, former chief of staff in the Clinton White House, who serve as chairmen of the National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform, President Obama's bipartisan effort to reduce the federal debt.

The pastel spring coat disappeared decades ago, replaced by variations of the between-season trench coat. New this year: trenches with dressmaking details at the shoulder or whimsical sleeveless designs. The most curious was a trench-coat top and sleeves attached to what appeared to be the coat's exposed lining. When it actually rains, some people unfurl doorman-size umbrellas, a strange trend in a crowded city. Perhaps New York could solve its budget woes by putting a surtax on the carriers, whose gear takes up the room of nearly three normal umbrellas on the sidewalks.

A First-Time Trip to Brazil A group of us (four to six) want to visit Brazil as first-time travelers. We do not want to go to Carnaval or do a nature trip; we want highlights of the life, culture and art of this amazing country. Where do we start? We're thinking that August or September might be a good time to go.

The Mortgages column last Sunday, about the prospects for homeowners whose debt exceeds the value of their homes, misspelled the name of an executive vice president of the Loan Value Group in Rumson, N.J., which is working with banks to help borrowers recover more quickly. He is Frank Pallotta, not Pollotta.

MOTORCYCLE deaths in the United States fell steeply last year, according to a new study. After 11 straight years of increases, motorcycle traffic fatalities are projected to decline by at least 10 percent nationally in 2009, the Governors Highway Safety Association announced in a report released on Thursday.

C. K. Prahalad, a management professor and author who popularized the idea that companies could make money while helping to alleviate poverty, died Friday in the La Jolla neighborhood of San Diego. He was 68 and lived in San Diego. The cause was an undiagnosed lung illness, his family said.

HESS--Norma. The Trustees and the entire community of the American Museum of Natural History are deeply saddened by the death of our beloved Trustee Norma W. Hess. Serving on the Board since 2000, Norma was a devoted champion of the Museum's work in science and education. Quickly recognizing the importance of the Museum's new Richard Gilder Graduate School, and immensely proud of the Museum being the first museum in the country to grant Ph.D.s, she became one of its earliest and most generous supporters. She established the Hess Graduate Fellowships in Comparative Biology to enable the most promising doctoral students to attend. With wide-ranging interests, she was generous of time and support to so many institutions in our community. At the Museum, we will remember her fondly as a bright, insightful, committed woman who blended keen intellect, engagement, and conviction with a quick wit and a fun-loving nature. With her signature grace and integrity, she was a wonderful colleague, and we will miss her terribly. Our heartfelt sympathies go to her children, Connie, Marlene, and John, and the entire Hess family. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President

I HAVE a burning question for those clueless, self-absorbed troglodytes who honk their horns in residential neighborhoods. Why, because the person in front of you doesn't move within a millisecond of a green light, do you feel that slamming your jarring, piercing horn does anything other than upset everyone else in the vicinity -- particularly those whose right to the quiet enjoyment of their residential premises is being violated? Last fall, yet another study reported that traffic noise is a health hazard, causing stress and hypertension in people who live near it. A honking horn is not just a noise ordinance violation; it's a direct assault on the health of those exposed to it.

1 One of a handful of hairstylists known simply by their first names, Guido (Palau) is the coiffeur of choice for fashion-industry titans like Miuccia, Marc, Donatella, Donna and Alber. His calling card: versatility. He can do cool-girl tangles, edgy up-dos or pretty and polished with a flick of his wrists. ''The runway is for testing new ground,'' he says. ''When I do the shows, I strive for a mixture of wearability, humor, fantasy and amazement.'' 2 Like a lot of style-world heavies, he's inspired by the work of the painter John Currin. ''There's something about his art that touches me,'' he says. ''It's not always about making things tasteful. Good taste is boring. It's the things that provoke that excite me.'' Go to gagosian.com. 3 The fashion landscape may shift, but the British-born Palau stays grounded in Prada's black lace-ups. They're $595 at select Prada boutiques. 4 The look he created for Alexander Wang's spring show was inspired by the young Brooke Shields. ''She was the quintessential sporty American girl of the late '80s and early '90s,'' he says. ''There was a wholesomeness to her appearance -- the thick eyebrows, the full, luscious hair. The semi-quiff in the front of her hair was key: it epitomized a certain kind of girl.'' 5 Palau is also the creative consultant for Redken. During the shows, a can of Redken Forceful 23 Super Strength Finishing Spray ($15) is practically an extension of his arm. ''It's not the lightest of sprays,'' he says. ''But it will lock into place even the most extreme styles.'' For at-home use, he recommends spraying some into your hand and then applying it to your hair. Go to redken.com for salons. 6 The stylist sends models like Karen Elson, Agyness Deyn and Raquel Zimmermann to the ''superstar'' colorist Laurie Foley's East Village salon, L'Atelier de Laurie. ''She has a gift for achieving different weights of color,'' he says. ''After all, there is a big difference between a surfer blonde and an Upper East Side blonde.'' Go to latelier delaurie.com. 7 Palau can't live without a Mason Pearson brush and a good tail comb, like this Y. S. Park Pro Series half-moon version, which is $14 at Ray Beauty Supply. Go to raybeauty.com. 8 He chills out to beats by bands like Marina and the Diamonds, Florence and the Machine, and Vampire Weekend, whose new album (above) made its debut atop the charts. Go to vampire weekend.com. 9 Palau likes to fiddle with volume. For a nonchalant, disheveled look, he dampens hair and applies Redken Aerate 08 Bodifying Cream-Mousse ($16) to the sections where he wants a bit of lift. Then he ''rough-dries'' it, ruffling his fingers through the hair as he hits it with a dryer. ''You get natural texture and movement, which is less labored-looking and more modern,'' he says. 10 For models with overworked hair, he recommends a six-month course of Viviscal, a hair-growth product that contains vitamins and marine protein. ''I've known loads of people who have used it, and they've all said it's the only thing that helped regenerate their hair.'' A 30-day supply is $50 at viviscal.com. 11 Whenever he's in Milan, the stylist browses the bookstore at 10 Corso Como. ''I have a voracious appetite for photography and art books,'' he says. ''I absorb and memorize the images in them, and they come out a few seasons -- or even years -- later as hairdos.'' Go to 10corsocomo.com. 12 The less your locks are exposed to heat, the better, so the hairdresser's dryer du jour is the powerful (and fast) Sultra Sophisticate, which is $280 at sephora.com. 13 Even superstylists need a bit of a boost sometimes. According to Palau, Redken's Rootful 06 Root Lifting Spray ($15) helps make hair big but leaves it soft and brushable.

On a March morning at Coon Rock Farm -- 55 acres of just about everything you can grow and raise -- in Hillsborough, N.C., Jamie DeMent is showing me a fallen tree that's being milled into tabletops for the farm's biggest project to date: Eno Restaurant and Market. Who knew the farm-to-table loop would become so compressed or so literal? But it was only a matter of time before the farmers' market evolved into the farmers' restaurant.

In Beverly Hills he is referred to simply as Patrick -- a single name that in certain circles can make your eyelashes curl (in a good way). Patrick Foley, you see, is a personal shopper who is thriving at a time when many in the retail business are struggling to stay afloat. Maybe that's because he's on the ground floor of Barneys in Beverly Hills selling a $30 lipstick, rather than on the fourth floor pushing a $5,000 suit. ''People don't feel guilty splurging on makeup,'' says the 42-year-old personal shopper, whose title is resident makeup artist. Beauty enthusiasts see Foley as a guru, and suppliers are well aware of the influence he wields -- so much so that cosmetics companies scramble to get him new products at least a month before they hit the other stores. But like his clients, he is a tough sell, and since he doesn't work for any label, he can cherry-pick from established lines and any number of indie brands. His office/makeup studio (conveniently located near women's shoes) is a Hollywood hot spot. But instead of sitting in the middle of a department store, clients are ushered into his stark white studio, with Carrara marble countertops, professional lighting and complete privacy. ''Especially in Beverly Hills,'' Foley says, ''you don't want to see people with half their face on!'' SUSAN CAMPOS

Giants defensive tackle Chris Canty is entering the second of a six-year, $42 million contract that includes $17.25 million guaranteed. Like many professional athletes, he is in an enviable financial position at age 27. Fred Gibson was drafted one pick ahead of Canty toward the end of the fourth round in the 2005 N.F.L. draft. At 28, he is out of football and working toward completing his undergraduate degree at the University of Georgia. Gibson played on the practice squads of three teams, including the Giants, but never saw action in an N.F.L. game.
