MARTIN--Michael Townsend, 68, of New York, NY and Longboat Key, FL died April 17, 2010 at home in New York City surrounded by family, after a courageous three year battle with cancer. He was born on November 21, 1941 in New York City to Townsend B. Martin, a founding owner of the New York Jets, and Georgia Shanton who passed away when he was five years old. His stepmother was Irene R. Martin. Michael was the great-grandson of Henry Phipps, a business partner of Andrew Carnegie. The Phipps' family business continues today as Bessemer Trust. He attended Rumson Country Day, Choate, and Rutgers. After serving in the US Navy, Michael became the Assistant General Manager of the NY Jets. While there, the Jets won the Super Bowl in 1969. In 1974, he was named Vice President and Director of Football Operations of the World Football League. At age 34, Michael became the youngest general manager in professional sports when appointed Vice President and general manager of the NY Cosmos of the North American Soccer League. Under his leadership, the Cosmos won NASL crowns in 1977 and 1980. He was a consultant to international sports marketing companies and founded his own business, SportsMark Inc. in 1990. Owner of Michael T. Martin Racing Stable, Michael served on the board of the NY Thoroughbred Horsemen's Association (President, 1994-1997). Michael devoted time and resources to numerous non-profit organizations including Mote Marine Laboratory, The Ringling College of Art and Design, Lemur Conservation Foundation, The Marine Biological Laboratory/Woods Hole, PBS, Phipps Houses, Old Westbury Gardens, The Big Apple Circus, Very Special Arts, NY Special Olympics, Morris Animal Foundation, National Lighthouse Museum, and Juilliard, Choate, and Pennington schools. Michael is survived by Jean Meyer, his wife of thirty years; brother, Alan of Lawrence, KS; son, Ryan and daughter-in-law Maureen, of Butler, PA; son, Christopher of Aurora, IL; stepdaughter, Kathleen Hunt and son-in-law Peter of Chattanooga, TN. Michael, his first wife, Jennifer Johnston Theobald, and Jean were childhood friends. Michael had seven grandchildren, Brandon and Caitlyn Martin, Justin and Margaret Martin, and Mac, Will, and Jack Hunt. The memorial service will be held at St. Bart's Episcopal Church, New York City on Saturday, May 22 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Mote Marine Laboratory, 1600 Ken Thompson Parkway, Sarasota, FL 34236, Ringling College of Art and Design, 2700 No. Tamiami Trail, Sarasota, FL 34234, and Lemur Conservation Foundation, Myakka City Lemur Reserve, P.O. A map with the ''Living In'' article last Sunday, about Branchburg, N.J., labeled an Interstate highway in the area incorrectly. It is I-287, not I-278.

AN ''affordable'' Maserati? A new Enzo supercar? Those were just two surprises that emerged last week from a conference call in which Fiat laid out its five-year plan. Sergio Marchionne, chief executive of Fiat and Chrysler, spoke after the Fiat Group issued its quarterly report, detailing an elaborate plan in which Fiat and Chrysler will combine to produce six million vehicles annually by 2014 -- a figure he said was crucial in keeping the company solvent.
Television Mike Hale
Film Neil Genzlinger

RIO DE JANEIRO -- A former Nazi-era German soldier who founded a secretive German cult in southern Chile, where he sexually abused about 25 children, died of heart failure at a prison hospital early Saturday, Chilean officials said. He was 89. The former soldier, Paul Schaefer, was serving a 20-year sentence for the sexual abuse of minors, but he was also under investigation for the 1985 disappearance of Boris Weisfeiler, an American citizen who vanished while on a hiking trip.

HESS--Norma. The officers, trustees and members of Ocean Beach Club mourn the passing of their friend and member and send heartfelt condolences to her children Connie, Marlene and John and their families. Jack Lehman, President Jennifer Marrus, Secretary

SILVERMAN--Mike, Realtor, (ninety years old), of Malibu, California and Bellingham, Washington died at his home in Bellingham Saturday, April 17, 2010. At his side was his wife, Davey Davison. He is also survived by nieces, Marcia and Norman Silverman, nephews, Peter and Michael Silverman, and cousins Jack Silverman and Steve Hollander of New York. Services will be private.

ANJELICA HUSTON: The actress Anjelica Huston, who reveals her recherché pick in perfumes on Page 58, has many beauty icons. ''Sophia Loren, Ava Gardner, Audrey Hepburn (far right), Katharine Hepburn . . . all dead people!'' she said. (Albeit ones with ''long necks and doe eyes.'') ''The eldest Obama daughter is developing nicely,'' she added before ticking off another batch. A beauty icon herself -- ''I think it's a great mistake!'' -- Huston feels most attractive when she's told she's lovely by ''people who are more intelligent, more beautiful than oneself.'' She is currently filming in Vancouver, British Columbia, with Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Seth Rogen, Bryce Dallas Howard and Anna Kendrick. What beauty advice does Huston wish she'd been given at their age? ''Enjoy life,'' she said. ''Confidence is primary.'' RICHARD BURBRIDGE: During the photo shoot for ''Surreal Reveal'' (Page 46), the lensman Richard Burbridge fretted over his makeup artist, Peter Philips. ''He had gone three straight days with only four hours' sleep, coming from Chanel, Alexander McQueen and a bunch of photo shoots without stopping,'' Burbridge says. But Philips pulled through, and Burbridge showcased the proof: a foundation-free, Man Ray-inspired exploration of minimalism in makeup (with Chanel bags!). Burbridge specializes in lending drama to beauty-centric spreads, and he frequently contributes to Italian Vogue, Allure and V magazines. A New Yorker for the past 10 years, the British-born Burbridge was last spotted in Marrakesh, Morocco, on a family vacation. Imagine the photo albums.

WINNING isn't everything. At least, that's what we tell the losers. But to the victors go the spoils. For the winner of this June's Le Mans 24-hour auto race, the prize is a Jeff Koons Art Car, the 17th in a series that BMW began in 1975 with a custom paint job by Alexander Calder. The BMW M3 GT2, which can go from zero to 100 miles an hour in three seconds, will be raced by a team of drivers. Mr. Koons, whose concept is shown above, will give the car an added boost with a finish expressing what he called ''the aesthetics of winning.'' Who knew that winning had an actual look? His inspiration: the lights on a Christmas wreath he saw in passing. (The car's interior will have a silver lining.) Mr. Koons will direct a team of BMW painters and add his signature on June 1 at the Pompidou Center in Paris, where the car will be on display for 24 hours before heading to Le Mans. LINDA YABLONSKY

ON THE MALECÓN, HAVANA, MARCH 15, 2010 Jack Lin (standing, in pink shirt), a 27-year-old financial engineering student from Taiwan studying at New York University. ''To see is to believe. Cuba is a mystery for us, so we were very curious as to what people look like, how everything works. We stayed at this kind of homestay, ate what they eat and used what they use. For them, beef is a luxury food. It's very different from any country I'd been to. Especially the cars. One night there was a thundershower, so we just grabbed a car and got in and there were no windows. And I thought, wow, a car with no windows, it's very funny. My friend said he would never think this kind of car would be driving on the road. I loved the coastlines, like the Malecón. Lots of people were on the embankments, just lying there for the sunset. They have nothing to lose, they have nothing to win, they just are lying there to enjoy the breeze and laughing. I recommend people go to Cuba if they are trying to see different lifestyles, or even different cars. But if you are trying to see a fancy city or fancy buildings, then maybe save your money. Go to Vegas.''

Most beauty stories are about the latest makeup trends. For ''Surreal Reveal,'' the makeup artist Peter Philips and the photographer Richard Burbridge took a decidedly reductive, and ultimately seductive, route. Using photographs by Man Ray as a springboard, Philips, who is Chanel's global creative director of makeup, stripped down the idea of a beauty image to its naked core. He didn't even use foundation on the model's skin. ''After all, great skin is the ultimate luxury,'' he says But bare doesn't mean you don't use any makeup at all, he stresses. ''When you pare it down to such an extent, every element you do wear has to be perfect -- the perfect lipstick, the perfect eyeliner, the perfect nail polish.'' For Philips, the new bare lies somewhere between the overdone maquillage of the late '80s and the raw, unkempt look of the early '90s. ''I don't think women today feel the need to be so extreme,'' he says. Working on the shoot, Philips found the contradictions inherent in creating deconstructed beauty images

LANGBAUM--Francesca Levi Vidale, 88, died in Charlottesville, VA on April 11, 2010, surrounded by loving family--her husband of 60 years Robert Langbaum, daughter Emily, son-in-law Marcelo Rubin, grandchildren Jessica, Nora, Peter. Born in Bologna, Italy, a graduate of Wellesley and Cornell, she edited a Random House French dictionary and taught Latin at The Masters School, French at Cornell, Italian at University of Virginia. She inspired all with her intellect, charm and courage.

The narcissistic preoccupation with pet exploitation in the name of art is abhorrent. The poor creatures, beautiful in their own right, are subject to the impoverished imaginations of their owners. Ron Brady

Hair powder was so common in late-18th-century England that a parliamentary tax was placed on it. Are you listening, Congress? This spring sees the debut of iterations by Oribe, Kevin.Murphy, Alterna, Umberto Beverly Hills and Tresemmé. While some are branded as dry shampoo and others as hair powder, all provide matte texture and body. And you'll need them well past the lank days of summer: backstage at the fall 2010 shows, hair powder was no longer a secret oil-absorbing weapon but rather a key component of the look, especially the season's two most prominent trends, naturally undone and ''Mad Men''-inspired glamour. ''I like hairstyles that look like there's no product in the hair,'' says Orlando Pita, who flanks his dry shampoo with a dry conditioner. ''Shine products have run their course.'' HOLLY SIEGEL

IN 1908, the International Tract Society put out a slim exercise manual that promised men not hardened abs but ''a graceful carriage.'' Recently reprinted as ''Exercises for Gentleman'' (Universe, $14.95), the manual had a section titled ''50 Exercises to Do With Your Suit On.'' These century-old calisthenics fell into three categories: the curious (''Explosive Breathing''), the laughably low-impact (''Standing'') and the even more laughably low-impact (''Sitting''). We're all for that, but we've updated the uniforms (think slim). STEPHEN HEYMAN LEFT Marni jacket, $1,062, and pants, $486; at Marni, 159 Mercer Street; (212) 343-3912. Patrik Ervell shirt, $220; at Bblessing, 181 Orchard Street; (212) 378-8005. J. Crew tie, $60; jcrew.com. Florsheim by Duckie Brown shoes, $395; barneys.com. Moscot glasses (worn throughout), $179; moscot.com.

Alex Rodriguez may have breached an unwritten rule of baseball etiquette last week when, after making it to third base on a foul ball hit by a teammate, he wandered across the pitcher's mound on his way back to first. Dallas Braden, the pitcher for the Oakland Athletics, was not happy. ''I don't go over there and run laps at third base. I don't spit over there. I stay away. You guys ever see anybody run across the mound like that? He ran across the pitcher's mound. Foot on my rubber.'' -- BRADEN

Wayne Gretzky, the N.H.L.'s career leader in goals (894) and points (2,857), met his match in Viktor Ghamari of Sweden in a shootout on April 14. They were playing N.H.L. 10, part of the EA Sports Champions of Gaming Finals, staged by Gillette in Manhattan. (Ghamari was chosen from more than 350,000 online entrants to compete against a celebrity.) Gretzky, 49, won four Stanley Cup championships with the Edmonton Oilers in the 1980s. Then he played for three other teams, retiring as a Ranger in 1999. He coached the Phoenix Coyotes for four seasons before stepping down in September. The Coyotes play Game 6 of their first-round playoff series against Detroit on Sunday.

THE NEWS The five biggest banking companies in the United States reported a total of $17 billion in profits for the first quarter of 2010, by far their best showing ever. BEHIND THE NEWS Much of the gain came from proprietary trading, the risky business that got the big banks in trouble to begin with, and which they would have to spin off under President Obama's proposed regulatory overhaul. News of the profits was overshadowed by the government's charges that Goldman Sachs created securities that were secretly designed to fail, so that a favored customer could bet against them.

IT was a busy day. In the morning, I'd followed a creek as far upstream as I could, until it disappeared underground. At midday, I'd stopped in town for a slice of pepperoni pizza. And in the afternoon, I'd explored a chain-link-fence maze at the edge of a university. Now, with dinnertime approaching, I was pedaling home on the trusty bicycle that had taken me to the far corners of my world. I was 10 years old. That blue BMX may have been the last bike I owned, but in the past quarter-century I've never lost my appreciation for the freedom of movement that two wheels offer. Powered not by expensive gas but by cheap leg energy, easy and usually free to park, bicycles are perhaps the ideal vehicle for a frugal traveler, capable of taking you across a city or, if you have the time and ambition, around the world.
GIVENS--Cornelius. History remembers you as the first black man to run for mayor of a major American city. We remember you with love. Ernestine & Wilton

ON New York's hurried streets, one passing cyclist can appear no different from another. But cyclists are hardly a monolithic subculture -- more like a collection of finely divided sub-subcultures, each with its own uniform, lingo and attitude toward the bicycle's place in the urban landscape. Bike messengers continue to hold their place as iconic New York riders, but Transportation Alternatives, a group that advocates cycling, walking and public transit, counted only 1,700 of them last year; there are about twice as many food deliverers on two wheels in the five boroughs, according to the group. And both those tribes account for a small fraction of the 185,000 New Yorkers said to commute by bicycle, to say nothing of those who ride for exercise or road-trip on weekends.

India's luxury hotel scene -- long dominated by opulent palaces and converted mansions -- is joining the arty boutique craze with Le Sutra, a 16-room property in Mumbai's posh Bandra neighborhood, billed as ''the first Indian art hotel.'' Fronted with a bright orange mural painted by the artist Vincent Fantauzzo and the movie director Baz Luhrmann (both Australians), the hotel recruited a roster of Indian artists and designers to outfit the interior. Each floor is intended to exemplify one of the three gunas, the ancient Indian attributes of being: erotic tamas, vibrant rajas and serene sattva.

de CORDOVA--Arthur E.,who was a New York Stock Exchange floor specialist for 30 years, and responsible for trading the IBM book, died in Sarasota, FL on April 16. He was 75. The cause was heart failure, said his son, Arthur E. de Cordova III. Mr. de Cordova was the fourth generation to work as a floor specialist in a family firm that originated as Alfred de Cordova & Co., in 1882. He was later joined by his younger brother, Eustace de Cordova Jr., until de Cordova, Cooper & Co. was purchased by Paine Webber in 1989. In 1914, IBM was listed on the New York Stock Exchange, and assigned to Cyril de Cordova & Brother, who acted as market maker and managed all floor trading activity in the new stock. IBM became a bellwether stock as the company grew in the post WWII economic expansion, and their trading volume on the exchange soared. Mr. de Cordova assumed responsibilities for managing the IBM book from his father Eustace de Cordova in 1968, and remained the IBM floor specialist until 1989. "Arthur E. de Cordova and his firm were part of the proud history of IBM on the New York Stock Exchange dating back to its listing nearly a hundred years ago," said Mike Fay, an IBM spokesman. "Mr. de Cordova was IBM floor specialist at the NYSE during a period of tremendous growth and achievement for IBM and American business. The IBM company would like to extend our thanks for his years of service and our best wishes to his family and friends." Arthur Erroll de Cordova was born on July 23, 1934, in New York City. The family were longtime residents of Weston, CT, where they retained a family home until 1972. He attended the Unquowa School, and was graduated from The Lawrenceville School in 1952. He was President of his fraternity, Phi Sigma Kappa, and after earning a Bachelor of Arts degree in psychology from Hobart College in 1956, joined the United States Air Force, completing his service at Ladd Air Force Base in Fairbanks, Alaska. He retired from the Air Force in 1960 with the rank of Captain. He soon joined de Cordova & Co., becoming a member of the New York Stock Exchange in March, 1961. He remained a member for 45 years until the NYSE's public listing in 2006. During his more than 30 years as an active member trading on the exchange, he also served as a NYSE Floor Governor and Director of the NYSE Luncheon Club. He is survived by his wife of more than 33 years, Jerri C. de Cordova, of Casey Key, FL. and Westport, CT, and a son, Arthur E. de Cordova III, of San Francisco, from a previous marriage to Carole Magner. In 2005, Hobart and William Smith Colleges awarded him a Doctor of Humane Letters in recognition of his long and enduring contributions to the school. "Arthur de Cordova was a valued alumnus who distinguished himself in the world of business and was a thoughtful and attentive graduate who nurtured and cared for his alma mater," commented Mark D. Gearan, President of Hobart and William Smith Colleges. "Despite the rigors of his professional life, he always found time to support Hobart and William Smith and our Board acknowledged his life of consequence by bestowing its highest honor to him - an Honorary Degree presented at Commencement in 2005. At Hobart and William Smith Colleges we prize excellence and Art de Cordova embodied a true Hobart Statesman." A private service for family members will be held in Del Mar, CA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Association, www.americanheart.org

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Pressure Builds as Giants' Stoic Architect Begins Repairs'' (April 19): Behind the scenes, Jerry Reese is a thoughtful but fierce competitive man who is driven to win. He has had unusual initial success, but only because he was wonderfully prepared by a nurturing organization that early on recognized his unique skill set. He was surrounded by and learned from a terrific group of talent evaluators, probably some of the best in the N.F.L.

When Dallas Braden, the Oakland Athletics starting pitcher, criticized the Yankees' Alex Rodriguez for running over the pitcher's mound during last Thursday's game, it put the focus on baseball's unwritten rules, with many people unaware that Rodriguez had broken one. The rules of the game were recently dissected by Jason Turbow in his book, ''The Baseball Codes: Beanballs, Sign Stealing, and Bench-Clearing Brawls: The Unwritten Rules of America's Pastime.'' Turbow, who has analyzed the Rodriguez incident for his Web site, thebaseballcodes.com, talked about the intricacies of the game.Q.Among this latest incident, the pop-up in Toronto and the slap against Boston, has Rodriguez become the king of breaking the game's unwritten rules?A.The only guy in A-Rod's class is A.J. Pierzynski - who also makes a habit of crossing over pitcher's mounds. The primary difference between A-Rod and A.J. is that Pierzynski is devious; everything he does on a ball field is calculated. He'll cross close enough to the pitcher to actually brush him - nothing so obvious as a bump, but enough to tick the guy off. It's all designed to take the pitcher's focus off the hitter. I don't give A-Rod that much credit.

Ring Around the Rosy The artist Anish Kapoor is known for his large-scale, often highly polished and mind-bending sculptures, many of which are currently on view at the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao, where he is having a major solo exhibition. The ring he recently designed for Bulgari would make the ultimate souvenir. The concave stainless-steel band capped in pink gold is like one of the artist's works -- pocket size rather than park size -- and will serve as the inspiration for a larger piece to be auctioned off later this year to benefit Save the Children's Rewrite the Future program. ALIX BROWNE

BERNAL--Jose, 85, died on April 19, 2010. A noted artist in his native Cuba and in the United States, his works are in museums across the USA. Funeral will be private.

WEINSTEIN--Lloyd Bertram died on April 12, 2010. His humor and resilience were remarkable, despite a difficult illness. He grew up in Jamaica Estates, NY, graduated from University of Pennsylvania, married Shirley Farber, and raised three daughters in Great Neck, NY while running his dye works company. After divorcing, he lived in Great Barrington, MA, and worked as a real estate developer. In recent years he lived in Newton, MA, near children and grandchildren who will miss him dearly. He is survived by daughters Debra, Janet and Linda Weinstein, son-in-law Anthony Rosenzweig, and grandchildren Leah, Paul and Alison Rosenzweig and Benjamin and Zachary Lord; his sister and brother-in-law, Elese and Daniel Itzler, and his dear nieces and nephews.

HESS--Norma Wilentz. The Board of Directors and the Officers of Hess Corporation express their deep sorrow over the passing of Norma Hess, the wife of our late company founder, Leon Hess. She was a true partner and asset in everything he did and contributed in so many ways to the success of our company. We will miss the warmth, enthusiasm and graciousness she demonstrated throughout the years and send our deepest heartfelt condolences to her son, John, and daughters, Constance and Marlene, and their families.

ANGELE--Homer, 96, died peacefully in his sleep on April 17, 2010 in Limassol, Cyprus. Born in Leonarrisso, Cyprus on May 13, 1913, he emigrated to England in 1939, where he met Fanny Alexandra Myefsky during the Blitz. Homer and Fanny married, and after the second world war he opened Homer Models, a couture and bespoke establishment in London. He continued working as a Savile Row tailor until his retirement in 1976. Fanny died in 1990. Homer is survived by his second wife Demetra, his only child Alan Peter Angele, his daughter-in-law Susan Meryl Angele, his grandchildren Elizabeth Colette Angele and Caroline Ming Angele and numerous nieces and nephews. Homer was a person of compassion, sensitivity, generosity, elegance and strength, and he will remain in our hearts forever.

HESS--Norma. The trustees, faculty and staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of Norma Hess, wife of the late Mount Sinai Trustee Leon Hess. Norma, along with her husband, was a founding sponsor of Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Their generosity spanned many areas, including the Gustave L. Levy Stroke Unit, research in hematological and lung cancers, and a professorship in surgical oncology. Norma Hess's legacy continues on through the trusteeship of her son, John Hess. We extend our deepest sympathy to John, Mrs. Hess's daughters, Connie Hess Williams and Marlene Hess, and the entire Hess family. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center
The Medium column on Page 16 this weekend, about the television series ''Lost,'' misstates the number of seasons it has run. It is six, not five.

Maybe the world is sick of women who try too hard, be it on the red carpet or on ''Jersey Shore.'' A new slacker-beauty standard seems to be emerging, perhaps best exemplified in the quirky photography of Bettina Rheims, the Annie Leibovitz of France. Rheims's work ranges from the official portrait of former President Jacques Chirac to a new $2,000 Taschen erotic art book, ''Rose C'est Paris,'' but her vision of femininity is especially on display in the 2007 mistresspiece ''Heroines.'' Her women are haute without a shard of glacial, natural without falling off the cliff toward grunge, beautiful but profoundly undone. ''I'm not attracted to perfection,'' Rheims says. Hence the choppy anime hair, the makeup that looks like it might have been applied the night before, the attitude suspended between brash and breakable. ''The women you see in magazines are so powerful, so flawless, so retouched,'' she says. Rheims is more interested in capturing the nuanced moment when a woman with strength ''can let go and be fragile, and not be reproved.'' The photographer's own style icon is Patti Smith; in fact, she keeps Robert Mapplethorpe's photo of the rebel rocker in a place of honor in her studio. You can see the look on Smith herself once again these days, as well as on various younger countesses of coolness, including the actress Lou Doillon and her half-sister Charlotte Gainsbourg, the models Tati Cotliar and Kate Moss, the stylist Camille Bidault-Waddington and Sting's musician daughter, Coco Sumner. It also surfaced on the runways, at Marc Jacobs, Proenza Schouler, Burberry Prorsum and Alexander Wang.

To the Sports Editor: I am glad that the Rangers did not make the playoffs this year because it means there will be no illusions that this season was somehow successful. Glen Sather has accomplished nothing. Just making the playoffs cannot be considered a success in a league where more than half the teams make it in. BELMONT--Lillian, age 86, died on April 2, 2010. She was a long-time researcher at the NYS Psychiatric Institute. Lillian's papers on birth order and family size effects, in particular her 1973 Science paper with Dr. Francis Marolla, remain the preeminent sources on the subject. In 1981 she developed the TQ (Ten Questions), a culture-neutral screening instrument to assess severe childhood disability that is still used worldwide. She is survived by sons David, Joseph, and Daniel, and grandchildren Ami and Jules. A memorial will be held in the coming months. For information, email draqbl@aol.com.

CAIOLA--Benny, passed away peacefully on April 22, 2010. He is survived by his wife Bettina, his children; Benny III, Luigi, Alfred and Rose. He was beloved brother to Alfred, Bettina, Louis and the late Salvatore, cherished grandfather of eight; Anabela, Benny, Andre, Avery, Maria, Sasha, William and Adam, and so much to so many. Mr. Caiola was deeply loved by his family and all who knew him. His charismatic and gracious personality made him a giant among men. He leaves behind a legacy which will keep his spirit alive for generations to come. He came to America at the age of 17 from San Fratello, Italy. Mr. Caiola founded B & L Management, LLC, which owns and manages buildings all over Manhattan. He worked his way up from plasterer to general contractor finally building a Real Estate Empire of his own throughout Manhattan. The joy of providing for his family was what drove him. In addition to being well known as a real estate developer and owner Mr. Caiola was known for his wit and his generous and caring ways. His passion included owning the largest and most extensive Ferrari collection in the world. Having worked his way up he never forgot what it was like for the average working person. He was always there to offer advice and assistance in any way possible. Services will be held Saturday, April 24, and Sunday April 25 at the Frank Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue (81st) from 2-4:30 and 7-9pm. He will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved him. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to: The American Cancer Society.

Over the last couple of years, sales of vinyl records increased; the numbers aren't huge, but they sparked a lot of public musing about the format's qualities. Cassette sales, meanwhile, steadily dwindled to a mere 34,000 last year through the retail venues tracked by SoundScan. Considering this not long ago, I concluded that the romance associated with vinyl doesn't apply to its longtime analog rival. I was wrong about that. In looking (and asking) around online, I realize now that there is extensive evidence of ongoing appreciation for the cassette -- or at least the idea of the cassette. Part of what changed my mind was a long essay on the Web site Pitchfork. In that essay, Marc Hogan noted the cassette's stunning fall from prominence (8.6 million sold in 2004), but only as a preamble to declaring that a ''netroots resurgence'' is fueling a cassette ''comeback.'' The essay pointed to examples of indie labels that are now releasing tapes, sometimes exclusively, and noted a variety of aesthetic and cultural rationales for what could certainly be construed as a willfully perverse stance in favor of a format that hardly anybody seemed excited about during its actual heyday. Perhaps because of Pitchfork's distinctly music-crit worldview (''One sound that helped was chillwave a k a glo-fi a k a hypnagogic pop,'' etc.), I wasn't fully convinced. But I was interested.

HESS--Norma W. The Rockefeller University deeply mourns the loss of Norma W. Hess, beloved mother of our trustee Marlene Hess and widow of late Rockefeller University Council member Leon Hess. Mrs. Hess's spirit of generosity and volunteerism has left an indelible imprint on New York City. She served on the boards of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, the American Museum of Natural History, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She was also president of the Hess Foundation, which has supported many cultural, scientific, and educational institutions in New York City and beyond. We are deeply grateful that Mrs. Hess and her husband embraced The Rockefeller University, and that the Hess Foundation has created two distinguished professorships on our campus. The Hess family's longstanding involvement at Rockefeller is continued today by Marlene, who is a cherished member of the University community. Mrs. Hess will be greatly missed, and we extend our deepest condolences to Marlene, her sister Connie, her brother John, and their families. Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Paul Nurse, President Titia de Lange, Leon Hess Professor Sohail Tavazoie, Leon Hess Assistant Professor

ASHTON--Caroline B. Tyler Creo, (1929-2010). Caroline Ashton, beloved mother passed away peacefully surrounded by family and pets following a brief illness on April 22, 2010. She is survived by daughters Claudia Creo, Francesca Creo (Ronald L. Pettiway), Cristina Creo (Forest Flanigan), granddaughters Andrea Creo Towle, Chelsea Creo Sharon, Danielle A. Pettiway, greatgrandson Ekijah Creo Christianson, brother David Tyler and family, cousin Susan Whittlesey Wolf and family and other relatives and friends. Caroline was a devoted and accomplished horsewoman. She was a faithful friend of animals of all kinds. She was a pioneer of American Dressage. Caroline imported, trained and bred Warmblood, Andalusian and Lipizzaner horses. Over the years, Caroline's horses competed on an international level and won many national and local awards. She is well remembered as a talented riding instructor and a pony club activist. Caroline was a devoted patron of the arts. She brought a fine sense of aesthetics to everything she touched. She enjoyed gardening, travel and interior design. Caroline made her home around the world. She spent many years in New Jersey, Massachusetts, New York City, Mexico, Florence and Rome, Italy, Pennsylvania and Mount Dora, Florida. Memorial services will be held on May 1, 2010 at noon at the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church, 716 Watchung Avenue, Plainfield, NJ 07060 and a memorial will be held in Mount Dora, Florida at a date and location to be announced. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to: Last Chance Ranch, Inc., 9 Beck Road, Quakertown, PA, 18951, Doctors Without Borders, USA, P.O. Box 5030, Hagerstown, MD, 21741 and The Morris Animal Foundation, 10200 East Gerard Avenue, Suite B-430, Denver, CO 80231. To carry on for Caroline please rescue an animal in need.

On a recent Tuesday, Twitter crackled with anticipation. A significant episode of ''Lost,'' the eerie long-running TV series about plane-crash survivors on a haunted island, was coming up. A Twitterer called dmaul53854 announced his plans to lift weights and ''get ready for some #Lost awesomeness!'' using the pound sign to create a tag to make his tweet easier to find. ''Happy #LOST day!'' wrote peterkz. Macarolribeiro tested her character allowance: ''#LOSTDAY!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!!'' ''Lost,'' ABC's tour de force farrago, ends on May 23 after a run of six seasons, during which it inspired ardent fan sites, rococo wikis and message boards packed with conjecture about the meaning of the show. The possibility now exists that the mystery-rich drama, which dug its tendrils into the Internet as no other show before it, might at last pay off its fans' psychic investment in the show's supernatural cosmology. What would that be like, to be paid back? Fans can only imagine. All questions answered, we would no longer toss and turn over the legion ''Lost'' enigmas, including Jacob, the Man in Black, the Smoke Monster and the number 4815162342. The pieces of the plot would fit together like a dresser from Ikea. Complete and perfect understanding: an epistemological heaven in which all is revealed.

When Dallas Braden, the Oakland Athletics starting pitcher, criticized the Yankees' Alex Rodriguez for running over the pitcher's mound during last Thursday's game, it put the focus on baseball's unwritten rules, with many people unaware that Rodriguez had broken one. The rules of the game were recently dissected by Jason Turbow in his book, ''The Baseball Codes: Beanballs, Sign Stealing, and Bench-Clearing Brawls: The Unwritten Rules of America's Pastime.'' Turbow, who has analyzed the Rodriguez incident for his Web site, thebaseballcodes.com, talked about the intricacies of the game.Q.Among this latest incident, the pop-up in Toronto and the slap against Boston, has Rodriguez become the king of breaking the game's unwritten rules?A.The only guy in A-Rod's class is A.J. Pierzynski - who also makes a habit of crossing over pitcher's mounds. The primary difference between A-Rod and A.J. is that Pierzynski is devious; everything he does on a ball field is calculated. He'll cross close enough to the pitcher to actually brush him - nothing so obvious as a bump, but enough to tick the guy off. It's all designed to take the pitcher's focus off the hitter. I don't give A-Rod that much credit.

LOTS of young women today show their bedrooms, clothes and character in the thousands of ''haul'' videos made for YouTube. These are short videos that feature a woman's recent shopping haul, hence the name. They are scrupulously thorough, these women. They open their shopping bags, hold the goods in front of the Web cam and rave about the article. Often their voices are tipped with wistfulness. Felicia Noel, on her littlewomen1 channel, explains that shopping ''is something I've always loved since I was a child,'' and then proceeds to show off her new dress by dancing in her bedroom. Their bedrooms tend be absurdly childish -- awash in pink and stuffed animals -- or as impersonal as a motel.

ZEN is expensive. The flattering Groove pants, Lululemon's answer to Spanx, may set Luluheads, the devoted followers of the yoga-apparel brand, back $108. Manduka yoga mats, favored for their slip resistance and thickness, can reach $100 for a limited-edition version. Drop-in classes at yoga studios in New York are edging beyond $20 a session, which quickly adds up, and the high-end Pure Yoga, a chain with two outposts in Manhattan, requires a $40 initiation fee, and costs $125 to $185 a month. You can even combine yoga with a vacation in the Caribbean, but it will cost you: in August, the luxurious Parrot Cay resort in Turks and Caicos has a six-night retreat with classes taught by the ''yoga rock stars'' (in the words of the press release) Rodney Yee and Colleen Saidman. The cost? A cool $6,077. (In August!)

One day several years ago, I was reaching the end of my first visit with a patient, J.J., who had come to see me for anxiety and insomnia. He was a salesman for a struggling telecommunications company, and he was having trouble managing the strain on his finances and his family. He was sleeping poorly, and as soon as he opened his eyes in the early morning, the worries began. ''I wake up with a list of things to worry about,'' he said. ''I just go through the list, and it seems to get longer every day.'' A psychiatric interview has a certain rhythm to it. You start by listening to what your patient says for a few minutes, without interrupting, all the while sorting through possible diagnoses. This vast landscape of distress has been mapped into a series of categories in psychiatry's diagnostic manual, DSM-IV. The book breaks down mental suffering into 16 groups of disorders, like mood disorders, anxiety disorders, psychotic disorders, eating disorders and several others. As I listened to J.J. (a nickname that he agreed I could use to protect his privacy), it was clear to me that he had one of the anxiety disorders, but which one? In order to systematically rule in or rule out the disorders, I asked J.J. dozens of questions. ''Do you have panic attacks?'' ''Do you get fearful in crowded situations?'' ''Have you ever experienced a traumatic event that later caused flashbacks or nightmares?''

KLINEMAN--Robert (Bob) David, died on April 20, 2010 at home in Aspen, CO after a battle with Cancer. Bob was a long time resident of New York City as well as East Hampton, NY and was born in Cleveland, OH on October 19, 1927. He is the son of the late Julia and Emery Klineman. Bob graduated from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania in 1948. He worked for Marshall Field in Chicago before joining the family business, Majestic Specialties, a ladies sportswear company, in New York where he was until the mid 1960's. His work at Majestic was interrupted by a tour with the United States Army where he was stationed in Germany in the early 1950's. After leaving Majestic Specialties, he taught at the Fashion Institute of Technology before moving to Aspen, CO in the mid 1970's where he pursued his love of the American Musical Theatre. Among other pleasures, he created and taught a college accredited course on the subject and was involved in virtually every theater and dance venue in Aspen. He assisted with the formation of the Aspen Community and Institute Committee and participated in the Wheeler Film Series at the Wheeler Opera House where he conducted programs on his most beloved topic "Fred Astaire." Bob made a name for himself by pursuing the Astaire legacy. In the early 1990's, he conducted a weekend presentation on Astaire at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, DC. He is survived by three daughters, Melissa and husband Stephen, Mary Elizabeth, Suzanne and husband William, three grandchildren William Jr., Alexandra and Annie and his son, Robert Jr. Additionally, he is survived by his brother, William and wife Barbara, a niece, Andrea, a nephew, Jeffrey, many cousins and countless friends of all ages whose relationship he cherished. Donations may be made in his memory to the Aspen Music Festival and School, 2 Music School Road, Aspen, CO, 81611, Attn: Kat Berg.

Subletting Your Co-op

WAITE--Liane Fenelon, 86, died April 4, 2010 of cancer. Born in Yonkers to Earl and Mary Blanchard Fenelon, raised in Pittsburgh and for years a resident of Bronxville, she had a colorful career. Receiving her BS at Syracuse University in Food Science in 1945, she started work in the test kitchens of General Foods in New York City. There, she developed special flours for cakes, pies and breads. She then became food editor at the Ladies Home Journal, overseeing the publication of the Ladies Home Journal Cookbook in 1963, edited by Carol Truax, In which 75 years of the Journal's food recipes were brought up to date. Ahead of her time as a woman professional, from 1968 until she retired she held a senior management position in the Diamond International Corporation as Communications/Government Relations Specialist (i.e., Lobbyist). Upon her death she was serving as Board Vice-President of her Rockledge Manor Condominium. Her hobbies and interests included ham radio, baseball, opera (attending Wagner festivals throughout the world), needlework, collecting art of the Southwest, and hosting elegant dinner parties. Later, in defiance of her advancing years she became skilled in using the computer for email, creating her own holiday cards, and surfing the web. In personality she was tart, crisp but fun. She cared deeply for many friends from all walks of life. How can one NOT miss such a person dearly?! She is survived by several Fenelons (a nephew Curt and wife Betty, two nieces Christine and Carol, and a grandnephew Will) and her long-time companion, Edgar (Ted) Coons, a professor at NYU.

On a March morning at Coon Rock Farm -- 55 acres of just about everything you can grow and raise -- in Hillsborough, N.C., Jamie DeMent is showing me a fallen tree that's being milled into tabletops for the farm's biggest project to date: Eno Restaurant and Market. Who knew the farm-to-table loop would become so compressed or so literal? But it was only a matter of time before the farmers' market evolved into the farmers' restaurant.

SOMETHING borrowed, something old, something new -- the only thing missing from this one-off necklace ($2,900) by Marsha Chun-Matsubara (her fledgling label is called Abakus) is something blue. Unicorn Disco, inspired by a client's old necklace, is composed of vintage aluminum discs from Germany, bubble pearls, antique copper mesh, fake coral, rhinestone buttons and snakeskin-print beads. ''It reminds me of something by Miriam Haskell,'' Ms. Chun-Matsubara said, ''but turbocharged.'' For information, go to abakuscollection.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE

Before he goes to sleep, between 11 and midnight, Dan Pfeiffer, the White House communications director, typically checks in by e-mail with the same reporter: Mike Allen of Politico, who is also the first reporter Pfeiffer corresponds with after he wakes up at 4:20. A hyperactive former Eagle Scout, Allen will have been up for hours, if he ever went to bed. Whether or not he did is one of the many little mysteries that surround him. The abiding certainty about Allen is that sometime between 5:30 and 8:30 a.m., seven days a week, he hits ''send'' on a mass e-mail newsletter that some of America's most influential people will read before they say a word to their spouses. Allen's e-mail tipsheet, Playbook, has become the principal early-morning document for an elite set of political and news-media thrivers and strivers. Playbook is an insider's hodgepodge of predawn news, talking-point previews, scooplets, birthday greetings to people you've never heard of, random sightings (''spotted'') around town and inside jokes. It is, in essence, Allen's morning distillation of the Nation's Business in the form of a summer-camp newsletter.
KOENIGSBERG--Lawrence, 86, adoring husband of Rita. Beloved father of Mark, Steve, Gary and Ellen. Loving grandfather and father-in-law. Restauranteur- Hectors Cafeteria, Chandlers Steakhouse.

KAPLAN--Roberta Wennik. Born March 9, 1930 in New York City she died peacefully at home in South Orange, New Jersey on Sunday, April 18th, surrounded by her family and her tireless and beautiful nurse's aide Catherine Marquis. She loved Mozart, Bach, Handel, Sinatra, Rodgers and Hammerstein, Kaufman and Hart, Larry David, and Freud; she loved flowers, colors, dachshunds, coffee ice cream, her friends, silly laughter and the Upper East Side of Manhattan; most of all she loved her family: her late husband Robert Edward Kaplan; Rob, Maria, Bob and Will; Peter, Lisa, Caroline, Charlie, Peter Walker and Davey; Jim, Karen, Jacob, Aaron and Avery. She will be missed forever by every one of us.

HESS--Norma W. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Norma Hess, a faithful friend of our company for many years. In 2000, she succeeded her late husband, Leon, as an Advisory Director on the Met's board, where she served with dedication until retiring in 2007. We are deeply grateful to be one of the many cultural institutions in New York that Norma and her family have supported with such generosity and thoughtfulness over the decades. We will miss seeing her in her usual box at the opera house on Monday evenings and at the gala celebrations she enjoyed attending with family and friends. On behalf of the company, we extend our sincere condolences to her daughter Marlene Hess, an Advisory Director of the Met; to Norma's other children, John B. Hess and Constance H. Williams; and to all the other members of the Hess family. Christine F. Hunter, Chairman of the Board William C. Morris, President & CEO James W. Kinnear, Honorary Chairman Peter Gelb, General Manager

Joy never did it for me. My friend Joan Juliet Buck, then the rédactrice en chef of French Vogue -- and what's known in the business as a very good nose -- showed me Mille when I was visiting in Paris and said, ''This would be great for you.'' From the moment I smelled it, it was mine in a way that no other perfume had been since Blue Grass, which my mother firstgave me when I was a child. It's round and floral and warm, with just a hint of spice without being too hippie, and just floral enough without being too sweet. It smells like midnight in the Bois de Boulogne -- sexy and mysterious. I think it creates a mood. It's alluring. It says, I'm interested in life, in olfactory senses as well as visual ones. It says, I'm in the mood for something. It also says, I'm feminine, I'm complete. It stands to exist with my mother's perfume, Shalimar, which haunts me to this day. I even wear it to go to bed: I spray it behind my ears, old style. (Unless I'm wearing pearls.) People really like it. Even when I was a smoker, they told me I smelled good -- which is saying something! When you find yourself in an embrace and someone tells you that you smell good, it's wonderful and unexpected. Mille is rare, hard to find, which I like about it. It means I don't bump into many people who smell like me. AS TOLD TO CHRISTINE MUHLKE

Less than two weeks ago, the Mets were among the worst teams in baseball, staggering to a 2-6 record to open the season as speculation raged over how long it would be before they might take drastic action, like firing the manager. Since then, the Mets have fought their way back to respectability with excellent pitching and fundamental play, even as many of the hitters have slumped. With their 3-1 victory over the Atlanta Braves on Saturday at Citi Field, the Mets have won three games in a row for the first time this season, and they have won five of their last six. After that miserable start, they have returned to .500 (9-9) for the first time since they were 2-2 on April 9.

PITTARI--Lydia Valle, was born on August 14, 1912 and passed away April 6, 2010. Lydia was born to Frank and Angela Valle in New York City. She grew up in the City with her brother Mario and after she graduated high school she studied opera and performed in many operas at "The Met" and in radio musicals. Lydia and her family traveled frequently to Italy and on one the trips she met and fell in love with an Italian Pediatrician, Giuseppe (Joe) Pittari. Lydia and Joe were married in Italy and lived in Milan throughout the War. After World War II, Lydia and Joe frequently traveled to the United States. In 1979 Joe passed away and after burying him in his native Sicily, Lydia returned permanently to the United States. She resided in Miami in the Marjorca Towers and then moved to the Palace of Kendall where she resided until the time of her death. The family would like to thank the owners and staff of The Palace for making Lydia's final journey extremely comfortable and care free. The family would also like to especially thank her primary care giver, Nivian Rodriguez, for her timeless hours and efforts to maintain Lydia's lifestyle and comfort level to maximum degree. Lydia leaves countless friends and children of friends in New York City and Miami. She is survived by her loving family, nephew Larry (Carole) Valle, Chris (Debbie) Valle, Stacia (Christopher) Cannon and Bryce and Vincent Valle. The family will celebrate Lydia's full life in a private memorial and requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the charity of your choice.

Parriott Endowed Scholarship Fund at Pratt Institute, Department of Institutional Advancement, Pratt Institute, 200 Willoughby Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11205. The Local Stop feature last Sunday, about Red Hook, Brooklyn, misstated the address of the Waterfront Museum. It is at 290 Conover Street, on Pier 44 -- not at 699 Columbia Street. An accompanying map also included the error.

Wayne Gretzky, the N.H.L.'s career leader in goals (894) and points (2,857), met his match in Viktor Ghamari of Sweden in a shootout on April 14. They were playing N.H.L. 10, part of the EA Sports Champions of Gaming Finals, staged by Gillette in Manhattan. (Ghamari was chosen from more than 350,000 online entrants to compete against a celebrity.) Gretzky, 49, won four Stanley Cup championships with the Edmonton Oilers in the 1980s. Then he played for three other teams, retiring as a Ranger in 1999. He coached the Phoenix Coyotes for four seasons before stepping down in September. The Coyotes play Game 6 of their first-round playoff series against Detroit on Sunday.

McCLENDON--Mary Orbison Thomas, of New York City and Stonington, CT, died April 23, 2010. She is survived by her husband, James Stewart McClendon, her daughters, Margaret Aspinwall and Janet Vaskas, two grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.
In the flesh

DAMASHEK--Nancy, died April 22nd at age 91. Nancy was one of a kind - feisty, forthright, devoted to family, and forever generous. The youngest of six children, she is survived by her brother David, 98, and was predeceased by her brothers Samuel and George and her sisters Beatrice and Martha. Nancy died as she lived, with incredible strength and dignity. Her indomitable spirit will live on in the hearts of her family, her friends, and all who were fortunate enough to know her. We will not forget her.

In America, you are best known for being the Vicky in Woody Allen's ''Vicky Cristina Barcelona.'' Were you surprised that he cast you? Shocked! I quizzed him about it one day on set. I was like, ''What did you see in me that persuaded you to take this strange risk in giving me this really amazing part?'' He said, ''I don't know.'' [Laughs] Woody was incredibly vague about it, so who knows if he ever saw me onstage or anywhere else. It could have just been a whim. What was the audition like?

The fountain of youth is legendary in myth and history; some scientists and skin-care experts think it still exists, thanks to an enzyme called telomerase. Dr. Gregory Bays Brown of RéVive has created a $1,500 skin cream, Peau Magnifique, containing telomerase. In fact, the 2009 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine went to three scientists who discovered how chromosomes are protected by the enzyme, and further research could prove telomerase to be a key factor in infinite cell proliferation. No one's promising the death of funerals yet, but hope springs eternal. Here's the CliffsNote: As cells divide, they send copies of themselves to new cells. But that copying process chops off bits of the originals' protective tips. As we age, the tips, known as telomeres, get shorter and shorter till the original cells die, and we do too. Cancer cells, stem cells and some rogue cells produce a substance that blocks the snipping process -- telomerase. How it can be deconstructed, harnessed and activated remains to be seen: lab-made telomerase would have to penetrate skin, pass through tissue and cell walls, and hook into chromosomal activity in order to be effective. But RéVive's Brown claims that telomerase can recruit the skin's resting stem cells -- which exist in case of injury -- to manufacture new skin. So far, there are no major peer-review studies or clinical trials. And animal testing isn't possible since only humans produce it. Nevertheless, the party has definitely begun; in addition to RéVive, Jan Marini's Age Intervention Regeneration Booster and Goldfaden's DNA Telomere Cream boast telomere science. Other beauty products are sure to follow. S.S. FAIR

WINNING isn't everything. At least, that's what we tell the losers. But to the victors go the spoils. For the winner of this June's Le Mans 24-hour auto race, the prize is a Jeff Koons Art Car, the 17th in a series that BMW began in 1975 with a custom paint job by Alexander Calder. The BMW M3 GT2, which can go from zero to 100 miles an hour in three seconds, will be raced by a team of drivers. Mr. Koons, whose concept is shown above, will give the car an added boost with a finish expressing what he called ''the aesthetics of winning.'' Who knew that winning had an actual look? His inspiration: the lights on a Christmas wreath he saw in passing. (The car's interior will have a silver lining.) Mr. Koons will direct a team of BMW painters and add his signature on June 1 at the Pompidou Center in Paris, where the car will be on display for 24 hours before heading to Le Mans. LINDA YABLONSKY

Buff/ (buf) / adj. / Slang for having well-developed musculature, as well as being in a state of undress; a soft, naturally tan leather beloved this season by neo-minimalist designers, i.e., ''Since I started wearing these buff Céline sandals, I feel like I'm getting an extra workout -- their wooden platform soles are giving me calves of steel!'' Ergo, you've got to be buff to be in the buff. ARMAND LIMNANDER

For more than 100 years the Michelin's famous red guide to France has helped travelers with information on hotels, restaurants and service stations. Now it is also offering discounts and perks in restaurants. Inserted in the 2010 French red guide is a card -- called Le Printemps du Guide Michelin, Pass Privilege -- entitling the bearer to special deals at more than 1,000 restaurants in France, through June 21. The pass is good for two people, and the card must be presented at the restaurants.

HESS--Norma W. Closest friend of 50 years. Wise and discerning, elegant and unpretentious, she will live on in my conscience, my fondest memories, my sense of humor and my gratitude for all we shared. To Connie and Sankey, Marlene and Jim, John and Susan and all their progeny, may she be your Jiminy Cricket always. Foo

SALLY HERSHBERGER, the hairdresser who pioneered the $600 cut (now $800), may be tearing her hair out. Not only did she lose her star colorist Marie Robinson, who famously took Scarlett Johansson from a blonde to a brunette for ''The Nanny Diaries,'' but Ms. Robinson has also put a dent in the staff, hiring seven high-profile colleagues for her eponymous new salon in the Flatiron district. The light-filled 5,000-square-foot space, at right, will also be home to the celebrity stylist Danilo when he's in town. And if that's not enough of a lure, there's Master Cleanse lemonade on tap, and the music runs from Hot Chip to Kylie Minogue. And so far, there aren't any $800 services on the menu. 155 Fifth Avenue; (212) 358-7780. HOLLY SIEGEL

The evolution of Ryan Howard's game has been striking. To watch him against the Atlanta Braves last week - stretching to make a catch, diving to spear a sharp grounder, nimbly executing a flawless slide at the plate - was to see a player who has reinvented himself.

Mark Cuban, who bought the Dallas Mavericks in 2000, is one of the most passionate, outspoken and accessible owners in professional sports. He is a vivid example of how an owner's personality can be just as important as his largesse. With the Russian billionaire Mikhail Prokhorov on the verge of taking control of the Nets, Cuban spoke about his insights on ownership.

The American striker Charlie Davies fractured the tibia, fibula and femur in his right leg in a car accident last October. He broke his elbow, his nose and his eye socket. His bladder was lacerated and he had a serious head trauma. Doctors estimated a 6- to 12-month recovery period, which would have ruled out his participation in this summer's World Cup. But after seven operations and more than six months of grueling physical rehabilitation, Davies is making a feverish, last-ditch effort to make the American team that will travel to South Africa. Last month, Jeffrey Marcus had several telephone conversations with Davies while he was at CERS, a sports rehabilitation center in Capbreton, France, and when he returned to Montbeliard and resumed training with his club team, Sochaux. Here are edited excerpts from those conversations.
Adam Ellick reports from Lahore, Pakistan, about the worst power shortages the country has been facing in decades.

To anyone who has been following First Amendment jurisprudence in the past 40 or 50 years, the recent Supreme Court decision (United States v. Stevens, April 20) striking down a statute criminalizing the production and sale of videos depicting animal cruelty in a manner intended to satisfy a particular "sexual fetish" will come as no surprise.The proverbial ordinary citizen, however, may be surprised to learn that, according to Chief Justice John Roberts' majority opinion, the First Amendment must be read to allow the production and dissemination of so called "crush videos," videos (and I quote from Roberts' opinion) that "feature the intentional torture and killing of helpless animals" often by women wearing high-heeled "spike" shoes who slowly "crush animals to death" while talking to them in "a kind of dominatrix patter" as they scream and squeal "in great pain." How has it come to this?

Senator John Kerry is trying to tamp down the advance obituaries on his effort, with two colleagues, to cobble a passable Senate energy and climate bill. He just listed three reasons for climate optimism on Talking Points Memo. The first was that he and Senators Joseph Lieberman and Lindsey Graham had invested enormous amounts of time and effort; the second, that a very variegated coalition (from oil companies to environmental groups) was behind the effort; and the third, that everyone recognized China would celebrate if the effort failed.

A. O. Scott learns his ABC's (Always Be Closing) with the film adaptation of David Mamet's play "Glengarry Glen Ross." The film looks at a group of aggressive salesmen who jockey for the top position in a cutthroat real estate office. Mr. Scott praises the film's dialogue, saying that "nobody but David Mamet can write with this kind of hard-boiled, lyrical mysticism." Mr. Scott also says the film points to the origins of the current economic crisis, looking at a culture of relentless buying and selling that muddled the true value of things. Please share your thoughts on "Glengarry Glen Ross."

With more than 240 credits among the three of them (but surprisingly only three Academy Awards), it was merely a matter of time before Robert De Niro, Morgan Freeman and Ed Harris found the right project to appear in together. In this case, it is the debut performance of the multimedia work "The Dream Lives On: A Portrait of the Kennedy Brothers," which will take place as part of the Boston Pops' 125th anniversary season, the orchestra said on Monday. The work, which will have its premiere on May 18 at Symphony Hall in Boston, will have the actors narrating as three of the Kennedy siblings: Mr. De Niro as John F. Kennedy, Mr. Harris as Robert F. Kennedy and Mr. Freeman as Edward M. Kennedy. Composed by Peter Boyer with lyrics by Lynn Ahrens, "The Dream Lives On" will also feature the Boston Pops Orchestra conducted by Keith Lockhart and the Tanglewood Festival Chorus, as well as original texts and videos. The work will receive additional performances May 19 through 22 and July 3 and 4. It will also be performed on July 18 at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., with Alec Baldwin narrating, and on Aug. 1 at the Hyannis Village Green in Hyannis, Mass., where it will be narrated by Chris Cooper.

According to our fellow Times blog Bucks, the College Board has found that bachelor's degree recipients who graduated with the most student debt tended to be those who went to for-profit institutions or were independent, "meaning they generally did not get support from their parents." Jennifer Saranow Schultz writes: "The findings in the report [pdf], 'Who Borrows Most? Bachelor's Degree Recipients with High Levels of Student Debt,' released on Monday, were based on an analysis of government data about postsecondary student aid for students who received their bachelor's degrees in 2008, the most recent figures available." Read more and comment on Bucks.

Every year at the Milan furniture fair, there is a stand-out, seemingly ubiquitous object; this time around we couldn't help but notice the abundance of cool coat trees. For those who don't have an entry hall closet, or, for that matter, an entry hall, the coat tree stands as the perfect design solution. One of the best was the 25 Liter Coat Stand by the design darling Peter Marigold for Skitsch. The quasi-ready-made is anchored by a 25 liter plastic tank -- filled with water for stability -- and has a metal tube with hooks extending out of the spout. At Japanese furniture manufacturer Karimoku, the Swiss design trio Big-Game came up with the Signs coat tree. Made in natural or gray stained wood, this coat stand has movable arms which pivot out from the frame when you place your coat on it or snap back in place with hidden magnets when not in use.

Dorothea Tanning, the last of the Surrealists, has always been something of a fashion plate. A long-limbed beauty and a piquant dresser, Tanning scoured vintage shops and played dress-up with extravagant 19th-century pieces. Her eclectic style sense is celebrated in the 1942 self-portrait "Birthday" in which the bare-breasted artist sports an Elizabethan-style jacket, a draped skirt and what appears to the be the entire root system of a very large tree.
A. O. Scott takes a look back at the 1992 film adapted from David Mamet's play about the real estate world's culture of unfettered selling.
John Hardzog uses trained greyhounds to hunt coyotes, a common pest for farmers. It's a practice that goes back generations, but is also opposed by some animal rights groups.

The short story is not so small that it can't accommodate two winners for one of the more prestigious prizes in that genre. On Monday, the organizers of the PEN/Malamud Award for Excellence in the Short Story, which in recent years has recognized a veteran author and a writer at the start of a career, announced that Edward P. Jones and Nam Le were the winners of its 2010 prize. Mr. Jones, a Pulitzer Prize winner in 2004 for his novel "The Known World," was cited for short story collections like "Lost in the City" (from 1992) and "All Aunt Hagar's Children" (2007). Mr. Le, a Vietnamese-born writer who splits his time between the United States and Australia, was honored for his debut collection, "The Boat," which was published in 2008. Mr. Jones and Mr. Le will a share a prize of $5,000 and take part in the 2010-11 PEN/Faulkner Reading Series at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington.

But on Monday night, he will use makeup to add sags to his face and bulges to his eyes and an eyebrow pencil to make his teeth look rotted as he returns to the role of Henry the old actor in the Off Broadway production of "The Fantasticks" to recognize its 50th anniversary on May 3.

In this lesson, students explore sound topics and strategies for a written comparison as well as its authentic purpose, and then write their own compare/contrast essays, based on and inspired by models from The Times.

The White House Correspondents' Dinner, an annual black-tie festival of schmoozing, preening and source-greasing, is taking steps this year to reduce its carbon footprint. From decorations to menu choices to recommended modes of transport, the association is trying to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions generated by its 2,600 revelers.

A group of pastors and advisers have resigned as the executive council of a faith-based social service start-up in Brooklyn after saying it has been plagued by "incongruities and lies" and concluding that it could not even vouch for the project's veracity.

If you thought Britain's country house hotels - usually dilapidated and ennui-inducing throwbacks to Olde England - had remained comfortingly formulaic, think again. A new generation of clued-in hoteliers are sprucing up some of the once-forgotten countryside piles, turning them into stylish getaways with impeccable interiors, haute cuisine and, more often than not, spectacular spas - all amid a pastoral panorama dotted with horses, foraging sheep and darting deer.

If you associate "Jackass" with outrageous, over-the-top feats, know that the guys behind that hit MTV stunt show appreciate athleticism, too. In his new documentary "The Birth of Big Air," Jeff Tremaine, the "Jackass" co-creator and director, pays tribute to Mat Hoffman, the freestyle BMX biker who ushered the sport from backyard ramps in the 1980s to the two-story-tall half-pipes of the modern-day X Games. The eerily mature film is also a grown-up endeavor for the "Jackass" star Johnny Knoxville, who is one of its producers.

Artek, the Finnish company that was co-founded by the architect Alvar Aalto to produce his furniture designs, is celebrating its 75th anniversary by asking designers and artists to reinterpret its classic armchairs in a program called Dress the Chair! For the opening of Artek's new Stockholm showroom earlier this year, the British designer Ilse Crawford covered Aalto's chunky 1936 Armchair 400 - better known as the Tank chair - with reindeer fur, in a nod to its Finnish roots. And the Swedish textile designer Fanny Aronsen covered Aalto's chairs in her own colorful fabrics. The second stop was Milan, where the fashion house Missoni dressed the Tank chair in its graphic textiles (above) during last month's furniture fair. New York, Sydney, London and Tokyo come next, with more guest designers, before a final stop back home in Helsinki.

Evidence of the benefits that volunteering can bring older people continues to roll in. "Volunteers have improved physical and social functioning," said Fengyan Tang, an assistant professor at the University of Pittsburgh School of Social Work, who has studied older volunteers. "They report better well-being and greater life satisfaction. There's a reduced risk for mortality compared to non-volunteers."

After 14 years with the restaurateur Tony May, Odette Fada is leaving SD26 on May 3. She was executive chef of San Domenico on Central Park South, which closed in 2008, then at SD26, the relocated, updated version of the restaurant that opened last year on Madison Square Park. Her replacement, Matteo BerganiniBergamini, who is from Lake Garda in northern Italy, has been the chef de cuisine and also worked for two years with Daniel Boulud.

Laugh all you want, but the name ''Design Within Reach'' was never meant to be about affordability. When Rob Forbes founded the high-end modern furniture retailer in 1999, he was throwing open the doors to a realm that was - at least in this country - maddeningly difficult for the average civilian to penetrate without the help of an interior designer. With his new company, Public, he's taking the pain out of acquiring another elusive design object: the stylish, practical city bike, the kind that the Dutch and Danish ride. A longtime urban cyclist himself, Forbes watched as places like New York, San Francisco and even Louisville, Ky., spent the last decade opening bike lanes and encouraging alternative transportation, and yet, he argues, most American bike stores still cater primarily to athletes. ''Bicycle technology here is centered on lightweight performance, so they're not as interested in a customer that wants a kickstand, rack and fenders,'' he says. The Public M (left) is a lightweight update on classic French models from the '60s and '70s, à la ''Jules et Jim.'' And at $600 to $1,200, Public's bikes are more or less within reach. Forbes still believes in living a well-designed life, but this time around he's taking his gospel to the streets. Go to publicbikes.com.

"Arias With a Twist: The Docufantasy," which examines the theatrical collaboration between the performance artist Joey Arias (best known for his vocal style that channels Billie Holiday) and the puppeteer Basil Twist as a way to explore the history of New York's downtown art and club scene. Traversing the '70s until today, the film includes interviews with several artists who were a part of the scene. But its most intriguing subject is Mr. Arias himself, who has spent more than 30 years at his craft.

After several years of planting, pruning and planning, Seaver's two cabernets - GTS and Nancy's Fancy - are coming into their own.

With his floppy bowl haircut and adorable lisp, the teenage pop star Justin Bieber may not seem like a dangerous figure. But make no mistake: his public appearances can be battlegrounds. On Monday the Australian police shut down a free performance that Mr. Bieber, 16, was to give in Sydney as his fans began injuring one another at the crowded concert site, Agence France-Presse reported. More than 4,000 fans, some who camped out overnight, showed up to hear Mr. Bieber sing three songs at Sydney Harbor, but the plug was pulled on the event hours before showtime when attendees started pushing and shoving. "I am so sorry that it got out of control," Mr. Bieber said later in an Australian television appearance. "We don't want anyone to get hurt. It gets crazy sometimes." Last November, an appearance by Mr. Bieber at the Roosevelt Field Mall in Garden City, N.Y., resulted in a fan stampede after which the singer's manager, Scott Braun, was arrested on charges of reckless endangerment and criminal nuisance. The Australian police said that fans at Sydney Harbor had sustained only minor injuries and were treated at the scene.

The bullfighter, who is known to fans and the media simply by his double-barreled first name, José Tomás, needed 17 pints of blood and three hours of emergency surgery after being gored by an 1,100-pound bull named Navegante  on Saturday afternoon.

Former President George W. Bush's memoir, "Decision Points," will be released by Crown Publishers, a division of Random House, on Nov. 9, the publisher said Monday. Mr. Bush will write about political and personal challenges and discuss his handling of events including the 9/11 attacks and Hurricane Katrina, as well as his embracing of his faith amid his effort to quit drinking. In a news release, Crown said that Mr. Bush would focus on 14 critical decisions in his life and share his reflections on subjects including the closely fought 2000 presidential election and the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.

One in Three San Francisco Employees Made $100,000 | Almost one in three of 27,000 city workers in San Francisco made six-figure salaries last year, more than one in three of all city employees. It's a pay club whose membership has grown steadily over the past decade, even without counting health insurance or pension benefits. Overtime and payouts for unused vacation days sent many of those city workers' 2009 compensations over the $100,000 level. The retired deputy police chief, Charles Keohane, who left the force in mid-2009, led the pay pack, receiving $516,118 because of stored-up vacation, sick days and comp time. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

There is something very elementary that recreational players can do to improve their games in a highly sophisticated way. First, when you get to the range, pick a target in the distance to aim at -- a specific flag or a cluster of small trees. Then, lay a club on the ground parallel with your shoulders so that it is pointing in the direction of the target. Before you hit your first ball, it is essential that you use an alignment aid to train your eyes to aim properly. People think this is too simple to be of value, but poor alignment could be the culprit for a third of all the unhappy results in a golfer's average day on the golf course. Ever played in a scramble in which it's acceptable to stand behind one of your partners as he hits a shot or putts? Isn't it amazing to see how mistaken everyone's preshot aim is?

Brandon Crawford, the 33-year-old former Ball State defensive end who held on to his hopes of reaching the N.F.L. through a high school arrest and a stint in the Marines, will get a chance to prove he belongs after all. Crawford was invited to try out for the Giants at their rookie camp this weekend. Crawford drew interest from small colleges when he was a high school player in Fort Wayne, Ind., but his options dried up when he was arrested after jumping into a car with friends. He later found out the car was stolen. Crawford took a series of jobs after high school, including one on an auto parts assembly line, before deciding to enlist in the hopes of finding a way to pay for college. He was so committed to trying to make it in the N.F.L. that he would not even play pickup football at his Marine base because he feared injury. After an honorable discharge, he walked on at Ball State as a 29-year-old, eventually earning all-Mid-American Conference second team honors in his final two years.

WASHINGTON -- Empathy is out. Understanding ordinary lives is in. Is there a difference? President Obama is about to find out. A year after Mr. Obama made ''empathy'' one of his main criteria in picking his first Supreme Court justice, he is avoiding the word, which became radioactive, as he picks his second nominee. Instead, he says he wants someone with ''a keen understanding of how the law affects the daily lives of the American people.''

RIO DE JANEIRO -- A former Nazi-era German soldier who founded a secretive German cult in southern Chile, where he sexually abused about 25 children, died of heart failure at a prison hospital early Saturday, Chilean officials said. He was 89. The former soldier, Paul Schaefer, was serving a 20-year sentence for the sexual abuse of minors, but he was also under investigation for the 1985 disappearance of Boris Weisfeiler, an American citizen who vanished while on a hiking trip.

BELMONT--Lillian, age 86, died on April 2, 2010. She was a long-time researcher at the NYS Psychiatric Institute. Lillian's papers on birth order and family size effects, in particular her 1973 Science paper with Dr. Francis Marolla, remain the preeminent sources on the subject. In 1981 she developed the TQ (Ten Questions), a culture-neutral screening instrument to assess severe childhood disability that is still used worldwide. She is survived by sons David, Joseph, and Daniel, and grandchildren Ami and Jules. A memorial will be held in the coming months. For information, email draqbl@aol.com.

SHELLY FREIERMAN

The Vietnamese version of the 2010 census questionnaire used the words ''dieu tra'' to describe the population tally -- but what the words really conveyed was something like a communist government investigation. On Korean forms, ''county'' was translated into ''nation.'' And the Chinese hot line offered information only in Mandarin at first, although elderly Chinese immigrants, who are less likely to be proficient in English, speak Cantonese. Then there was this: In some questionnaire assistance centers in Queens, where people could get help filling out their forms, census workers instructed countless Bangladeshi to check ''Indian'' as their ethnicity.

Education Secretary Arne Duncan has vowed to press states to remake the 5,000 or so chronically failing schools that account for about half of the nation's dropouts and usually serve -- or more to the point fail to serve -- the poorest children. A $4 billion school improvement fund is intended to give states the help and the incentive to turn these schools around. Piecemeal plans that evaporate once the grant money is spent won't do the job. Only comprehensive, districtwide approaches deserve to be financed.

(Sundance) ANGEL-A (2007) A Moroccan-American hustler (Jamel Debbouze) in debt to the French mob contemplates suicide by throwing himself off a perch high above the Seine -- only to watch a leggy blonde (Rie Rasmussen, above with Mr. Debbouze) in a black mini-dress take the plunge first. Welsch, all grown up at 16 and in competition with the mean girl Marion Hawthorne (Vanessa Morgan) to become the official blogger of their high school class.
