BROIDO--Sally Frowenfeld. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of our dear mother and grandmother, Sally Frowenfeld Broido on Sunday, April 25, 2010. Sally was predeceased by her mother, Frances Moschcowitz Frowenfeld, her father Percy Morgan Frowenfeld, her dear sister Ellin Frowenfeld Ente and her beloved husband Theodore K. Broido. She is survived by her loving daughters Katie (Paul) Pearlman, Emily (Eugene) Chadbourne, and Peg Munves (Moy Wong). She is also survived by her devoted grandchildren Louie Pearlman and Jenny, Molly, and Elisabeth Chadbourne, and by her niece Chrystie Munves (Peter Plaue), her nephews Stephen and Douglas Ente, and her step-children Bill, Andrea, Tommy, and Steven Broido, and countless devoted friends. Sally was the president of the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, and was on the board of numerous organizations, including the Kaufmann Center, Hebrew Union College, and the Stecher and Horowitz Foundation and was a member of the Harmonie Club and the Lotos Club. Sally had a love of learning which never ended. She greatly enjoyed the symphony, the ballet, the opera, music of all kinds, Broadway musicals and theater, and Jeopardy. Her greatest passion was traveling, which she began in 1960 with her dear uncle and pioneering doctor, Eli Moschcowitz. Over her lifetime she traveled to every continent except for Australia, returning with amazing stories of monkeys in India, seeing the penguins in Antarctica, and her favorite place, Alaska. On her travels she made many good friends who have remained close to her over the years. Our mother's acerbic wit and joy for life will be greatly missed by all of us and her many friends. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the charity of your choice. Funeral services will be at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St, New York, NY on Wednesday, April 28th. Private burial to follow.
TISHMAN--Marcia W. Your love and wisdom continue to inspire us. We miss you so much. Love, Steven, Andy, Michael and Robert

As the week comes to a close iPhonegate continues to captivate the country; stores remain closed, truckers can't buy gasoline, life is essentially at a standstill ... O.K., it didn't really captivate the country, but the missing iPhone did make it onto almost every major media outlet, including ''Good Morning America'' and ''Late Show With David Letterman.'' Still, in the nerdosphere, the debate continues among technologist and gadget blogs. But what did commenters on The Times Web site think? Many believed that the entire production was just another Apple publicity stunt.My initial take was, ''Who cares?'' Then, I gave it some thought, and now suspect it's just another media manipulation by Apple. -- Jeff Broido Hehehe...... pretty good move by Apple (and Gizmodo) - probably the least expensive, far-reaching advertising possible. I see lots of winners. -- George Jung

PULIN--Charles. Photographer died April 20, 2010. He is mourned by his sister Janet Kasimis, niece Demetra, nephew Nicholas and brother-in-law Peter. Service by Rabbi Eckstein at Redden Funeral Home was on April 22.

Mike Tanier writes for Football Outsiders and is a contributor for the Fifth Down. When Bruce Campbell ran the 40-yard dash in 4.85 seconds at the N.F.L. scouting combine, many experts thought he ran straight to the top of the first round of the draft.

STAMEN--Lawrence L.,81, died April 21, 2010. Born July 10, 1928, in Highlands, NJ., Larry graduated from The Peddie School & Seton Hall University, lived in Los Angeles for 50 years and co-founded Dembo Realty. Larry was an avid sailor who enjoyed the beach and relished the camaraderie of his many friends in California and Florida. He is survived by his wife Sondra Stamen of Hutchinson Island, Florida, his daughter Justine Stamen Arrillaga, his son-in-law John Arrillaga, his grandsons Jack, Finn and Ben of Woodside, CA, and a band of devoted friends. Celebrations will be held in L.A. and FL. Donations can be made to The TEAK Fellowship.

HESS--Norma W. Monmouth Medical Center and Monmouth Medical Center Foundation Board of Trustees wish to express their deepest sympathy to the family and friends of Norma W. Hess, who was a champion of medical advancements and care through the Leon Hess Cancer Center and the Jacqueline M. Wilentz Comprehensive Breast Center, both at Monmouth Medical Center. With her late husband, Leon, Mrs. Hess began her philanthropic legacy at Monmouth Medical Center in 1961, and in the ensuing 49 years, our physicians, residents, nurses and staff have taken to heart the honor of having the Hess and Wilentz names linked to Monmouth Medical Center through their generosity. We send our sincere condolences to her family on the loss of their mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, the gracious and lovely Norma Hess. Webster Trammell, Jr., Psy.D. Chairman of the Board Gerald C. Marrone Chairman of the Foundation Board Frank J. Vozos, M.D., FACS Executive Director

There are a lot of types of practice golf balls. They've been around for decades. Some are pretty useless, like the hard white plastic ones with no holes. They do not mimic a true ball's flight in any way. Here are some better alternatives: The Almost Golf Ball is a pressurized ball with semisoft covering that has some of the feel of a real golf ball and yet won't fly too far, so you can find it and hit it again. Almost Golf Balls are good training aids and great for beginning golfers. A sample 10-pack retails for $9.95.

McCLENDON--Mary Orbison Thomas, of New York City and Stonington, CT, died April 23, 2010. She is survived by her husband, James Stewart McClendon, her daughters, Margaret Aspinwall and Janet Vaskas, two grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.

STROLL--Helen F.,of Shelter Island on April 25, 2010 at the age of 100. Wife of the late, Dr. George M. Stroll. Mother of Carol (Les) Larsen. Sister of Gloria Hegeman. Grandmother of Kari Pedone and great-grandmother of Maddie and Ellie. Friends may call on Tuesday from 2-4pm only at The Shelter Island Funeral Home, 23 West Neck Road, Shelter Island, NY 11964. Funeral services, Wednesday at 10:30am at the Shelter Island Presbyterian Church. Interment Emily French Cemetery. Memorial donations to San Simeon by the Sound Nursing Home would be appreciated.

HESS--Norma W. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Philadelphia Museum of Art mourn the passing of Norma W. Hess, noted philanthropist and advocate for education, the arts, and culture. We extend our deepest sympathies to her daughter Constance H. Williams, our Chair-Elect, and to her extended family.

An article last Monday about airlines' efforts to loosen a European flight ban because of a volcanic ash cloud erroneously attributed, in some copies, a distinction to Heathrow Airport of London. While that airport is generally believed to serve the greatest number of internationally bound passengers, it is not the world's busiest airport. In terms of total passengers and flights, the busiest is Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport. (Go to Article)

2:59 p.m. | Updated Added Blippy's explanation on its Web site of what went wrong. In my article in Friday's New York Times, I wrote about sites that let people share all kinds of personal information with the world, and about how these sites are embraced by users, despite possible privacy concerns. Now the blog VentureBeat has unearthed one of those problems involving a site I wrote about, Blippy, which lets people publish their credit card purchases online.

LEVI--Inge, died peacefully on April 24, 2010. Born in Germany, she emigrated to America in 1937 where she married Eric Levi. She was a Life Master at bridge, a beloved grandmother and proud great-grandmother. She will be greatly missed by her children Barbara Frank and Michael (Gail) Levi, her grandchildren Josh (Marcy) Frank, Adam (Dana) Frank, Jacob and Elena Levi.

An article last Monday about changes in the way New York City's public schools buy some classroom books referred imprecisely to the new procedures for trade books. While two large discount wholesalers from outside the New York region provide nearly all ''single title'' books -- novels, works of nonfiction, test guides and other publications that supplement textbooks -- other vendors, including local ones, still provide other types of supplemental books, including classroom library collections and ''prebound'' books, generally paperbacks reprinted with more durable covers. A Sports of The Times column on Thursday, about a meeting at Citi Field on Wednesday that included former Mets and veterans of war, misstated the surname of a Vietnam veteran who attended. He is Bill Welyczko, not Wisleski. The error was repeated in accompanying picture captions. (Go to Article)

For years chief executives at many major cultural organizations in New York City enjoyed salary growth that was buoyed by a booming economy and rivaled that seen in corporate America. Compensation increases of 25 percent to 50 percent over five years were not unusual, and in some cases packages nearly doubled. Reynold Levy's annual compensation to run Lincoln Center topped $1 million. Carnegie Hall began paying Clive Gillinson more than $800,000. Glenn D. Lowry, director of the Museum of Modern Art, earned $2.7 million in the year that ended in June 2008, including several one-time bonuses and the cost of his apartment in the tower beside the museum.

There is roughly a week left in an April promotion offering golfers a free 15-minute club fitting and the opportunity to trade in their old clubs toward new properly fit equipment. The promotion is being sponsored by PGA teaching professionals nationwide. Now, can a proper, thorough fitting for all your clubs be accomplished in 15 minutes? Probably not. But in 15 minutes you could get good advice on a few of your most important clubs and some general expert direction. And a lot of PGA pros offer club fittings for free or a small fee year-round anyway.

BALTIMORE - The way things are going for Javier Vazquez, this had to happen: A wicked liner off the bat of Nick Markakis zoomed into the Yankees' dugout in the fifth inning Tuesday night. Vazquez was quick enough to avoid sustaining a direct hit, but the ball caromed off the back wall and struck him in the side. If it had nailed him on the fly, Vazquez said it really would have stung.

This week's review subject is the Mark by Jean-Georges, a new venture in the Mark Hotel from Jean-Georges Vongerichten. It's a safe play for the man known at Diner's Journal as JGV: a simple two-star restaurant for a neighborhood that doesn't want to be pushed too hard in any one direction (and certainly not toward big, powerful spices). And it is very pleasant for that, a power-player dining room where you can hear yourself talk, with good, casual service that marks the restaurant as slightly less formal than its only real competitor in the neighborhood, Café Boulud, one block away.

On Wednesday, the worlds of wine collectors and art collectors will merge at the Whitney. There, they will bid on limited-edition bottles of 2007 Ornellaia with labels designed by Ghada Amer and Reza Farkhondeh to benefit the museum. The lot of 18 double-magnums with the phrase "Happily*Ever*After" spelled out among them is pretty, but the obvious keepers are the imperial (six-liter) bottles whose labels feature hand embroidery, and the salmanazar (nine-liter) bottle with its one-of-a-kind painted and embroidered canvas label signed by the artists. You won't be surprised to learn that Wall Street doesn't like the idea of a bank tax. Wall Street lobbyists argue that a tax on banks -- meant to discourage risky investments and cover the costs of financial crises -- will keep banks from being able to lend to worthy borrowers. That's not theoretically impossible, but it doesn't seem very likely. The taxes under discussion would have a low rate. It's also worth remembering that Wall Street's lobbyists often claim that they are just looking out for the interests of borrowers.

Enough with the PIIGS, a totally unhelpful acronym. What we're really seeing now is a crisis of the "cohesion countries" -- the countries that entered the EU relatively poor, and for a time received substantial aid in the form of "cohesion funds". (In Eurospeak, it's important to know the difference between cohesion and convergence: cohesion means convergence in per capita GDP, while convergence means getting inflation rates in line so that monetary cohesion is possible. Get it?)

When we last left Sergei Supinsky of Agence France-Presse at the Ukrainian Parliament in early March, he was recording the departure of Yulia V. Tymoshenko from the chamber after a no-confidence vote removed her as prime minister. At the time, the scene seemed to reflect the best "peaceful transition" school of legislative behavior. On Tuesday, however, the scene was strikingly different. Mr. Supinsky (and Efrem Lukatsky and Genia Savilov) depicted members of parliament throwing punches, igniting smoke bombs, tossing eggs and abandoning decorum completely. Those of us who live in New York State could take momentary comfort.

Gilbert Martínez has his work cut out for him. A reef ranger for the Belize Department of Fisheries, he spends his days patrolling a 87,000-acre Marine Protected Area called Glover's Reef, an azure paradise of an atoll about 28 miles from the country's mainland. I met him while reporting for an article in Tuesday's Science Times about a reef-monitoring project in the atoll that is sponsored by the Bronx-based Wildlife Conservation Society.

It can be easy to forget, in all the excitement over the current election, that Britain is a small country that does things in a small way. Its election season is a paltry four weeks long, though it can sometimes stretch to six. The two main parties typically spend about 18 million pounds (not much more than $27 million) apiece on a national campaign (Labour, which has had trouble raising money this past year, is likely to spend considerably less this time around).

The writers on The London Review of Books's panel "The Author in the Age of the Internet" this past Saturday might have been divided into two categories: those who know how to operate a portable electronic gadget, and those who don't. In the "do" camp: James Wood (critic, novelist, subject of YouTube "finger drum" video) and John Lanchester (journalist, novelist, proud owner of new iPad). In the "don't" camp: Colm Toibin (novelist, teacher, enthusiastic chronicler of gay chat-room culture), who claims such an aversion to phones, mobile or not, that he's grateful that in the Age of the Internet, we have e-mail, which "doesn't ring." Also on the panel was Mary-Kay Wilmers, editor of the Review, and Nicholas Spice, publisher, who moderated. Neither was forthcoming about his or her gadget use, although there were some early, tricky moments having to do with a microphone.

Evidently there are a lot of people in New York who identify with the forlorn Edward Scissorhands (and possibly with the murderous Sweeney Todd, too). The Museum of Modern Art said on Tuesday that its retrospective on Tim Burton, the filmmaker of "Edward Scissorhands," "Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street" and "Alice in Wonderland," drew the third-highest attendance of any exhibition in the museum's history. During the run of the show, which opened on Nov. 22, 2009, and closed on Monday, 810,500 visitors went to see artifacts like Mr. Burton's early illustrations and a prop of Sarah Jessica Parker's severed head from his movie "Mars Attacks!" (Additionally, 10,700 people attended ticketed screenings of Mr. Burton's films as part of the exhibition.) Mr. Burton is now in the rarefied company of Picasso, whose 1980 retrospective at MoMA remains the museum's most popular (with 976,800 visitors), and Matisse, whose 1992 retrospective is still the runner-up (with 940,000).

If you blame your parents for your problems, or even if you don't, be sure to read this fascinating obituary of Alice Miller, a psychoanalyst whose focus on family dysfunction started it all. Kelly Wearstler's life is as vibrant and busy as the rooms she creates. With her husband and sons Oliver, 7, and Elliott, 6; residences in Beverly Hills and Malibu, Calif.; and a business that takes her from Los Angeles to Anguilla to Paris in the space of a week, her only downtime is in the air. (Not a fan of flying, she travels with her good-luck charm, Franc, the stuffed bear that belonged to her grandmother and mother. She had him re-covered in linen since ''his fur had been loved off,'' and sewed on the buttons from her grandfather's navy blazer to replace his eyes.) When she does escape, she says she likes places ''where I can relax, but also go into a city and be inspired and shop. Otherwise I go stir crazy.'' View interactive >>

Charter schools came under a harsh spotlight last week, with State Senator Bill Perkins holding his long-awaited hearing in an attempt to examine how the privately operated schools spend their public money. The hearings prompted several articles in the papers exploring potential conflicts of interest and other practices that have raised the ire of critics -- and the issues are not limited to New York. And The New York Post took on Mr. Perkins with zeal in its editorial pages.

Last Wednesday, the Vatican formally accepted the resignation of Bishop James Moriarty, the third Irish prelate to step down over his role in sex abuse cover-ups. The next day, a German bishop, Walter Mixa of Augsburg, offered his resignation over allegations that he'd been involved in physical abuse at an orphanage in the 1970s and '80s. Then on Friday it was Belgium's turn: The bishop of Brugges resigned after publicly admitting to having sexually abused a minor two decades ago. And over the weekend, Sweden's lone Catholic bishop announced his willingness to resign over a woman's claim that he'd failed to respond to an allegation of sex abuse against one of his diocese's priests.

"Ugly money - busy, jarringly colored, divided by grimly utilitarian security strips - is hard to copy.  The treasury is in a continual arms race with counterfeiters ... I expect that by 2040, we'll be using currency so ugly that it will have a known visual disorder associated with it, and people will be forced to use blindfolds when they're checking out at the grocery store. On the other hand, we don't use that much currency, so I'm not sure what all the fuss is about ... The amount of currency that gets used in the United States is too small for counterfeiting to have any realistic impact on prices; these days, money is created not with the printing press, but in the electronic accounts of banks and the Federal Reserve. But fraud! you will say. Well, sort of. If the stuff isn't distinguishable from real money, then who's defrauded? The people who get the money will be perfectly able to exchange it for real goods and services. What it actually does is transfer a small amount of seignorage revenues from the federal government to the counterfeiters. An anarchocapitalist might argue that this is as it should be - that the federal government's monopoly on currency is illegal. I won't go that far; the counterfeiters are, after all, free-riding on the full faith and trust of the US government. What I will suggest is that the trivial damage done by counterfeiters might not be worth making our national currency a laughingstock."

President Obama recently signed legislation that changes the federal student loan program. The new law eliminates fees to private bank intermediaries, expands Pell grants and makes it easier for students who borrow money, starting in July 2014, to pay it back.

In their nearly 20 years together, the graphic artists Michael Amzalag and Mathias Augustyniak - who go by the name M/M (Paris) - have designed more than 50 typefaces, from an alphabet built from the sliced-up photographs of 26 male models to the inky resin letter forms that spell out ''Medulla'' on the cover of Bjork's 2004 album. Their latest, the Pradalphabet (above), was originally conceived as a temporary five-letter logotype for the house of Miuccia: Prada-M. (The M stands for Milano and M/M.) But the duo's ideographic tendencies got the best of them, and in the end, M/M designed a whole alphabet of ornamented initials, each representing a hazy portrait of the Prada brand. ''It's like looking at a planet from afar,'' says Augustyniak, who along with Amzalag spent up to six hours hand-drawing each letter. ''You can see a continent, but it's impossible to say what's inside.'' Examine the letters closely, however, and you'll spot cleaning implements, Italian phrases, strange machines and a picture of two men standing on a balcony. (''They're inhabitants of the Prada world,'' Amzalag says.) For now, they live in a collector's edition of T-shirts, each silk-screened with a P, R, A, D or M and packaged in a cloth-bound box with a 64-page album describing the project. Other letters are available on demand at Prada stores worldwide.

The auction rooms at the Hôtel Drouot in Paris date to 1852. They've been modernized since then, but the general atmosphere probably hasn't changed much. On any day of the week, a throng of characters straight out of a Maupassant novel can be found bidding for dusty treasures straight out of the proverbial Old Curiosity Shop. Annually, about 800,000 lots pass through the 16 rooms, over the course of more than 3,000 auctions.

An article on Monday about compensation paid to executives of major cultural organizations in New York and some other cities referred incorrectly to pay received recently by executives at the Metropolitan Opera and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The $1.3 million cited for Peter Gelb, general manager of the opera, reflects his total compensation, including salary, benefits and other allowances; it is not just his salary. The salaries for top executives at the Brooklyn Academy were frozen during its last fiscal year, an academy official said. They did not receive modest raises during that period. A chart accompanying the article included outdated information about the compensation package for Zarin Mehta, the president and executive director of the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Mehta's most recent compensation, for fiscal year 2010, is $807,500, which reflects a 5 percent pay cut taken by senior staff members last September. The $2.67 million figure in the chart was for the fiscal year ending in August 2008 and reflected his salary in addition to eight years of accumulated deferred compensation. The chart also misstated the year for the salary figures given for Timothy Rub, the director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art ($450,00) and George Steel, the general manager and artistic director of New York City Opera ($360,000). They are their current salaries, not their 2008 salaries. (Both worked at other organizations in 2008.)

RIEDLER--Audrey S. nee Dresden. A resident of Tenafly, NJ and Boynton Beach, FL. Audrey died at home in Tenafly, NJ after a two and a half year battle with pulmonary hypertension. She was born New York City in 1920 and was a graduate of New York University. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Walter Riedler, her parents, Dr. Marcus and Sadie Dresden, her brother, Arnold Dresden and her adored grandson, TJ Cosgriff. Audrey was an elegant lady who was a lover of people, golf, bridge and clothes. She was a member of Montammy Golf Club, in Alpine, NJ and Hunters Run Golf Club in Boynton Beach, FL. She is survived by her devoted daughter Jill Cosgriff-Nowell and her son-in-law Richard Nowell of Saddle River, NJ, her grandson Jason Cosgriff and his wife Amy of Upper Saddle River, NJ and five great-grandchildren: Shannon, Tommy, Wyatt, Savannah and Cooper Cosgriff. Audrey had a special bond with her niece, Linda Silverman and her nephew, Dr. Gary Dresden. She was fortunate to have had the love of generations of extended family and she will be greatly missed. The family would like to thank Mercy Tetteh for the excellent care that she provided to Audrey over the past two years. Private graveside services were held on April 25th. Please send contributions to the American Lung Association.

Five months ago, Charlie Davies could not stand on his own. His once sculptured legs shook under the strain of his own weight. His girlfriend pushed him around in a wheelchair because he could not walk. After a month in the hospital after a car accident in October that killed a young woman and cost him his standing as one of the most explosive young players in American soccer, Davies was swollen, scarred and in a great deal of pain.

For cancer patients who survive treatment, a change in perspective is inevitable. They may have to adapt to physical scars and pain, and they confront the new task of living a life that may have only recently -- or may still -- hang in the balance. In this issue of Science Times Katherine Russell Rich tells one story, writing eloquently (below) of a two-decade struggle against breast cancer. But there are many stories, each different. Two weeks ago an online feature, ''Picture Your Life After Cancer,'' was created as a way of capturing these stories.

An obituary on Friday about the architect John Carl Warnecke referred incorrectly to the publication Amerika, in which the critic Peter Blake wrote about Mr. Warnecke's work. It was a Russian-language magazine published by the United States Information Agency for readers in the Soviet Union; it was not a ''Soviet magazine.'' The obituary also misidentified the street in Manhattan where one of Mr. Warnecke's large-scale projects, the AT&T Long Lines Building, is located. It is on Thomas Street, not Thompson Street.

More than 800 giant wind turbines spin off the coasts of Denmark, Britain and seven other European countries, generating enough electricity from strong ocean breezes to power hundreds of thousands of homes. China's first offshore wind farm, a 102-megawatt venture near Shanghai, goes online this month, with more in the pipeline. But despite a decade of efforts, not a single offshore turbine has been built in the United States.

PANZA di BIUMO--Giuseppe. The Trustees and staff of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation express their profound sympathy to the Panza family on the death of Count Giuseppe Panza di Biumo. With his wife Giovanna, Count Panza assembled one of the great art collections of the twentieth century. Prescient and empathetic, the Panzas befriended and championed the work of dozens of artists. On their behalf and that of audiences today and into the future, we salute the inimitable spirit, vision, and accomplishments of Count Panza and celebrate his sharing with the Guggenheim the masterpieces in the Panza Collection. PARIS -- In a warren of side streets not far from the stately Boulevard Haussmann is a squat concrete building that contains another world. The Hôtel Drouot is France's oldest, largest, most storied and most profitable auction site, a frenetic three-story bazaar of marvels and junk: Picassos and Basquiats, stamps and used handbags, dusty carpets, couches, clattering glassware. Its walls upholstered in ratty red velour, its 16 salesrooms teeming and clamorous, Drouot figures among this nation's most beloved monuments to the material.

Let's say a subway station had peeling paint, decaying ceilings, cracked tiles. And let's say you would be happy to see just one of those problems go away. For years, you would have been out of luck. A strict policy at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority dictated that, barring an emergency, no single component of a station could be fixed unless the entire station underwent a top-to-bottom rehabilitation.

BAGHDAD -- Seven weeks after Iraqis went to the polls, a special elections court disqualified a winning parliamentary candidate, most likely reversing the narrow defeat of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki's alliance and possibly allowing him the first chance to form a new coalition government. The court disqualified the candidate on charges that he was a loyalist of Saddam Hussein's Baath Party, and it left open the possibility of barring still more.

For the estimated 12 million cancer survivors in the United States, some of life's biggestchallenges begin when treatment ends. We asked readers to submit photos and a brief description of how their lives have changed after cancer. Here are a few highlights from the 350 submissions we have received so far. When I was prepping for a stem cell transplant to treat my leukemia, my wife bought this canoe. It is the best canoe in the world: a Minnesota 2 in graphite. Cathy said if I were to survive the transplant it would be my canoe, and we could keep paddling together. Well, it is almost six years now, and we have put over 1,000 miles on the Min; thing is, mile by mile, year by year, it has become ''our'' boat, not Matt's boat. I guess that is surviving, getting back to us, not me. MATT GARRISON

HOLLAENDER--Mary McMahon, born March 12th, 1925 died at her home on Saturday. Mary graduated magna cum laude from Fordham University. She went on to NYU's School of Retailing on a fellowship. By the time she received her master's degree, Macy's had already recruited her. At Macy's she quickly rose through the ranks and went on to have an illustrious career, rising to the level of senior vice president, one of a few women with that title. Mary was often called on to speak and loved to work with young people. Teaching at the Fashion Institute of Technology afforded her a way to mentor. Her interest in business was very broad, which is why she enjoyed her membership in the prestigious Economic Club. Mary laughed easily and had a warm and friendly smile. But those of us who knew her well, knew that her warmth was not a sign of weakness and that she had determination and tenacity in all that she did. Mary traveled extensively for business and developed many lasting relationships. On one business encounter in 1954 she met William Hollaender, another Macy's employee. They married a year later. Mary's home, like herself, were well known. She lived in the first "Cinderella" brownstone in Park Slope in Brooklyn, which was part of the beginning of the revitalization of Brooklyn and the Brownstone Revival Movement led by her dear friends the late Evelyn Ortner and her husband Everett. Mary's generosity, affable smile and infectious laugh will be missed. Left to mourn are Daniel McMahon, nephew, Susan Elchick, niece, both of Annapolis, MD, Kathleen Jones Silber, cousin, of Brooklyn, Richard Jones, cousin, of Manhattan and a host of close friends. Visiting hours are Wednesday from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Joseph G. Duffy Funeral Home, 255 9th Street, Brooklyn, NY 718-499-8700. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 9:45am at St. Francis Xavier Church. Interment to follow at Greenwood Cemetery.

(IFC) FOOD PARTY The Brooklyn artist and gourmand Thu Tran, above, is back for a second round of surreal exploits, starting with a glimpse of what she insists is just an average day in her life. BROIDO--Sally F. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and friend, Sally F. Broido, and send condolences to her family.

WU--Wynne. The faculty and students of Bard High School Early College wish to express their deepest sympathy to the family of Wynne Wu. Wynne will be missed not only by her fellow teachers who held her in highest regard but also by her many students whom she inspired to continue their study of Chinese culture and language. She was a masterful teacher who combined high standards with a creative and playful approach to learning. Her love of music, language and life deeply affected her colleagues and the many students she left behind.

LAST week, Pope Benedict XVI told victims of sexual abuse by priests in Malta that the Catholic Church was doing all it could to investigate abuse accusations and find ways to safeguard children in the future. With the pope's pledge, and the resignation in recent days of three European bishops involved in the sex abuse scandal, it might appear that the church is finally taking responsibility for failing to protect children against molesters for hundreds of years. But the church is not doing everything in its power to help victims. In fact, it is worsening the sins of the past by taking a leading role in preventing abused children from getting the compensation they need to help remedy past abuse.

The evolution of Ryan Howard's game has been striking. To watch him against the Atlanta Braves last week - stretching to make a catch, diving to spear a sharp grounder, nimbly executing a flawless slide at the plate - was to see a player who has reinvented himself. Howard, 30, is an elite power hitter for the Philadelphia Phillies, with at least 45 home runs in each of the last four seasons. But he has transformed himself from a one-dimensional slugger into an asset in the field and on the bases, too. It helped earn him a five-year, $125 million extension on Monday from a team that had once been uncertain about how long to keep him.

BROIDO--Sally F. NCJW NY Section mourns the passing of Sally F. Broido, our beloved Past President. As a former chair of Council Senior Center, Sally set an example for others to follow and we valued her ongoing guidance. We remember with gratitude her many years of service and exceptional dedication. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. Beatrice Kahn & Beth Mitchell, Co-Presidents Joan Shapiro Green, Executive Director

Parents and teachers often tell children to pay attention - to be a ''good listener.'' But what if your child's brain doesn't know how to listen? That's the challenge for children with auditory processing disorder, a poorly understood syndrome that interferes with the brain's ability to recognize and interpret sounds. It's been estimated that 2 to 5 percent of children have the disorder, said Gail D. Chermak, an expert on speech and hearing sciences at Washington State University, and it's likely that many cases have gone undiagnosed or misdiagnosed.
HAZAN--Leslie Beth. To my daughter on her 47th Birthday. You are in my heart today and always.

An article on Monday about compensation paid to executives of major cultural organizations in New York and some other cities referred incorrectly to pay received recently by executives at the Metropolitan Opera and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The $1.3 million cited for Peter Gelb, general manager of the opera, reflects his total compensation, including salary, benefits and other allowances; it is not just his salary. The salaries for top executives at the Brooklyn Academy were frozen during its last fiscal year, an academy official said. They did not receive modest raises during that period. A chart accompanying the article included outdated information about the compensation package for Zarin Mehta, the president and executive director of the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Mehta's most recent compensation, for fiscal year 2010, is $807,500, which reflects a 5 percent pay cut taken by senior staff members last September. The $2.67 million figure in the chart was for the fiscal year ending in August 2008 and reflected his salary in addition to eight years of accumulated deferred compensation.

BARGMAN--Abraham, 85, died April 24, 2010, beloved husband of Terri, father of Susan, David and Perry, grandfather of Jennie, Joanna, and Benjamin, and father-in-law of Susan and Lee. Pursued his lifelong passion for world peace at the World Federalists, United Nations and as Professor of Political Science at Brooklyn College and the City University of New York Graduate Center. Contributions may be made to the Abraham Bargman Memorial Fund, The Brooklyn College Foundation, 2900 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11210.

BLOOM--Lynne G.,died April 24 at age 85. Beloved sister of Janet Slater, aunt of John Adelman, Lucy Adelman O'Brien, Daniel Adelman. Lynne, with her great intellect and sharp sense of humor, will be deeply missed.

WASHINGTON -- Senate Republicans, united in opposition to the Democrats' legislation to tighten regulation of the financial system, voted on Monday to block the bill from reaching the floor for debate. As both sides dug in, the battle has huge ramifications for the economy and for their political prospects in this year's midterm elections. Republicans said they were intent on winning substantive changes to the bill and accused the Democrats of rushing the most far-reaching overhaul of the financial regulatory system since the Great Depression. Both sides say they expect the overhaul eventually will be approved.

The world was young, leafy green and overrun with dinosaurs so many eons ago that stories from prehistoric times are mostly fantasy and supposition. But the medical world was exactly that young, primitive and full of unusual creatures barely a century ago, giving historians ample fodder for true stories stranger than any fantasy. Few of them surpass the biography of the man often credited with founding modern American surgery: William Halsted, professor of surgery at Johns Hopkins, and lifelong drug addict. Gerald Imber's new biography is the first retelling of Halsted's story in many decades and a particularly expert and thought-provoking narrative.

Franklin Mieuli, the unconventional and popular owner of the Golden State Warriors for nearly a quarter century who in 1975 brought the franchise its only National Basketball Association championship in nearly 40 years on the West Coast, died Sunday. He was 89. The death was announced by the Warriors, who said he died of natural causes in the Bay Area. A local boy who made good, Mr. Mieuli (pronounced MEW-lee), grew up in San Jose and ran a successful radio production company. He bought a partial stake in the Warriors when the team moved to the Bay Area from Philadelphia in 1962 (taking with them the star center Wilt Chamberlain) and became a majority shareholder shortly thereafter.

COWLES--Allison S. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Allison Cowles, beloved wife of Arthur O. Sulzberger, a long-time Trustee who was the Museum's Chairman 1987-98 and is now a Trustee Emeritus. Allison graced our institution with her passion, warmth, and intelligence and was a dear friend to us all. Always lovingly at Punch's side, she championed the Met and its mission. She will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to the Sulzberger and Cowles families. James R. Houghton, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President

Don Zimmer decided to sneak out to the racetrack one day in 1996 and asked Joe Torre if he wanted to come along. Torre could not get away, but he gave his longtime friend a few hundred dollars and asked Zimmer to invest it for him at the betting windows at Baltimore's Pimlico Race Course. Zimmer must have had one of those days at the track where every horse he picked ran like a champion. Torre's bankroll grew exponentially. ''He brought me back more than I gave him,'' Torre said prior to Monday's washed-out Dodgers-Mets game at Citi Field. ''He hooked me.''

BROIDO--Sally. Kaufman Center mourns the passing of Sally Broido, our dear friend, Board Member and advocate for music education. Her exuberance about everything and everyone she loved was whole-hearted, and her death leaves a void. We count ourselves among the mourners, but reach out with sympathy to her family who loved her so. Lydia Kontos, Executive Dir. Bethany Millard, Chair

BROIDO--Sally Frowenfeld. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of our dear mother and grandmother, Sally Frowenfeld Broido on Sunday, April 25, 2010. Sally was predeceased by her mother, Frances Moschcowitz Frowenfeld, her father Percy Morgan Frowenfeld, her dear sister Ellin Frowenfeld Ente and her beloved husband Theodore K. Broido. She is survived by her loving daughters Katie (Paul) Pearlman, Emily (Eugene) Chadbourne, and Peg Munves (Moy Wong). She is also survived by her devoted grandchildren Louie Pearlman and Jenny, Molly, and Elisabeth Chadbourne, and by her niece Chrystie Munves (Peter Plaue), her nephews Stephen and Douglas Ente, and her step-children Bill, Andrea, Tommy, and Steven Broido, and countless devoted friends. Sally was the president of the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, and was on the board of numerous organizations, including the Kaufmann Center, Hebrew Union College, and the Stecher and Horowitz Foundation and was a member of the Harmonie Club and the Lotos Club. Sally had a love of learning which never ended. She greatly enjoyed the symphony, the ballet, the opera, music of all kinds, Broadway musicals and theater, and Jeopardy. Her greatest passion was traveling, which she began in 1960 with her dear uncle and pioneering doctor, Eli Moschcowitz. Over her lifetime she traveled to every continent except for Australia, returning with amazing stories of monkeys in India, seeing the penguins in Antarctica, and her favorite place, Alaska. On her travels she made many good friends who have remained close to her over the years. Our mother's acerbic wit and joy for life will be greatly missed by all of us and her many friends. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the charity of your choice. Funeral services will be at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St, New York, NY on Wednesday, April 28th at 11:15am. Private burial to follow. The family will receive friends on Thursday, April 29 from 4-7pm at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th St.

VECCHIOTTI--Frank John, on April 25, 2010 of Bergenfield, NJ. Before retiring he owned and operated Star Manufacturing, Inc. as well as Lantana Ristorante. He was an Army veteran of WWII. Beloved husband of Inez. Devoted father of Maria Vecchiotti. Loving grandfather of Stephen, Peter and Daniela Tanico. Brother of Vincent. The funeral will leave Riewerts Memorial Home, 187 So. Washington Ave. Bergenfield on Thursday at 10:30am for the Funeral Mass at St. John the Evangelist R.C. Church, Bergenfield at 11am. Entombment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, E. Hanover, NJ. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, Memphis, TN would be appreciated. Send a lasting condolence at: riewertsmemorialhome.com

Todd Pletcher may have lost three starters for the Kentucky Derby in recent days, including the favorite, Eskendereya, but he gained one starter with the entry of the filly Devil May Care. With her entry, Pletcher now has four horses among the likely field of 20 that will line up in the starting gate at Churchill Downs on Saturday. Devil May Care will also be the first filly to enter the race since Eight Belles ran second in 2008, only to be euthanized after breaking down past the finish line.

GIORDANO--Gerard Francis, of Glen Head, NY. Born August 4, 1930. Died April 22, 2010. Loving husband of Helen. Loving father of Nancy Turner (Robert) and Susan Elizabeth. In this week's Tech Talk podcast, J.D. Biersdorfer explores a new global effort to share information on repairing tech gear. She speaks with Kyle Wiens, a founder of the iFixit Web site, which offers free how-to advice on fixing Apple products. The site has a collaborative repair manual known as Repair 2.0 that aims to reduce electronic waste by enabling people to fix things instead of throwing them away.

For a long time my view on the euro has been that it may well have been a mistake, but that bygones were bygones -- it could not be undone. I was strongly influenced by the view expressed by Barry Eichengreen in a classic 2007 article (although I had heard that argument -- maybe from Barry? -- long before that piece was published): as Eichengreen argued, any move to leave the euro would require time and preparation, and during the transition period there would be devastating bank runs. So the idea of a euro breakup was a non-starter.

After Wednesday's article on the Great Epistemic Closure Debate that has engaged conservatives, a number of philosophers wrote in to complain: Don't drag philosophy into it! The obscure term "epistemic closure" is being used in a vigorous online discussion to refer to a tendency on the right to operate in a closed information bubble, where news from outside the bubble is immediately ignored or discounted. Julian Sanchez, a libertarian at the Cato Institute, was the first to use the phrase in this context, and he noted, as did The Times article, that it had an unrelated meaning in philosophy, where it refers to a problem of logical deduction. Here are two links for the ambitious from Stanford and the Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy.

The word up north these days is no longer Scandinavian, please, it's Nordic. More precisely, in food trends, it's New Nordic - a kind of frosty Slow Food locavore movement in which chefs (with toques off to Rene Redzepi of Noma in Copenhagen) are resurrecting and refreshing old food traditions. Butter and rapeseed oil are in, and Tuscan olive oil is out.

It seems wherever you look there's a photo festival happening somewhere in the world, but perhaps the most anticipated one is the International Festival of Fashion & Photography in Hyères, France. The festival, which takes place April 30 to May 3, is located at the Villa Noailles, a former modernist residence that has since become a venue for cultural events. Each year ten up-and-coming photographers exhibit their work to the public and an esteemed jury of media professionals. This year's highlights include Carlo van de Roer's ethereal Polaroid portraits, James Reeve's nocturnal cityscapes, and Yann Gross's Ugandan skateboarder series. Hyères 2010 will also feature a Walter Pfeiffer retrospective and a new video by Steven Klein depicting his fashion photography from the past ten years. Klein's highly structured, subversive images are a good counterbalance to Pfeiffer's more jocular, candid photos. In case you can't make the festival this weekend, the exhibitions run until May 30.

Wednesday morning in Madagascar's capital, Antananarivo, which is known as Tana, and with all research permits now in hand, it is time to start thinking about the practical aspects of starting the fieldwork. That means trying to plan (and pack) for everything that can go wrong.  And a lot can go wrong in Madagascar.  For example, when the car breaks down and strands you in the middle of nowhere, with absolutely no roadside towing, except maybe a couple of zebu cows in the closest village, if you can find their owner.  So, a very good place to start the practical preparation is with the car -- my trusty old Land Rover, "Baby."

Apparently, it will no longer be good enough for the Izod IndyCar Series to crown just one champion. The open-wheel series that that has lost much of its traction to Nascar announced on Tuesday that it will begin to recognize three champions: an overall champion, plus separate series champions in races on ovals and in races on road and street courses.

"The Kennedys," the coming History Channel miniseries, has found its lead actors to play the central members of that Democratic political clan. Greg Kinnear, an Academy Award nominee for "As Good As It Gets," will play John F. Kennedy; Barry Pepper ("Saving Private Ryan") will play Robert F. Kennedy; Tom Wilkinson, an Emmy Award winner for "John Adams," will play the family patriarch, Joseph P. Kennedy; and Katie Holmes ("Batman Begins," "Dawson's Creek") will play Jacqueline Kennedy.

There may be a good reason why German taxpayers are so unhappy about having to lend money to Greece. In effect, they already have. Germany's financial institutions hold some 28 billion euros, or $37 billion, in Greek bonds, Barclays Capital estimates, extrapolating from International Monetary Fund data,  Jack Ewing of The New York Times reports from Frankfurt.

When Michael Bastian decided to leave his job as men's fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman to start his own line, his parents were so concerned that they told him he could move back home if it didn't work out. "That's exactly the push I needed," he said. "To know that if the worst happened, I could move back into my bedroom in Rochester!" Four years later, Mr. and Mrs. Bastian still have a spare room, and their son has carved out a niche for himself as the go-to guy for better-than-the-original takes on classic American sportswear. Come fall, he'll expand his fan base further with a lower-priced collection for Gant. Here, Bastian talks to The Moment about finding the perfect Nantucket Reds, women in ties, and the importance of cut-offs.

The private interviews N.F.L. teams hold with draft prospects have often been odd affairs, littered with questions of the "if you were a tree, what tree would you be?" variety. General managers and scouts have complained that players are so thoroughly prepped for interviews by their agents that it is increasingly difficult to get a accurate read on players' personalities. This year, though, in an attempt to divine a players' character, Miami General Manager Jeff Ireland may have finally crossed a line by asking receiver Dez Bryant if his mother was a prostitute.

The Metropolitan Opera last year freed up $22 million of its $242 million endowment to help cover operating expenses. With the permission of the donors, $15 million was shifted into the less restrictive endowment trust as an emergency reserve. The move, reported in the Wall Street Journal on Wednesday, was yet another effort by the Met to manage a deficit that is expected to be about $4 million for this fiscal year. With the permission of Chevron Texaco, the Met also moved $7 million in restricted funds. The Met has reduced the total budget by $18 million for the current fiscal year, resulting in an operating budget of about $300 million.

I was a Diamond Crystal baby. Diamond Crystal kosher salt was the only salt my mother used, the only one I knew as a child. Now, half a century later (yikes!), it remains the salt I reach for first - although I now have to fish for it among half a dozen that sit on the shelf. All those fancy sea salts, however, are used to finish dishes or added at the table, where their varied textures are a source of tactile delight. For cooking, I rarely use anything but the kosher salt of my childhood; I can judge, by eye and by feel, how much I need for any task from making a well balanced vinaigrette to seasoning a steak.

Today I thought I would take you through my morning activity, so you can get a sense of what an exercise rider does. Exercise riders are those guys who are piloting the Kentucky Derby horses around the track for their morning training. I have never had the privilege of galloping a horse that is preparing for the Derby, but I have galloped at least one horse who ran in the Derby. Storm Treasure, trained by Steve Asmussen, ran the year Barbaro won. He came up to Woodbine in 2008 and 2009 when I was galloping for Asmussen in Canada.

He was Picasso, Copernicus, a Shakespeare with shears. Yes, those are grand comparisons, but they're consistent with the gushing of hair geeks interviewed for "Vidal Sassoon The Movie," a documentary that had its world premiere on Friday at the Tribeca Film Festival. Was Sassoon really so great? From his Bond Street salon in the 1960s, he created a geometric approach to the cut, exemplified by the "five-point," which coiffeurs still speak of like it's their Rosetta stone. "You cut hair like we cut clothes," the Swinging Sixties designer Mary Quant tells Sassoon during a tender scene in which they sift through old pictures of the models Nancy Kwan and Grace Coddington. A narrative quickly emerges: Quant popularizes the mini-skirt, Sassoon tops off the King's Road look, and the rest - the shampoo bottles, the global network of salons and styling academies - is history. Well, not quite.

Inter Milan qualified for the UEFA Champions League final, 3-2 on aggregate, after a tense match that saw Barcelona dominate possession but fail to find the back of the net more than once. The Italian side will face Bayern Munich on May 22 in Madrid. But despite a man advantage for much of he match, the defending European champion could not score against Inter's locked-down defense.

Billboard's album chart this week is all about soundtracks. "The Power of Madonna" (Columbia), the seven-song companion to last week's all-Madonna episode of the Fox show "Glee," opened at No. 1 with 98,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and 75 percent of its sales were as digital downloads -- an extraordinary number, although not quite record-breaking. (In January, Kesha's "Animal" had 76 percent, and the "Hope for Haiti" charity album was released only online.) Not far behind "Glee," the all-AC/DC soundtrack to "Iron Man 2" (Columbia) reached No. 4 in its first week, with 76,000 sales. Billboard reported that it is the first time in the five-decade history of its main album chart that two soundtracks have made their debuts in the Top 5.

Where Banksy is involved, there usually are no accidents, but in this case it truly does appear to be an accident that a street-cleaning crew in Melbourne, Australia, painted over a mural by that pseudonymous graffiti artist and provocateur. The Associated Press reported that Susan Riley, the deputy lord mayor of Melbourne, dispatched street cleaners to the city's Hosier Lane after residents complained about squalid conditions at an alley known for its displays of public art. Among the works painted there was a stencil of a goggle-wearing rat, created by Banksy during a visit to Melbourne in 2003 - and removed by the crew, which was instructed to remove all graffiti from the area. In an interview on Australian radio, Kathy Alexander, the chief executive of the city of Melbourne, said, "Unfortunately, the contractors were not made aware by us that that was an important piece and unfortunately that means the piece is gone."

Clio Barnard's film "The Arbor" is hard to categorize. It's a documentary, as it uses the interviews of real people to tell its story of the British playwright Andrea Dunbar (who died in 1990 at age 29) and the difficult relationship she had with her daughter Lorraine. But it's also a narrative feature, because it uses actors to lip-sync the audio of those interviews in highly stylized scenes. Also mixed in is a performance of Ms. Dunbar's play "The Arbor," staged and filmed on the street where she lived in Bradford, England. The film screens Wednesday night at the Tribeca Film Festival and includes a post-screening panel.

What's the point of design these days, anyway? That's the question the curators at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum wrestled with for nearly three years as they assembled ''Why Design Now?,'' the museum's fourth National Design Triennial, which opens May 14. Their response, presented through 134 projects from around the world, might be the design equivalent of the Hippocratic oath. Many are high-minded, utilitarian responses to critical problems overseas (cleaner-burning stoves, a land-mine-removal suit) and at home (New York City's new Hoop bike rack, M.I.T.'s prototype for a lightweight electric city car). ''There's room for high-style design, but there also needs to be room for the rest of the world,'' says Matilda McQuaid, the museum's deputy curatorial director. But its definition of socially responsible has room for whimsical conceptualism (Interactive Institute's Energy Aware Clock, above), architectural grandiosity (Foster & Partners' sustainable city of Masdar in Abu Dhabi) and simple beauty (Heath Ceramics tableware). Even Twitter made the cut. ''People say the focus on socially responsible design is just because of the Wall Street crisis and isn't going to survive once things are back to normal,'' McQuaid says. ''I think it's here to stay.''

Rudolf Stingel has a lot on his plate these days - literally. The New York-based conceptual artist collaborated with Bernardaud, the French porcelain company, and the Art Production Fund's WOW (Works on Whatever) on a pair of luscious-looking dinner plates that are almost too beautiful to mar with a meal. The plates, which come in an edition of 2,500 in both black and white, are based on photographs of a wall relief that Stingel began in 2008. Fittingly, that project was inspired by the wallpaper in the dining room of his childhood home. Why make tableware? ''I like to eat,'' the artist says. ''And I like to look at my work - two birds, one stone.'' It's not the artist's first excursion into the everyday. In 2004, he famously swathed Grand Central Station's cavernous Vanderbilt Hall in floral carpeting. Impressive, of course. But this is one project he'll be able to dine out on for years. And at $98 each, so will you. Available at worksonwhatever.com and Bernardaud boutiques in New York and Chicago.

Janna Bullock, a Russian-born real estate developer who joined the board of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation in 2007, abruptly left that position two weeks ago to deal with a business dispute in Russia -- a conflict involving her husband, who was a regional finance official there, and a company connected to the former judo coach of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin. Ms. Bullock's departure from the board, which oversees the Guggenheim Museum, is the latest twist in an operatic life of a woman who immigrated from St. Petersburg, and worked as a nanny in Brooklyn before starting a New York real estate business that grew into a $2 billion company. Santa Clara Tables Toys with Fast-Food Meals | Happy meals were sad in Santa Clara County on Tuesday. Supervisors voted by 3-2 to prohibit restaurants from serving toys with meals packed with fat, sugar and calories. The ordinance, the nation's first such law, seeks to fight childhood obesity. The law's practical impact will be extremely limited, however, because it only applies to restaurants in the unincorporated areas of the county, like San Martin, Cambrian, Burbank and Stanford University. Before the toy ban takes effect, the board will vote to reaffirm the decision on May 11. [The San Jose Mercury News]

No superlatives will be used to describe the condition of the 1964 Aston Martin DB5 that will be offered at Bonhams's Monaco auction on Friday. In fact, Bonhams will dutifully point out that the automobile's paint is chipped and faded, the metal is rusted, the leather seats are ripped and cracked, and the filthy, corroded engine hasn't been started in two decades. Yet, this rusting hulk is expected to bring as much as $266,000.

COWLES--Allison Stacey. The President and Trustees of Columbia University in the City of New York express deep sorrow at the passing of Allison Stacey Cowles, wife of University Chair Emeritus, Arthur ("Punch") Sulzberger. A dear friend of the University and an influential advocate of education, culture, and conservation, her life of service was marked by exceptional insight and passion. Columbia University extends its profound sympathy to our friend and alumnus Punch and to the Sulzberger and Cowles families. Lee C. Bollinger, President of the University William V. Campbell, Chair of the Trustees

SIMON--Gerald F.,actor, of Port Washington, NY died April 23, 2010. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Dammarell. Loving father of Phillip, Tara, Will and Elizabeth Ann. Cherished brother of James and Edward Simon. Memorial Thursday, April 29 7-9pm at Knolls Funeral Home.

An article on March 28 about security plans for Tiger Woods's recent return to the professional golf tour misidentified the company that provides security services to Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia for the Masters tournament. Since 2004 it has been Securitas Security Services USA -- not Pinkerton's. The error first appeared on March 17 in an article on Woods's announcing his return to the PGA Tour.

WASHINGTON -- When President Obama approved a plan to withdraw combat forces from Iraq this summer, it was based on the assumption that a newly elected government would be in place by the time Americans headed home. Fourteen months later, that assumption is exploding but the plan remains the same. The delay and messy aftermath of the Iraqi election mean it may be months before the next government is formed, even as tens of thousands of American troops pack to leave. Yet Mr. Obama has not had a meeting on Iraq with his full national security team in months, and the White House insists that it has no plans to revisit the withdrawal timetable.

Please be advised that if you see Justin Bieber on his tour of the Southern Hemisphere do not attempt to apprehend him yourself, as he may be adorable -- and dangerous. One day after the seemingly harmless 16-year-old singer's planned appearance at Sydney Harbor in Australia led to pushing and shoving that forced the cancellation of the event, the authorities in New Zealand are taking no chances when Mr. Bieber brings his floppy hair to their country on Wednesday. The New Zealand Herald reported that Auckland Airport had increased its security in anticipation of Mr. Bieber's visit, and that his record label there is keeping his arrival time secret. A spokesman for the airport told The Herald, ''We are meeting with police and other airport security tomorrow morning to discuss the issue.'' An earlier appearance by Mr. Bieber at a Long Island mall in November resulted in a fan stampede and the arrest of his manager, Scott Braun.

Fighting to save a significant contract, General Electric and Rolls-Royce said on Tuesday that they had once again cut their prices in an offer to build alternate engines for the Pentagon's Joint Strike Fighter. The companies said they would build up to 150 engines at fixed prices, saving the government as much as $1 billion if a rival, Pratt & Whitney, matched the price.

O'SULLIVAN--John B.,died April 23 at his home in Washington, DC. He leaves behind his wife of 37 years, Susan, daughters Sarah and Kate, sister Chris, mother Sonya Schulberg O'Sullivan, son-in-law Jason McCullough, and countless friends. Born in Los Angeles in 1943, he spent his childhood in Washington, DC, Mamaroneck, NY, and Martha's Vineyard, MA. Following graduation from Riverdale Country School, he majored in the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton University, where he was an All-American fencer and a member of the 1964 NCAA championship team. John's keen interest in politics led him to join the national staff of Eugene McCarthy's 1968 presidential campaign and to become a senior organizer of the 1969 Vietnam Moratorium. He graduated from the NYU School of Law in 1970. During the Carter Administration, John was Chief Advisory Counsel at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. A nationally-recognized energy regulatory attorney, John was a long-time partner at Chadbourne & Parke LLP. A proud father, devoted husband, and generous friend, John will be greatly missed. John will be buried on Martha's Vineyard. A memorial service will be held in Washington, DC.

HIRSCH--Jacob. The faculty of the Department of Medicine of the New York University Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of our colleague, Jacob Hirsch. Dr. Hirsch, an alumnus of the School of Medicine (class of 1952), was a devoted teacher, physician, and colleague. He served as the Director of the Biomedical Engineering Training Program at NYU, and he was instrumental in applying computers to the interpretation of electrocardiograms. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Martin J. Blaser, M.D. Chair, Department of Medicine NYU Langone Medical Center

NATHANSON--Dr. Noel. The Board of Directors, Staff and Community of the Samuel Field YM & YWHA, Inc. mourn the loss of our beloved and esteemed Board member Dr. Noel "Buz" Nathanson. For over 30 years he selflessly devoted himself to the well being of others and to the mission of our agency. His vision and leadership was an inspiration to everyone who knew him. In every sense "Buz" was a model of generosity, kindness and integrity. While serving as our President and Chairman of the Board, he transformed the Y into the truly pervasive and highly respected community service agency it is today. His work will endure for many years to come, and he will always be remembered with gratitude, love and profound respect for his life that was filled with good deeds, acts of loving kindness and countless friends. We extend our thoughts and condolences to his devoted wife Susan, his children, Lisa and Jeff, Debbie and Victor and Gary, his grandchildren Brian, Alex, Daniel, Rachel, Sarah, Jacob, Talia and Kaylie and his sister Bobbie. Richard Tanenbaum, President Steven Goodman, Executive Vice President & CEO

JAFFRAY--Helen Zabriskie Lippincott, 89, died at home in Blue Hill, Maine on April 21. She was a church and civic leader, devoted mother of four and beloved wife of William J. Lippincott (deceased 1992) and James F. Jaffray. A memorial service will be held at 11am, May 3 at First Congregational Church, Blue Hill. Condolences may be sent to jordanfernald.com
RUFF--David Y. Loving husband of Betty, father of Leslie, grandfather of Emily and Daniel died peacefully on April 26, 2010.

GUMORA--Pearl, on April 27th at the age of 93. In memory of our mother, who only wanted to give and sought nothing in return. Living alone for so many years, yet so touching the lives of all who surrounded her family, friends and even casual acquaintances. "Grandma Gigi" took pride in her two daughters, Cheryl and Loni, sons-in-law Michael and Bill, her grandchildren Dani, Peter, Matthew and Joanna, their spouses John, Jeni, Kelly and Aaron, and her four great-grandchildren Hannah, Sarah, Jesse and George. She would have equally loved Samantha Paige, born just this week. Mommy, we will miss you dearly and remember always your style, keen eye, exquisite taste and demanding standards. Memorial contributions may be made to The Mount Sinai Hospital Department of Palliative Care.

NATHANSON--Noel, MD. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging the passing of Noel "Buzzy" Nathanson, MD, beloved brother of our dear friend and colleague, Bobbie Abrams, longtime member of the Continuum and Beth Israel Boards of Trustees. Noel served with great distinction on the Jacobi Medical Center-Albert Einstein College of Medicine faculty. With a vast oil slick now within only 20 miles of the ecologically fragile Louisiana coastline, Coast Guard officials said they were considering a ''controlled burn'' of the petroleum on the surface of the Gulf of Mexico. IT'S been 25 years since the New York City Board of Estimate, under Mayor Edward Koch's leadership, approved a plan to reduce the need for putting municipal garbage in landfills by developing facilities to burn it to create energy. At the same time, the city took the first steps toward creating a recycling program. Since then, disposal costs have risen faster than inflation, and the need to find better methods of getting rid of wastes is even greater. That fledgling recycling program evolved into the effective system the city has in place today, but no waste-to-energy plants were ever built. Instead, in 2001, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani closed the city's last remaining landfill, and since then the city has sent every pound of nonrecycled municipally collected trash out of the city -- about 15 percent of it to a waste-to-energy plant in Newark, but most of it to destinations in western Pennsylvania, eastern Ohio, Virginia and South Carolina. In such places, New York's waste despoils the landscape at a rate of 140 acres a year.

WASHINGTON -- Politicians like nothing more than a convenient foil, and Democrats locked in a stubborn impasse with Republicans over new rules to govern Wall Street believe they have found a gold-plated one in Goldman Sachs. Democrats say the convergence of their push for an overhaul of financial regulation and a prominent federal securities case against the prestigious investment firm is a matter of coincidence, not planning.

LONDON -- BP, the British oil company, said Tuesday that its profit more than doubled in the first quarter, helped by higher oil prices. Profit rose to $6.08 billion from $2.56 billion in the first quarter of last year. The results beat some analyst expectation, setting the tone for other large oil companies, including Exxon Mobil and Chevron, that are reporting later this week.

BROIDO--Sally Frowenfeld. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of our dear mother and grandmother, Sally Frowenfeld Broido on Sunday, April 25, 2010. Sally was predeceased by her mother, Frances Moschcowitz Frowenfeld, her father Percy Morgan Frowenfeld, her dear sister Ellin Frowenfeld Ente and her beloved husband Theodore K. Broido. She is survived by her loving daughters Katie (Paul) Pearlman, Emily (Eugene) Chadbourne, and Peg Munves (Moy Wong). She is also survived by her devoted grandchildren Louie Pearlman and Jenny, Molly, and Elisabeth Chadbourne, and by her niece Chrystie Munves (Peter Plaue), her nephews Stephen and Douglas Ente, and her step-children Bill, Andrea, Tommy, and Steven Broido, and countless devoted friends. Sally was the president of the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, and was on the board of numerous organizations, including the Kaufmann Center, Hebrew Union College, and the Stecher and Horowitz Foundation and was a member of the Harmonie Club and the Lotos Club, and Temple Emanu-El. Sally had a love of learning which never ended. She greatly enjoyed the symphony, the ballet, the opera, music of all kinds, Broadway musicals and theater, and Jeopardy. Her greatest passion was traveling, which she began in 1960 with her dear uncle and pioneering doctor, Eli Moschcowitz. Over her lifetime she traveled to every continent except for Australia, returning with amazing stories of monkeys in India, seeing the penguins in Antarctica, and her favorite place, Alaska. On her travels she made many good friends who have remained close to her over the years. Our mother's acerbic wit and joy for life will be greatly missed by all of us and her many friends. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the charity of your choice. Funeral services will be at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St, New York, NY on Wednesday, April 28th at 11:15am. Private burial to follow. The family will receive friends on Thursday, April 29 from 4-7pm at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th St.

GUERRAND-HERMES--Mathias, beloved son, father and brother, dies at age 38 in Paris, France. Mathias passed away surrounded by his family, of heart complications due to cancer. Mathias, who split his life between Paris and New York, touched everyone with his kindness, generosity, and big heart. Mathias worked at Metropole Realty where he was instrumental in restoring a neglected 1912 McKim Mead and White building on Fifth Avenue and 54th Street in Manhattan to its former glory and acquiring a luxury retail real estate portfolio. Preceeding this he founded his own investment capital firm, Blue Growth Capital, and started his career at Alex Brown. Mathias was a lover of the outdoors, sports, skiing, nature, and horses. A fine horseman, he was awarded the Gold Medal of the French National Academy of Sports, and European Polo Champion. Mathias is survived by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Guerrand-Hermes, his children, Lucien, Clea, Anna-Lou, his brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Olaf Guerrand-Hermes. A funeral service will be held in his memory at the Temple Reforme de l'Etoile, 56 Avenue de la Grande Armee, Paris, Wednesday 28 April at 11 o'clock.

It was a silent call to arms: an easy-to-overlook message urging New Jersey students to take a stand against the budget cuts that threaten class sizes and choices as well as after-school activities. But some 18,000 students accepted the invitation posted last month on Facebook, the social media site better known for publicizing parties and sporting events. And on Tuesday many of them -- and many others -- walked out of class in one of the largest grass-roots demonstrations to hit New Jersey in years. The protest disrupted classroom routines and standardized testing in some of the state's biggest and best-known school districts, offering a real-life civics lesson that unfolded on lawns, sidewalks, parking lots and football fields.

MCALOON--Paul Francis, on April 25, 2010, at age 61. Beloved husband of Rose, loving father of Sean and Alex, cherished brother of Anne, uncle of Vanessa, Christopher, Julia and David. Paul survived a battle with polio as an infant and as a result relied on crutches and braces from the time he could walk. He refused to let his disability define or limit him in any way. He was valedictorian of his high school, a Presidential Scholar and National Merit Scholar, finished Trinity College in three years and graduated from Columbia Law School. He was appellate counsel to the Bar for nearly 30 years and appeared before the Appellate Division, First and Second Departments, routinely. He appeared before the New York Court of Appeals and the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit, many times as well. Paul and Rose were married 38 years until her untimely passing last year. Paul was an inspiration to his sons who loved him immensely and will miss him dearly, just as he was an inspiration to all who had the privilege to know him. Reposing at "The Riverside" 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave, New York City, Thursday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral services Friday, 10am. Interment Greenwood Cemetery.

"While it's normal to feel cold when you step outside on a winter's day without a jacket, the feeling of cold comes way too easily for sufferers of Raynaud's," writes Winnie Yu in The Times Health Guide: "When Cold Fingers Mean Raynaud's, or Worse." "Holding a cup of yogurt, strolling through the freezer section of the supermarket, even touching a glass of water can turn fingers a mottled mix of white and blue and create chills normally reserved for the iciest exposures." And while Raynaud's is just a minor nuisance for the great majority of sufferers, for a small minority, coldness in the fingers and toes is a prelude to a more serious ailment like lupus or scleroderma.

A new rule to protect airline passengers from being held on a plane on the tarmac for too long went into effect today. The rule, issued by the Department of Transportation, was announced in December after a series of cases on various airlines left passengers stranded on the tarmac for hours without being able to get off and, in some cases, without food, water or working toilets. In one case, 47 passengers were trapped overnight on a Continental Airlines flight in August 2009 after thunderstorms forced the plane to divert to Rochester, Minn.

Once upon a time, Goldman Sachs' raison d'etre was to serve the ongoing needs of its clients and be paid fees for helping them raise capital, trade blocks of stock or by providing merger and acquisition advice, a business strategy that made the firm for years the envy of Wall Street and immensely profitable. This strategy forced Goldman's bankers to be "long-term greedy"  a shopworn phrase coined by a former senior partner, Gus Levy  and to do everything possible to stay in their clients' good graces in order to have a legitimate shot at the next fee. While it was not exactly backbreaking  or the Lord's  work, from one year to the next nothing was assured unless the Goldman partnership maintained that fragile bond of trust.

While the days of the printed newspaper may be numbered, it continues to inspire a generation of ... playground equipment designers. That's right. On Wednesday, the Parks Department unveiled a new jungle gym at Printers Park in the Bronx that is shaped like the first rotary printing press, invented in 1846 by Richard March Hoe, whose former estate the park now occupies and who lent his name to Hoe Avenue, the street that runs by the park, in the Longwood neighborhood. It is part of a $1 million overhaul of the park, made possible through City Councilwoman Maria del Carmen Arroyo.

The Gowanus neighborhood of Brooklyn, the city's latest industrial desert turned cultural outpost, makes for a pleasant afternoon's wander. The namesake canal, while it holds tons of poisonous stuff, is serene and calming. Things still do get a little post-apocalyptic: the weird drone of a cement factory, wide empty streets dotted with used condoms, a lone cormorant perched on the bank of a Superfund site. But with its historic bridges, canoeing club, low-slung buildings and growing selection of restaurants (Ethiopian, anyone?), Gowanus is laid-back and friendly. And markedly accessible: Jump off the B, D, M, N, Q, R, 2, 3, 4 or 5 trains at the Atlantic/Pacific station and head down Fourth Avenue from the Williamsburgh Savings Bank tower to start your day in big-sky country.

It was 43 years ago today, give or take, that a series of real-life events and everyday occurrences, including a newspaper article about the numerous potholes in the British town of Blackburn, Lancashire, inspired John Lennon and Paul McCartney to write what would become the final song on "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band" and one of the Beatles' best-known recordings. And for a sum that could probably pay for the restoration of more than a few bumpy British roads, Lennon's original handwritten lyrics for his part of "A Day in the Life" could be yours: Reuters reported that at an auction on June 18 Sotheby's would sell the single sheet of paper on which  Lennon composed his verses, starting with the famous line, "I read the news today, oh boy."

In my New York Times column this morning, I reviewed cellphone apps that prevent you from calling, texting or e-mailing when you're driving. I noted that they're far from perfect solutions. For one thing, they work only on BlackBerrys and Android phones, which is, at this point, a tiny percentage of all phones. And they can't distinguish between the motion of you, the driver, and the motion of you, a passenger in someone else's car or even on a train or a bus.

In the debate over financial reform, the Senate G.O.P. seems to be proceeding the way Democrats and a large swathe of the chattering class wanted them to proceed on health care reform. For most of the way, they've been the party of "yes, if ..." rather than the party of no, using the limited powers of the minority to ease the bill in their direction, rather than trying to defeat it outright. As a result, it seems likely that "FinReg" will pass with more than a few G.O.P. votes, having been amended in ways that address at least some conservative concerns. You can chalk this compromise up to pure political self-interest - financial reform is much more popular than health care reform and everybody knows it - or to the fact that the ideological stakes are lower on these issues than they were on health care. But either way, the Republicans have behaved extremely "responsibly" on the issue, at least as the Beltway consensus defines "responsible."
