My first experience with a business group came about 20 years ago, when I tried to assemble my own. In theory, it seems like this should be an easy thing to do. It's not. It is very hard to find enough people to get a group going -- even if you're not charging anything. And even if you do get it going, it can be difficult to keep it going. It feels like a full-time job because it is a full-time job - one that I wasn't very good at and didn't have time to do. My do-it-yourself group lasted less than a year and did not have the benefit of the resources that professional groups have, including the ability to recruit new members.

SAN JOSE, Calif. (AP) -- California geology officials have released an updated seismic map that includes more than 50 new fault lines discovered over the last two decades. The officials hope the map, which had not been updated since 1994, will improve earthquake preparedness and construction decisions. The map was unveiled Tuesday at the Tech Museum in San Jose as the California Geological Survey celebrated its 150th anniversary. The Geological Survey also presented an updated version of a second map that identifies the makeup of rock and soil.

The Bloomberg administration is moving ahead with what amounts to a radical, river-to-river reimagining of another major corridor: 34th Street Automobiles would be banned on the block between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, creating a pedestrian plaza. The intent is to create more space for pedestrians and to speed up bus trips on the street's crosstown routes, which are among the slowest in the city. The New York Times, April 23, 2010City Room looked into its crystal ball. This is what we saw: May 25, 2010:Promising to speed commutes by more than 80 percent, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Assistant Transportation Commissioner Philippe Petit unveiled a network of crosstown tightrope lanes and zip-line stations Tuesday. ''Wheeeeeee,'' the mayor declared, seconds before cutting a rope he mistook for a ribbon. Mr. Petit escaped serious injury.

You win a bet, but the loser does not have enough cash on him to settle it. If he has a credit card, and most people usually do, there is finally a solution. A number of big and small companies -- including eBay's PayPal unit, Intuit, VeriFone and Square -- are creating innovative ways for individuals to avoid cash and checks and settle all debts, public and private, using their cellphones. Several of the companies have developed small credit card scanners that plug into a cellphone and for a small fee enable any individual or small business to turn a phone into a credit card processing terminal. PayPal's cellphone app calls for only a simple bump of two cellphones to transfer money. Apple has submitted a patent application for a cellphone payment system.

AGING ANTI-AGERS Makeup spoils. From the moment a mascara or a face cream that contains plant-derived substances is opened, it is a petri dish for bacteria. But stickers like these from Beauty Alert ($8.50 for 24) can help keep track of when it's time to say goodbye, as can the labels in the Once Opened Beauty Expiration Kit ($9.95 for 24). They can be found respectively at beautyalert.biz and at onceopened.com. Consult the Food and Drug Administration Web site for ballpark estimates of the shelf life of cosmetics.

A picture on April 20 with the Big City column, about efforts to reduce Caesarean sections, showed Dr. Mitchell A. Maiman, the chairman of the obstetrics and gynecology department at Staten Island University Hospital, at his job. But the woman in the picture with Dr. Maiman, who does not offer elective Caesarean sections, was not his patient and the situation was posed. Under The Times's guidelines, pictures of news situations should not be staged. Had editors known the details, the picture would not have been used.

PHOENIX -- Arizona is well accustomed to the derision of its countrymen. The state resisted adopting Martin Luther King's birthday as a holiday years after most other states embraced it. The sheriff in its largest county forces inmates to wear pink underwear, apparently to assault their masculinity. Residents may take guns almost anywhere, but they may not cut down a cactus. The rest of the nation may scoff or grumble, but Arizona, one of the last truly independent Western outposts, carries on.

Joni Mitchell used to sing that ''you don't know what you've got 'til it's gone.'' And in the world of electronic gadgets, you don't know what you've been missing until you get something new. While my Bose SoundDock has been serving me well for six years, I didn't realize how much better iPod music could sound on a device that size until I tried out the new Harman Kardon Go and Play Micro dock.

If you shoot a lot of video or snap huge amounts of RAW digital photos, you've probably heard about the SanDisk Ultra 64-gigabyte memory card. The card uses the new SDXC format, which will enable memory card makers to achieve huge capacities of up to 2 terabytes. For now, 64 gigabytes is the highest capacity card on the market. SanDisk sent me a loaner, and I put it through some real-world tests to evaluate its performance against other SD cards. The 64-gigabyte card costs $240 at Amazon, and that's not exactly an impulse buy. But is it worth it?

BENNETT--Jack Franklin, of John's Island, Vero Beach, Florida, died peacefully in Greenwich, Connecticut on April 25, 2010 after a year-long battle with cancer. He had lived in Greenwich on and off for nearly 50 years before moving to Florida. He also maintained a summer residence in York, Maine. Mr. Bennett was born in Macon, Georgia on January 17, 1924 to Andrew Jackson Bennett and Mary Eloise Franklin Bennett. He graduated from Yale University in the war-shortened Class of 1945 and served as a U.S Navy Lieutenant (j.g.) on the destroyer U.S.S. Boggs in the Pacific during World War II. He worked in post-war Germany alongside his father who, as Financial Advisor to the U.S. Military Commander of Germany, was the principal administrator of the Deutschemark currency reform that reignited the German economy. On his return from Germany, he earned a Ph.D. in Economics from Harvard University in 1951. Mr. Bennett later moved to Washington, DC where he served in the War Department, the State Department, and the Executive Office of the President, and as the Economist on two Presidential Commissions, including the Fairless Committee on Mutual Security which focused on U.S. - foreign economic policy. In 1955, Mr. Bennett joined the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and worked for its successor Exxon Corporation for over 30 years in New York, London, and Houston. From 1975 to 1989, he was Chief Financial Officer, Senior Vice President and a Director of Exxon. During his tenure at Exxon, the Company became well known for its pioneering use of various financial innovations, including bond defeasance, shelf registrations, sale of Company securities by Dutch auction and large-scale repurchases of company shares. He also served as a Director of the Discount Corporation, the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, Philips Electronics N.V., Dean Witter Mutual Funds and Tandem Computers, Inc. From 1971 to 1975, Mr. Bennett served at the U.S. Treasury in Washington, DC under Secretaries John Connolly, George Schultz and William Simon. He succeeded Paul Volcker as Undersecretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, serving in that role from 1974 to 1975. His work was instrumental to the implementation of the global movement to currency exchange systems based on floating exchange rates and the dismantling of U.S. controls over international capital flows. He also introduced the use of Dutch auctions in the sale of U.S. Treasury securities (still used today). He was awarded the Alexander Hamilton Medal by Secretary Schulz. He was an active Member of the Council on Foreign Relations, a Trustee of the Committee for Economic Development, and a member of the Bilderburg Group for which he also served as Chairman of the U.S. Friends of Bilderberg. He was a member of the University Club (New York, NY), the Stanwich Club (Greenwich, CT), the Blind Brook Club (Purchase, NY), the John's Island Club (Vero Beach, FL) and the York Harbor Reading Room and York Golf and Tennis Club (York, ME). He was predeceased by his wife of 56 years, Shirley Elizabeth Goodwin of Sunderland, Massachusetts. He is survived by three sons and a daughter, and their spouses: Jackson Goodwin (Win) and Rosanah Bennett of Greenwich, Connecticut; Philip D. and Lisa Bennett of London, England; Hugh F. and Kim Bennett of Winchester, Massachusetts; and Fraser Bennett Beede and Robert Beede of Greenwich, Connecticut, as well as by seven grandchildren. He will be remembered for his devotion to his family, his wonderful sense of humor and his innovative approach to business, economic and monetary issues. He loved to play golf and horseshoes with his family and friends. While working on his personal memoirs, he also published in 2009 a book titled Physics Doesn't Need to be That Difficult. Funeral services are private. A memorial reception is planned for a future date.

An article on Tuesday about accusations of criminal conduct at a Paris auction house, the Hôtel Drouot, misstated the charges against a dozen people who were arrested in the case. They were accused of ''criminal association, theft and possession of stolen goods in an organized band,'' according to French media reports. They were not charged with conspiracy to commit fraud, as the unattributed reference in the article said. (The French police did not report the charges.)

SEOUL, South Korea -- On Friday, President Lee Myung-bak will travel to China under growing pressure at home to make the case for crucial Chinese support for tough international sanctions against North Korea if, as is widely expected, the North is found responsible for the sinking of a South Korean ship. But he is unlikely to win that support, experts say, a reflection of China's growing role in the Korean Peninsula. Since taking office in 2008, Mr. Lee has wound down his predecessors' ''sunshine policy'' of aid and engagement with the North, heightening Chinese fears of instability and driving the North into China's economic embrace. Ultimately, that could give Beijing greater leverage in determining the fate of the northern half of the Korean Peninsula, a situation that many South Koreans would consider to be a nightmare.

HIRSCH--Jacob I.,MD, a member of New York University's Division of Cardiology for many years, died on Tuesday, April 20th, after a long bout with rheumatoid arthritis. He was 83. Dr. Hirsch received his undergraduate degree at Brooklyn College and his MD from NYU in 1952. Subsequently, Dr. Hirsch held various positions including consultant in Internal Medicine at the Manhattan VA Hospital, Chief of the Electrocardiography Lab at Bellevue Hospital, Medical Director at Bellevue Hospital Biomedical Engineering Department as well as Bellevue's School of Nursing, Associate Professor of Medicine and Associate Attending Physician in the Department of Medicine at New York University. In addition, Dr. Hirsch was appointed as Honorary Cardiologist for the Police Department of the City of New York, and as the Chair of the NYPD Article 2 Medical Board. Other notable appointments include Chair of the Instrumentation Section for the New York Academy of Sciences, Chair of the Group on Engineering in Medicine and Biology, New York Chapter of the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers, and various committees for the National Institute of Health. Dr. Hirsch was a member of the Alpha Omega Alpha Honor Society, Sigma Xi, the Harvey Society, the American Federation for Clinical Research, the Society for Experimental Biology and Medicine, and was a Fellow of the American College of Physicians and American College of Cardiology. Dr. Hirsch enjoyed traveling, gardening, repairing antique clocks, and was an avid SCUBA diver. More notably, he was a master photographer who won numerous awards in exhibitions and photography contests on Long Island. Dr. Hirsch's wife, Gloria, passed away in May of 2009. He is survived by his three children, Robert, Russell, and Laurel, his two daughters-in-law, Shauna, and Daria, and his four grandchildren, Nicole, Natalie, Giancarlo, Elena, and his sister Judy Weston. A celebration of Dr. Hirsch's life will be held on Saturday, the first of May, between the hours of 2-6pm, at: The Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture 53 Prospect Park West Brooklyn, NY 11215.

Robert Natkin, a painter who rose to prominence in the late 1960s and 1970s with work that blended Abstraction with Post-Impressionist colors, died on April 20 in Danbury, Conn. He was 79 and lived in Redding, Conn. The cause was a bacterial blood infection that developed during a hospital stay after a fall, said his wife, Judith Dolnick.

An article in some editions on April 4 about a ruling by New York State that the Indian Point nuclear power plant violates the federal Clean Water Act referred imprecisely to the portion of the electricity used by New York and Westchester County that the plant provides. It is up to 30 percent, but can be considerably less depending on the time of year and which other power plants are working; it is not always 30 percent. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated, in some copies, the year the plant opened. It was 1962, not 1973.

If there's one thing that's guaranteed to make me feel like a dope, it's when I can't remember where I parked my car. And based on the number of products that are designed to help in this situation, I'm not the only one with the problem. You can always find your car if you push the alarm button on your key's remote control, which is found on most contemporary vehicles. But that only works if you're within 10 or 20 yards of your car. How do you find your car when you're really far away, and have no idea where you parked?
SIMMONS--Wiley. Announcing the passing of our beloved Wiley Simmons, April 23, 2010. Services Saturday, May 1, 2010, 10am, Central Baptist Church, 166 W. 92nd St., NY.

GUMORA--Pearl, on April 27th at the age of 93. In memory of our mother, who only wanted to give and sought nothing in return. Living alone for so many years, yet so touching the lives of all who surrounded her family, friends and even casual acquaintances. "Grandma Gigi" took pride in her two daughters, Cheryl and Loni, sons-in-law Michael and Bill, her grandchildren Dani, Peter, Matthew and Joanna, their spouses John, Jeni, Kelly and Aaron, and her four great-grandchildren Hannah, Sarah, Jesse and George. She would have equally loved Samantha Paige, born just this week. Mommy, we will miss you dearly and remember always your style, keen eye, exquisite taste and demanding standards. Memorial contributions may be made to The Mount Sinai Hospital Department of Palliative Care.

GUMORA--Pearl. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Pearl Gumora, beloved mother of Cheryl Minikes and mother-in-law of Michael Minikes, who express an admirable commitment to strengthening the Jewish community. We extend our deepest condolences to Pearl's children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and entire family. John M. Shapiro, President; Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

OESTREICHER--Irma. On April 27, in her 89th year, from Lymphona, at her home, with her family. Born July 4th 1920 to Barnett and Dora Kaplan. Married 1943 to Martin Shapiro and had two children, Robert (Jacqueline) and Daniel (Lynne). In 1958 married Gerard Oestreicher and was a wonderful stepmother to his three children, Lee (Alejandra), Lynn (Noel Jeffrey), and Laurie (Larry Lowenstein). Adored her grandchildren, Holiday Shapiro (Robyn Linde), Brett Haussamen (Jim Sabo), Gerard Jeffrey, Jay Lowenstein (Jayme), Victoria Shapiro (Jon Forsberg), Abi Shapiro, and Caitlin Shapiro (Rowan Gay). Found renewed joy in her great-grandchildren, Evan, Sophie, Kara, and Ava. In later life she was grateful for the companionship of Dan Rodgers. She is survived by her brother Bill Kaplan (Anita). She was raised (forever proud) in Brooklyn, graduated Erasmus High School and Hunter College. She lived in New Rochelle and in 1958 moved to Manhattan (her true home). Her second husband, Gerard Oestreicher, was the chairman of Oestreicher Realty and a Broadway producer. He died in 1987. Irma became a Broadway angel and then a producer in her own right. She produced "Cantorial", "Mademoiselle Colombe", and co-produced "Long Day's Journey Into Night" for which she received a Tony nomination. She was a director of the American Theatre Hall of Fame. Active until her last few months she devoted herself to her family, her many friends, the Theatre, her charities, the Democratic Party, books, bridge, and crosswords. She will be sorely missed by many who loved her keen intellect and tremendous wit, her generosity and her loyalty. The family will receive at the home of Lynn and Noel Jeffrey, 33 East 70th Street, Sunday, May 2nd between 4-8pm. Services will be Monday, May 3rd at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, followed by a reception at the Jeffreys'. In lieu of flowers, please consider a contribution to the Democratic candidate of your choice.

HESS--Norma. The Glaucoma Foundation was deeply saddened by the death of Norma Hess, a longtime generous supporter of our programs to eradicate blindness from Glaucoma. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Robert Ritch, M.D., Founder Gregory K. Harmon, M.D., Chairman Maurice H. Luntz, M.D., Board Member Scott R. Christensen, President & CEO

VOS--Frank, 90, died on April 19. Resident of Stamford, Connecticut. Graduated from New Rochelle High School in 1936, attended the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In World War II he served in the U.S. Army as an Infantry First Lieutenant, earning a Bronze Star. In 1951 he married Mary Catherine Dempsey of Philadelphia. A pioneer in the direct marketing industry and one of its most effective innovators, he founded Frank Vos & Co. in 1957, a direct marketing advertising agency in New York City. He sold it in 1986 to The Interpublic Group and enrolled in Columbia University, where he earned a B.A and an M.A. in American History. He was inducted into the Phi Beta Kappa Society. Avid skier and sailboat racer, he was also a licensed pilot for twin engine aircraft and held his instrument rating. Member of The Lotos Club in New York City since 1958. He is survived by his wife Mary Catherine Vos of Stamford, Connecticut, his brother Eugene Vos of Tivoli, New York, his son George Vos of Stamford, his daughter Julie Lindsey of New York City and five grandchildren: Ellis and Mary Lindsey of New York City, and Kate, Julia and Connor Vos of Stamford. Contributions may be made to The Friends of Nathaniel Witherell, Inc., 70 Parsonage Road, Greenwich, CT 06830.

An article in some editions on Tuesday about the discovery of the body of Laura Garza, a Brooklyn woman who was reported missing in 2008 after leaving a nightclub in Manhattan, referred incorrectly at one point to the status of the main suspect in the case, Michael Mele. As noted elsewhere in the article, he is serving one to three years in prison for violating probation -- not parole -- in an unrelated case. The article also misstated, in some copies, the location from which Ivan Garza, Ms. Garza's brother, spoke during a phone interview. He was at his mother's home in McAllen, Tex. -- not in Monterrey, Mexico.

Attention amateur butchers, meat lovers and hungry aesthetes: At the Paul Kasmin Gallery, the artist Mark Ryden is doing wonders with off cuts at his new show, "The Gay '90s: Olde Tyme Art Show." The paintings of a Gibson girl riding a bicycle built for two with Jesus and a brooding beauty in period finery are spooky and lovely, but it's his meatier images that steal the show - a wispy girl in a gown of hams, hindquarters and sausages, or Abraham Lincoln grinding fresh chuck for a tea-drinking demoiselle. Surreally delicious.

This woman is walking down the street ahead of me, ordinary looking, but as she passes, every male head swivels. I can almost see dotted lines streaming from popping eyes to bobbing cheeks. And then I think, Of course, buttocks are the new breasts. Every culture and every time has its template for the ideal female form. Here in the United States, after more than 50 years of breast fixation, the bottom has come into its own. Jennifer Lopez's generous seat probably started the trend, but it doesn't take a degree in anthropology to tie a bottom heavy silhouette to the ascendance of African-American and Hispanic influence in entertainment (e.g., that hip-hop classic ''Baby Got Back'').

Carbon capture and storage, or C.C.S., is shorthand for a complex technology to remove carbon dioxide from power plant emissions and store it (for a few millenniums at least) somewhere other than the atmosphere. With coal-fired power plants accountable for roughly 40 percent of the world's carbon emissions, it's a long-sought-after solution to the looming threat of climate change.

Swiss justice officials said on Friday that they did not require access to the sealed testimony of a prosecutor involved in the sex case against the director Roman Polanski, even though lawyers for the filmmaker have said the testimony was needed for the officials to rule on his possible extradition to the United States. On Thursday, Mr. Polanski's American lawyers filed a motion in Los Angeles County Superior Court seeking the sealed testimony of Roger Gunson, a retired deputy district attorney, about a sentencing plan devised by Judge Laurence J. Rittenband. Mr. Polanski pleaded guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl but fled the United States in 1978 before he could be sentenced by Judge Rittenband, who died in 1993.

No doubt there will be some talk, in the wake of Charlie Crist's completely unsurprising decision to run for Florida's Senate seat as an independent, about how this shows that the intolerant Tea Party spirit is driving moderates out of the Republican Party. As I've argued before, this is exactly the wrong way to look at the case of Charlie Crist. The Florida governor may be a moderate in some sense, but his real loyalties are to cynicism, self-interest (though this time, I'm pretty sure that he's misjudged where those interests lie), and the persistent pursuit of the budgetary free lunch.  At a time when the country desperately needs politicians who are equipped to make tough choices, Crist's record suggests that he's the last person that anyone - conservative or liberal - should want to see in a position of responsibility in Washington D.C.

The conventional wisdom is that Senator Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas, up for re-election this fall, is one of several Democrats in danger of losing her seat. But right now, a Republican opponent is the least of her worries. I admit I have a thing about golf rain suits. What I find most amazing about rain suits is that so few golfers have one. And I concede, I was one of those golfers who spent years trying to make due with a heavy windbreaker and lots of towels. Then I got a rain suit made for golf and wondered why I had been torturing myself. A lot of golfers will think nothing of spending $100 to play golf for one day but won't spend $400 on a quality rain suit that might last 10 years and allow them to enjoy 40 more golf rounds when it's raining. So think of it as an extra $10 for every round it rains. You spend that on a hot dog and drink at the turn.

Jacqueline Byrne developed the creative teaching techniques that form the basis of the academic and verbal test prep curricula at Ivy Educational Services. Her SAT prep book, "SAT Vocabulary Express" (McGraw Hill, 2004), introduces students to a new strategy for improving their functional vocabulary and raising their SAT and ACT verbal scores. In addition, Ms. Byrne designed Ivy Educational Services' college essay writing program.

The World's Fair may have lost the luster it brought decades ago to world capitals like Paris. But China has dusted off the concept in an attempt to give its second city, Shanghai, the same coming-out party that the 2008 Summer Olympic Games were for Beijing.

Now that the major training is completed and we are only a day from the big race, many of the starters will have started to focus on the finer details of race preparation, which includes schooling both in the starting gate and in the paddock. It is really important that a horse is as relaxed as possible as it prepares for its race, and schooling helps with this. When I worked for Steve Asmussen, we paddock-schooled every horse before each of its races, and we gate-schooled every horse once a week. With a race as important as the Kentucky Derby, those activities take on a greater significance.

The photographer Francesca Woodman had all the markings of becoming the next big art star: precocious talent, beauty, charisma and a driving ambition and a work ethic to match. The trajectory of her life, however, followed an all-too-familiar story line: the artist who died too young. "The Woodmans," a new film about her and her family, took the top prize for the best New York documentary on Thursday night and is screening Saturday at the Tribeca Film Festival.

3:18 p.m. | Updated MIAMI -- Florida's eye-catching Senate race has just received another entertaining addition. Jeff Greene - a billionaire who bet against the housing market and whose friends include Heidi Fleiss, the Hollywood madam, and the boxer Mike Tyson, who was the best man at his wedding - announced today that he was entering the race as a Democrat.
The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania held its 12th annual business plan competition on Wednesday. Eight finalists were selected from the 231 teams that applied.

Arts advocates in Los Angeles are pushing back against new efforts by city officials to sap the funding streams that keep their organizations alive, The Los Angeles Times reported. They have flooded city hall voice-mail and e-mail in-boxes to oppose a proposal by Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa to redirect $415,000 in arts grants from groups that qualified under a standard competitive application process to four groups of his choosing. The proposal was part of the mayor's budget recommendations, which call for a nearly 25 percent cut in city arts spending. They were presented to the City Council on April 20 and were reviewed by the council's budget and finance committee on Thursday.

A new rule to protect airline passengers from being held on a plane on the tarmac for too long went into effect Thursday. The rule, issued by the Department of Transportation, was announced in December after a series of cases on various airlines left passengers stranded on the tarmac for hours.

Excuse an utterly self-interested comment from a scribbler about reporters protecting confidential sources. You see, this was an ongoing point of contention during the Bush administration. Prosecutors sought to subpoena reporters to find their confidential sources, and courts then threatened to throw them in prison if they refused to reveal those sources. We had thought that the Obama administration would be different, a little less likely to want to menace and jail journalists. But, alas, the Obama Justice Department has now issued a subpoena for my Times colleague James Risen (although it's for a book he wrote, not for material that appeared in the Times). Speaking obviously just for myself, not for my institution, I find this utterly disappointing. The Washington Post article writes:

For art lovers, almost nothing equals the thrill of discovering what goes on behind the scenes in the studio. With that in mind, artists who live in Havelock Walk, a mews in southeast London, began opening their studios to the public nine years ago, providing visitors an opportunity to view art --and the artist -- in their natural state. This year's Open Studio weekends are scheduled for May 8 to 9 and 15 to 16.

Plans for a New Face on San Francisco's Eastern Edge |Today, the Hunters Point Naval Shipyard, now idle for more than 35 years, looks like a ghost town. Buildings stand empty. The few people on the property are involved in the continuing cleanup or are among the sculptors, painters and photographers who created an improbable artists' colony in some of the shipyard buildings. But a crucial decision is facing the Board of Supervisors in a few weeks. It will open - or close - the door to the Lennar Corporation's $7 billion redevelopment plan for the 770-acre site, one that would include 10,500 homes, large amounts of retail and commercial space and even new accommodations for the artists' colony. The development project is headed by Kofi Bonner, a vice president at Lennar who spearheaded the redevelopment of Emeryville, which, like Hunter's Point, was plagued by toxic waste. Mr. Bonner served as San Francisco's economic development director under Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. during the 1990s.Wine on Tap | At Frances, the restaurant in San Francisco's Castro neighborhood getting all the buzz these days, customers pay by the ounce for the wine they drink. But that is not the only difference from the way most of the city's other eateries handle their drinks. The beverage director, Paul Einbund, blends the house wines -creating unconventional blends from the fruits of the Sierra foothills - himself, after they are brought from the wineries in kegs.

For the second time in less than six months, Random House, the world's largest publisher of trade books, announced a significant restructuring of its Crown Publishing Group, the division that produces books by President Obama, Deepak Chopra and Cesar Millan and that will release former President George W. Bush's forthcoming memoir. Most notably, the company said that Shaye Areheart, who publishes Mr. Chopra and Mr. Millan and who famously worked with Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis to edit ''Moonwalk,'' Michael Jackson's autobiography, will step down as publisher of both Shaye Areheart and Harmony Books. The Shaye Areheart imprint is also being shut down.

BENNETT--Jack Franklin, of John's Island, Vero Beach, Florida, died peacefully in Greenwich, Connecticut on April 25, 2010 after a year-long battle with cancer. He had lived in Greenwich on and off for nearly 50 years before moving to Florida. He also maintained a summer residence in York, Maine. Mr. Bennett was born in Macon, Georgia on January 17, 1924 to Andrew Jackson Bennett and Mary Eloise Franklin Bennett. He graduated from Yale University in the war-shortened Class of 1945 and served as a U.S Navy Lieutenant (j.g.) on the destroyer U.S.S. Boggs in the Pacific during World War II. He worked in post-war Germany alongside his father who, as Financial Advisor to the U.S. Military Commander of Germany, was the principal administrator of the Deutschemark currency reform that reignited the German economy. On his return from Germany, he earned a Ph.D. in Economics from Harvard University in 1951. Mr. Bennett later moved to Washington, DC where he served in the War Department, the State Department, and the Executive Office of the President, and as the Economist on two Presidential Commissions, including the Fairless Committee on Mutual Security which focused on U.S. - foreign economic policy. In 1955, Mr. Bennett joined the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and worked for its successor Exxon Corporation for over 30 years in New York, London, and Houston. From 1975 to 1989, he was Chief Financial Officer, Senior Vice President and a Director of Exxon. During his tenure at Exxon, the Company became well known for its pioneering use of various financial innovations, including bond defeasance, shelf registrations, sale of Company securities by Dutch auction and large-scale repurchases of company shares. He also served as a Director of the Discount Corporation, the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, Philips Electronics N.V., Dean Witter Mutual Funds and Tandem Computers, Inc. From 1971 to 1975, Mr. Bennett served at the U.S. Treasury in Washington, DC under Secretaries John Connolly, George Schultz and William Simon. He succeeded Paul Volcker as Undersecretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, serving in that role from 1974 to 1975. His work was instrumental to the implementation of the global movement to currency exchange systems based on floating exchange rates and the dismantling of U.S. controls over international capital flows. He also introduced the use of Dutch auctions in the sale of U.S. Treasury securities (still used today). He was awarded the Alexander Hamilton Medal by Secretary Schulz. He was an active Member of the Council on Foreign Relations, a Trustee of the Committee for Economic Development, and a member of the Bilderburg Group for which he also served as Chairman of the U.S. Friends of Bilderberg. He was a member of the University Club (New York, NY), the Stanwich Club (Greenwich, CT), the Blind Brook Club (Purchase, NY), the John's Island Club (Vero Beach, FL) and the York Harbor Reading Room and York Golf and Tennis Club (York, ME). He was predeceased by his wife of 56 years, Shirley Elizabeth Goodwin of Sunderland, Massachusetts. He is survived by three sons and a daughter, and their spouses: Jackson Goodwin (Win) and Rosanah Bennett of Greenwich, Connecticut; Philip D. and Lisa Bennett of London, England; Hugh F. and Kim Bennett of Winchester, Massachusetts; and Fraser Bennett Beede and Robert Beede of Greenwich, Connecticut, as well as by seven grandchildren. He will be remembered for his devotion to his family, his wonderful sense of humor and his innovative approach to business, economic and monetary issues. He loved to play golf and horseshoes with his family and friends. While working on his personal memoirs, he also published in 2009 a book titled Physics Doesn't Need to be That Difficult. Funeral services are private. A memorial reception is planned for a future date.

ARONSON--Herbert R.,husband to Connie for 59 years, father to Gigi and Peter, pop pop to Seth, Alex, Mabel and Maisy, passed away peacefully at his home in Morris, CT, on April 26, 2010. His family is deeply saddened by Herb's death. We share this sadness with his countless business friends, golfing buddies, and the many folks Herb and Connie befriended over the years in NYC, Connecticut, Europe and elsewhere. Herb lived a wonderful, passionate life. Growing up in Philadelphia. A loving family life with Connie, Gigi and Peter in Westchester. His business success in the menswear world in New York City. Building a company with vision and foresight, Herb was a larger-than life presence, mentoring, encouraging, leading. Herbert R. Aronson was born on May 30, 1921, in Burlington, NJ, one of three children for Rebecca and Joseph. He grew up in a modest household, the son of shop owners. Herb "Reds" Aronson wasn't much of a student, but he loved playing basketball, starring at Overbrook High School in Philadelphia in the late 1930s. He wore number 13, a number later made famous at Overbrook by a player named Wilt Chamberlain. Herb was a flag-waving member of "America's Greatest Generation," a World War II vet who served in England with the U.S. Army Air Corps as an airplane radio mechanic. After the war, he returned to Philadelphia, attending night school at Penn, working in a shoe store and... playing cards with his buddies. And he met Connie. Never one to tread lightly, at a dinner dance, Herb intentionally spilled a drink on Connie's date to get rid of him, so he could meet Connie. They were married on August 24, 1950 Herb was a travelling salesman at the time, eking out a living. Soon after, the couple moved to New York City, where Herb would make his life's mark in the menswear business, manufacturing and selling ties. Herb worked as a salesman for his father-in-law Joseph Wollman. He was not paid enough, so he set off on his own in the heart of the garment district. He bought into a partnership by borrowing $20,000. Soon, Berkley Cravats Ltd. was flourishing, with Herb as chief stylist, buyer and salesman. With a larger than life presence and a natural ease at making friends, Herb befriended and endeared himself to industry leaders across Europe, buying the finest silks, cottons and woolens. With vision, Herb pushed silk paisley ties, bold stripes and introduced English Rugby shirts to America. He travelled the country selling. Store buyers found it hard to say no to Herb Aronson. Beautiful ties. Sound craftsmanship. A good price. Perhaps a little table pounding. But what really sold the ties was Herb's personality his passion for his business, and the simple fact that store executives, including countless presidents and CEOs, grew to respect and love Herb Aronson. By the early 1970s, Berkley Cravats was booming. But Herb had a problem. His partner didn't work hard enough. Herb arranged to sell the company to Manhattan Industries. Herb's partner got a nice pay-off and a Florida retirement. Herb became president and CEO of a new, larger company built around his original tie company, The Manhattan Accessory Division, manufacturing and selling ties, belts and wallets. Manhattan Shirts was added to the portfolio. So was Perry Ellis. Herb's ties were made of Liberty of London's cotton; Como, Italy's silk; the UK's woven fabrics. As president and CEO of Manhattan Menswear Group and, later, as executive VP of Salant Corp. (after it bought Manhattan Industries), with the help of many colleagues who would become life-long friends, Herb built a multi-million dollar business. But more important than the bottom line was the respect Herb earned because of his dedication, passion and friendship, and his strong desire and willingness to help others. Herb loved to help others. He was a mentor to many executives in the menswear field, quick to make a phone call to help someone get a job. When an employee didn't have money to fly home for a relative's funeral, Herb bought the man a plane ticket. Herb proudly served on the Board of Directors for the Greater New York Councils of Boy Scouts, the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, and the Hampshire House co-op. He is a past president of the Neckwear Association of America Herb helped raise hundreds of thousands of dollars for charities and was honored for this work by the Boy Scouts of America with the Good Scout Award and later with the Silver Beaver Award. The United Jewish Appeal and the Conference of Christians and Jews both gave Herb a Man of the Year Award. He also was honored by the Neckwear Association of America and the Young Men's Association. Despite his hard work, Herb Aronson was a dedicated and loving husband to Connie and father to Gigi and Peter. Herb encouraged and loved Connie's beautiful paintings. They travelled widely, making life-long friends in Europe. He could not have been more proud of his children Gigi, the retail executive, then school teacher, Peter the journalist turned lawyer. Herb supported Gigi and Peter, always offering an ear to listen and a shoulder to lean on. Sometimes his opinions were strong, but this was Herb, never shy about giving the advice he thought best. Herb relished the energy, individuality and success of his grand kids: Seth, the soon-to-be law school graduate; Alex, the Peace Corps volunteer and future law school student; Mabel, the spunky, artistic second grader; and little Maisy, the precocious pre-schooler with Herb's red hair for life. Herb adored Peter's wife, Emily, and Gigi's husband, Chuck, happy that his children had found wonderful mates for life. Herb is also survived by his older sister, Florence, who he loved. Herb left his impact on all of us with his love and enduring passion for life and his will and encouragement for achievement. We will remember his supportive words, his strong embrace, his wonderful smile, his sweet kiss. We will remember his love forever. His memorial service is Sunday, May 2, at 1:30pm at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave.; Reception follows at the Aronson's NYC home. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Ronald McDonald House of New York, 405 East 73rd St., New York, NY 10021, in memory of Herb.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Oh Eun-sun of South Korea, who on Tuesday reached the summit of Annapurna in central Nepal to lay claim to being the first woman to scale the world's 14 highest mountains, misstated her age. She is 44, not 34. The article also referred imprecisely to the number of people who have accomplished the feat. The figure, ''fewer than 20 people,'' referred to the number of people who had done it before Tuesday; that did not include Oh.

An article on Tuesday about circulation losses at American newspapers misstated the circulation drop in the last year for the Sunday edition of The New York Times. It was 5.2 percent, not 5.1 percent.

LUCKYRICE Most entrants into America's ever-shifting cuisine arrive via the high road (like sushi, a byproduct of Japanese-American corporate ties) or the low road (chitterlings, a soul food with origins in the scraps given to slaves). And some cuisines arrive and remain in the middle, becoming items that people unthinkingly incorporate into a regular diet.

A news analysis article on Wednesday about President Obama's determination to stick to his timeline of withdrawing American combat forces from Iraq this summer misstated the rank of a spokesman for Gen. Ray Odierno, the American commander in Iraq. The spokesman, Stephen G. Lanza, is a major general, not a brigadier general. (He was promoted from brigadier general late last year.)

TELTSER--Patricia. We mourn with our nieces and nephews the untimely death of our sister, Pat. One would be hard pressed to find anyone who lived with such courage and died with such grace. She has left an indelible mark upon the lives of our children, grandchildren and all who knew her. She was a remarkable woman. We will remember her vitality, her sense of humor, her presence upon entering a room and we will love her forever. Phyllis and Leon Charash

St. Vincent's Hospital in Greenwich Village has declared bankruptcy and is officially closing its doors today. Since four nuns opened it during a cholera epidemic 160 years ago, the hospital has served millions of New Yorkers -- from the passengers of the Titanic to the victims of 9/11. In the days before it closed, I wandered around the hospital, talking to people and drawing pictures. Ambulance drivers gathered around their vehicles outside the hospital's emergency room on Seventh Avenue. ''We all had to submit letters of resignation,'' one said. Another added, ''Someone was hit by a car here yesterday and had to be taken to Bellevue, 30 blocks away.'' (In the weeks before the closing, ambulances were delivering only psychiatric patients to the emergency room.) In recognition of the role the hospital played in caring for victims of the 9/11 attacks, most of the ambulances were decorated with a picture of the twin towers and the American flag, and the inscription, ''In memory of our fallen brothers.''

BEIJING -- China's legislature has imposed tighter requirements on Web and telecommunications companies to shield the nation's state secrets, which are often defined as including a broad array of information the authorities deem detrimental to security. The amendment to the state secrets law, adopted Thursday and set to take effect Oct. 1, obligates network operators and service providers to cooperate with the police, state security officials and prosecutors in investigating leaks of state secrets. On discovering a leak, they must promptly block it and report it to higher authorities, according to a final draft distributed at a news conference in Beijing. Regulatory or security authorities would punish those who fail to comply.

SUMMERER--Friedl, beloved wife of the late Peter Summerer, passed away peacefully at home on April 16, 2010. After working for a short time as an actress, Friedl fled war-torn Europe during World War II and eventually settled in New York. She was a lifelong supporter and an Honorary Member of The French-American Aid for Children. Friedl was a gracious hostess, a fervent animal lover and an ardent supporter of public television. She will be greatly missed by her friends. Memorial Service is on Wednesday, May 5, 2010, at 2:00pm at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, New York.

An article last Friday about accusations of sexual abuse against the Rev. Fernando Karadima, a priest in Chile, erroneously attributed a distinction to a Jesuit priest he considered himself a disciple of, the Rev. Alberto Hurtado. It was Juanita Fernández Solar -- not Father Hurtado -- who was Chile's first saint.

ARONSON--Herbert R. The Board of Directors, Volunteers, and Staff of the Ronald McDonald House wish to express our sincere sympathy of the sudden passing of our friend, donor and advisor, Herb Aronson. We can only be grateful for the extraordinary opportunity of counting him as part of our family and the love and care he offered so freely to those he touched in life! Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan, President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc.

An article on Wednesday about growing financial fears in Europe after the downgrading of Greece's credit rating misstated the date of the Maastricht Treaty, which created the European Union. It came into force in 1993, not 1997. (It was substantially amended by the Treaty of Amsterdam in 1997.)

An Associated Press report in the baseball roundup in some editions on Sunday about the 5-4 victory by the Chicago White Sox over Seattle on Saturday described a disputed play incorrectly. A double touched by a fan with two outs in the top of the ninth inning was declared dead as the Mariners' Jose Lopez scored from second, not first. (The umpires also allowed Jack Wilson, who was on first, to score, giving the Mariners a 4-2 lead.)

FERY--Sidonie Zoleikha. Born on September 11, 1991, deceased on April 22, 2010 was a shooting star and angel who lived on earth for 18 years. The family will receive friends 6-9pm on Friday April 30 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Interment to take place 11am Saturday May 1st at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

AERENSON--Robert A.,91, died April 28, 2010. Beloved husband of the late Marjorie. Loving father of Carol Lucy. Devoted brother of the late Dorothy Rosenberg and the late Lee Aerenson. Survived by sisters-in-law Annette Aerenson, Helen Gurwitt Saltzman and Lenore Gurwitt, his nephew, many nieces, great-nieces and nephews, cousins and friends. Founding partner of Fields, Fischgrund & Aerenson CPA's and partner of BDO Seidman upon merging with that firm. Funeral 10:00am Sunday, May 2, 2010 at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. If desired, donations may be made to Baruch College of City University of New York.
'PETER PAN' A new production of this J. M. Barrie classic offers something that may seem even more remarkable than a magical, ageless boy who flies: a boy playing a magical, ageless boy who flies.

OESTREICHER--Irma. On April 27, in her 89th year, from Lymphoma, at her home, with her family. Born July 4th 1920 to Barnett and Dora Kaplan. Married 1943 to Martin Shapiro and had two children, Robert (Jacqueline) and Daniel (Lynne). In 1958 married Gerard Oestreicher and was a wonderful stepmother to his three children, Lee (Alejandra), Lynn (Noel Jeffrey), and Laurie (Larry Lowenstein). Adored her grandchildren, Holiday Shapiro (Robyn Linde), Brett Haussamen (Jim Sabo), Gerard Jeffrey, Jay Lowenstein (Jayme), Victoria Shapiro (Jon Forsberg), Abi Shapiro, and Caitlin Shapiro (Rowan Gay). Found renewed joy in her great-grandchildren, Evan, Sophie, Kara, and Ava. In later life she was grateful for the companionship of Dan Rodgers. She is survived by her brother Bill Kaplan (Anita). She was raised (forever proud) in Brooklyn, graduated Erasmus High School and Hunter College. She lived in New Rochelle and in 1958 moved to Manhattan (her true home). Her second husband, Gerard Oestreicher, was the chairman of Oestreicher Realty and a Broadway producer. He died in 1987. Irma became a Broadway angel and then a producer in her own right. She produced "Cantorial", "Mademoiselle Colombe", and co-produced "Long Day's Journey Into Night" for which she received a Tony nomination. She was a director of the American Theatre Hall of Fame. Active until her last few months she devoted herself to her family, her many friends, the Theatre, her charities, the Democratic Party, books, bridge, and crosswords. She will be sorely missed by many who loved her keen intellect and tremendous wit, her generosity and her loyalty. The family will receive at the home of Lynn and Noel Jeffrey, 33 East 70th Street, Sunday, May 2nd between 4-8pm. Services will be Monday, May 3rd at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, followed by a reception at the Jeffreys'. In lieu of flowers, please consider a contribution to the Democratic candidate of your choice.
HANRAHAN--Margaret, passed April 28. Survived by Laura Solomon, Dorothy Gorton, Michael Lumary and Eugene Greenlief. Services Sunday, May 2nd, Plaza Funeral Home, 91st and Amsterdam, NYC at 1:15pm.

NESLIN--Illene 85, died on April 27, 2010 at home in her own bed of cancer. The youngest child of pharmacist Joe and Rose Pinck she was also predeceased by WWII Navy Veteran, brother Richard and his daughter Leslie. Ilene studied at the Art Students League in New York City and exhibited widely under her middle name Dana. She received awards from prominent juried shows including the prestigious National Arts Club. An extraordinary artist, gourmet cook and "fashionista" she was a beautiful woman with great flair and a fabulous sense of humor. Greatly loved and loving she had a long, fascinating life. Illene was married for twenty years to television producer, the late John A. Aaron and widowed after nineteen years by musician Jack Waltzer. In 1985 she married childhood "crush" the beloved Stanley Neslin, who survives. Illene ADORED her family: Brother Dr. Robert Lloyd Pinck (Rita), daughter Lynn Aaron (Bob Friedman), step-son Scott Neslin (Betsey) and their children Jenny, Louise, and Lenny. She also leaves numerous nieces, nephews, wonderful friends and extended family, particularly Elaine, Ergin and Troy. Bravely determined she died exactly as she wished because of the exemplary, loving care, lavished on her by our incomparable Carin (Thank-You "Dah-ling") and hospice. In lieu of flowers please donate Valley Hospice, 15 Essex Road, Suite 301, Paramus, NJ 07652, or any Humane Animal Society. Services Private. Illene....unforgettable, that's what you are.

An article on Wednesday about a debate among conservatives about their movement's intellectual health misidentified the conservative research institute that fired Bruce Bartlett, who has criticized such groups. It was the National Center for Policy Analysis, which fired him in 2005 after he wrote a book critical of President George W. Bush -- not the Heritage Foundation, where he worked in the 1980s.

DERRIEY--Grace. Wife of the late John, mother of Louise and Lionel, grandmother of Peter, James and Jennifer Weingarten, and of Leon and Alia Derriey. Mother-in-law of Richard Weingarten and Sarah Derriey. A forthright and independent thinker, she will be fondly remembered and dearly missed.

COLEMAN--Dennis. The Board of Directors, staff, volunteers and supporters of Episcopal Social Services (ESS) are deeply saddened by the recent death of Dennis Coleman, the former New York State Senator from the Bronx, who served as a dedicated member of the Board of Directors for Episcopal Social Services for more than a decade. He is fondly remembered and his contributions to the agency and his community are greatly appreciated. Dennis Coleman was a staunch advocate of quality education for all and as a State Senator served on numerous state committees and the Joint Legislative Education Revision Committee. For over 35 years he was a member of the Community School Board of District 8 where he provided support to parents and educational staff and positive leadership for the education of children. As a member of the ESS Board, he was instrumental in the development of ESS' Early Head Start program, the only such program serving low-income families in the South Bronx. He also assisted in developing the ESS After School Program, expanding the agency's educational initiatives. Thanks to the efforts of Dennis Coleman ESS now serves over 1,800 of New York's neediest children in after school and early childhood education. All of us at Episcopal Social Services offer our sincerest condolences to the Coleman family and his many friends, especially his wife, Arline, children Dennis, Michael, Kevin, Lori and Richard; five grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren, two nephews, one niece and brother-in-law, Fitz. Marshall Green, Board Chair Kenneth Kramer, Board Pres. Robert H. Gutheil, Exec. Dir.

COWLES--Allison. Columbia/Barnard Hillel mourns the passing of our supporter and friend, Allison Cowles. Wife of our dear founding board member and honorary chair, Arthur Ochs "Punch" Sulzberger, Allison cared deeply about our community and in inspiring the next generation in acts of service and leadership. Her passing is a tremendous loss for us all. May her memory be a blessing. Judith Schwartz, President Simon Klarfeld, Exec. Dir.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE - I mentioned in my previous post that solving is a personal experience. A lot depends on what you know. Brendan Emmett Quigley knows many things I don't, as I'm often reminded. He has a deep understanding of pop culture, and he's not afraid to fill the grid with questions like "1970s-'80s rock genre" and "1991 top 10 hit for Chris Isaak" and "Bygone N.Y.C. rock club." We've had that last one before. It was supposedly the birthplace of punk. Whose puzzle was it in? I'll give you one guess.

It's Derby morning at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky. And the weather has not cooperated. As of 11 a.m. we do not know exactly what the weather will do for the remainder of the day, and consequently how this will affect the racing surface. The track superintendant, who is in charge of decisions regarding the state of the racetrack, has not made a decision regarding whether the track will be sealed, or opened up, at Derby time. This decision will be determined solely by the state of the track, and the weather, throughout the afternoon. Between the second and third race, the track was "floated," which means it remained sealed. The rain seems to have eased off.

On Friday I was on a panel at Bay Path College along with Somaly Mam, my friend and hero. Somaly is a Cambodian who was trafficked into a brothel as a little girl but managed to escape -- and then started an anti-trafficking organization to fight the brothels and help other girls escape. She has been extraordinarily courageous in keeping up the fight when the brothel-owners just want to kill her, and she seems so unbelievably poised when she speaks in English -- her fourth language -- before large audiences under a spotlight. But on Friday, I saw a reminder of how that past haunts her and anyone who went through such a trauma.

I am a Pollyanna. I believe I will live to see a Triple Crown. I state that every January 1 as I proclaim loudly to the heavens -- "This IS the year of our Triple Crown winner." So when I went to my first horse race, which was the Big Brown Belmont Stakes, I sat for an hour or more in the stands not wallowing in disappointment but pondering the Triple Crown trail. I wrote a story that night that said that in the future I would go to the Kentucky Derby to watch the beginning of a dream.

I was recently at Greene Acres Community Garden in Bedford-Stuyvesant, giving a group of enthusiastic gardeners a tour of edible weeds, when I couldn't help noticing a lovely patch of violets crouching along the edges of a soil bed. Like many of the city's flowering plants, including dandelions, cherry blossoms and magnolias, wild violets appeared super early this year. Though many folks were unaware that the violets were edible, this group of urban gardeners hungrily nibbled on the delicate flowers that I passed around.

9 P.M. (Starz) ANGELS & DEMONS (2009) In Ron Howard's sequel to ''The Da Vinci Code,'' (the films are based on the novels by Dan Brown), Tom Hanks (above, with Ayelet Zurer) reprises his role as the Harvard symbologist Robert Langdon. Langdon is summoned to the Vatican to help with a deadly situation involving antimatter stolen from the Large Hadron Collider; papal succession; and the Illuminati, ancient pro-science terrorists. Ms. Zurer, as Vittoria Vetra, an Italian scientist specializing in ''bioentanglement physics,'' is his sidekick; Armin Mueller-Stahl, Stellan Skarsgard and Ewan McGregor are players in a Vatican power struggle following the death of a beloved pope. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said: ''The utter silliness of 'Angels & Demons' is either its fatal flaw or its saving grace, and in the spirit of compassion, I suppose I'd be inclined to go with the second option. The movie all but begs for such treatment.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Lucky Severson reports on the proposal by conservatives on the Texas School Board to amend history textbooks to correct what they perceive as liberal bias. Judy Valente interviews Mary Karr about her new memoir, ''Lit.'' And Bob Abernethy talks with Bishop Gerald Kicanas of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Tucson about his church's opposition to Arizona's controversial new immigration law, which allows the police to stop people and demand proof of citizenship.

Bowing to pressure from community groups upset by the noise of whirring rotors, city officials have banned most types of helicopter sightseeing flights leaving from Manhattan. The new rules, which went into effect this week, prohibit tourist flights from swooping over Central Park, the Empire State Building and all of Brooklyn. They are restricted to flying over water, with one exception: tours that hover over Yankee Stadium in the Bronx are still allowed, said David Lombino, a spokesman for the city's Economic Development Corporation.

A picture caption on Friday with the Advertising column, about the growing popularity of New Jersey characters and culture in television shows and advertising, reversed the identifications of two stars of the Style Network show ''Jerseylicious'' and misspelled the given name of one of them in some copies. Olivia Blois Sharpe is at the right; Tracy -- not Tracey -- DiMarco is at the left. The column also misstated the number of episodes in a series, ''Jersey Couture,'' to be shown starting June 1 on the Oxygen cable channel. It is eight, not six.

HESS--Norma. The Board of Directors at Raritan Bay Medical Center and the Raritan Bay Medical Center Foundation wish to extend their deepest condolences to the Hess Family and the many cherished friends and loved ones of Norma W. Hess. Mrs. Hess' life-long charitable endeavors and her assurance of increasing the quality of life for members of our healthcare community is a legacy that will live on in the hearts and minds of medical staff, constituents, and local residents who were and forever will be positively impacted by her graciousness and unfaltering generosity. Through her family's support, Raritan Bay Medical Center was able to establish the Jacqueline R. and Robert N. Wilentz Cancer Center, to enhance our oncology services and patient care. Mrs. Hess' name, legacy and civic and social consciousness will be remembered fondly. From her treasured hometown of Perth Amboy, New Jersey we send our heartfelt sympathy.

A new rule to protect airline passengers from being held on a plane on the tarmac for too long went into effect Thursday. The rule, issued by the Department of Transportation, was announced in December after a series of cases on various airlines left passengers stranded on the tarmac for hours. Airlines now face fines of up to $27,500 per passenger when a plane sits on the tarmac for more than two hours without providing food or water or more than three hours without giving passengers the option of getting off the plane. The rule applies to domestic flights only. Read more

He will be missed. Eric R. Marcus, M.D. Director Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research Jules Kerman, M.D., Ph.D. President Association for Psychoanalytic Medicine

Memorial service to celebrate his life Sunday, May 2, 2:30-3:30 at the UN Church Center, 777 UN Plaza, 44th St between 1st and 2nd Avenues.

An article on Thursday about a new immigration enforcement law in Arizona described incorrectly action by the Legislature to put in place new requirements for office seekers. The Arizona House has passed a bill that would require presidential candidates to provide documentation on their citizenship, age and residency. But the state does not have a new law requiring all political candidates to prove citizenship. (The sponsor of a Senate bill on presidential candidates said on Thursday that the measure was being shelved for now because of lack of Republican support.)

CLASTER--Robert A. The directors, shareholders and professional colleagues of Carl Marks & Co. mourn the sudden passing in Israel of Robert A. Claster, younger brother of Mark L. Claster, our President, CEO, and valued friend. The pain of the loss is all the greater because of the special closeness and bond that exists among the Claster family members. To Mark, his wife Susan, and the entire Claster family, we extend our deepest sympathy and profound regrets.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The stretch at Churchill Downs can seem never-ending, especially when you are aboard a talented filly named Blind Luck and you are the 6-5 favorite in the 136th running of the Kentucky Oaks. Rafael Bejarano knew Blind Luck had plenty of run left in her, but she had dawdled a little a bit early in the race and they had lost ground. He asked his filly for some juice before he had wanted to heading into the far turn.

CHIRIACKA--Ernest, artist and sculptor, died peacefully at home April 26. Darcy to his friends he was born May 11, 1913 in New York. A illustrator of pulp covers and magazines, he is best known for his Esquire calendar pin ups. In the 1960's, he began painting the American west. He has an art gallery in Santa Fe. He and his wife Kathryn lived in Kings Point, NY. After her death in 2001, he lived with his daughter in Minneapolis, Minnesota. He spent his last years traveling the world with her. He leaves his son, Leonard Shera , his daughter, Athene Westergaard and their children and grandchildren. Visitation will held Sunday 3-5 and 7-9pm at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset. Funeral Mass Monday, 10:45am St Aloysius Church, 592 Middle Neck Road, Great Neck with interment to follow at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in his name to your local Hospice or Alzheimer's foundation.

An article and a picture caption on Wednesday about protests by students in New Jersey over cuts in state aid to education misidentified the county in which High Tech High School, one site of the protests, is located. It is in Hudson County, not Bergen.

The College Board, in a new report, found that bachelor's degree recipients who graduated with the most student debt tended to be those who went to for-profit institutions or were independent -- meaning they generally did not get support from their parents. The findings in the report, ''Who Borrows Most? Bachelor's Degree Recipients with High Levels of Student Debt,'' released on Monday, were based on an analysis of government data about postsecondary student aid for students who received their bachelor's degrees in 2008, the most recent figures available.

NEW YORK An article in some copies last Saturday reported that Jeff Ragsdale, a 32-year-old computer consultant, had tried to make up with his girlfriend, Megan Brady, by wearing a sandwich board in Madison Square Park that apologized for being ''verbally abusive.'' Subsequently, questions were raised about whether this public lovers' quarrel had been staged. A closer look at whether it was a hoax can be found at nytimes.com/cityroom, which first reported the account.

The Kentucky Derby provided three basic storylines. There is the "Nobody gets between the rail and our Calvin" line of stories about Calvin Borel in numerous papers including The Daily News, The Louisville Courier-Journal, The Newark Star-Ledger and The Los Angeles Times. There are the "Todd Pletcher off the schneid" stories in The New York Post, the Times, The Troy Record, The Courier-Journal and The Baltimore Sun, and there are the combination of both of these stories from Ray Kerrison, The Daily News and ESPN. It should be pointed out that these are not the easiest stories to write well. Borel is an absolutely open book who has been written about to the point of exhaustion, and to say that Pletcher is reserved is a gross understatement.

For nearly three weeks the tenor Jonas Kaufmann has been knocking out audiences at the Metropolitan Opera, first during four sold-out performances as Cavaradossi in "Tosca," and then in two appearances as Don José in "Carmen," the last of which was on Saturday night. Here's hoping that during Mr. Kaufmann's breaks from rehearsals and performances, Peter Gelb, the Met's general manager, was brandishing contracts and talking future projects with this 41-year-old German tenor, who is at a career peak.

CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- One of the most influential voices in golf chose an odd time to criticize the widely praised Quail Hollow Club. Phil Mickelson, who shot a one-under-par 71 to move to seven under and stay within two shots of the leader going into the final round of the Quail Hollow Championship, went out of his way Saturday to pan the greens following his round.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- Super Saver is Baltimore-bound to pursue the second jewel of the Triple Crown, the Preakness Stakes. It appears he is going to have a lot of company on May 15, as the trainers of several Derby runners indicated they wanted another shot at the colt.

Silence Surrounding Racial Tensions Broken | It has been years since race relations in the Bay Area, where tolerance is a civic religion, have taken such a sharp turn for the worse. Gerry Shih reports that repeated attacks on Asians by young African-Americans led to angry public gatherings in San Francisco and Oakland in the past week. Underlying the rising tension is rapid demographic change, which has brought a wave of Asian relocation into the Bayview and Hunter's Point, historically black neighborhoods since the heyday of the Hunter's Point Naval Shipyard. While scores of Chinese angrily demanded better police protection, two young African-American siblings, Amanze Emenike, 21, and Sherry Blunt, 22, talked to Mr. Shih about their motives in the robberies of Asians for which they were convicted, and their feelings about the changes in their Hunter's Point neighborhood.

Curtis Granderson of the Yankees said Sunday that he hoped to miss no more than the 15 days his current stay on the disabled list entails. But Manager Joe Girardi said Granderson's strained left groin could keep him out twice as long.
Authorities quickly evacuated Times Square in Manhattan after a street vendor alerted police to smoke billowing from the back of a vehicle.

Four years ago on Sunday, a ravenous 10-alarm blaze gutted abandoned warehouses of the historic Greenpoint Terminal Market on the Brooklyn waterfront, spectacularly turning most of the 14-acre site into a charred ruin, and sending a towering plume of smoke above the city. It was one of the largest fires in the city's history.

DENNIS--Les, 78, of Salem, WV formerly of Long Island, NY passed away Friday, April 30, 2010, at Sunbridge Care & Rehabilitation of Salem, WV due to Alzheimer's Disease. Les was born in Brooklyn, New York on March 28, 1932, the son of the late Mortimer Dennis and the late Edith Lispenard Dennis. He graduated from Adelphi University. Les served in the U. S. Army during the Korean Conflict. He was a reporter and producer for NBC News and Sports and he received a television Emmy Award. He is survived by his wife Barbara Foote Dennis, and children, Richard Dennis and wife Bettina of Morgantown; Lynn Taylor and husband, Don of New Jersey, Neil Dennis and wife Teresa of Texas and Daniel Dennis and wife Janet Brightly of Virginia. Also he is survived by 10 grandchildren. Hastings Funeral Home provided cremation services. Memorial contributions may be made in Les's memory to the Alzheimer's Association, P.O. Box 96011, Washington, DC 20090-6011. Send condolences online at hastingsfuneralhome.com

ANN ARBOR, Mich. -- President Obama on Saturday directly confronted the sharpening political rancor in Washington, on the airwaves and on the Internet, telling the graduating class at the University of Michigan that the country needs a ''basic level of civility in our public discourse.'' As a panoply of protesters shouted outside, many of them carrying signs decrying Mr. Obama as a ''socialist,'' the president told some 8,500 graduates -- and 80,000 family members, professors and others in the audience in Michigan Stadium -- that passions were overheated and that people on all sides of the political debate needed to find ways to listen to one another.

In their nearly 20 years together, the graphic artists Michael Amzalag and Mathias Augustyniak -- who go by the name M/M (Paris) -- have designed more than 50 typefaces, from an alphabet built from the sliced-up photographs of 26 male models to the inky resin letter forms that spell out ''Medulla'' on the cover of Bjork's 2004 album. Their latest, the Pradalphabet (above), was originally conceived as a temporary five-letter logotype for the house of Miuccia: Prada-M. (The M stands for Milano and M/M.) But the duo's ideographic tendencies got the best of them, and in the end, M/M designed a whole alphabet of ornamented initials, each representing a hazy portrait of the Prada brand. ''It's like looking at a planet from afar,'' says Amzalag, who along with Augustyniak spent up to six hours hand-drawing each letter. ''You can see a continent, but it's impossible to say what's inside.'' Examine the letters closely, however, and you'll spot cleaning implements, Italian phrases, strange machines and a picture of two men standing on a balcony. (''They're inhabitants of the Prada world,'' Amzalag says.) For now, they live in a collector's edition of T-shirts, each silk-screened with a P, R, A, D or M and packaged in a cloth-bound box with a 64-page album describing the project. Other letters are available on demand at Prada stores worldwide. JILL SINGER

An article in the Bay Area pages on April 23 on issues arising from aggressive debt collection gave an incorrect figure of the price range for portfolios of delinquent debt that creditors will sell to debt buyers. The range is 3.5 cents to 7.5 cents on the dollar, not 35 cents to 75 cents on the dollar.

MOSCOW -- Violence broke out in two North Caucasian republics on Saturday, as militants attacked gatherings on May Day, a revered Soviet holiday that still draws flocks of Russians to public celebrations. A bomb went off around 12:40 p.m. in a hippodrome in Nalchik, the capital of the republic of Kabardino-Balkaria, killing a 104-year-old war veteran and wounding about 30 others, the local authorities said.

PENHALIGON'S, the perfume house established in the 1870s, has a storied history. Oscar Wilde and Rudyard Kipling were fans. Queen Victoria appointed it the court perfumer. Winston Churchill counted its Blenheim Bouquet as his favorite fragrance, and Princess Diana adored its Bluebell scent. Now, having mined its vast archives, the company is incrementally releasing an Anthology collection of 12 oldies but goodies. Arriving in the United States next week are the latest: Eau de Cologne, a faithful recreation of a classic citrus from 1927; and Orange Blossom, a lush honeyed floral -- with neroli, tuberose and sandalwood -- inspired by the 1976 original. Summer in a bottle. Or two.

ROSENMAN--Dr. Bernard, died in his 100th year at about three this morning. He did not leave behind a daughter Karen, sons Joel and Douglas, a son-in-law John, daughters-in-law Chris and Kathy, grandchildren Alexis, Hilary, Molly, Tim, and Ned because they, like anyone else fortunate enough to have met this lovely man, will always carry with them forever his tenacity for life, his ability to see the best in things, and his loving humorous way of making you feel special.

Rudolf Stingel has a lot on his plate these days -- literally. The New York-based conceptual artist collaborated with Bernardaud, the French porcelain company, and the Art Production Fund's WOW (Works on Whatever) on a pair of luscious-looking dinner plates that are almost too beautiful to mar with a meal. The plates, which come in an edition of 2,500 in both black and white, are based on photographs of a wall relief that Stingel began in 2008. Fittingly, that project was inspired by the wallpaper in the dining room of his childhood home. Why make tableware? ''I like to eat,'' the artist says. ''And I like to look at my work -- two birds, one stone.'' It's not the artist's first excursion into the everyday. In 2004, he famously swathed Grand Central Station's cavernous Vanderbilt Hall in floral carpeting. Impressive, of course. But this is one project he'll be able to dine out on for years. And at $98 each, so will you. Available at worksonwhatever.com and Bernardaud boutiques in New York and Chicago. SANDRA BALLENTINE

TOM FORD has a rare eye, not just for designing beautiful clothes, creating sexy advertising campaigns and, most recently, creating a visually luscious movie -- ''A Single Man'' (2009) -- but also as an art collector. This spring he has decided to capitalize on the high prices that top works by Andy Warhol have been bringing by selling one of his many canvases by this Pop master. Painted a year before Warhol's death, this 1986 self-portrait is so spooky, with its gaunt face and spiky hair, that Warhol once said the image actually scared him. Now the canvas, which is nine feet square, is considered historically important. ''Decades from now the most famous images by Warhol will be his Marilyns, his disaster paintings and his self-portraits,'' said Tobias Meyer of Sotheby's.

What's the point of design these days, anyway? That's the question the curators at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum wrestled with for nearly three years as they assembled ''Why Design Now?,'' the museum's fourth National Design Triennial, which opens May 14. Their response, presented through 134 projects from around the world, might be the design equivalent of the Hippocratic oath. Many are high-minded, utilitarian responses to critical problems overseas (cleaner-burning stoves, a land-mine-removal suit) and at home (New York City's new Hoop bike rack, M.I.T.'s prototype for a lightweight electric city car). ''There's room for high-style design, but there also needs to be room for the rest of the world,'' says Matilda McQuaid, the museum's deputy curatorial director. But its definition of socially responsible has room for whimsical conceptualism (Interactive Institute's Energy Aware Clock, left), architectural grandiosity (Foster & Partners' sustainable city of Masdar in Abu Dhabi) and simple beauty (Heath Ceramics tableware). Even Twitter made the cut. ''People say the focus on socially responsible design is just because of the Wall Street crisis and isn't going to survive once things are back to normal,'' McQuaid says. ''I think it's here to stay.'' JESSE ASHLOCK

ON its Web site, the motorcycle helmet manufacturer Advanced Carbon Composites warns buyers not to trust helmets made in China or India; instead, it says, they should buy Advanced's American-made models. But the company's helmets have been recalled so many times by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration that the agency has demanded that the company never make another motorcycle helmet. The agency's demand stems from what it says is the company's failure to properly carry out three safety recalls since 2005.

DICK CAVETT The question I can never find an answer to is the one that makes dreams so mysterious. When you watch a movie or read a story you don't know what's coming next. You're surprised by what happens as it unfolds. You know that someone wrote the book or made the movie. So how can anyone but you be the author of the dream? How can that be you if you don't know what's coming? Do you write the dream, then hide it from yourself, forget it, and then ''sit out front'' and watch it?

WASHINGTON -- The federal government has a large rainy day fund on hand to help mitigate the expanding damage on the Gulf Coast, generated by a tax on oil for use in cases like the Deepwater Horizon spill. Up to $1 billion of the $1.6 billion reserve could be used to compensate for losses from the accident, as much as half of it for what is sometimes a major category of costs: damage to natural resources like fisheries and other wildlife habitats.
