AFTER opening in November to some of the best reviews of the theater season, the Off Broadway production of ''The Orphans' Home Cycle'' seemed on a fast track for Broadway. Three of New York's most prominent play producers began trying to raise $2.5 million to move the show, even though its length (nine hours, broken into three parts) and lack of star performers made it an iffy investment for commercial Broadway. But the producers thought the show, the final opus of the acclaimed writer Horton Foote, had a good shot at Tony Awards -- which go only to Broadway productions -- and they believed that a wide audience would want to see the work, given the huge demand for tickets at its 160-seat Off Broadway house. Yet ''Orphans'' did not go to Broadway this winter; the obstacle ended up not being money, the show's running time or its cast of no-names. ''We couldn't get the right theater,'' one of its producers, Daryl Roth, said in January when the decision was made. (Her team is now aiming for the fall.) ''Real estate is really difficult to come by on Broadway these days. And it's too bad, because some great shows aren't being seen.''

KISSING THE MASK Beauty, Understatement and Femininity in Japanese Noh Theater With Some Thoughts on Muses (Especially Helga Testorf), Transgender Women, Kabuki Goddesses, Porn Queens, Poets, Housewives, Makeup Artists, Geishas, Valkyries and Venus Figurines

''The Chinese don't understand us,'' Amedeo Felisa, Ferrari's global chief executive, said in a recent interview. ''They don't understand why we make only two-door cars. They don't understand why we don't make a limousine.'' If Ferrari does someday make a stretch limo, it will be because the Asian market demanded it. China, or what is being increasingly referred to as the ''C-Factor'' in the auto industry, is likely to have a significant say from now on in how automobiles are designed, built and sold.

Zach Marlowe, 18, from South Orange, is a senior at Columbia High School in Maplewood. He took part, along with an estimated 200 of his classmates, in the state-wide walk-out on Tuesday, April 27, to protest Gov. Christopher J. Christie's school budget cuts. He recounts the moments when the students started to leave their classrooms to gather on the front lawn of the high school, and explains why he chose to walk out. When Columbia Cable Network (CCN) showed a shot of students who had already left school, just shortly after 9 a.m., the image was surreal (as the whole day shortly became). The shot inspired me, and a few friends of mine, to walk out -- after we hesitated at the door for a while.
'People keep waiting for us to screw up, but we didn't let up. We kept pouring it on.' JEFF FRANCOEUR,

SOLING--Chester, father of Caytha Jentis, Courtney Smith and Cevin Soling, husband of Carole, grandfather of Sean and Sally Jentis and Brennan Smith, died in New Jersey on April 29th. He was 78. An architect, real estate developer, and philanthropist, Chester was known for his creative mind and independent spirit. He founded the children's hotel Piper's Hill, built The Orchards hotel in Williamstown , MA, and was president of Syracuse's Library Associates for 10 years in addition to being a trustee of Syracuse University where he endowed The Soling Program for Qualities of Mind Development. He opened the San Francisco Ship Model Gallery, a New York City gallery that sold models of famous ships and authored the book, We the People: Government to Serve, Not to Rule. Chester's community involvement included serving as a member of the Scarsdale Parent Teacher Association and as a Scarsdale auxiliary policeman. He also served as vice president of the Apartment Owners Advisory Council and was a member of the Stamford Area Commerce and Industry Association. In Williamstown, he served on several town committees and was elected a selectman. In Tucson, he was on the Advisory Board of the Tucson Opera League. He received the George Arents' Pioneer Medal in 1980. He strived to make the world a better place.

THE art world always hungers for new talent, and Matthew Day Jackson is ''it'' right now. But only a few of his works are up for sale this spring. Tucked near the end of Sotheby's contemporary-art auction is an oval wood panel depicting Harriet Tubman, the African-American abolitionist and Civil War spy. Mr. Jackson, 36, is the youngest and perhaps least-known artist in the sale, which is to be held May 12. Prescient collectors like the gallery owner and advertising impresario Charles Saatchi, the luxury goods magnate François Pinault and the London jeweler Laurence Graff have been recently snapping up anything they can get by Mr. Jackson. When a Jackson painting went up for sale at Christie's in London in February, its high estimate was $61,760. Mr. Graff bought it for $928,330.
ILL FARES THE LAND By Tony Judt

Artek, the Finnish company that was co-founded by the architect Alvar Aalto to produce his furniture designs, is celebrating its 75th anniversary by asking designers and artists to reinterpret its classic armchairs in a program called Dress the Chair! For the opening of Artek's new Stockholm showroom earlier this year, the British designer Ilse Crawford covered Aalto's chunky 1936 Armchair 400 -- better known as the Tank chair -- with reindeer fur, in a nod to its Finnish roots. And the Swedish textile designer Fanny Aronsen covered Aalto's chairs in her own colorful fabrics. The second stop was Milan, where the fashion house Missoni dressed the Tank chair in its graphic textiles (below) during last month's furniture fair. New York, Sydney, London and Tokyo come next, with more guest designers, before a final stop back home in Helsinki. PILAR VILADAS

SEROTA--Nathan. A Love letter to Nathan Serota. It's been said that the way a man dies, is a reflection of the way he lived. And it's with a heavy heart that I have to write that Nathan Serota my husband of 40 years died the morning of May 1, 2010, the way he had lived: With courage, humility and, in the last days of his life, taking care of the people he loved. My husband was a self made man who against all odds - built a successful business, became an international philanthropist, art collector and absolutely loved life. We traveled the world meeting interesting, powerful people and shared a glamorous and beautiful life. But Nathan also lived by the rule that to whom much is given, much is expected. My Husband unselfishly contributed to the organizations and causes he believed in, but it was his everyday quiet acts of kindness that defined Nathan Serota: The veteran who needed a special car, the children he sent to collage and the families whose bills he paid. Oftentimes I would learn about these gifts, many anonymous weeks and years later. For Nat, these were acts of Gratitude for the beautiful life, children and grandchildren - We were blessed with. My darling Nat, we had hard times and good times but through it all we had love. With love, Vivian

For much of the 20th century, the 133 studios at Carnegie Hall sheltered musicians, artists, dancers, photographers and writers. I arrived in 1950 as a hat designer and an apprentice to the photographer Ray Solowinski (Photo 11). Over the six decades I lived there, this august atmosphere was a constant inspiration -- and often, hilarious fun. It was also a lot like a dorm: most of the studios shared the hall bathrooms. My roommates included Lady Jeanne Campbell and Norman Mailer, who once walked down the stairs naked and scared my milliners. Marilyn Monroe tried on my hats between acting classes. And I often found Katharine Hepburn on the stairs, awaiting her vocal coach. Among my neighbors and highlights: the portrait photographer Editta Sherman (1), who performed ''The Dying Swan'' as a hobby, and raised five children in the building. The opera singer Jeanne Beauvais (2 and 6), who was married in the in-house synagogue. Dr. Michael Zuekal (3), a psychoanalyst. Oliviero Tuscani (4) lost his cameras in a break-in. Mrs. Sherman's fire-damaged studio (5) after workers cooked lunch on the roof. Ms. Sherman, the artist Tom Fogarty and the floral designer Toni Cimino (7). Pierre Houlès (8), the photographer, and a girlfriend. The artist Lorraine Geiger (9). The model Cathy Damon (10). Roof sunbathers (12). Ms. Cimino (13). The designer Charles James (14), dressing a model for the illustrator Antonio, a Henry Higgins who discovered many models. Spoofing a Vogue photographer's set (15). Lila Tiffany (16), former circus performer, busking out front. Cecil Gill (17) ran elevators. Ingeborg Markus (18), designer. My move out last week (19) resembled ''A Hard Day's Night'': Carnegie's men pushed my files down Seventh Avenue. For the first time in 60 years, I have my own bathroom.

An article on April 18 about Brandon Crawford, a 33-year-old former Ball State defensive end who held on to his hopes of reaching the N.F.L. through a high school arrest and a stint in the Marines, omitted part of the name of a university in Georgia that expressed interest in him when he was in high school. It is Clark Atlanta University, not Clark University. (After being passed over in the recent draft, Crawford has been invited to try out for the Giants.)

The auction rooms at the Hotel Drouot in Paris date to 1852. They've been modernized since then, but the general atmosphere probably hasn't changed much. On any day of the week, a throng of characters straight out of a Maupassant novel can be found bidding for dusty treasures straight out of the proverbial Old Curiosity Shop. Annually, about 800,000 lots pass through the 16 rooms, over the course of more than 3,000 auctions. ''I wouldn't miss a day at Drouot,'' said Bill Pallot (above), a Pickwickian figure who is the 18th-century furniture specialist at the antiquarian gallery Didier Aaron. ''There is an endless, constantly changing supply of paintings, furniture and bric-a-brac from every epoch and at every price. There is a massive turnover, and there are great bargains to be found.'' (And also the chatter of swindles and scams.)

WITH the art world flocking to see ''Red,'' John Logan's two-man Broadway play about Mark Rothko, in which the actors share the stage with copies of some of Rothko's deep-red canvases, the timing of the sale of this 1961 work couldn't be better. And the painting itself could not be redder. In the catalog Sotheby's says it belongs to a private collector, but experts familiar with the painting say the seller is David Martinez, the Mexican financier who bought a two-floor apartment in the south building of the Time Warner Center for $54.7 million about five years ago. Before he purchased this painting from L&M Arts, an East Side gallery, it had been up for sale several times before, including at Christie's in 1997, when it brought $1.8 million. That was years before Broadway transformed Mr. Rothko and his obsession with red into a must-see show.

There was a certain buzz at the dinner table a few months ago. My sons had heard that the new Mets left fielder, Jason Bay, was considering moving to our town of Larchmont from the Boston area, where he had played for the Red Sox. I barely paid attention, since baseball chatter around our house is constant background noise. A few days later, they were talking about it again. One son claimed he and his friends walked past Mr. Bay's house on the way to Hebrew school. But I was still fairly sure this was one of those false rumors that fly around a small community and gather steam as they hit the schools.Then proof arrived, in the form of a tidbit my husband discovered on the Web site of Major League Baseball, which was then picked up by our local online newspaper, The Larchmont Gazette. Mr. Bay had indeed chosen our town over Connecticut - even though apparently all his friends had urged him to move to Greenwich, the ritzier community up north.

PRICES for Giacometti sculptures have risen dramatically since the $104.3 million sale of his ''Walking Man I'' at Sotheby's in February. Dealers started asking more for their stock, and the auction houses' experts are expecting higher numbers too. This head, conceived of in 1954 and cast a year later, is from the Brody estate and was purchased the year it was cast. Although other examples from this edition have been included in major Giacometti retrospectives worldwide, this sculpture was exhibited just once, in a show at the Museum of Modern Art in 1965. Experts consider the bust the most important among a series of male heads that Giacometti created in the mid-1950s. Depicting his brother Diego, it stands more than two feet high. Besides the bust's large scale, its craggy surface and blade-sharp face make it particularly desirable.

With cooler weather approaching in the Southern Hemisphere, IHG -- which operates seven hotel brands including InterContinental, Crowne Plaza and Holiday Inn Hotels and Resorts -- is offering up to 50 percent off stays throughout Australia, New Zealand, Fiji, French Polynesia and Papua New Guinea. Additionally, children under 12 stay free at Holiday Inn Hotels. The full list of participating hotels will be released on April 30, but the sale will include the new InterContinental Fiji Golf Resort & Spa, the Rialto in Melbourne and the Crowne Plaza Adelaide.

HUMPHREY--Carol Frances (nee Sise), died April 23, 2010, Boca Grande, FL. Born 1917 in Montreal. Moved to the US following her marriage to Frank Humphrey. She will be remembered by her children, Susan, Peter and Sarah, and her eight grandchildren, as a gracious example of fairness, kindness and generosity. A great lady at 92, sharp as ever and keenly interested in literature, travel, sports and world affairs. Memorial service in Tuxedo Park, NY, at a later date.

GROSSMAN--Cecile, passed away on April 21 at the age of 74 after a brief, but valiant struggle with cancer. Cecile was a pioneer in many ways. She worked with Fred Friendly and David Susskind in the early days of TV, and was a tireless advocate for abused and handicapped children. Her legal career began with her attendance at night school at the New York School of Law, while working full-time as an editor at Prentice Hall Publishers. After receiving her law degree, she had a distinguished career as an assistant district attorney in the Office of the Bronx District Attorney. She also did pro bono work for Death Row inmates. She was a loving and devoted foster parent. She is survived by her goddaughter Jennifer, her brother Martin, her sister Shirley, and five nieces. Gifts in her memory may be made to The Institute of Retired Professionals, 66 West 12th St. NY, NY 10011.

Earlier this week, Zipcar, the car-sharing company based in Cambridge, Mass., that lets members reserve a car for one-hour slots, acquired Streetcar UK, a similar company based in London.

(Planet Green) GREENSBURG: A FINAL LOOK On May 4, 2007, an enhanced F5 tornado -- one of the strongest in American history -- plowed through Greensburg, a small town in southwestern Kansas, leaving virtually nothing standing in its wake. For two years, Planet Green has been watching Greensburg rise like a phoenix on the Great Plains as residents rebuild their town as an oasis of environmental sustainability. This special looks back at highlights from previous episodes before the premiere of the third, and final, season at 9. Above, a scene from the show. 10:30 A.M. (NBC) MEET THE PRESS This news program will make its debut in high definition, from a new set. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton will weigh in on domestic and foreign policy; Charlie Crist, the Republican governor of Florida, will talk about his decision to run independently for the United States Senate; and Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano and Interior Secretary Ken Salazar will discuss the environmental effects of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Ms. Napolitano and Mr. Salazar will also appear on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10, and on ''This Week,'' at 10 on ABC.

Lost in the shuffle of university admission and graduation rates is a reality that those statistics often mask: about 1 in 3 students who enroll in either a four-year or two-year college will probably transfer at some point. This, to me, is the takeaway statistic in a report issued Tuesday by the National Association for College Admission Counseling. For readers of The Choice, the most valuable information in the report may be the results of a survey asking college admissions officers what criteria they most prize in a transfer applicant. ''The postsecondary grade point average is clearly the most important factor for transfer admission,'' the researchers report.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the 2010 Congressional elections referred incorrectly in some editions to four Senate races that are among those the Republicans would need to win to gain control of the Senate. The contests in Kentucky, Missouri, New Hampshire and Ohio are for seats being vacated by Republican incumbents. Democrats will not be challenging ''four vulnerable Republican incumbents'' in those states.

PHILLIPS--Kit, formerly of Emerson, passed away Friday, April 30, in her sleep, at home in Maplewood, NJ. She was 95. Kit, wife of the late Murray Phillips, is survived by sons and daughters-in-law Rick Phillips and Barbara Canace of South Orange, NJ, Ted and Pat Phillips of Niantic, CT, and by four beloved grandchildren: Jeanna, Lara, Simon and Brennan. Born Mina Alice Mulford in New York City, Kit graduated from Cooper Union in 1934 and attended the Art Students League in NYC. A professional painter and sculptor, she started as a fashion illustrator in the 1930's, becoming senior fashion artist for the Maas Brothers department store chain in Tampa, FL. Donations may be made to American Hospice Foundation. For information on the upcoming memorial service visit: www.prestonfuneralhome.net

A JASPER JOHNS flag is the ultimate trophy for rich American collectors. And what makes this particular ''Flag'' even more desirable is that it comes from the estate of the best-selling novelist Michael Crichton. Mr. Crichton, who died in November 2008, was not only a collector but also a friend of many of the artists whose works he owned, including Mr. Johns, David Hockney, Robert Rauschenberg and Roy Lichtenstein. In 1973 he bought this ''Flag'' directly from Mr. Johns and, until Christie's began showing it, the painting was last seen in public 18 years ago when it was included in a Pop Art survey organized by the Royal Academy of Arts in London. It is a particularly vibrant image, painted in Mr. Johns's signature encaustic, an ancient technique in which pigment is suspended in wax, giving each brush stroke a distinct materiality.

The Spokes column last Sunday, about New York City's bicycling culture, misidentified the bike owned by Dante Pryor, a racer and Columbia University student. It is a $5,700 Orbea Orca, not a Colnago. Because of an editing error, the column also misidentified the city building to which Transportation Commissioner Janette Sadik-Khan commutes by bicycle. It is the Transportation Department headquarters on Water Street, not City Hall.

OESTREICHER--Irma. On April 27, in her 89th year, from Lymphoma, at her home, with her family. Born July 4th 1920 to Barnett and Dora Kaplan. Married 1943 to Martin Shapiro and had two children, Robert (Jacqueline) and Daniel (Lynne). In 1958 married Gerard Oestreicher and was a wonderful stepmother to his three children, Lee (Alejandra), Lynn (Noel Jeffrey), and Laurie (Larry Lowenstein). Adored her grandchildren, Holiday Shapiro (Robyn Linde), Brett Haussamen (Jim Sabo), Gerard Jeffrey, Jay Lowenstein (Jayme), Victoria Shapiro (Jon Forsberg), Abi Shapiro, and Caitlin Shapiro (Rowan Gay). Found renewed joy in her great-grandchildren, Evan, Sophie, Kara, and Ava. In later life she was grateful for the companionship of Dan Rodgers. She is survived by her brother Bill Kaplan (Anita). She was raised (forever proud) in Brooklyn, graduated Erasmus High School and Hunter College. She lived in New Rochelle and in 1958 moved to Manhattan (her true home). Her second husband, Gerard Oestreicher, was the chairman of Oestreicher Realty and a Broadway producer. He died in 1987. Irma became a Broadway angel and then a producer in her own right. She produced "Cantorial", "Mademoiselle Colombe", and co-produced "Long Day's Journey Into Night" for which she received a Tony nomination. She was a director of the American Theatre Hall of Fame. Active until her last few months she devoted herself to her family, her many friends, the Theatre, her charities, the Democratic Party, books, bridge, and crosswords. She will be sorely missed by many who loved her keen intellect and tremendous wit, her generosity and her loyalty. The family will receive at the home of Lynn and Noel Jeffrey, 33 East 70th Street, Sunday, May 2nd between 4-8pm. Services will be Monday, May 3rd at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, followed by a reception at the Jeffreys'. In lieu of flowers, please consider a contribution to the Democratic candidate of your choice.

He has now crossed the threshold into a painless life of light and love. We will miss you always.

Don't be fooled by the title. ''The Story of Graphic Design'' (Abrams) is actually a book about the history of reading -- a deftly told and well-laid-out survey that begins with the Rosetta Stone and continues chronologically through to the Kindle. With a nod to E. H. Gombrich's landmark ''Story of Art'' (which favored art over history), the author Patrick Cramsie (who along with Bobby Birchall also designed the book) puts a premium on composition and style in his assessment of everything from the Gutenberg Bible and Milton Glaser's Dylan poster to graffiti from Pompeii and British frigate camouflage. Science, superstition, fashion, commerce and politics all get credit for shaping the written word. (See: the signs for the Munich Olympics, which had to overcome the last German-hosted Olympics' stigma as the ''Nazi Games,'' or the First Things First 1964 and 2000 manifestos, which urged designers to prioritize their commissions in terms of societal issues rather than profit margins.) The book appears not a moment too soon, when how we read is hurtling toward a hairpin curve. An epilogue -- for the iPad -- might be in order. LEANNE SHAPTON

A illustrator of pulp covers and magazines, he is best known for his Esquire calendar pin ups. In the 1960's, he began painting the American west. He has an art gallery in Santa Fe. He and his wife Kathryn lived in Kings Point, NY. After her death in 2001, he lived with his daughter in Minneapolis, Minnesota. He spent his last years traveling the world with her. HER ROVING EYE Kelly Wearstler's life is as vibrant and busy as the rooms she creates. With her husband and sons Oliver, 7, and Elliott, 6; residences in Beverly Hills and Malibu, Calif.; and a business that takes her from Los Angeles to Anguilla to Paris in the space of a week, her only downtime is in the air. (Not a fan of flying, she travels with her good-luck charm, Franc, the stuffed bear that belonged to her grandmother and mother. She had him re-covered in linen since ''his fur had been loved off,'' and sewed on the buttons from her grandfather's navy blazer to replace his eyes.) When she does escape, she says she likes places ''where I can relax, but also go into a city and be inspired and shop. Otherwise I go stir crazy.'' Paris, London and Buenos Aires are top destinations, as is Miami. ''Believe it or not, there's really great shopping there,'' says Wearstler, who's been collecting vintage clothing since she was 15. Naturally, the woman known for mixing styles doesn't have a favorite period. ''Like with furniture, there's always something good that comes out of every decade.''

PAUL--Karen J.,55, passed away on April 22, 2010 in Allentown, PA. Cherished daughter of Dr. George and Beverly Paul, beloved sister of Susan Dembo (Tom) and Joanne Paul, adored aunt of Matthew and Jillian Dembo. We will miss her. She will always be in our hearts.

Laugh all you want, but the name ''Design Within Reach'' was never meant to be about affordability. When Rob Forbes founded the high-end modern furniture retailer in 1999, he was throwing open the doors to a realm that was -- at least in this country -- maddeningly difficult for the average civilian to penetrate without the help of an interior designer. With his new company, Public, he's taking the pain out of acquiring another elusive design object: the stylish, practical city bike, the kind that the Dutch and Danish ride. A longtime urban cyclist himself, Forbes watched as places like New York, San Francisco and even Louisville, Ky., spent the last decade opening bike lanes and encouraging alternative transportation, and yet, he argues, most American bike stores still cater primarily to athletes. ''Bicycle technology here is centered on lightweight performance, so they're not as interested in a customer that wants a kickstand, rack and fenders,'' he says. The Public M (left) is a lightweight update on classic French models from the '60s and '70s, à la ''Jules et Jim.'' And at $600 to $1,200, Public's bikes are more or less within reach. Forbes still believes in living a well-designed life, but this time around he's taking his gospel to the streets. Go to publicbikes.com. MONICA KHEMSUROV

THE NEWS After voting three days in a row to block the Senate from considering a major overhaul of the nation's financial regulatory system, Republican senators relented and allowed floor debate to begin. BEHIND THE NEWS The Republicans, who oppose many parts of the bill, apparently retreated after concluding that their tactics were irritating voters who want to rein in Wall Street. They won no concessions from Democrats for the decision, and a tough fight over amending the bill lies ahead. Republicans can still block the bill with a filibuster if they stick together.

CLAUDY JONGSTRA ''There are only about 1,000 remaining Drenthe Heath sheep, the oldest breed in Europe,'' says the Dutch textile artist Claudy Jongstra, who owns 200 of them. Jongstra is a felt virtuoso: her textiles have been used by Christian Lacroix and John Galliano, and one of her huge felt murals is now on view at Lincoln Center's David Rubenstein Atrium in New York. Jongstra rendered our trademark T in the fuzzy stuff (Page 57), but her practice is about so much more than the final product. In addition to shearing wool, treating it and felting it, she grows plants to make her own organic dyes, including ''madder,'' a red she used for the T. A typical Dutch dye, it's the same one that Vermeer used in his painting ''Girl With the Red Hat.'' ''When you see this color, there's an instant cultural reference,'' Jongstra says.
We need to grow up. We need to learn not to cheat or to let others cheat. IOANNIS PLAKOPOULOS, a Greek newsstand owner, on the rampant tax evasion in his country. [1]

NUSSBAUM--Ruth, beloved matriarch of Temple Israel of Hollywood. Adored wife of the late Rabbi Max Nussbaum, cherished mother of Hannah Marsh and Jeremy (Charline) Nussbaum, loving grandmother and friend to Daniel and Cindy Marsh, Margaret and Sharone Sinai, Gabriel Nussbaum and Elizabeth Wood, and Lily Nussbaum. Ruth was also the adoring "GG" to Ruby, Max, Jake, and Gabriella. An international leader in Zionist causes, Ruth was a national Vice Chairman of ARZA and in 1996 received an honorary doctorate from Hebrew Union College. Born in Berlin in 1911 and married to the love of her life, the Berlin Jewish leader and firebrand, Rabbi Max Nussbaum in 1938, Ruth and her husband fought tirelessly to rescue Jews from Nazi Germany. In late 1940, Ruth and Max immigrated to the U.S. to a welcoming congregation in Oklahoma and then to their permanent home at Temple Israel in Hollywood. Throughout her life Ruth felt strongly that the Civil Rights Movement was the American parallel to the Zionist fight; She fought actively for racial equality in the United States. Her love of literature and music was legendary as was her deep friendships which crossed many generations. Her memory will be as a blessing.

TELTSER--Patricia. We mourn with our nieces and nephews the untimely death of our sister, Pat. One would be hard pressed to find anyone who lived with such courage and died with such grace. We will remember her vitality, her sense of humor, her presence upon entering a room and we will love her forever. Phyllis and Leon Charash

NESLIN--Illene 85, died on April 27, 2010 at home in her own bed of cancer. The youngest child of pharmacist Joe and Rose Pinck she was also predeceased by WWII Navy Veteran, brother Richard and his daughter Leslie. Ilene studied at the Art Students League in New York City and exhibited widely under her middle name Dana. She received awards from prominent juried shows including the prestigious National Arts Club. An extraordinary artist, gourmet cook and "fashionista" she was a beautiful woman with great flair and a fabulous sense of humor. Greatly loved and loving she had a long, fascinating life. Illene was married for twenty years to television producer, the late John A. Aaron and widowed after nineteen years by musician Jack Waltzer. In 1985 she married childhood "crush" the beloved Stanley Neslin, who survives. Illene ADORED her family: Brother Dr. Robert Lloyd Pinck (Rita), daughter Lynn Aaron (Bob Friedman), step-son Scott Neslin (Betsey) and their children Jenny, Louise, and Lenny. She also leaves numerous nieces, nephews, wonderful friends and extended family, particularly Elaine, Ergin and Troy. Bravely determined she died exactly as she wished because of the exemplary, loving care, lavished on her by our incomparable Carin (Thank-You "Dah-ling") and hospice. In lieu of flowers please donate Valley Hospice, 15 Essex Road, Suite 301, Paramus, NJ 07652, or any Humane Animal Society. Services Private. Illene....unforgettable, that's what you are.

I have never been quite sure what to make of the usual ''you should go to this college'' comment. Usually it comes from former classmates -- those a year ahead of me, enjoying their freshman year at any one of many exciting colleges. Now that I have committed to attend Michigan State, I do not receive idle suggestions like I did before, when nearly every encounter with missed friends brought more inconsequential tips for the best places to attend. It was almost always their schools they were plugging.

ACKERMAN--Don Eugene, 76, of New York, NY and Naples, FL passed away on the 25th of April 2010 at home in New York City. Born in Gothenburg, Nebraska and educated at West Point he was a proud member of the class of 1956. During the Cold War he flew tactical nuclear weapons missions with the 492nd Squadron of the 48th Fighter Bomber Wing. He received his Masters degree from Harvard Business School in 1963 and while teaching economics at the United States Air Force Academy he began his business career by developing an apartment building with his mother. During the Vietnam War he served in the Pentagon. He resigned his commission as a major in 1967 and was hired by the venerable Venture Capital firm J.H. Whitney and Co. where he continued to repeatedly distinguish himself. After heading the National Venture Capital Association he went on to have a very successful career as a private investor. Don lived the great American dream but remained unchanged by success. He led by example, preferring that others take his place in the spotlight. Above all, he was a hard working man with an unimpeachable moral character. He is survived by his wife Jean, his brother Jim, his daughter Cheri, his sons Michael and Steven, and seven grandchildren, all of whom deeply mourn his passing. A service will be held at West Point on May 10 at 10am in the Old Cadet Chapel located in the cemetery. Prayer and full military honors will follow at the gravesite. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

CLASTER--Robert A. The directors, shareholders and professional colleagues of Carl Marks & Co. mourn the sudden passing in Israel of Robert A. Claster, younger brother of Mark L. Claster, our President, CEO, and valued friend. The pain of the loss is all the greater because of the special closeness and bond that exists among the Claster family members. To Mark, his wife Susan, and the entire Claster family, we extend our deepest sympathy and profound regrets.

SEROTA--Nathan. "The value of a man", Albert Einstein observed, "should be seen in what he gives and not in what he is able to receive". In one word, Nat Serota was a man who gave. For over 30 years as a devoted and respected trustee and former Chairman of Daytop, he gave of himself to the legions of young people struggling to overcome addiction. His biography, "Don't put your dreams on hold", is not only a saying Nat lived by, but one he embodied. He encouraged our young residents by impressing upon them that they can do anything they wanted to do. "Make up your mind to do it," he would tell them. "Work at it, and you will succeed. Don't put your dreams on hold!" Nat's generous financial support was greatly appreciated, but more importantly he gave of his time, love and concern. Doing for others is what made Nat happy and in doing so thousands of lives were changed for the better. Through his own strength of character, determination and keen business acumen, he built a highly regarded and successful real estate company. And upon reaching the pinnacle of success--no matter whether he was in the company of celebrated personalities, potentates, popes or just plain folks, Nat was always the same down to earth, straight talking guy that we all loved. Nat not only talked the talk, but he walked the walk. As Chairman of Daytop, of all the remarkable people he met along the way, it was Pope John Paul who saw in Nat a truly good soul. During a private mass that followed lunch with the Pope, Nat felt compelled to be blessed by John Paul. When the Pope offered Nat communion he reminded the Pope that he was a Jewish, and Pope John Paul, without hesitation replied, "My Son, so was Jesus". Nat Serota provided us a singular example of what one determined, talented, charismatic, caring and giving individual can do for the betterment of mankind. And though he has died, his contributions will live on in the lives of countless others whose dreams he so generously fulfilled. Rather than our own death, it is the death of a friend that hurts us. With the passing of Nat Serota, there are untold numbers in every walk of life, who are deeply hurt today. He was just that kind of special of friend.

SEROTA--Nathan L. A Real Estate Developer on Long Island for the past 53 years after a long hard struggle has passed away on early Saturday morning May 1, 2010. Mr. Serota who began his career as a ticket merchant for the Pennsylvania Railroad in the late 1940s and early 1950s began his real estate development business truly from the ground up. He built over 300 homes on the south shore of Long Island. Soon thereafter, Mr. Serota through his undaunting efforts developed over 50 shopping centers throughout Long Island. Mr. Serota continued this development business alongside his three sons, Charles, Geoffrey and Daniel. Along with his family, he developed a wonderful group of employees that have made his business one of the most important and solid businesses in Long Island. Mr. Serota served his country gallantly as a Aircraft Gunner post Pearl Harbor for the next three and a half years receiving a Honorable Discharge. He has been philanthropic in an extremely effective way. He has been a member and Chairman of the Board of Daytop Village, an important drug abuse program which is a program fighting drug abuse for the past 40 years. Mr. Serota is survived by his wife Vivian, his sons Charles, Geoffrey and Daniel, his daughter Deborah, his son-in-law Kenneth, daughters-in-law Sherry, Karen and Joelle. He is also survived by nine grandchildren. We will forever miss this wonderful, fertile human being.

SEROTA--Nathan L.,passed away peacefully in his home Saturday morning, May 1, 2010. Loving husband of Vivian, devoted father of Charles and Karen Serota, Geoffery and Joell Serota, Daniel Cherie Serota, Deborah and Kenneth Carbone. The playoffs often force players to change their typical role with a team, and the first round this season was no exception. While Oklahoma City's Kevin Durant had his scoring average drop considerably, Deron Williams took over as a dominant scoring option in the Utah Jazz's first-round win over the Denver Nuggets. Williams, who has never averaged more than 19.4 points in the regular season, or 21.6 points in the postseason, averaged 25.8 points in the six-game series, scoring more than 30 twice.

THE other day I had the pleasure of being a juror at the student fashion presentation by Pratt Institute. We met in Manhattan at Milk Studios, roughly 30 of us, to choose the best designs for the graduation show on May 13. Among my fellow jurors were the costume designer William Ivey Long, the style legend Iris Apfel and Eric Gaskins, a former designer who now has a blog. We each were assigned to a panel -- I got evening wear and bridal. So, this is a partial view of Pratt's aspiring designers. Some of the work was uneven -- poor execution combined with unclear concept -- and Mr. Gaskins, on my panel, usually spotted the snag and gently set the student straight. A collection we all seemed to like was Devin Cole's hand-painted dresses in cotton gauze with asymmetrical braided trim. But we didn't think the style or the tea-stained colors said ''bridal.''

This spring, Delta Air Lines resumes seasonal service to Valencia, Spain, with four weekly nonstop flights from New York City. This is the third year Delta has offered this route. Service begins May 28 and goes until Oct. 30. A recent search found a $978 round-trip fare for travel in early June.

OPTIMISM has returned to the multibillion-dollar art market. Expectations are so high that many will be disappointed if Picasso's 1932 painting ''Nu au Plateau de Sculpteur (Nude, Green Leaves and Bust)'' doesn't break the record for a work of art sold at auction when it is offered at Christie's on Tuesday. That sale will kick off two weeks of important spring auctions, and bets are that this seminal painting of Picasso's mistress Marie-Thérèse Walter is poised to eclipse the $104.3 million paid for the current record holder, Giacometti's ''Walking Man I.'' The Giacometti was bought in February by Lily Safra, widow of the banker Edmond J. Safra, at Sotheby's in London.
Dance Jack Anderson

Graduate of Brooklyn and Bank Street Colleges and NYU, guidance counselor committed to quality public education for all; a progressive activist, member of the Teachers Union of New York, later led the Teachers Action Caucus of the UFT. KNOWN for her vibrant, dripping, wildly expressive portraits of models ripped straight from fashion magazines, Katherine Bernhardt paints like a person infatuated with her subject. And she is. ''I paint what I'm obsessed with,'' she admits. ''At the moment, it's Morocco.'' Case in point: she has traveled there three times in the last six months, and her new show, ''Tombouctou 52 Jours,'' now at Canada gallery, takes its cues from Morocco's rugs, murals and women. She is also releasing a book that is part travelogue, part catalog, and has started a rug-importing company called Magic Flying Carpets of the Berber Kingdom of Morocco (magicflyingcarpets.com).
MACINTYRE--Robert C.,83, passed on April 20, 2010. A life dedicated to family, love, learning and sharing. He will always be in our hearts.

SETTERSTROM--Carl A.,Chemist and Polymer Entrepreneur, died surrounded by loving family in Denver, CO on April 17th. Carl was 94 and originally from New York City. An early pioneer of Polymer Science, his specialties were polymer development and the creation of new companies. Carl worked for Union Carbide, Pfizer, Sun Oil, and his own consulting firm. A force for peace, church unity and equal rights, Carl served the Riverside Church of New York City for many years. Carl enriched each life he came in contact with. Carl met everyone with enthusiasm and appreciation and had a special gift of making each person he interacted with feel genuinely valued. He was larger than life. He is survived by his two daughters, Star and Barbara, four grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.

I dine out often, and lately I've noticed a new trend occurring in some restaurants. I call it the Great Roundup. The last time it happened, I was having a perfectly adequate meal at one of my favorite neighborhood bistros. My lunch, including tax, was $14.71. I placed a crisp $20 bill in the leatherette folder and waited for change. After a few minutes, the waitress returned. I was given a $5 bill and one quarter.

Being a star in a big Bollywood production takes lots of training. But if all you want is to be an extra, join the tourist crowds on Colaba Causeway, at popular spots like Leopold Cafe or Cafe Mondegar. More likely than not, you'll be approached by a casting agent with an offer that might sound something like this: an all-expenses-paid day on a movie set, payment of about 500 rupees (about $11.50, at 43 rupees to the dollar) and a chance to share the screen with stars like Shahrukh Khan.

SEAR--Walter E. April 27, 1930-April 29, 2010. A recording engineer, tuba designer, composer, tuba player, synthesizer pioneer, and vintage recording equipment guru. Beloved husband of Edith, father of Shana and Julia, father-in-law of James and Johan and grandfather of Adam, Maggie and Chris. Born in New Orleans he graduated from the Curtis Institute of Music and Temple University. As a performing tuba player and composer he not only designed and produced the recognized "Walter E. Sear" 4-valve tuba, but also pioneered the development of analog electronic music and recording. Founder of New York's first electronic recording studio "Sear Sound" he counted Sonic Youth, Steely Dan, Paul McCartney and Yoko Ono among his many clients. A celebratory memorial will be held date to be announced. Donations may be made in Walter's name to the Curtis Institute of Music.

English is now just an effective language for communication. No one studies English literature to speak English. In France literature is by tradition highly respected. They publish and translate a lot of books from around the world. The question is not French vs. English, but between two conceptions of culture. One as mercantile, producing mostly for entertainment, the other deeply rooted in the European attempt to think about the world. Guillaume Hérisson of Montreal, responding to Michael Kimmelman's essay on the shift in francophone culture.

EVEN before it was announced that ''American Woman'' would be the theme of the Costume Institute's spring exhibition at the Met (which opens May 3 with a star-spangled gala), many designers seemed to have Americana on their minds. From Elvis to L. L. Bean, the Wild West to ''The Wild One,'' archetypal symbols of the country's identity popped up throughout the spring collections. Alexander Wang took inspiration from 1950s collegiate football uniforms. Ralph Lauren referenced the kind of Dust Bowl women seen in Dorothea Lange photos. For Derek Lam, East Coast honky-tonk beach towns served as his point of reference -- places like Asbury Park, N.J., and Coney Island that were ''so bad,'' he said, ''they're good.'' American fashion, as he noted, doesn't always have to be ''this pristine, uptown kind of thing.'' It can also come with a side of kitsch.

''It sounds crazy to say this, I know, but our pants are a steal.'' -Scott Sternberg, a clothing designer who makes cotton gabardine khakis that sell for $550. The khakis are tailored like dress pants, and the details are largely sewn by hand. MANY native New Yorkers would be uncomfortable going on a tour of their city. After all, the very word ''tour'' shares etymological roots with the much-maligned ''tourist,'' and many natives insist that, as far as the five boroughs go, they've seen it all anyway. It doesn't help the standing of tours that the City Council was so miffed about their blaring loudspeakers that on Thursday it voted to require them to use headphones. But city natives should know that not all tours feature noisy buses, and not all focus on the Empire State Building or other obvious sights. The menu of tours in this city, in fact, is as diverse as its population. There are jogging tours, tours conducted by retired city police officers, and tours just for you and your MP3 player. And there are tours of special niches of the city -- like the offerings below -- that would interest even the most highly informed born-and-bred. SARAH MASLIN NIR

GOLDSMITH--Dolores. May 2, 2009. I Am Not There. Do not stand at my grave and weep, I am not there I do not sleep, I am a thousand winds that blow, I am the diamond glints on snow, I am the sunlight on ripened grain, I am the gentle autumn's rain, When you awaken in the morning's hush, I am the swift uplifting rush of quiet birds in circled flight, I am the soft stars that shine at night, Do not stand at my grave and cry, I am not there, I did not die.

THERE are several classic recordings of Benjamin Britten's ''Billy Budd,'' including the 1967 Decca release conducted by Britten, with Peter Glossop in the title role and Peter Pears in a haunting, multilayered account of a role written for him, Captain Vere. Even amid the strong competition, the newest ''Billy Budd'' stands out: a Virgin Classics release (5 19039 2; three CDs) recorded live in December 2007, featuring the rising English conductor Daniel Harding, the London Symphony Orchestra and the exciting American baritone Nathan Gunn as the young sailor Billy Budd, a boyishly handsome, simple-minded and thoroughly decent foundling who is pressed into naval service aboard the British ship Indomitable in 1797.

HESS--Norma. The Board of Directors at Raritan Bay Medical Center and the Raritan Bay Medical Center Foundation wish to extend their deepest condolences to the Hess Family and the many cherished friends and loved ones of Norma W. Hess. Mrs. Hess' life-long charitable endeavors and her assurance of increasing the quality of life for members of our healthcare community is a legacy that will live on in the hearts and minds of medical staff, constituents, and local residents who were and forever will be positively impacted by her graciousness and unfaltering generosity. Through her family's support, Raritan Bay Medical Center was able to establish the Jacqueline R. and Robert N. Wilentz Cancer Center, to enhance our oncology services and patient care. Mrs. Hess' name, legacy and civic and social consciousness will be remembered fondly. From her treasured hometown of Perth Amboy, New Jersey we send our heartfelt sympathy.

AS a longtime set stylist and editor at large for Elle Décor, Carlos Mota knows a thing or two about making spaces beautiful. Flowers factor heavily. ''They change everything,'' he said. ''They make a room happy.'' And as Mr. Mota demonstrates in his new book, ''Flowers Cheap & Chic,'' they don't have to cost a fortune. Likening it to a cookbook, he serves up numerous recipes for concocting bouquets from the things around you: paint cans, recycled beer bottles, a branch from the backyard, carnations from the local deli. ''People think you need to spend $100 for something good,'' he said. ''Well, guess what? A glass of water with one peony in it is as beautiful as 20.'' Carlos Mota, ''Flowers Cheap & Chic'' (Clarkson Potter), $25.

THIS 1959 gem of a painting may be small -- only 10 inches by 8 inches -- but it incorporates many of Mr. Johns's signature techniques. Here he takes a single stenciled zero as his subject and creates a playful, densely colored canvas that also uses fabric collage. This painting is being sold by the distinguished collector Steven A. Cohen, a hedge-fund billionaire. Mr. Cohen recently scored a coup when he bought one of Mr. Johns's ''Flag'' paintings from Jean-Christophe Castelli, son of Leo Castelli, Mr. Johns's celebrated dealer, for a reported $110 million. That 1958 canvas is twice the size of the ''Flag'' being sold by the Crichton estate this spring.

Will any Broadway show approach the record-tying 15 Tony Award nominations of last year's "Billy Elliot: The Musical"? Will the cavalcade of Hollywood stars on the boards dominate the Tony acting nominations announced Tuesday morning, or will lesser-known theater veterans receive their fair share for critically acclaimed work? Will plays and musicals that opened and closed earlier in the 2009-10 theater season - like "Finian's Rainbow," "Ragtime," "The Royal Family," "Superior Donuts," and "Time Stands Still" - receive much recognition compared to shows that are still running? Which shows were blanked among the nominees? Who wuz robbed? We're live-blogging the Tony nominations starting at 8:30 a.m. here.

With spring's arrival, I hear them calling and chirping outside my window, but I rarely turn around to look. Instead my eye is drawn to designers and artists producing their own versions of ornithology.

The impact of a car bomb discovered Saturday night in Times Square could be felt underground on Monday. As Ray Rivera wrote in The Times, "For New Yorkers, it was an unsubtle and unsettling reminder that threats could be lurking in the trunks or back seats of any of the thousands of vehicles that push their way into the city every day" -- on streets only a few feet over the subway lines.

As my colleague Vikas Bijaj reports, a court in Mumbai, India has convicted the lone surviving gunman who took part in the Nov. 26, 2008 attacks in that city of murder, conspiracy and waging war against India. The gunman, Ajmal Kasab, who was filmed taking part in the attacks, quickly confessed to the authorities from a hospital bed that he had been trained and sent by the Pakistani militant group, Lashkar-e-Taiba. Although he later recanted that confession, it was captured on video and broadcast on Indian television.

Some of the uncertainty lingering around the financial rescue for Greece cleared Monday, as the German government approved its share of a huge bailout, and the European Central Bank said it would accept Greek bonds as collateral for loans, regardless of any future downgrades, The New York Times's Judy Dempsey and Jack Ewing report from Germany.

This week, the paint company Benjamin Moore will present its Hue Awards for the best use of color in architecture and interiors, and the lifetime achievement award will go to the New York design team of William Diamond and Anthony Baratta, whose sophisticated, bold, and vividly-colored interiors have been featured in The New York Times Magazine. Although the choice of Diamond Baratta would seem a no-brainer, this is the first time that the award has gone to interior designers; past winners were the architects Steven Holl, Ettore Sottsass, and Ricardo Legorreta. Diamond Baratta is known for custom-designing everything from fabrics to braided rugs, and paint colors are no exception. But in an odd coincidence, the designers have always used Benjamin Moore paint bases. And when they told told the company that they were donating their $5000 prize money to the Center for Special Studies at New York-Presbyterian Hospital, which provides specialized care to people with HIV and AIDS, Benjamin Moore matched Diamond Baratta's donation. Baratta credits Diamond with being the firm's color maven. "Bill is really the maestro of color selection," he said. "It's like music--you have to have perfect pitch." Above, a few of the firm's colorful interiors.

Overview | Is PowerPoint a valuable tool, or does it stifle critical thinking and innovative presentation of material? How can information be presented visually using PowerPoint without falling into the trap of simplistic bullet-point prose? In this lesson, students examine perspectives on effective and ineffective uses of PowerPoint, then develop a set of rules for effective use of this tool for their class projects and presentations. They then create PowerPoint slides and a prose narrative on the same subject and compare the impact of each on the intended audience.

'Bjork plays a parking garage' sounds like a dreamy Michel Gondry video pitch, but this weekend, it was a sweaty reality. Above the Auto Parts is an accurately named space: literally above an auto parts store in Bushwick, Brooklyn, it is a parking garage for much of the week that's lately doubled as a DIY club. Bjork liked it enough to DJ a show there on Sunday night, a benefit for the Haiti relief group Partners in Health. (She checked out another venue, the Market Hotel, which has since been shut down, but preferred Above the Auto Parts because it was rougher, said the promoter, Todd Patrick.) The other DJs were also a who's who of the New York music scene: Dave Longstreth of the art-rock favorites the Dirty Projectors, Tyondai Braxton of the math rock-y Battles, Alex Ross of The New Yorker and Brandon Stosuy, an editor at the music blog Stereogum, who helped organize the event, all took turns or buddied up at the decks to play a mix of obscure tunes and pop hits. The crowd was mostly Brooklyners who turned out to dance despite the fact that the unventilated space had them sweating even when standing still.

The Massachusetts Institute of Technology IT Sloan Sports Analytics Conference is regarded as a gathering of like-minded sports dorks pushing basketball statistics away from traditional measures, such as points and assists, and toward more advanced measures, including hockey-style plus/minus. But at this year's conference in March a debate continued over whether plus/minus is relevant when evaluating individual players in basketball. Some critics contend it might work better in measuring the effectiveness of five-man lineups.

This post by Cato's Daniel Griswold, comparing the difficulties involved in border control to the failures of Prohibition, offers a useful way to understand the contours of the immigration controversy. Most supporters of "comprehensive" reform, conservative and liberal and libertarian alike, basically agree with Griswold that trying to secure America's borders when so many people want to cross them is the equivalent of the Volstead Act - a fool's errand no matter what resources you throw at it. In this theory, laws are no match for markets: So long as there's a supply of workers south of the border and enough demand for their services north of it, roughly the same number of immigrants are going to enter the United States every year no matter what kind of enforcement measures you implement.

However the Afghan war is faring over all, across the wide and varied expanse of Afghanistan, with all of its political and cultural complexity, one thing is abundantly clear: toggling between fighting and outreach can create head-spinning scenes. Some of these scenes underline the difficulties inherent in a counterinsurgency doctrine that mixes lopsided violence with attempts to make nice. But they also simultaneously demonstrate that the efforts to follow the doctrine far from Kabul, out on remote ground, have become a central part of how the war is waged, even as the merits of the doctrine are quietly debated.

Today we have a veritable puzzle-fest, as we explore the kaleidoscopic work of a fascinating modern polymath, Clifford Pickover. "Add two doses of Isaac Asimov, and one dose each of Martin Gardner and Carl Sagan, and you get Clifford Pickover, one of the most entertaining and thought provoking writers of our time," writes Michael Shermer, editor of "Skeptic" magazine. A prolific author and futurist, Pickover has published more than 40 books, exploring topics ranging from computers and creativity to art, mathematics, parallel universes, Einstein, time travel, alien life, religion, dimethyltryptamine elves, and the nature of human genius. All of today's puzzles were either designed by Pickover or are based on his work. For our puzzle prize we offer his latest, stunningly illustrated work, "The Math Book," which has the intriguing subtitle "From Pythagoras to the 57th Dimension: 250 Milestones in the History of Mathematics."

Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, has posted an open letter explaining why Flash, which makes it possible to view videos and animations on your computers, won't be on iPhones. Short answer: He prefers a standard called H.264, in which Apple holds a stake.

While Abigail Breslin's Broadway debut in "The Miracle Worker" did not meet with much success, a stage adaptation of the movie that helped put her on the map (and earned her an Academy Award nomination at age 10) is inching ever closer to the Great White Way. The musical version of "Little Miss Sunshine" will be presented next year at the La Jolla Playhouse in San Diego, Variety reported [subscription required]. The film, which also starred Greg Kinnear, Steve Carell, Toni Collette and Alan Arkin, centered on a precocious young performer (Ms. Breslin) and her eccentric family's do-or-die efforts to get her into a beauty pageant. It was a breakout hit at the 2006 Sundance Film Festival and went on to earn more than $100 million at the box office worldwide. A version of the musical was presented last year at the Sundance Institute Theater Lab at White Oak in Yulee, Fla. The La Jolla production, which will run from Feb. 15 through March 27, 2011, features music and lyrics by William Finn and a book and direction by James Lapine, who previously collaborated on "Falsettos." No casting has been announced, though an ArtsBeat colleague churlishly asked if Kristin Chenoweth was available.
Let's be honest. This year's Kentucky Derby was an ugly horse race. Certainly the grim weather had much to do with it, and was something we cannot control. But still, the race was ugly.

Katie Allison Granju wrote a book, some say the book, about attachment parenting. She writes a popular blog, mamapundit.com, about the ups and downs of her blended family of four children, who range in age from 3 to 18, with a baby girl due this summer. As she puts it, "I've blogged through marriage, the end of a marriage, a horrifically painful divorce, re-entry into the full-time work force, single parenting, working motherhood, falling in love, remarriage, blended family life, pregnancy, miscarriage, childbirth, breast-feeding, baby- and toddlerhood."

Recently I discovered a place in San Francisco that is apparently a very well kept secret -- no one that I mentioned it to there had ever heard of it. It's called Wave Organ, and it is one of those phenomena that could only exist in northern California. Originally created in 1986 by the environmental artists Peter Richards and George Gonzales and newly restored, Wave Organ, which is part of the Exploratorium, is a 10-minute walk toward the Marina and out onto a jetty. Approaching the white and gray stone multi-layered structure I felt like I had been transported to a Greek island if not for the amazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge. I stepped out on to the granite and marble stones (which I later learned were donated to the project from an old Gold Rush era cemetery that was demolished to make way for a housing development), tilted my ear onto one of the numerous PVC pipes sticking out of the floor, and began to hear poetically eerie sounds. Each pipe makes a different sound depending on the tide. I then sat in a 3-sided room, listening to the music bounce off of the walls while seagulls dipped in an out of view. It was peaceful and calming and by the time I left, I felt as if I had been on holiday.

These unnamed babydoll sheep have spent the first 11 months of their lives at a farm upstate. But they are finally ready for the big time: the farm menagerie at the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn, where they will make their debut at this weekend's Fleece Festival and be relieved of their winter coats. The zoo is also taking votes for names. The choices: Raggedy Ann and Andy, Peep and Beau, Lucy and Ricky, Amy and Charlie, Ginger and Fred. What, no Megan and Jeff?

Harold T. Shapiro, a former president of Princeton University and the University of Michigan, will lead a 12-member panel that will review the practices of the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which has been criticized for errors.

The Interacademy Council has named the 12-member panel that will assess the activities and approach of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and issue a report by October. The committee, led by Harold Shapiro, a past president of Princeton and the University of Michigan, contains some scientific luminaries, including the Nobelist Mario Molina and Syukuro Manabe, one of the pioneers in efforts to simulate the climate system using computers.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
Q.

When McNeil Consumer Healthcare announced its recall of certain liquid versions of children's Tylenol, Motrin, Zyrtec and Benadryl over the weekend, its news release told people not to give the products to their children. The company also put up a Web site that included instructions for safe disposal of the medicine in the trash.

The Signature Theater Company and Hartford Stage's epic co-production of Horton Foote's "Orphans' Home Cycle" was named outstanding play and the Vineyard Theater's presentation of the John Kander and Fred Ebb musical "The Scottsboro Boys" was named outstanding musical on Sunday at the ceremony for the Lucille Lortel Awards, which are presented annually by the Off-Broadway League. "When the Rain Stops Falling," a Lincoln Center Theater production, was the night's biggest winner, picking up five awards including ones for outstanding director (David Cromer) and featured actress (Mary Beth Hurt). Michael Urie of "The Temperamentals" was named outstanding actor and Judith Ivey was named outstanding actress for "The Glass Menagerie"; the Roundabout Theater Company and Long Wharf Theater's production of that Tennessee Williams play was also named outstanding revival. Susan Stroman claimed the Lortel for outstanding choreography for "The Scottsboro Boys," and Colman Domingo's "A Boy and His Soul," also presented at the Vineyard, was named outstanding solo show.

United Airlines and Continental Airlines agreed to a $3 billion merger that would create the world's biggest airline, according to people briefed on the negotiations. United is buying Continental, and the combined company will keep the United name and be based in Chicago. Read more.

Karl Haendel's breezy, virtuosic powers with a pencil have produced 34 large-scale works on paper that confront the limitations of drawing as a medium. The installation -- a commission for Lever House - pits paper and pencil against the soaring, glass curtain wall of Gordon Bunshaft's modernist icon. But if it's a David and Goliath matchup, then Haendel comes out on top. After all, a modernist glass tower has, relative to its size, a thin skin and these drawings seem to take direct aim at that vulnerability. Cracks - both literal and figurative - are the leitmotif: smashed glass, shattered light bulbs, arresting images of broken eggs, snaking power cables and a gigantic fingerprint fractured into dash marks. Haendel takes pleasure in toying with the conventions of display -- the drawings are hung on two specially built and intentionally unfinished walls -- and his use of tacks and staples is a delightful affront to the works' inherent fragility. Frank, handwritten comments on the walls and on annotated lists of absurd phrases and book titles bring the age of anxiety into focus.

G.O.P. Candidates for Governor Debate | With a little more than five weeks before the June primary, two Republicans vying to lead California debated on Sunday night. Meg Whitman, the former chief executive of eBay who is considered the front-runner in the race, and Steve Poizner, the state insurance commissioner, each sought to portray themselves as the more conservative of the two. Both candidates called for the repeal of the new federal health care law and the suspension of the state's landmark global warming law. Ms. Whitman is now almost even in polls with Jerry Brown, the Democrats' major candidate, who also is the state's former governor. Mr. Poizner, who wore a blazer with no tie, tried to paint Ms. Whitman, a billionaire who has poured her own money into the race, as out of touch with ordinary people. Mr. Poizner, a former Silicon Valley entrepreneur, has also spent much of his own money on his campaign. [The New York Times]

United Airlines and Continental Airlines agreed Sunday to a $3 billion merger that would create the world's biggest airline, according to people briefed on the negotiations. The deal, to be announced officially on Monday, would form a coast-to-coast behemoth with a leading presence in the top domestic markets, including New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, along with an extended network to Asia, Latin America and Europe. The deal was completed in a remarkably swift two weeks, and would give the airlines the muscle to fend off low-cost rivals at home and to take on foreign carriers abroad.

The opening Monday of a monthlong United Nations conference to strengthen the main treaty meant to halt the spread of nuclear arms is likely to be dominated by Iran's president denouncing the West and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton warning that if Tehran gets the bomb, the rest of the Middle East will soon follow. But far less visibly, the Obama administration has been mounting a country-by-country campaign to go beyond the treaty and ensure that Iran's push toward atomic mastery does not ignite a regional nuclear arms race. In recent months, diplomats have been holding meetings in Washington and shuttling to the Middle East in pursuit of agreements that will let countries develop nuclear power while relinquishing the right to make atomic fuel that could be turned into bombs.

SOBOTKA--Bernice, 91, passed away peacefully on May 1, 2010 in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida. Born in Lodz, Poland to Jacob and Rejla Rifka Katz, she survived internment in the Lodz Ghetto and Auschwitz during the Holocaust. After the war, she and her husband of 52 years, the late Mark Sobotka, moved to the Hartford, Connecticut area in 1949, where they raised their sons, Jacob (Cheryl) of Las Vegas and David (Karen) of New York City. She also leaves behind six beloved grandchildren, Seth (Pamela), Elizabeth, Andrew, Corey, Jesse and Ashley Sobotka, her brother Michael Katz (Sara) of Howard Beach, NY, her loving cousin Eva Libitzky (Martin) and many cousins, nephews and a niece. She was an active member and supporter of the Beth David Synagogue and Sisterhood, the Hebrew Home of Hartford Auxillary and Hadassah. She will be greatly missed by her family and many, many friends. A service will be held at 11am on Tuesday, May 4 at the Weinstein Mortuary, 640 Farmington Ave., Hartford, CT. Donations may be made to The Mark and Bernice Yom Hashoah Endowment c/o Yale Hillel, 80 Wall St., New Haven, CT 06511.

An article last Monday about a controversy surrounding sex ads on Craigslist, the online classified ad company, misstated the financing source of a new charitable initiative at the company and also rendered incorrectly part of its name. The new charity is the Craigslist Charitable Fund (not Trust), and it was started in 2008 with a $2.7 million contribution from Craigslist, not from the company's founder, Craig Newmark, and chief executive, James Buckmaster. (Mr. Newmark and Mr. Buckmaster, the two largest shareholders in Craigslist, are the two directors of the charity.)

MILLS--Gertrude "DuDu", 94, died on May 2 surrounded by her loved ones. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Mills, loving sister of Harriet and the late Bernard Brownstein, the late Sidney and Lee Wolfberg; devoted Aunt of Joan and the late Jordan Derwin, Gail and Alan Paley, Lynn and Martin Halbfinger, June and Jerry Gottlieb, Becky Kodish, Kathy and Neal Kodish and Lisa Case; adoring great-aunt of Sydney Paley and Brad Sitko, Steven Gottlieb, Allison Paley, Melissa Gottlieb, Bonnie and Caroline Halbfinger. She was a passionate supporter of liberal causes and will be remembered as a lifelong source of inspiration and support to everyone who knew her. Du will be greatly missed by all those whose lives she touched.

8 P.M. (Sundance) THE MATADOR (2008) As a boy in Granada, Spain, David Fandila, above, would fight imaginary bulls with his mother's dish towels. He grew up to confront real bulls, some weighing 1,300 pounds or more, to his mother's dismay. This documentary from Stephen Higgins and Nina Gilden Seavey chronicles Mr. Fandila's quest to reach 100 fights in a single season, a goal only 12 matadors have achieved. ''Barbaric, elegant, primitive, erotic, revolting, thrilling: the movie, like bullfighting itself, is all of these,'' Jeannette Catsoulis wrote in The New York Times. ''Blessed with a charismatic leading man, an arcane setting (bullfighting has roots in Roman sacrificial religion), and a narrative steeped in blood and hand-to-hoof combat -- not to mention a triumphant six-bull climax -- the film is a Hemingway fantasy.'' 9:30 A.M. (Fox Business Network) FOX BUSINESS Liz Claman starts the countdown to her 500th show, to be broadcast on Wednesday, by interviewing Warren E. Buffett, the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway; Charlie Munger, its vice chairman; and Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, on the heels of the annual Berkshire Hathaway shareholder meeting in Omaha. The topics include the economy, new investing opportunities, Goldman Sachs and Wall Street reform.

An article on Thursday about the death of a New York City subway motorman who collapsed in his cab as the train pulled out of a station in Queens referred incorrectly to the train's so-called dead-man feature, in which emergency brakes are applied if the operator lets go of the controller arm for any reason. While several transit officials and subway experts said this was the first time they had heard of the feature being activated, it has happened at least twice before. (A reader pointed out that, according to The Times's archives, the paper had written about such instances in 1927 and in 1940.)

SEROTA--Nathan L.,was a loving father and grandfather to Charles, Karen, Jennifer and l, Lauren. He was a selfless person who carried the burden and weight of others in order for his family to have a blessed life. He was the true essence of embodying the nature of a loving father and grandfather. He will walk next to us as we continue to walk our life paths. He has now crossed the threshold into a painless life of light and love. We will miss you always.

SEROTA--Nathan. When I needed a St Jude Heart Valve operation, we prayed to Saint Jude who gives "Hope to the Hopeless", and he sent us Nathan Serota. Mr. Serota, your compassion and generosity will live on in the hearts of my family forever. Thank you, Anne Mae

An article on Friday about the diverging paths of Motorola and Palm, two early innovators in the cellphone industry, misspelled the city in which Motorola is based. It is Schaumburg, Ill., not Schaumberg.
In a sonar search last year for the Loch Ness monster, scientists with a submersible device instead discovered more than 100,000 golf balls. Who knew the Loch Ness monster even played golf?

The top 10 financial news and information Web sites tracked by Nielsen drew some 71 million unique visitors in March. The larger sites in this category, like Yahoo Finance and MSN Money, offer one-stop shopping: users have access to business news, market and investment data and tools for managing personal finances, and they can track the market. About the only thing they cannot do is execute trades. Some sites are narrow in scope. Reuters, for example, pretty much sticks to economic news, and BNET.com operates as a resource for business professionals. SHELLY FREIERMAN

HECHT--Theodore, suddenly, on January 1, 2010, after a long illness. Son of the late Samuel and Lillian Hecht, husband of the late Ruth Hertz. After working for Time, Inc., including as a journalist in Washington, DC, later for many years worked in independent publishing in New York as a magazine editor. Hobbies included birdwatching, jewelery-making, trapshooting, travel, photography. Survived by his children Michael, James and Pamela. Contributions can be made to NYU Langone Medical Center for Acute Cardiac Unit, 11th Floor, (212) 404-3469.

SEROTA--Nathan. Nathan liked to say, "I negotiate like an enemy, but come through like a friend." For over 40 years Nathan Serota has been a builder, contractor and developer on Long Island, and with his death we see one of the last of a generation of businessmen who, when they gave you their word, you knew you had a deal. Nathan, both the Man and the Character, will be missed. Your friends on Long Island

SEROTA--Nathan. Dear Vivian and Nat, it was one of the luckiest days of my life, when over 30 years ago, you became my friend. The added bonus was your love for my husband Gerard. Many times, Nat told us that he could not believe that a poor boy from Brooklyn could live such a beautiful life and he knew that without his wife Vivian -- it would not have been possible. The last years of his life were not easy, but knowing that the end was near, he said the words every wife wants to hear words of love and gratitude, and once more endeared himself to all of us who loved him. We will miss you. Cheryl lee Terry and Gerard Potier

An article last Monday about an American effort to extradite a Jamaican political power broker to face charges of cocaine and marijuana trafficking misstated the Jamaican government's connection to the hiring of an American law firm that held meetings on the issue with White House and State Department officials. The Jamaican government said it had not been involved in the hiring of the firm, Manatt, Phelps & Phillips -- not that it had been involved. Because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly at one point to Peter Phillips, an opposition lawmaker who pressed for the Jamaican government to clarify who had hired the firm. It was Mr. Phillips -- not ''Mr. Peters'' -- who said, ''It seems at minimum that the government of Jamaica lent their name to an effort to represent the interests of an accused person.''

CUTLER--Cy. Beloved husband of Maxine for 60 years, father of Robert, Sara and Barry (deceased), father-in-law of Rob Shaw, brother-in-law of Harry Gordon. A graduate of Virginia Polytechnic Institute with a degree in metallurgical engineering, he built Standard White Metals into a leading manufacturer of zinc alloys. He represented his industry at the League of Nations (Geneva) International Lead and Zinc Organization. He was a long-time supporter of music in New York and Palm Beach, a former patron of the Metropolitan Opera, and a talented artist who exhibited photographs and paintings. Memorial service on Thursday, May 6 at 4:30pm at the Riverdale Yacht Club, 800 West 254th Street. Donations in his name to the Visiting Nurse Service of NY will be gratefully accepted.
SEROTA--Nathan. Our dear friend Nat, we will all miss you. Our love to your beautiful wife, Vivian. Love, Mona and Dan Morello

Danny was married to his beloved wife, Cindy Lamb Aiello, on March 8, 2001. Danny was an accomplished actor, director and stunt coordinator, who always loved what he did. Danny is survived by his parents, Danny and Sandra Aiello: his loving wife Cindy Lamb Aiello: daughters, Dawn and Allison: brothers, Rick and Jaime: sister, Stacey: and his nieces and nephews, Brielle, Rick Jr., Tori, Sydney, Gabrielle, Zachary and Jake.
