(www.riversidememorialchapel.com) In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The International Dyslexia Association. (www.interdys.org)
SEROTA--Nathan. Pop Pop, you left us too soon. We will love and miss you for the rest of our lives. You're loving grandchildren, Michael, Stephen, Jonathan, James and Chase

SETTERSTROM--Carl A.,Chemist and Polymer Entrepreneur, died surrounded by loving family in Denver, CO on April 17th. Carl was 94 and originally from New York City. An early pioneer of Polymer Science, his specialties were polymer development and the creation of new companies. Carl worked for Union Carbide, Pfizer, Sun Oil, and his own consulting firm. A force for peace, church unity and equal rights, Carl served the Riverside Church of New York City for many years. Carl enriched each life he came in contact with. Carl met everyone with enthusiasm and appreciation and had a special gift of making each person he interacted with feel genuinely valued. He was larger than life. He is survived by his two daughters, Star and Barbara, four grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.

Four years ago on Sunday, a ravenous 10-alarm blaze gutted abandoned warehouses of the historic Greenpoint Terminal Market on the Brooklyn waterfront, spectacularly turning most of the 14-acre site into a charred ruin, and sending a towering plume of smoke above the city. It was one of the largest fires in the city's history. A homeless immigrant from Poland, Leszek Kuczera, 63, was arrested and charged with accidentally setting the blaze while trying to melt the insulation off a copper wire. He was a sad sight in newspapers: an exhausted man, his belly sticking out of his filthy, loosely buttoned shirt, his face worn down by years of heavy drinking and living on the street.

SHANGHAI -- For English speakers with subpar Chinese skills, daily life in China offers a confounding array of choices. At banks, there are machines for ''cash withdrawing'' and ''cash recycling.'' The menus of local restaurants might present such delectables as ''fried enema,'' ''monolithic tree mushroom stem squid'' and a mysterious thirst-quencher known as ''The Jew's Ear Juice.'' Those who have had a bit too much monolithic tree mushroom stem squid could find themselves requiring roomier attire: extra-large sizes sometimes come in ''fatso'' or ''lard bucket'' categories. These and other fashions can be had at the clothing chain known as Scat.

GAISMAN--Catherine. The Division of Pulmonary, Critical Care and Sleep Medicine of the Mt. Sinai Medical Center is shocked and saddened by the sudden passing of Mrs. Catherine Giasman, our champion and partner for more than 40 years. She was strong and caring. She was honest and wise. Her exemplory life was the product of her devotion to her church, education as a nurse, service with the Mt. Sinai Army Hospital in North Africa during World War II, and with her husband Henry Gaisman, the support of patients at the Mt. Sinai Medical Center. Her legacy includes the Gaisman operating theatre, the Gaisman Division of Pulmanary, Critical Care and Sleep Medicine and the Gaisman fellowship. While intensely devoted to traditional values, she understood and supported advances in modern medicine by endowing the first professorial chair in palliative medicine and the new state of the art auditorium and classrooms for students of the Mt. Sinai Medical School. Her first question always was "What do you need to improve patient care?" Our deepest sympathies are offered to her devoted, supportive family. We share your enormous void. Scott M. Lorin, MD Alvin S. Teirstein, MD

If you have lost a golf ball recently - in other words, if you have played golf recently - it might make you feel better to know that there is an army of thousands looking for it. Finding and reselling lost golf balls at roughly a 50 percent discount is a $200-million-a-year industry, golf retail associations estimate. According to Gary Shienfield, whose company, Knetgolf.com will sell more than 20 million reclaimed golf balls this year, the average golfer loses a ball about every four holes.

SEROTA--Nathan L. A Real Estate Developer on Long Island for the past 53 years after a long hard struggle has passed away on early Saturday morning May 1, 2010. Mr. Serota who began his career as a ticket merchant for the Pennsylvania Railroad in the late 1940s and early 1950s began his real estate development business truly from the ground up. He built over 300 homes on the south shore of Long Island. Soon thereafter, Mr. Serota through his undaunting efforts developed over 50 shopping centers throughout Long Island. Mr. Serota continued this development business alongside his three sons, Charles, Geoffrey and Daniel. Along with his family, he developed a wonderful group of employees that have made his business one of the most important and solid businesses in Long Island. Mr. Serota served his country gallantly as a Aircraft Gunner post Pearl Harbor for the next three and a half years receiving a Honorable Discharge. He has been philanthropic in an extremely effective way. He has been a member and Chairman of the Board of Daytop Village, an important drug abuse program which is a program fighting drug abuse for the past 40 years. Mr. Serota is survived by his wife Vivian, his sons Charles, Geoffrey and Daniel, his daughter Deborah, his son-in-law Kenneth, daughters-in-law Sherry, Karen and Joelle. He is also survived by nine grandchildren. We will forever miss this wonderful, fertile human being.

KLOMBERG--Annette. Devoted wife of George, adoring mother of Jeff and Pam Klomberg and Linda and Harry Itzkovitz. SEROTA--Nathan. It's with sadness and gratitude that we offer our condolences to the family of Nathan Serota. When Nat saw my wife struggling down the stairs with my wheelchair, he stopped his car and he and his driver helped a perfect stranger. Later that week, a crew came over and built a wheelchair ramp -- followed by a specially equipped car that gave me back my dignity and freedom. There are no words to thank a perfect stranger, whose act of random kindness, gave me back my life. George and Nancy

O'CONNOR--John Cardinal. Ten years ago Cardinal O'Connor died and what a legacy he left us-one of inspiring homilies and superb writings. He will always be in our hearts and prayers. Margaret Mary McDermott

Al, Bruce, Chuck and Dave arrive at the most difficult hole on the course, a long par four with thick woods to the right and left of the hole. Al hits his drive deep into the left woods and without making any announcement hits another ball down the middle of the fairway. Bruce's drive is his best of the day traveling about 250 yards but landing in the thick heather to the right of the fairway. Concerned that his ball may be lost, he announces he will hit a provisional ball that he pops up. It comes to rest in the fairway about 100 yards from the tee.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- Hakimullah Mehsud, the leader of the Pakistani Taliban reported killed in an American drone strike four months ago, was shown alive and well in an Internet video posting early Monday, warning of suicide revenge attacks on United States cities. It was the first time Mr. Mehsud had been seen since his supposed death in January.

Gene Lees, a prolific jazz critic and historian who approached his subject with a journalist's rigor and an insider's understanding, died on Thursday at his home in Ojai, Calif. He was 82. The apparent cause was a stroke, said Leslie A. Westbrook, a family spokeswoman.

SEROTA--Nathan. A Love letter to Nathan Serota: It's been said that the way a man dies, is a reflection of the way he lived. And it's with a heavy heart that I have to write that Nathan Serota my husband of 40 years died the morning of May 1, 2010, the way he had lived: With courage, humility and, in the last days of his life, taking care of the people he loved. My husband was a self made man who against all odds-built a successful business, became an international philanthropist, art collector and absolutely loved life. We traveled the world meeting interesting, powerful people and shared a glamorous and beautiful life. But Nathan also lived by the rule that to whom much is given, much is expected. My husband unselfishly contributed to the organizations and causes he believed in, but it was his everyday quiet acts of kindness that defined Nathan Serota: The veteran who needed a special car, the children he sent to college and the families whose bills he paid. Oftentimes I would learn about these gifts, many anonymous weeks and years later. For Nat, these were acts of gratitude for the beautiful life, children and grandchildren we were blessed with. My darling Nat, we had hard times and good times but through it all we had love. With love, Vivian

SIMKOWITZ--Isidore Benjamin, died on May 1, 2010 in Miami Beach, FL. He was born of immigrant parents in New York City on March 17, 1913. He attended City College in New York, finished his education at the University of Miami and became a certified public accountant. He married Lucy Levy on May 17, 1933. He is survived by his four children, Elizabeth Gasser, Michael Simkowitz, Sara Simkowitz, and Philip Simkowitz and nine grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his granddaughter, Amy Simkowitz-Rogers. Following his father's death in 1953 he managed his family's real estate holdings in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester County, New York. Izzy was known for his immense intelligence, encyclopedic knowledge and a deep love of the arts. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. The funeral is on Monday, May 3, 2010. Memorial donations may be sent to: Amy C. Simkowitz-Rogers Fund, National Jewish Health, P.O. Box 5898, Denver, CO 80217, Attention: Becky Witte.

JONESTOWN, Guyana -- Carlton Daniels was sweating as he sliced through the jungle with his cutlass. He pointed at some bushes and said a chimpanzee named Mr. Muggs had once lived there in a cage. Then he emerged in a clearing, proclaiming, ''Welcome to the People's Temple Agricultural Project.'' Better known as Jonestown, where more than 900 Americans committed suicide or were murdered one night in 1978 at the behest of the cult leader Jim Jones, the site yields few signs of remembrance. Rains, termites and scavengers have laid waste to its buildings. Vines camouflage its rusting vehicles, including an old flatbed truck and a tractor.

CARVER--Tina Betsy (nee Kasloff), 65, May 1, 2010 after gracefully surviving a brain tumor for three years. Devoted mother of Jeff (Christopher), Brian (Melissa), and Daniel, loving grandmother of Andrew, Barry, and Zachary. Cherished sister of Harriet Berman (Stan), dear aunt of Jessica, Eric, Jonah, Eliza and Nora, cousin of Toba Stutz and Robert Simels. Respected and beloved by colleagues and friends in every corner of the world, Tina devoted her career to finding, creating, and publishing English language instructional texts for adult speakers of other languages. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Tina B. Carver Fund at TESOL (Teachers of English to Speakers of Other Languages), 1925 Ballenger Ave., Ste. 550, Alexandria, VA 22314.

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes Monday's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday. The Interactive Data Corporation, a financial market data provider whose biggest stakeholder is Pearson of Britain, is close to selling itself for $3.1 billion to two private equity firms, Warburg Pincus and Silver Lake, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Sunday night. A deal could be announced as soon as Monday, these people said, cautioning that an agreement had not yet been finalized and negotiations could still break apart.

Some people try to forecast the future. Angus Maddison devoted his life to forecasting the past. Professor Maddison, a British-born economic historian with a compulsion for quantification, spent many of his 83 years calculating the size of economies over the last three millenniums. In one study he estimated the size of the world economy in A.D. 1 as about one five-hundredth of what it was in 2008.

SEROTA--Nathan. "The value of a man", Albert Einstein observed, "should be seen in what he gives and not in what he is able to receive". In one word, Nat Serota was a man who gave. For over 30 years as a devoted and respected trustee and former Chairman of Daytop, he gave of himself to the legions of young people struggling to overcome addiction. His biography, "Don't put your dreams on hold", is not only a saying Nat lived by, but one he embodied. He encouraged our young residents by impressing upon them that they can do anything they wanted to do. "Make up your mind to do it," he would tell them. "Work at it, and you will succeed. Don't put your dreams on hold!" Nat's generous financial support was greatly appreciated, but more importantly he gave of his time, love and concern. Doing for others is what made Nat happy and in doing so thousands of lives were changed for the better. Through his own strength of character, determination and keen business acumen, he built a highly regarded and successful real estate company. And upon reaching the pinnacle of success--no matter whether he was in the company of celebrated personalities, potentates, popes or just plain folks, Nat was always the same down to earth, straight talking guy that we all loved. Nat not only talked the talk, but he walked the walk. As Chairman of Daytop, of all the remarkable people he met along the way, it was Pope John Paul who saw in Nat a truly good soul. During a private mass that followed lunch with the Pope, Nat felt compelled to be blessed by John Paul. When the Pope offered Nat communion he reminded the Pope that he was a Jewish, and Pope John Paul, without hesitation replied, "My Son, so was Jesus". Nat Serota provided us a singular example of what one determined, talented, charismatic, caring and giving individual can do for the betterment of mankind. And though he has died, his contributions will live on in the lives of countless others whose dreams he so generously fulfilled. Rather than our own death, it is the death of a friend that hurts us. With the passing of Nat Serota, there are untold numbers in every walk of life, who are deeply hurt today. He was just that kind of special of friend.

SEROTA--Nathan L. Upon gazing on The Parthenon, The Pyramids, The Taj Mahal and The Great Cathedrals, I have often wondered as to what "Great Passion" conceived and actualized such incredible treasures at the outer limits of man's creative spirit. And closer to home, the Indomitable Robert Moses enjoyed my childhood fantasies with near godly powers to hurl great steel wonders across gaping chasms of rushing waters. A Builder, indeed, ranks among Heaven's blessed, pushing back in each generation the perimeters of man's creations. Nat Serota, my friend, is numbered among "This Tribe"! While Robert Frost in his Mending Wall begged the central question for the Master Builder: "Before I build a wall, I'd ask to know! What I was walling in or walling out!", Nat, just a "City Kid" who manned the coal chutes and the ice blocks of yesteryear, dreamed this "Builder's Dream" of creating wonderlands for the teeming masses emigrating to the wide expanses of suburbia. Bright and Imaginative in design, these bore the "Serota Stamp" of inclusiveness and overnight became the great people-gathering places: shopping arcades, theatres, housing, recreation meccas for the young, pleasant setting for the elderly. And all the while, he lent his limitless energies to building "new tomorrow's" for the young people of Daytop Village for over a quarter century-his quintessential building mission. Heaven has a special claim upon "His Tribe." We have been immensely enriched by his life-and immeasurably diminished by his passing. Our prayerful support for his beloved Vivian and his family. (Msgr.) William B. O'Brien President, Daytop Village, Inc
SEROTA--Nathan. We are saddened by our loss of a great friend and the honorary grandfather of my daughter Ariella. Our condolences to his family. Nurit, Werner, Ariella Haase

The two former Mexican seminarians had gone to the Vatican in 1998 to personally deliver a case recounting decades of sexual abuse by one of the most powerful priests in the Roman Catholic Church, the Rev. Marcial Maciel Degollado. As they left, they ran into the man who would hold Father Maciel's fate in his hands, Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, and kissed his ring. The encounter was no accident. Cardinal Ratzinger wanted to meet them, witnesses later said, and their case was soon accepted.

The financial regulation debate is entering tricky new territory - for the Republicans who are losing it, for the Democrats who are winning it, and for Wall Street. Now, with the issue on Washington's center stage, President Obama's adversaries are left with issues of far greater consequence for their business allies but far less political appeal.

She makes no speeches on the hustings; she remains aloof from the political fray. She admits no party affiliation and is not permitted to vote or stand for office. Yet, she addresses Parliament with bejeweled and regular fanfare; for more than half a century, she has held secret conversations with a cavalcade of 11 prime ministers; and, in a peculiarly British way, she could be cast in a central, yet largely powerless, role if Britain's elections on Thursday stray into the gray zone known as a hung Parliament.

8:27 p.m. | Updated A painting that Picasso created in a single day in March 1932, "Nu au Plateau de Sculpteur (Nude, Green Leaves and Bust)," sold for $106.5 million, a world record auction price for a work of art, at Christie's Tuesday night. The painting, more than 5 feet by 4 feet, shows Picasso's mistress Marie-Thérèse Walter, both reclining and as a bust. Picasso's profile can be discerned in the blue background.

4:58 p.m. | Updated With the field of Tony Award nominees sown this morning, the first underperforming show of the post-season has been claimed by the Grim Reaper this evening: "Enron," the play by Lucy Prebble about the rise and fall of that notorious Texas energy company, will close on Sunday, according to a statement on the show's official Web site. The Broadway production of the play, which opened last week after transferring from London's West End, collapsed almost as rapidly as its namesake: though its cast included Norbert Leo Butz ("Dirty Rotten Scoundrels," "Speed-the-Plow") and Gregory Itzin ("24") as the Enron executives Jeffrey Skilling and Kenneth Lay, as well as Marin Mazzie ("Kiss Me, Kate") as a composite Enron employee, it was shut out of most major categories. Stephen Kunken was nominated as a featured actor in a play, but its lack of a nomination for best play likely sealed its fate. "Enron" could still be the rare play to win the Tony for best original score, another category in which it is also nominated.

I can't pray when I am visiting a church. The problem is that I am a singer and choir director.  I find myself analyzing the hymnal while "fantasy conducting" the choir.  I generally end up having a great time but I do not achieve a quiet prayerful solace and comfort that church provides for the masses. But take me to a racetrack and it's another story.  At Santa Anita, there is a golden sunrise in the early morning when the horses are training on the track.  It is quiet and ethereally beautiful as the San Gabriel Mountains provide a glorious backdrop.  I climb the stairs and sit by myself. I am quiet and thoughtful. I empty my mind and let the images drift in front of me. Horses and exercise riders, trainers and jockeys, laughter and camaraderie.

The street artist Shepard Fairey, who is no stranger to legal trouble, has now run afoul of the New York City Department of Buildings. The Department issued a stop-work order and an Environment Control Board violation this weekend to Elizabeth Houston Associates, the owner of a building on Houston Street near the Bowery on which Mr. Fairey recently installed a mural connected with his show at Deitch Projects in Soho. The mural was pasted onto a structure built on top of the original wall, preserving another mural by the Brazilian brothers known as Os Gemeos. According to Ryan Fitzgibbon, a spokeswoman for the Department of Buildings, the violation was issued for installing the structure and the mural without a permit. She said the Environmental Control Board court would hold a hearing soon on the violation; if it stands, it could carry a penalty of up to $25,000. She added that the Department was also considering issuing a violation for illegal advertising on the grounds that the mural constituted an advertisement for the Deitch Projects show. But Daniel Killinger, a managing director of Goldman Properties, an affiliate of Elizabeth Houston Associates, said that Goldman did not see the mural as an advertisement. "We see it as a continuation of the history of the art that's always been on that site," he said, referring to the Os Gemeos mural and a previous mural designed by Keith Haring. The Department of Building's action was reported by the blog animalnewyork.com.

It was a scenario that would have given Anthony Bourdain agita. Last month at Gobo, a vegan restaurant downtown, The Moment met up with a self-described "eco-model," a healthy young woman who claims - not proudly, almost abashedly - never to have had a sip of alcohol or a cup of coffee in her life. Her name, because she was born during a June downpour, is Summer Rayne Oakes. "When I first went to a modeling agency, they thought I was a stripper," she says of her two given names, which she prefers to be said in unison. Oakes is just 25, but she's already written a book ("Style, Naturally"), contributed to an "eco-art" magazine (Above), served as a correspondent on Discovery's Planet Green channel, and co-founded a business (S4 Style). "Is everyone who abstains from alcohol this productive?" we wondered briefly, before ordering a glass of organic Albariño.

When I suggested recently that "conservative domestic policy would be in better shape if conservative magazines and conservative columnists were more willing to call out Republican politicians (and, to a lesser extent, conservative entertainers)" for advancing bad ideas and bogus arguments, I didn't expect to summon up anything quite as controversy-generating Jim Manzi's evisceration of Mark Levin's views on global warming. For an example of what I did have in mind, though, read Kevin Williamson's fine piece on supply-side economics from the last National Review, in which he goes after the panglossian misinterpretation of supply-side theory that's become dogma among too many Republican politicians and activists - namely, that tax cuts generate so much economic growth (and with it, increased government revenue) that they more than pay for themselves. As Williamson notes, the most prominent supply-side theorists themselves don't believe this, but they're tolerant of politicians who do:

"How would [the Transportation Security Administration] respond to this weekend's Times Square bomb threat? Well, by extrapolation from its response to the 9/11 attacks and subsequent threats, the policy would be: All vans or SUVs headed into Midtown Manhattan would have to stop and have their contents inspected. If any vehicle seemed for any reason to have escaped inspection, Midtown in its entirety would be evacuated ... A whole new uniformed force - the Times Square Security Administration, or TsSA - would be formed for this purpose ... The restrictions would never be lifted and the TsSA would have permanent life, because the political incentives here work only one way. A politician who supports more open-ended, more thorough, more intrusive, more expensive inspections can never be proven 'wrong.' The absence of attacks shows that his measures have 'worked'; and a new attack shows that inspections must go further still. A politician who wants to limit the inspections can never be proven 'right.' An absence of attacks means that nothing has gone wrong - yet."

Patrick Honner, who is a Math for America Master Teacher at Brooklyn Technical High School in Brooklyn, New York, created the quiz below for us to complement today's lesson plan on understanding the economic crisis in Greece.

Overview | Why is Greece experiencing a major financial crisis? How are its fiscal woes connected to the rest of the European Union, Europe and global financial markets? In this lesson, students complete a List/Group/Label activity to familiarize themselves with key terms, then research a single term further in order to teach their classmates about it. They then create a math or financial problem that demonstrates how the term "works." They not only become conversant with the European crisis but also develop financial literacy by putting key economic terms in context.

His name is David Spotanski, and in the early 2000s he was the chancellor of the diocese of Belleville, in Illinois, where Wilton Gregory was bishop. Gregory was elected president of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops in the autumn of 2001, just as the wave of sex abuse revelations began breaking over the American church. Four months later, Spotanski wrote his bishop a 10-page memo on the abuse crisis, which he read aloud to Gregory in the bishop's private study. In part, the memo was a blistering attack on the American hierarchy, from Boston's Bernard Law on down, for their dreadful negligence, cover-ups and excuse-making. In part, it was a blueprint for action: To have any chance of restoring their credibility, Spotanski wrote, the American bishops needed to invite victims from decades past to come forward and act swiftly on their claims, adopt strict nationwide standards for handling new allegations of sex abuse, and then turn over as much responsibility as possible for implementing the rules to an independent board of laypeople (and parents), who could issue annual reports and hold recalcitrant bishops' feet to the fire.

The French are very good at not making things easy. Take something as banal as a manicure. In Paris, nail salons are few and far between, and when you do find one, Madam must make an appointment! Walk-ins are unheard of. And forget having your cuticles cut. It is simply not done! But if you know where to look, the French are extremely good at lavishing you with care. And that's where "Pampered in Paris: A Guide to the Best Spas, Salons and Beauty Books" (The Little Bookroom, New York; available May 11 for $16.95 at littlebookroom.com) comes in. The author, Kim Horton Levesque, has scoured the boulevards and the back alleys. She's soaked in hammams and had had her corns and calluses attended by a Chinese chiropodist. She's been lathered and creamed, exfoliated and scrubbed to an inch of her life. This, so you can enjoy chocolate facials and bask in some of the most wonderfully designed spas on earth. F.Y.I.: body massage in France usually includes a chest massage. Madam may not like that. If so, simply say, "Pouvez-vous eviter le massage de la poitrine, s'il vous plait?"

Scott looks back at Akira Kurosawa's 1962 film "High and Low," about a business executive (Toshiro Mifune) who, through a dark turn of events, is forced to question his system of values. Ning, a company that allows users to build their own social networks, says it has signed a letter of intent with a major educational publisher to keep its service free for educators, several weeks after causing an outcry among nonprofit groups by announcing that it would end its popular free service. Ning did not give any more information about the deal, which it disclosed as it outlined its plans to begin charging subscription fees to all of its users.

The northbound Metro North train departing from Grand Central on Sunday morning had two types of sneetches on board: There were those destined for the Dia:Beacon Spring Benefit, distinguished by the double mwah mwah of their Francophile greeting. Then there was the Poughkeepsie bound, a group, on the whole, sporting more tattoos and less seersucker.

Emma Smith brought home an assignment from her fourth-grade teacher a few weeks ago, one that her parents had been expecting almost since the day they adopted their daughter 10 years ago. It is a staple of elementary-school science classes across the country, though her parents, Jenni Levy, a doctor, and David Smith, a geologist turned science educator, wonder if there isn't a better way for these lessons to be learned.

Monologue | Monday night on "The Late Show With David Letterman" on CBS: Anybody from the Gulf of Mexico area? It's going to be the biggest ecological disaster on the history of the planet. And today, a tourist thought they saw a blowfish in the Gulf of Mexico. Turned out to be a flounder holding its breath.

Monologue | Monday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Over the weekend, there were huge marches to protest Arizona's new immigration law. If you don't know, Arizona's new law says police have to ask anyone for immigration papers if reasonable suspicion can be found that they're in the country illegally. But what's reasonable suspicion? One Arizona lawmaker said, "Illegal immigrants are easy to spot because of their clothes." Really? I know it was obvious with me when I got off the plane because I was wearing Speedos, of course.

Mother's Day rolls around every second Sunday in May -- in sync with the waning of the April rains and an outburst of colorful blooms. Who cares that it also ushers in the annual grumblings about whether it is just another contrived Hallmark Holiday, more about card and gift sales than true sentiment?

Monologue | Monday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Have you guys been following the whole oil disaster? Yesterday, President Obama said: "Let me be clear. BP is responsible for this leak. BP will be paying the bill." And BP was like: "Ah, bailout? Right?"

Monologue | Monday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: The state of Arizona is the subject of a lot of controversy because of this new immigration law they passed. There were big demonstrations all around the country yesterday protesting it. Many people believe it's potentially racist, but the state announced today that despite the controversy, they're still planning to move ahead with their annual Cinco de Mayo party. I guess it's sort of a going-away thing.

The Hyundai Genesis PM580 looks capable of grinding out 24 hours at Le Mans or Daytona - and, given a few modifications, it probably could - but its mettle will instead be tested over just 10 minutes on Colorado's Pikes Peak. There, the purpose-built machine will confront notoriously capricious weather, blacktop yielding to rutted gravel, vertiginous precipices and thinning atmosphere as it revs toward the checkered flag waving from the mountain's 14,110-foot summit. No country for old coolant.

Governor Drops Plan to Pay for Parks With Oil Drilling | While the authorities contend with the vast oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California withdrew his support for a controversial offshore drilling plan in Southern California, which officials hoped would raise $1.8 billion for state parks in the next 14 years. "It will not happen here in California," he said, referring to the Deepwater Horizon spill in the gulf. The proposal, known as the Tranquillon Ridge project, would have been the state's first new oil lease in 40 years, bringing new wells to waters off Santa Barbara. Without the drilling project, state parks will need another source for $100 million this year. On Monday, the governor also vetoed a bill that would have banned smoking at all state parks and beaches. [The San Jose Mercury News, The Associated Press]

Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -- but not strictly -- by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. Top 10 lists tend to be. That's why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you're about to read.

Note to readers: My five posts this week chronicle the events of the week of Feb. 15. I'm publishing them with some misgivings, as one might get the impression that my business is days from failure at all times. Fortunately, this is not so. That week was especially dramatic because of the timing of the payments in and out. Also, it marked the beginning of an uptick in sales. From where I sit today, the recovery has begun. We now have a normal backlog of work and sufficient cash on hand to complete it.

Because of an editing error, an article on April 24 about spending and control issues at Imagine Schools, a manager of charter schools nationwide, misstated the source of the statement that school auditors for Hope Community Public Charter School in Washington chided the school's board for allowing Imagine Schools to pay several large bills without the required approvals. The information came from a report by the auditors posted on the Web site of the District of Columbia Public Charter School Board, Washington's charter school regulator -- not from James Kemp, chairman of the board of Hope Community.

Magazine readers no longer have to squint to see the health warning on ads for smokeless tobacco products. Big, bold health warnings, which stem from last year's landmark tobacco law, have begun showing up in magazines this month. The new rules requiring more prominent health warnings on advertising for smokeless tobacco products officially go into effect June 22 and kick in a year later for cigarette ads.

My sister, Ellen Dominus Broude, has been working in Times Square for the past 17 years -- longer than she's been a mother, longer than she's been married. It's an unyielding fact of her life that she rarely contemplates. But when given the option to work from home one day a week, back in 2006, she didn't have to think long about which day to pick. ''I chose Wednesday -- matinee day,'' she told me Monday. ''If I was the bad guy, that's the day I'd choose to plant a bomb.''

At a recent social gathering, a doctor friend who has been in private practice for almost 15 years revealed something that caused one physician to nearly choke on her drink, another to gasp in disbelief and the rest of us to stop what we were doing and gawk as if he had committed some grave social faux pas. ''I love what I do,'' he announced to all of us. ''I really love being a doctor.''

OWEN--Chloe. Internationally acclaimed opera singer and nationally renowned voice teacher Chloe Owen, 91, of New York City departed this world Wednesday, April 28 after a long illness. She leaves behind her beloved nephew, Owen Heter, of Las Vegas, NV; many dear friends, colleagues and students from her long and varied career in opera, art song and service to organizations such as National Association of Teachers of Singing, NYSTA, the prestigious American Academy of Teachers of Singing, and Boston University, where she was Professor Emeritus. Chloe demonstrated her incredible vocal range and technique with several remarkable "farewell concerts" at ages 75, 81, and 85 on both coasts. Her last public appearance was at age 89 in a tiny but flashy role with a small NY opera company. Memorial gathering TBA. In lieu of flowers, we ask that donations be made in Chloe's memory to VNSNY Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, 7th Fl., NY, NY 10001, Att: Stefanie Steel.

BUSINESS DAY An article on Saturday about the federally brokered sale of three troubled lenders in Puerto Rico misstated the sovereign status of Puerto Rico. It is a self-governing commonwealth of the United States, not a territory.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration maintains a national database that rates sections of the nation's coastline from most fragile to most resilient. The idea is to help local governments set priorities on where to place booms in case of an oil spill. Rocky shorelines are considered resilient because natural wave action will clean them. Sheltered islets, nurseries to so much wildlife, are among the most delicate and deeply affected by oil.

FRONT PAGE An article on Saturday about the response by BP America and the federal government to an oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico misstated a provision in a pollution law passed a year after the 1989 Exxon Valdez disaster. The law, the Oil Pollution Act of 1990, stipulates that ''each responsible party for a vessel or a facility from which oil is discharged'' is liable for cleanup costs. It does not state that the owner of a rig or a vessel is automatically responsible for the costs. An article on Sunday about an oil tax fund that helps pay for damages from oil spills repeated the error about the cleanup costs and it misstated part of the name of a federal agency responsible for coastal and deep ocean waters. It is the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, not the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration.

SEROTA--Nathan. When I needed a St Jude Heart Valve operation, we prayed to Saint Jude who gives "Hope to the Hopeless", and he sent us Nathan Serota. Mr. Serota, your compassion and generosity will live on in the hearts of my family forever. Thank you, Anne Mae

SEROTA--Nathan. A Love letter to Nathan Serota: It's been said that the way a man dies, is a reflection of the way he lived. And it's with a heavy heart that I have to write that Nathan Serota my husband of 40 years died the morning of May 1, 2010, the way he had lived: With courage, humility and, in the last days of his life, taking care of the people he loved. My husband was a self made man who against all odds-built a successful business, became an international philanthropist, art collector and absolutely loved life. We traveled the world meeting interesting, powerful people and shared a glamorous and beautiful life. But Nathan also lived by the rule that to whom much is given, much is expected. My husband unselfishly contributed to the organizations and causes he believed in, but it was his everyday quiet acts of kindness that defined Nathan Serota: The veteran who needed a special car, the children he sent to college and the families whose bills he paid. Oftentimes I would learn about these gifts, many anonymous weeks and years later. For Nat, these were acts of gratitude for the beautiful life, children and grandchildren we were blessed with. My darling Nat, we had hard times and good times but through it all we had love. With love, Vivian

GAISMAN--Catherine V. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of Catherine V. ("Kitty") Gaisman, an outstanding philanthropist and dedicated member of The Mount Sinai Boards of Trustees for more than 30 years. Kitty first gave us the gift of her caring 70 years ago when she graduated from The Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing and went on to serve overseas as a volunteer nurse with Mount Sinai in WWII. Following her service, Kitty worked as a Nursing Supervisor at the Hospital. After leaving her nursing post, she and her husband, the late Henry J. Gaisman, continued to partner with Mount Sinai in many ways, offering wisdom, leadership, and philanthropic support through the Catherine and Henry J. Gaisman Foundation. She had a permanent and incalculable influence in shaping the very nature and character of our medical center and will be linked in perpetuity to programs that bear the Gaisman name, including the Gaisman Medical Intensive Care Unit, the Catherine Gaisman Professorship in Medical Ethics, the Gaisman Frontiers of Biomedical Sciences Research Awards Program, the Gaisman Fellowship in Respiratory Research, and the Catherine and Henry J. Gaisman Division of Pulmonary, Critical Care, and Sleep Medicine. Always committed to patient care, Kitty created the Applause-O-Gram Program, which honors employees for their exceptional service and compassion for patients and their families. Through the establishment of the Dr. Alvin S. Teirstein Auditorium, her support has greatly enriched the educational experience of our medical students. The Catherine and Henry J. Gaisman Foundation's most recent generous gifts have seeded our advancement of biomedical informatics and an institution-wide electronic medical record system. Kitty bestowed a vast legacy of extraordinary contributions to Mount Sinai and her generosity and devotion will leave an indelible mark on our institution. We will miss her deeply. On behalf of Mount Sinai, we extend our heartfelt condolences to her nephew, Eric Waldman, a Mount Sinai Trustee, and the entire Gaisman family. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

ROBINSON--Janet Binder. Beloved wife, mother and grandmother died in Scottsdale, AZ on May 3, 2010 of pancreatic cancer at the age of 75. She is survived by her husband of 52 years, Irwin Jay Robinson of New York City and Scottsdale, AZ, daughter Elizabeth (Steven) Schubiner of Bloomfield Hills, MI, son Jonathan (Heidi Biegel) Robinson of New Haven, CT, daughter Eve (Joshua Wiener) Robinson of New York City, grandchildren Andrea and Julie Schubiner, Jasmine and Maia Robinson, and Nathaniel and Aden Wiener, brother Dr. Henry (Joan) Binder of New Haven, CT, and sister-in-law Bette Entin and brother-in-law Philip Entin of Bloomfield Hills, MI. Janet graduated from Bronx Science High School, Vassar College, and the Yale University Graduate Program in Education. She was a long-time volunteer and board member of the Society for the Advancement for Judaism, Jewish Board of Family & Children's Services, Riverdale Senior Center, and The Paper Bag Players. A dynamic, inquisitive, creative woman of enormous love, she was devoted to family and friends world-over. Janet will be greatly missed and will stay in our hearts forever. Services will be held at the Society for the Advancement of Judaism, 15 West 86th Street on Wednesday, May 5 at 12:15pm. Donations in her honor may be made to Vassar College, The Society for Advancement of Judaism, and Mayo Clinic Palliative Care Program in Scottsdale.

Therapists for years have listened to patients blame parents for their problems. Now there is growing interest in the other side of the story: What about the suffering of parents who are estranged from their adult children? While there are no official tallies of parents whose adult children have cut them off, there is no shortage of headlines. The Olympic gold medal skier Lindsey Vonn reportedly hasn't spoken to her father in at least four years. The actor Jon Voight and his daughter, Angelina Jolie, were photographed together in February for the first time since they were estranged in 2002.

It could have gone any way last night, considering the theme of the Costume Institute exhibition: ''American Woman: Fashioning a National Identity.'' There could have been neo-jazz babies, flappers, debutantes, feminists, disco queens, Hollywood sirens, Nouvelle Society matrons and Playboy bunnies. And that's just a few archetypes off the top of a stack. But most of the women attending the gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, among the 725 guests, dressed elegantly, more so than in recent years, and they did their best to heed Anna Wintour's e-mail messages to be on time.

The Drug Enforcement Administration is investigating allegations made in a lawsuit by a former employee of the New Orleans Saints that the club tried to cover up the theft of Vicodin pills from its training facility by a senior member of the team's staff. Special Agent Roberto Bryan Jr., a New Orleans-based spokesman for the D.E.A., told The Associated Press on Saturday that ''the D.E.A. was referred this case and there is a pending investigation.'' He said that in such cases, D.E.A. diversion investigators look into whether security procedures and record keeping for the drug complied with the Controlled Substances Act. The allegations are contained in a civil lawsuit filed late Friday afternoon by Geoff Santini, a retired F.B.I. agent who, until he resigned last August, was the Saints' security director. The Saints have vigorously denied the charges. They have characterized the lawsuit as an extortion attempt by a disgruntled former employee.

OBITUARIES An obituary on April 23 about the chef Jean Vergnes referred incorrectly to his employment at the Waldorf-Astoria. He was hired in 1950 by Claude Philippe, who was in charge of catering at the Waldorf and whose father owned a restaurant in Grenoble, France, where Mr. Vergnes had worked earlier. He was not hired by ''the Philippe family,'' and the family had not assumed the hotel's lease.

NATIONAL An article on Wednesday about officials' considering burning oil in the Gulf of Mexico as a method of controlling the spill referred imprecisely to the size of Louisiana's coastal wetlands. The area contains about 40 percent of the coastal wetlands in the lower 48 states -- not in the entire United States.

An article on Monday about a merger agreement between United Airlines and Continental Airlines misstated the amount of time it took to negotiate the deal. It was done in three weeks, not two. (While the first news reports of a possible merger appeared on April 16, Jeffery A. Smisek, Continental's chief executive, said talks began on April 9.)

WASHINGTON -- The oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico is bad -- no one would dispute it. But just how bad? TARBELL--John Weatherbee, Jr.,67, a former Wall Street financial advisor and investment banker who helped build the field of structured finance, passed away peacefully at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan on May 1, after battling cancer. Born in Boston in 1943, the youngest of five children, he graduated from The Governor's Academy in 1962 and Bowdoin College in 1966 and was a three-sport varsity athlete at both schools. He attended the Harvard Business School's Executive Education General Management Program in 1985. John began his career at First National City Bank in New York, and held positions at Chemical Bank, AIG, and other firms during his 30-year career in finance before launching a second career in executive search at DHR International, Inc., where he was Executive Vice President. During his tenure at Chemical Bank, he built and led the Bank's first designated Leveraged Buyout Group, and was a founder of its Mergers and Acquisitions Department, where he served as a Managing Director. During this time, he oversaw a number of important transactions, including financings for Revlon, Inc., Hanson Industries PLC, and Wang Industries. In addition to these responsibilities, he also served as a Director of the Allis Chalmers Corporation and Secretary to Chemical Bank's Midtown Advisory Board of Directors. It was also at Chemical Bank where he met his wife, Anne Adler Tarbell. They were married in 1990. In addition to his professional accomplishments, John was a life-long athlete. He was an avid runner and could often be found logging miles in Central Park. His daily running habit remained an unbroken streak for more than 26 years. John also played for the Old Blue Rugby Football Club (RFC) in his early years in New York and later coached and captained the Columbia Business School RFC. He earned a Black Belt in Tae Kwon Do at age 59. For all these successes, John was happiest in his private family life. He was a devoted husband to Anne, and a loving father to his daughter, Elizabeth Weatherbee Tarbell. In addition to his wife and daughter, he is survived by three sisters, Mary Ann MacLennan of Edina, MN, his twin sister Merideth DeLamarter of Concord, MA, and Joyce Morgan of Darien, CT, as well as a close circle of relatives including a brother-in-law, Douglas Adler of Washington, DC, and his family, and a sister-in-law, Mary Malhotra of New York City, and her family, and 17 nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, on May 14 at 11am. Memorial donations may be made to the John Tarbell Malawi Fund at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

WASHINGTON -- The Justice Department has decided not to file charges against Alphonso R. Jackson, the former secretary of housing and urban development in the Bush administration, over allegations that he improperly steered federal contracts to friends, his lawyers said Monday. Mr. Jackson's lawyers said that Peter Koski, a lawyer at the Justice Department's public integrity unit, informed them late last week that it was closing its investigation into Mr. Jackson, who resigned under pressure in 2008.

WASHINGTON -- In a decision ripe with symbolism about access to justice in the age of terror, the Supreme Courtannounced on Monday that visitors to its courthouse will no longer be allowed to enter through the front door. And it is not just any front door. For decades, people with cases before the court, their lawyers and those who just came to see the arguments have climbed the grand steps arrayed in front of the courthouse's marble columns, passed under the inscribed words ''Equal Justice Under the Law'' and walked through a passage flanked by two six-ton bronze doors that show historic scenes in the development of the law.

8 P.M. (ESPN) THE 16TH MAN In 1995, just a year after the overthrow of apartheid and as the new government of Nelson Mandela was seeking to rebuild the nation, South Africa hosted the Rugby World Cup. Despite having only one nonwhite player, the South African Springboks gained the support of the country and, bucking heavy odds, beat the New Zealand All Blacks. Afterward, Mr. Mandela, far left, wearing a Springboks jersey, walked to the center of the pitch and shook hands with the team's captain, François Pienaar, above right -- a gesture seen as a step toward healing a deeply divided nation. Morgan Freeman, who played Mr. Mandela in the 2009 feature ''Invictus,'' produced this film, directed by Clifford Bestall, as part of ESPN's ''30 for 30'' anniversary programming. 10 A.M. (ABC) RACHAEL RAY Rosie O'Donnell takes audience questions.
It’s hard to ignore the $106.5 million price tag attached to the Picasso piece whose sale on Tuesday is the biggest-ever price tag for a work of art sold at auction.

The former bosses of Bear Stearns said Wednesday afternoon that they did not believe their firm was too big to fail or too big to manage and that they were “shocked” when it suddenly collapsed in March 2008.

On Wednesday a Reuters wire report on the background of Faisal Shahzad, the suspect in the Times Square bomb case, called him “educated and well-heeled.” That fact is stated as if it is something of a surprise that this young professional, a full-fledged citizen of Western society, might have attempted a terrorist attack. But haven’t educated sons of privilege been behind almost every recent terror attack on the West?

The former heads of Bear Stearns disagreed Wednesday afternoon over how much the firm’s huge reliance on borrowed money contributed to its demise, with James E. Cayne arguing that the firm was overleveraged, while Alan Schwartz, his successor as chief executive, arguing that the firm was adequately capitalized.

The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission has released documents that show Bear Stearns appeared optimistic about its prospects a year before the rapidly growing subprime mortgage crisis caused the firm’s demise in March 2008.

Members of a panel investigating the financial crisis on Wednesday challenged former Bear Stearns executives on their view of what caused the Wall Street firm to implode two years ago, The Associated Press reports.

Updated | 3:12 p.m. As my colleagues Dan Bilefsky and Judy Dempsey report, three people have reportedly died inside a bank building in Athens set ablaze by protesters who took to the streets to oppose cuts the Greek government says are necessary to deal with the country’s debt crisis.

My Thursday column is about the President's Cancer Panel's new warning about the danger of environmental influences, such as chemicals around us. Let me say straight off that 780-word columns are not the ideal way to discuss endocrine-disruptors, carcinogens or specific chemicals such as phthalates. The evidence is typically complex and conflicting, and a scribbler dilettante like myself is not an optimal arbiter of the evidence.

Adam B. Ellick visits the family village in Pakistan of the Times Square bomb suspect, where relatives discuss his upbringing and dismiss claims of his involvement in the bombing attempt as an American plot to justify the Afghan war.

Botkin, a widely respected ecologist and author of noted books on environmental history, philosophy and science, has turned his attention to energy, with a new book charting one path to a prosperous post-fossil future in which energy is abundant but not a source of environmental ills. The book, "Powering The Future: A Scientist's Guide to Energy Independence" has just been published by Pearson FT Press.

Update, May 17 | It is now possible to search the "Moment in Time" interactive gallery by the name given in the photographer's credit line (actual name, pseudonym or screen name, as the contributor chose). You'll find the search box in the upper right corner of the opening page. If you believe your picture wasn't posted, we urge you to give this a try.

President Obama told several hundred Hispanics at the annual White House fiesta for Cinco de Mayo that "I want to begin work this year" on a comprehensive immigration law, reassuring them that he wants Congress to take up the issue even if it cannot be resolved in this election year.
What the New York Times tech reporters and editors have been reading the last couple of days:
Freddie Mac is asking for $10.6 billion in additional federal aid after posting a big loss in the first three months of the year, The Associated Press reports.

This week's New York Times Tech Talk podcast takes a look at Facebook's new features for sharing information. They've set off concerns among privacy advocates and some elected officials. Bettina Edelstein speaks with Kurt Opsahl, a senior staff attorney at the Electronic Frontier Foundation, an online civil liberties group. He says it's getting harder, and more complicated, to use Facebook's privacy settings, and he objects to the site making personal data public by default.

Paul Goydos, 45, has won two PGA Tour events, the 1996 Bay Hill Invitational and the 2007 Sony Open in Hawaii. He probably is best known for his plucky performance in a near-win: the 2008 Players Championship, which he lost to Sergio García in a sudden-death playoff. His Everyman demeanor and cool performance under pressure that week have helped make him a fan favorite. A 1988 graduate of Long Beach State University with a degree in Finance, Goydos is in his 19th year on tour. He is a member of the 16-member PGA Tour's Player Advisory Council.
Last June, analysts at Moody's published a report examining whether recoveries on corporate debt defaults during the most recent cycle could be lower than the historical norm.
Kenny White, a musician, lives under the eaves, in a small, top-floor space strewn with instruments.

A BP executive told members of Congress on Tuesday that the ruptured oil well in the Gulf of Mexico could potentially spill as much as 60,000 barrels a day, more than 10 times the current estimate. With the spill growing worse by the day, questions about the adequacy and effectiveness of offshore drilling regulations have become more urgent.
A look inside homes with walls on which plants grow.

The Yankees will be the stars of the latest sports test of 3-D production when the YES Network  collaborates with DirecTV to produce two Yankees-Mariners games from Seattle in July using the burgeoning technology.
Juan Agudelo is going to Europe. ... No, not jumping ship from the Red Bulls to a new club, but as part of the United States under-20 national team.

Former Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad, who is among the Republicans across the country who are running again for their old offices this year, underwent heart surgery today. He is challenging Gov. Chet Culver, a Democrat, in one of the races that Republicans are among the most enthusiastic about.
Jennifer Karady’s photographs of veterans, on view in San Francisco, put a surreal twist on their war memories.
At the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute ball, borrowed finery and a dinner no one has any intention of eating are the norm.

The Yankees are off Thursday before opening a three-game series in Boston on Friday night. They will travel Thursday by railroad - in a private three-car train - from New Rochelle, N.Y.
Despite consecutive incidents at Philadelphia's Citizen Bank Park involving fans who ran onto the playing field during Phillies games, Major League Baseball is not yet reconsidering game security.

Classic cars weren't the only things damaged when storms blew down the tents at the Russo & Steele auction in Scottsdale, Ariz., in January. The president of Russo & Steele, Drew Alcazar, said his company sustained serious damage -- financially and to its image -- and has filed a lawsuit against the tent provider, Tri-Rentals, in an effort to recoup at least the financial portion of those losses.

The media investor Haim Saban is moving into brand management and licensing. The Saban Capital Group will plow $500 million into Saban Brands, a new company dedicated to acquiring entertainment and consumer brands and exploiting them through retail, television and film channels.
All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we've created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

Faced with record enrollments, the City University of New York has decided to place prospective freshmen whose applications arrive after Friday on a waiting list. It is the first time in memory that CUNY will impose an across-the-board cutoff for applications to its 11 senior colleges and six community colleges.

Despite his reputation for hard-charging and profanity-spiced intensity, Rahm Emanuel has long kept a circle of loyal aides, both as a congressman and now as White House chief of staff. But he is about to lose the adviser who has been closest to him: Sarah Feinberg is leaving to join Bloomberg L.P. as a communications strategist.
Another day, another bit of bad news for Goldman Sachs -- even as Lloyd C. Blankfein, its chief executive, tried to shore up the firm's reputation.

Last June, I ran a guest post from Janice Lynn Schuster, about her daughter's drug addiction and her own despair at not being able to help. After following Katie Granju's vigil by her son, who was critically injured after an overdose and a drug-related assault, it seemed a good time to check in with Schuster for a look at life farther down the recovery road.
Chris Black, a Local contributor, reflects on his removal of hazardous waste in an opinion post.

Many commentators now believe that Greece will end up restructuring its debt -- a euphemism for partial repudiation. I agree. But the reasoning seems to stop there, which is wrong. In effect, the consensus that Greece will end up defaulting is probably too optimistic. I'm growing increasingly convinced that Greece will end up leaving the euro, too.

What do the Brits know that we don't about publishing weeklies in America? The Week and The Economist, both owned by British publishing companies, continue to grow even as it was announced today that Newsweek is up for sale with very meager prospects.
About 35 endangered sea turtles have washed up dead on beaches along the Gulf of Mexico since Sunday, sowing fears that they were done in by the growing oil spill.

The Rev. Isidro Bolaños, a Brooklyn pastor who persuaded hundreds of people to hand over copies of their personal records through false offers of employment at an apparently nonexistent social service agency, has returned to New York, according to three men who say they confronted him this week.

After months of pursuing charges against students involved in the large-scale campus demonstrations last fall, the University of California, Berkeley has dropped charges against dozens of them. At the same time, it is undertaking an extensive review of its procedure for investigating and charging students.
The Senate has finally started voting on amendments to the financial regulatory legislation.

House Republicans pointedly questioned the speed of the Obama administration's response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the day after British Petroleum executives said the ruptured well could spew sweet crude into the surrounding water 10 times faster than initially estimated.

Mike Konczal has an interesting post on how Wall Street and the role of the SEC were perceived in the late 1970s: back then, the securities abuses of the pre-New-Deal era were viewed as archaic evils, no longer part of the modern world thanks to effective regulation. Today, of course, regulation has been degraded, and the abuses are back in earnest.
Cupcakes are overrated. Everybody loves them, and they often look great: adorable, personal-sized morsels of cake mounded with colorful frosting.

Robinson III, former chairman and chief executive of American Express, and Alan Blinder, an economist and former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, both of whom serve on On Deck's board.

Imagine kashrut -- Jewish dietary law -- as a kid in an elementary school. It would probably take on the role of hall monitor, enforcing restrictive rules that may or may not be important to the authorities: Sayonara, shrimp! Ciao, cheeseburgers! And for the love of G-d, stay away from pork!

Bob Woodward, the prominent investigative reporter, will have a new book on the Obama presidency in September, just two months before the midterm elections. The book will be released by Simon & Schuster, Mr. Woodward's longtime publisher. Tracey Guest, a spokesperson for the publisher, said she had no other information about the content, and that it did not yet have a title. Mr. Woodward, whose reporting with Carl Bernstein on Watergate for The Washington Post first brought him prominence, is one of the few writers in recent years whose political books have consistently altered the talking points in Washington. The storyline in his four books about President George W. Bush's administration changed dramatically, as the first one, "Bush at War," described Mr. Bush as a strong leader and the third, "State of Denial," described the administration's troubles in handling the war in Iraq, a story continued in "The War Within," the final Bush installment.

The Paris-based fashion designer Rick Owens claims he fell into designing furniture simply because he needed something to sit on. And truth be told, the Art Deco and Robert Mallet-Stevens pieces he coveted were too big for his budget - and too polite in scale for the former French Socialist Party Headquarters that he now calls his home and office. "Like a typical American, I over-sized everything," says Owens, a Los Angeles transplant. And he's not kidding.

The Williamstown Theater Festival on Wednesday announced the appointment of its new artistic director: Jenny Gersten, a widely admired New York producer at the Public Theater who also worked as associate producer at Williamstown from 1996 to 2004.
In response to the $3 billion United-Continental Deal, The Room for Debate blog takes a look at who benefits when airlines merge. Read what the five experts have to say, and share your own opinion.

The annual Webby Awards were announced on Tuesday and there were two categories that caught our eye here at Bucks, Banking/Bill Paying and Financial Services.For the second year in a row, Mint won for Best Financial Services Web site, and for the third year in a row it won the People's Voice award. Mint, a personal finance Web site, beat CBS Moneywatch, which features video interviews with Jill Schlesinger; MicroPlace, a microfinance Web site; StockMapper, a site that specializes in stock heat maps; and wikinvest, an investment research portal.In the Banking/Bill Paying category, a money management site, moneyStrands, took the Webby, knocking last year's winner Xero out of the category. The London-based online lender Wonga won the People's Voice Award, which also went to Xero last year. The nominees in the category included The Morris Code, an interactive personal finance Web site sponsored by Bank of America and geared toward college students; Billeo, a bill paying site; and BillShrink.com, a Web site that scours the Internet for better deals on things like credit cards and cellphone plans.One additional note was in the Education category which nominated the Your Life, Your Money project. The project was produced by WNET-TV and Working Dog Productions and ran on the Public Broadcasting Service Web site.

Overview | In this lesson, students consider the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico and related cleanup efforts. They then design and execute experiments to learn more about the effects of oil spills, and apply their findings to the coastal communities in the gulf region. Finally, they explore the economic and political impacts of the oil spill as well as the technological progress toward stopping the leak.

Justin Bieber is not the only young protégé of a big Atlanta star to hit No. 1 on the Billboard album chart lately. B.o.B., a smooth-voiced 21-year-old under the wing of the rapper T.I., reached the top spot this week with his debut album, "B.o.B. Presents: The Adventures of Bobby Ray" (Rebel Rock/Grand Hustle/Atlantic), which sold 84,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. At its spring gala on Tuesday night, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts paid tribute to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg with an unusual gift. The center will move its Calder sculpture, "Le Guichet" ("The Box Office"), to any place in New York City the mayor chooses for a period of 90 days. In his remarks, Mr. Bloomberg said his deputy mayor Patricia E. Harris would find a good place for it. Ms. Harris said on Wednesday a site had yet to be determined. The sculpture, made of black steel plate, sits on the north plaza outside the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. It was presented to Lincoln Center in 1965. The philanthropist David M. Rubenstein, a Lincoln Center trustee, was honored at the gala.

Is there a member of the X-Men whose mutant powers include the ability to create a Hollywood blockbuster in just over a year? If so, Matthew Vaughn would probably like to speak to him. Fox has named Mr. Vaughn, whose films include the comic-book action film "Kick-Ass," the director of its next "X-Men" movie and announced a release date of June 3, 2011, for the film, Variety reported [subscription required].

Millions of people, more women than men, suffer from a feeling of extreme coldness in the fingers and toes, a problem called Raynaud's phenomenon. For some, the discomfort extends into the summer months, and even holding a cold drink or being in an air conditioned room can be unbearable. Here, Dr. Fredrick Wigley of Johns Hopkins Medical School responds to readers concerned about whether they have Raynaud's, how serious it might be and what can be done to ease the discomfort. For more information, see Dr. Wigley's earlier responses in "Ask the Expert: Raynaud's Phenomenon" and The Times Health Guide: Raynaud's Phenomenon.

Reactions to the Gulf oil spill have, I suppose, been predictable. We finally left Tana on May 2, fully loaded with all our equipment and supplies. The packing is always high stress, as the omission of a single item can have terrible consequences in the field, when resupply is not an option.  For example, no formalin or alcohol (perhaps due to a leaking bottle top), or no spare flashlight bulbs, can bring research to a complete stop.  I had hoped we could have departed the previous afternoon, but my driver, Nicholas, was nervous about nighttime attacks  on vehicles between Tana and Antsohihy, so we left at first light.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

David Brooks: Gail, would you mind if I praised Barack Obama today? I thought not. I'm feeling grateful to the prez these days because we happen to be in the middle of a bunch of midsized crises. There's the oil spill in the Gulf (which is verging on a big crisis, I guess). There's the Times Square bomber. There are various floods in Tennessee and elsewhere. The European Union is falling apart over the Greek debt crisis, and so on and so on.

Monologue | Tuesday night on "The Tonight Show With Jay Leno" on NBC: Hey, great news. They made an arrest today in that failed Times Square bombing attempt. It turns out the suspect is a foreign-born, naturalized American citizen. You know what that means? He would have been fine in Arizona.

Fergus Henderson, owner of St. John in London, and the John the Baptist of nose-to-tail cooking, will cook lunch at Barbuto, Jonathan Waxman's restaurant, on Thursday from 12:30 to 2 p.m., 775 Washington Street (12th Street) in Greenwich Village.

Toddlers who watch a lot of television were more likely to experience a range of problems by the fourth grade, including lower grades, poorer health and more problems with school bullies, a new study reports.

Monologue | Tuesday night on "The Late Show With David Letterman" on CBS: This bombing plot here in Times Square is upsetting. Are we more upset about that than the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico? Which do we hate worse? I think you've got to go with the oil spill. British petroleum, these boobs running this operation, they said: "O.K., now wait a minute. It's just going to be a P.R. nightmare. What can we do? We'll give everybody a free tank of gas. All you have to do is drive your car right down next to the Gulf of Mexico."
Co-vocabularists may be interested to know of a radio feature on Schott's Vocab that aired last Friday on Veronica Rueckert's Wisconsin Public Radio show.

Monologue | Tuesday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: It's rumored that six pages from the script of the "Lost" series finale have leaked online. BP executives were like: "Oh my God! That's definitely the worst leak of all time, right?"

Monologue | Tuesday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: Oil is still leaking off the coast of Louisiana. Lots of oil. BP, the company responsible for it, has a very good plan. BP is hoping to create a giant vinegar spill to turn the Gulf of Mexico into a delicious salad dressing.

Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Women's Professional Soccer in the league's first season. Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, will be filing to the Goal blog during the defending champions' 2010 season.
Companies like Google and Facebook capitalize on the power of user data, scouring our e-mail messages and profiles for keywords that can result in lucrative targeted advertising.
Google is making some very noticeable changes to its familiar search results pages, rolling out the changes gradually on Tuesday and Wednesday.

There have been a host of notable reader reactions to the continuing oil gusher in the Gulf of Mexico seabed, the solutions being debated and the potential for us to change our behavior in response. Below, you can read a few "Your Dot" highlights. I'll be posting my view on where we go from here later this morning. What's yours?
Don Ervin, a graphic designer and sculptor of fanciful streamlined car models, died in an automobile accident on March 10 in Ulster, N.Y. He was 85.
It's not even Memorial Day weekend and already "Glee" has managed to pack more camp into an hour's worth of television than most kids will get all summer.
Twice a week, Nocturnalist, City Room's newest feature, goes out at night and brings the story home to you.

Telenor, the Norwegian company that recently merged assets with the telecommunications arm of the Russian financial and industrial conglomerate Alfa to create Russia's second-largest mobile phone operator, announced Wednesday a 36 percent drop in first-quarter profits, due to a weak performance in Asian and Central European markets, Reuters reported.

The primary season is in full swing, after voters in Indiana, North Carolina and Ohio kicked off the season on Tuesday.

After its limited run earlier this year netted it two Tony Award nominations on Tuesday including one for best play, "Time Stands Still," which stars Laura Linney as a photojournalist recovering from wounds she sustained covering the war in Iraq, will take another shot at Broadway. On Wednesday morning, press representatives for the play, which was written by Donald Margulies and is directed by Daniel Sullivan, said that it would resume performances on Sept. 23 at a Shubert theater to be determined.
An article published by The New York Times Magazine today, delves into a growing body of evidence that suggests that babies do have a rudimentary moral sense from the very start of life.

The disproportionate attention that journalists, including this one, devote to the high rates of rejection at several dozen colleges and universities sometimes masks a basic truth of admissions: hundreds of other institutions have more available slots than qualified applicants.
Media giant Time Warner reported a 9.8 percent increase in earnings on Wednesday, beating expectations and providing more evidence that media companies are on the rebound.

BP and the federal government are working frantically on solutions for plugging and containing the spill in the Gulf of Mexico. But shutting off a gushing well that lies under 5,000 feet of water will require a delicate feat of engineering.
