ABB, the Swiss power and engineering company, said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy Ventyx, an American maker of software for energy companies, for $1 billion in cash.

On a recent visit to Paris, my wife, Jackie, and I went shopping for Breton sardines. In the French region of Brittany sardines are still canned in the old-fashioned way, from fresh, whole (though headless) fish that are often fried before being arranged in the familiar tins.

Senior managers at Goldman Sachs are beginning to question how tenable Lloyd C. Blankfein's position as chief executive is, given the bank's public relations difficulties, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Public Defender, D.A. Battle Over Police Records | Jeff Adachi, the San Francisco public defender, accused District Attorney Kamala Harris of unethical behavior on Tuesday. Ms. Harris fired back that Mr. Adachi's comments were "irresponsible." The district attorney's office failed to research and disclose the criminal and misconduct histories of about 80 police officers who testified in trials, according to The San Francisco Chronicle. By law, the officers' histories should have been revealed to defense lawyers, who could have used the information to challenge their credibility as witnesses in court. Ms. Harris called Mr. Adachi's assertion that hundreds of convictions could be in jeopardy "wild speculation" and "playing politics with public safety." Meanwhile, the SF Weekly reports that Ms. Harris now has the lowest felony trial conviction rate of any big-city district attorney in the state. She is the front-runner to become the Democratic Party nominee in the race for California attorney general. [The San Francisco Chronicle, SF Weekly]
Say what you like about synthetic collateralized debt obligations, but their explosions are figurative and their damage is financial.

A lawmaker at the European Parliament indicated Tuesday that the E.U. was close to an accord on new hedge-fund legislation that would curb the ability of some offshore funds to raise money from E.U. investors, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Société Générale, the large French bank, said Wednesday that its exposure to Greece's government debt was 3 billion euros ($3.93 billion) and that it had tightened credit at its Greek unit in response to the financial crisis there, The Associated Press reported.

Note to readers: My five posts this week chronicle the events of the week of Feb. 15. I'm publishing them with some misgivings, as one might get the impression that my business is days from failure at all times. Fortunately, this is not so. That week was especially dramatic because of the timing of the payments in and out. Also, it marked the beginning of an uptick in sales. From where I sit today, the recovery has begun. We now have a normal backlog of work and sufficient cash on hand to complete it.
Four private equity firms are vying to acquire InVentiv Health, an unidentified source told The New York Post.

Whatever the state of the global economy, there's always a ton of discretionary cash floating around looking for some place to land. Tuesday night at Christie's a chunk of it - $106.5 million to be exact - landed on a Picasso painting called "Nude, Green Leaves and Bust," setting the record for any art sold anywhere at auction up till now.

Today's idea: New devices like the iPad may discourage the scholarly tradition of gathering passages of text -- a tradition dating back centuries, to the personal "commonplace books" of the Enlightenment era, a writer says.

An initial public offering that would have been Singapore's largest this year and would have given the shipbuilder New Century a market value of 5.31 billion Singapore dollars ($384 million) has been canceled, Bloomberg News reported.

Twenty financial companies including Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are vying to manage Coal India's initial public offering, Bloomberg News reported. The I.P.O. could end up being the nation's largest first-time stock sale.
China Tian Yuan Mining, an iron ore miner, is looking to raise up to $457 million in a Hong Kong I.P.O., Finance Asia reported.
Citic Securities and Credit Agricole are teaming up to combine their global brokerage and investment banking businesses, Finance Asia reported.

Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -- but not strictly -- by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, though the future isn't ignored. Stats weren't acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don't make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. That's why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you're about to read.

The work of Paul Klee was denounced as "degenerate" in his lifetime, a frustration the artist vented on his tombstone, which reads: "I cannot be grasped in the here and now." But Klee's day has certainly come. Through July 19, at the Musée l'Orangerie in Paris, the artist is being rightly acknowledged as one of the major influences of the Expressionist movement in an exhibition that brings together 26 of the self-proclaimed poet and painter's masterpieces.
The producer Jerry Bruckheimer is said to have raised $300 million to $350 million in production co-financing to be used to fund films from Walt Disney's Touchstone label, local media reported.

On its first day of trading, Essar Energy made the worst I.P.O. debut in eight years, The Telegraph reported. The listing follows the company's $2 billion share offering last week in which it was forced to reduce its offer price at the last minute.

The Citigroup chief executive, Vikram Pandit, has said the bank plans to start a $200 million fund earmarked for loans to small businesses in low- and moderate-income communities, The Wall Street Journal reported.
ODL Group, one of Britain's largest retail foreign exchange brokers, has agreed to be taken over by a rival, FXCM Holdings, The Telegraph reported.
UBS's Wealth Management Americas brokerage, the unit run by Robert McCann, has space issues: too much real estate for a work force reduced by thousands in the past two years, Reuters writes.

The failed car bombing in Times Square raised security alerts in the area and reminded many people in New York and elsewhere to be vigilant about suspicious activity. Do you worry about terrorist attacks? Or do you generally feel safe?

Noteholders of Washington Mutual asked a bankruptcy judge on Tuesday to liquidate the company as its reorganization was on the "verge of unraveling" due to "scorched earth" tactics by shareholders who left nothing in the plan, Reuters reported.

The chairman and chief executive of the parent company of United Airlines, Glenn Tilton, has agreed to give up cash severance of $4.6 million in exchange for restricted shares worth the same amount if his airline combines with Continental, United said in a filing Tuesday, according to The Associated Press.
A lawsuit against the large credit ratings companies filed by the California Public Employees' Retirement System can proceed, a state court judge ruled, Bloomberg News reported.
8:32 a.m. | Updated DealBook colleague Julia Werdigier has more from London on how the F.S.A. stepped in at the last moment.

Toscafund, a large London hedge fund, is offering to write off as much as a fifth of the value of British mortgage holders' borrowings if they remortgage their property with a new lender, The Telegraph reported.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. -- George Huguely, the University of Virginia lacrosse player charged with killing Yeardley Love, also a Virginia lacrosse player, admitted to the police that he became violent with Ms. Love the night she died, according to a court document released Tuesday. Mr. Huguely, a 22-year-old senior from Chevy Chase, Md., told the police that he had entered Ms. Love's unlocked apartment early Monday, kicked his foot through her bedroom door and forced his way in. He then ''shook Love, and her head repeatedly hit the wall,'' said an affidavit filed in the case.

If there was one person who didn't need to wear a name tag at Edward R. Murrow High School, it was Saul Bruckner, Murrow's founding principal, who guided the school in Midwood, Brooklyn, to national prominence over 30 years, from 1974 to 2004. But the tag was usually there on his jacket's lapel as he stood near the entrance each morning, greeting by name many of the thousands of students who swirled by him. Like his well-tailored clothes and quiet manner, it served as a small reminder of the formality of an earlier era of public education in a school known for its progressive, free-wheeling spirit.

An illustration on Friday with an article about the divergence of Motorola and Palm over Android, the Google operating system for mobile devices, used an erroneous image. The cellphone at the right is an HTC Droid Eris, not a Motorola Droid smartphone.

An article on Tuesday about a new security arrangement at the Supreme Court misstated the words inscribed over the entrance to the building, which has closed its two six-ton bronze doors to visitors. They are ''Equal Justice Under Law,'' not ''Equal Justice Under the Law.''

BIGELOW--Chandler II, died on May 4, 2010 at his Sagaponack, NY home surrounded by his family. He was 72. Illness resulted in retirement from a long career in commercial real estate. Thereafter, he pursued his main interests, second only to his family, in painting, particularly varied Long Island landscapes, and ornithology. Mr. Bigelow prepared at Milton Academy for Trinity College from which he graduated in 1959. As a young man, he became a skilled sailor and was a crew member of "Merry Maiden", the 1958 Class B winner of the Bermuda Race. Chan shared his love and knowledge of sailing, skiing and nature with family and friends. Whether sailing his Sunfish on Mecox, kayaking off Northwest Harbor or walking his dogs on Sagg Main Beach, Chan spend many hours exploring the beauty of the East End. He founded a cancer support group at Joshua's Place, Southampton, NY. Through this group and his involvement with Fighting Chance, Sag Harbor, NY, Cham contributed tirelessly within the cancer community. He is survived by his wife, Margaret "PJ," his two sons, Chandler III (Elizabeth) of Northfield, IL and Bolan of Portland, ME; his two daughters Vanessa Bigelow Roy (James) and Lindsay, both of Stowe, VT; his four grandchildren, Eddy, Walker, Penrose Bigelow and Travis Roy and his three brothers, Nelson, Alfred and John. No formal memorial service is planned per Chandler's wishes. In his memory, donations may be made to East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978.

A front-page news analysis article on Tuesday discussed the uncertainty over the ultimate environmental impact of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. One expert quoted was Quenton R. Dokken, a marine biologist who is the executive director of the Gulf of Mexico Foundation. (He said the spill ''isn't the end of the Gulf of Mexico,'' but also said that ''we've always got to ask ourselves how long can we keep heaping these insults on the gulf and having it bounce back.'') The article described the Gulf of Mexico Foundation simply as a conservation group. It should have included more information about the organization, a nonprofit group that says its mission is ''to promote and facilitate conservation of the health and productivity of the Gulf of Mexico and its resources'' through research and other programs. While the group says the majority of its funding comes from federal and state grants, it also receives some money from the oil industry and other business interests in the gulf, and includes industry executives on its board.

An obituary and a headline last Wednesday about the voice actor Allen Swift misstated his age. As the obituary correctly noted, he was born on Jan. 16, 1924, therefore he was 86, not 87. The obituary also misidentified the role he played in the Broadway play ''Checking Out,'' which he wrote. Mr. Swift played the lead, not a supporting role. And the obituary, using information from his family, misstated the year he graduated from high school. It was 1942, not 1941.

TARBELL--John Weatherbee, Jr.,67, a former Wall Street financial advisor and investment banker who helped build the field of structured finance, passed away peacefully at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan on May 1, after battling cancer. Born in Boston in 1943, the youngest of five children, he graduated from The Governor's Academy in 1962 and Bowdoin College in 1966 and was a three-sport varsity athlete at both schools. He attended the Harvard Business School's Executive Education General Management Program in 1985. John began his career at First National City Bank in New York, and held positions at Chemical Bank, AIG, and other firms during his 30-year career in finance before launching a second career in executive search at DHR International, Inc., where he was Executive Vice President. During his tenure at Chemical Bank, he built and led the Bank's first designated Leveraged Buyout Group, and was a founder of its Mergers and Acquisitions Department, where he served as a Managing Director. During this time, he oversaw a number of important transactions, including financings for Revlon, Inc., Hanson Industries PLC, and Wang Industries. In addition to these responsibilities, he also served as a Director of the Allis Chalmers Corporation and Secretary to Chemical Bank's Midtown Advisory Board of Directors. It was also at Chemical Bank where he met his wife, Anne Adler Tarbell. They were married in 1990. In addition to his professional accomplishments, John was a life-long athlete. He was an avid runner and could often be found logging miles in Central Park. His daily running habit remained an unbroken streak for more than 26 years. John also played for the Old Blue Rugby Football Club (RFC) in his early years in New York and later coached and captained the Columbia Business School RFC. He earned a Black Belt in Tae Kwon Do at age 59. For all these successes, John was happiest in his private family life. He was a devoted husband to Anne, and a loving father to his daughter, Elizabeth Weatherbee Tarbell. In addition to his wife and daughter, he is survived by three sisters, Mary Ann MacLennan of Edina, MN, his twin sister Merideth DeLamarter of Concord, MA, and Joyce Morgan of Darien, CT, as well as a close circle of relatives including a brother-in-law, Douglas Adler of Washington, DC, and his family, and a sister-in-law, Mary Malhotra of New York City, and her family, and 17 nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, on May 14 at 11am. Memorial donations may be made to the John Tarbell Malawi Fund at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

ROBINSON--Janet Binder. Beloved wife, mother and grandmother died in Scottsdale, AZ on May 3, 2010 of pancreatic cancer at the age of 75. She is survived by her husband of 52 years, Irwin Jay Robinson of New York City and Scottsdale, AZ, daughter Elizabeth (Steven) Schubiner of Bloomfield Hills, MI, son Jonathan (Heidi Biegel) Robinson of New Haven, CT, daughter Eve (Joshua Wiener) Robinson of New York City, grandchildren Andrea and Julie Schubiner, Jasmine and Maia Robinson, and Nathaniel and Aden Wiener, brother Dr. Henry (Joan) Binder of New Haven, CT, and sister-in-law Bette Entin and brother-in-law Philip Entin of Bloomfield Hills, MI. Janet graduated from Bronx Science High School, Vassar College, and the Yale University Graduate Program in Education. She was a long-time volunteer and board member of the Society for the Advancement for Judaism, Jewish Board of Family & Children's Services, Riverdale Senior Center, and The Paper Bag Players. A dynamic, inquisitive, creative woman of enormous love, she was devoted to family and friends world-over. Janet will be greatly missed and will stay in our hearts forever. Services will be held at the Society for the Advancement of Judaism, 15 West 86th Street on Wednesday, May 5 at 12:15pm. Donations in her honor may be made to Vassar College, The Society for Advancement of Judaism, and Mayo Clinic Palliative Care Program in Scottsdale.

Europe's nervous markets were calmed, at last, on Monday after the European Union and the International Monetary Fund broke their logjam and approved a long-delayed financial rescue package for Greece. Stock markets across Europe plunged and the euro was beaten down to its lowest level against the dollar in a year.

The guitarist Tom Paronis, 51, at Bar Nine on Ninth Avenue at 53rd Street in Hell's Kitchen, where he can be found many nights playing with the 69th Street Band. By day, he writes software for a commodities trading company. ''I play old country, blues, bluegrass and some roots music,'' he said. ''Occasionally I get to play some Afro-beat music and jazz.'' His maternal grandfather was a concert-level violist, and Mr. Paronis, who was born in Brooklyn and raised upstate, has been playing guitar since he was a teenager. ''Living in New York City, you get to play with the best of them,'' Mr. Paronis said. ''There are hundreds of great musicians available here.'' VILLA--Roy Wayne Anthony, April 21, 1935 (full moon, Easter Sunday) -- May 1, 2010. He was New York ("the center of the universe"), from Juilliard, the Art Students' League, the Oak Room Bar, Carnegie Hall and the Met Museum, to Gray's Papaya and Row 41, Seat B at the fights at the Garden. "Point is this, kids: Every time you're out having a fun time and cracking a couple of jokes, good tips always, and simply loving the gift of a daily hello." Used as an epithet, "activist judge" is almost always applied to a judge who has just issued a decision that the speaker doesn't like. Conservatives affix the label to the Supreme Court of the 1960's and 1970's, as well as to anything they object to about the current court. The ink on Justice John Paul Stevens's letter of resignation last month was barely dry before conservative political candidates and bloggers lined up to bid good riddance to "the liberal activist now leaving the court."

American farmers' broad use of the weedkiller glyphosphate -- particularly Roundup, which was originally made by Monsanto -- has led to the rapid growth in recent years of herbicide-resistant weeds. In Africa, kangas - colorful sarong-like pieces of fabric - are used by local women for everything from wrap dresses to papooses, but they have also served as inspiration for spring fashion. And while designers like Dries Van Noten, Thakoon and Balenciagia showed bold ethnic prints, the kanga designers in Nairobi take it one step further, creating cultural mash ups of patterns - Arab geometrics, sub-continent psychedelics, and lots of local iconography like mangos, cashews and plenty of flowers.

After 16 years of presenting film, art, fashion, music and parties, Gen Art, a showcase devoted to young talent and young audiences with branches in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago, has folded, a victim of the financial downturn. "After struggling for the past 18 months since the economic crisis, Gen Art has finally succumbed to the recession," its founders, the brothers Ian and Stefan Gerard, wrote in a letter sent out late Wednesday and posted on the Gen Art Web site. "We have now halted all operations, have let go all of our amazing staff, and shuttered the business," they wrote, adding that they hoped that Gen Art "in some small way was as close to your heart  as it was ours."

Warner Music Group reported mixed results in the latest quarter, as it continued to lose money but had a 15 percent uptick in digital revenue. Over all, revenue at the company declined 1.3 percent, to $662 million, in the most recent quarter compared with the period a year earlier. The net loss was $25 million, or 17 cents a share, an improvement over its $68 million loss last year.

As the water recedes and Nashville recovers from the flooding that occurred when the Cumberland River became swollen from a weekend's worth of thunderstorms, many of the city's best-known musicians are assessing the damage to their property and making plans to help it get back on its feet. The country star Brad Paisley told The Associated Press that much of the staging and props for his coming concerts -- called the H2O tour -- were underwater during the floods, and that most of his guitars, amps and equipment had been destroyed. Ben Jumper, the owner of a storage plant called Soundcheck Nashville, where Mr. Paisley and other musicians kept their gear, said he expected his losses from the flood would amount to tens of millions of dollars. A publicist for Kenny Chesney told The A.P. that the musician's home would probably be condemned after water rose above its first floor.

Robin Roberts, the Hall of Fame right-hander who won 286 games and pitched the Philadelphia Phillies' 1950 Whiz Kids team to the National League pennant, died Thursday at his home in Temple Terrace, Fla. He was 83.

In their own ways, Nan Swid and Donald Kaufman have always been enablers. A founder of the design company Swid Powell, Swid worked with an A-list of artists and architects like Frank Gehry, Richard Meier and Ettore Sottsass to produce all manner of tabletop objects. The company archives - from a coffee maker to candlesticks - now reside at the Yale University Museum of Art. Kaufman - who with his wife and business partner, Taffy Dahl, founded Donald Kaufman Color in the '70s - has long been the go-to guy for architects and decorators looking for that elusive shade of not-quite-gray-not-quite-white or flaming red. Take a tour of Philip Johnson's Glass House or grab a drink at the Julian Schnabel-designed Gramercy Park Hotel and you get the picture. But for four days this week, instead of making other people look good, Swid and Kaufman will bask in the spotlight as artists in their own right, when they show their personal work at Gallery 9E in Chelsea. Unsurprisingly, Kaufman - whose work has been in museums like the Whitney and the Hirshhorn, but who hasn't had an exhibition in over 30 years - is a painter. His series of gouaches on paper, he says, are inspired by architectural color samples. And true to form, Swid is more object-oriented, layering pieces of old books, cellophane, legal files and other found materials into three-dimensional reliefs.

Since Alicia Alonso joined American Ballet Theater in 1941 her performances have been described as "breathtaking" and "eminently dainty and gracious." Now the woman synonymous with Cuban dance is returning to the company and the Metropolitan Opera House. She'll be there June 3 to celebrate her 90th birthday at an event that will include a film retrospective of her career and a special performance of "Don Quixote," Ballet Theater's artistic director, Kevin McKenzie, announced. The fete is part of a celebration of another milestone: the company's 70th anniversary.

The Venice Film Festival runs this year Sept. 1-11, though its organizers might consider adding at least a few hours to that schedule: on Thursday they announced that Quentin Tarantino, the expansive and prolifically talkative filmmaker, would serve as chairman of the festival's jury, which gives out the Golden Lion award and other prizes, Reuters reported. In an announcement on the festival's Web site the organizers wrote that they had chosen Mr. Tarantino, whose films include "Pulp Fiction" and "Inglourious Basterds," because "he has become a studied and imitated 'point of reference,' and he is perhaps the only American auteur to be adored worldwide like a rock star." The announcement also praised Mr. Tarantino for rediscovering "overlooked actors in impressive roles," and for his own work as "an atypical character actor" in films like Takashi Miike's "Sukiyaki Western Django" (a 2008 Venice festival entry in which he played a mysterious gunfighter named Ringo). Not least of all, the festival organizers also noted Mr. Tarantino is "a great admirer and connoisseur of Italian genre cinema."

The exhibition "Roy McMakin: When is a chair not a chair?" opened on Tuesday at Cristina Grajales Inc. in SoHo, to coincide with the publication of a monograph with the same title published by Skira Rizzoli.  McMakin, an artist and designer whose work has been featured in T and The New York Times Magazine, is known for his embrace of ambiguity and subversive humor in the design of seemingly mundane objects: A chest of drawers, for instance, that has no drawers; a teapot with the vestiges of a broken handle; a headboard that takes a "pretty" 1940s-inspired design and deconstructs it. While McMakin designs perfectly functional interior and furniture, he does it with an artist's eye, eschewing conventional ideas of perfection or comfort. The exhibition runs until July 2.

Even as the story lines on the Showtime comedy "Weeds" became increasingly byzantine and the series drifted away from its original premise about a suburban widow (Mary-Louise Parker) who sells pot to support her family, Elizabeth Perkins was a welcome presence on the show. LONDON -- Even with rioters on the streets of Athens and the 16 countries using the euro threatened with mounting turmoil, the economy remained the most frequently -- and least candidly -- discussed topic here as the three main parties entered the last hours of a monthlong general election campaign. Yet, with government deficits in Britain second in Europe only to those of Greece, some analysts have suggested that this might be a good election to lose. Whoever wins will be forced to make deep and unpopular cuts, a task made all the more difficult if the closely contested election produces a hung Parliament or a fragile coalition government that could delay important economic decisions.

The board of the New School approved plans on Wednesday evening to build a 16-story, $353 million University Center, the largest construction project in the university's 91-year history in Greenwich Village. The unusual bronze-and-glass structure will rise on Fifth Avenue, between 13th and 14th Streets, and house lecture halls, an auditorium, academic spaces, student lounges, stores and a 600-bed dormitory on the top nine floors. Horizontal and diagonal bands of glass on the sides of the building will allow pedestrians to see students and faculty members circulate along corridors and stairwells.

8 P.M. (HBO) SERGIO (2009) Charismatic, gifted and impossibly handsome, Sergio Vieira de Mello, above, a Brazilian diplomat and humanitarian who served the United Nations for more than 30 years, drew comparisons from his admirers to James Bond and Robert F. Kennedy. (Even President George W. Bush complained of feeling scruffy alongside him.) Mr. de Mello's career took him to Swaziland, Cambodia, Bosnia and East Timor, where he earned praise for his hands-on work inside nations in crisis. In 2003, shortly after the United States invasion of Iraq, he agreed to serve as the special representative to that country for Kofi Annan, then secretary general of the United Nations. This documentary from Greg Barker, based on the biography ''Sergio: One Man's Fight to Save the World'' by Samantha Power, tells the story of the Al Qaeda truck bombing of the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad on Aug. 19, 2003, that killed 22, including Mr. de Mello. 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES Kathy Reichs, the forensic anthropologist whose novels inspired this series, wrote this episode, which finds Brennan (Emily Deschanel) and Booth (David Boreanaz) learning a little about the Wicca religion after two bodies -- including one dating to the Salem witch trials of 1692 -- are found in a cabin. Meanwhile Hodgins (T. J. Thyne) and Angela (Michaela Conlin) land in jail because of Hodgins's driving.

Anyone with fond memories of Lite Brite will instantly recognize iBrite, a $1.99 iPad app that lets you make a picture using colored dots. Instead of jabbing plastic pegs through black paper to create a picture of lighted dots, you use a slider to pick a color, then every space you touch will show a dot in that color, accompanied by a popping sound.

8:27 p.m. | Updated A painting that Picasso created in a single day in March 1932, ''Nu au Plateau de Sculpteur (Nude, Green Leaves and Bust),'' sold for $106.5 million, a world record auction price for a work of art, at Christie's Tuesday night. The painting, more than 5 feet by 4 feet, shows Picasso's mistress Marie-Therese Walter, both reclining and as a bust. Picasso's profile can be discerned in the blue background. The painting broke the record price for a work of art set in February when a Giacometti sculpture, ''Walking Man I,'' was sold for $104.3 million at Sotheby's in London. Bidding for the Picasso lasted 8 minutes and 6 seconds; there were six bidders. Nicholas Hall, an expert at Christie's, took the winning bid by telephone. He declined to say who he was bidding for.

Practically from the moment of its birth 16 years ago, the lowly MetroCard has inspired flights of artistic fancy. Malleable yet practically indestructible, it has been folded, spindled and mutilated by commuters, bored booth attendants and credentialed magicians alike to make purses and frogs, boomerangs and stars, crowns and eyeglass frames. People have papered bicycles with MetroCards, sliced them up and rearranged the letters (Mr. Rat Code! Dermocrat! Dream cort! Cream drot!), published whole books of MetroCard origami.

The phrase ''life imitates art'' is probably no more apt than when applied to the newly published memoir by Laura Bush, ''Spoken From the Heart'' (Scribner). In fact, for readers of the 2009 novel ''American Wife'' (Random House), by Curtis Sittenfeld, in which the main character, Alice Blackwell, is a barely fictionalized version of Mrs. Bush, many scenes in the former first lady's book will feel eerily familiar -- from the car crash that killed a close childhood friend to her marriage to the hard-drinking scion of a powerful political family who later sobers up and seeks office himself. Where does Alice Blackwell end and Laura Bush begin? THE CAR CRASH

An article on April 22 about Judge Diane P. Wood, a possible Supreme Court nominee, and her working relationship with other judges on the federal appeals court in Chicago, referred incompletely to the academic association of Judge Wood and two judicial colleagues with the University of Chicago Law School. While Judge Wood, Chief Justice Frank H. Easterbrook, and Judge Richard A. Posner are former professors there, they have not ended their association with the law school; they are still senior lecturers.

Ernie Harwell, the neighborly Georgian who delivered Margaret Mitchell's newspaper in the 1930s and then delivered the play-by-play of more than 8,500 major league baseball games over 55 years, died Tuesday at his home in Novi, Mich. He was 92. The Detroit Tigers, for whom he announced games for more than four decades, announced his death, which came eight months to the day after he learned he had cancer of the bile duct.

If you're planning a summer vacation and need a new way to (lightly) pack and protect your camera gear, you might consider the new Bumblebee Ultra-Light 222 backpack from Kata. Every aspect of this $275 bag is meticulously engineered for durability, protection and economy of weight. Kata's founders got their start designing military-grade carrying solutions for the Israeli military, so they know a thing or two about high-performance design. I had a look at the Bumblebee Ultra-Light 222, Kata's flagship backpack, a few weeks ago, and I really liked the company's meticulous attention to detail and quality construction.

The Gimlet Eye column last Thursday, about the departure of clothing companies from garment district buildings, misstated the name of a real estate company that is the managing agent for a building in the district. It is Winoker Realty, not the Winokur Group.

FRIEDMAN--Jack July 9, 1939 May 3, 2010. Toy Pioneer Jack Friedman, who made his mark over his 50 year career with some of the most iconic playthings of our time, has died at the age of 70. Friedman, of Thousand Oaks, CA and originally from Queens, NY, was founder and Chairman for leading toymaker JAKKS Pacific, and founder of video game company THQ, Inc. Friedman launched some of the most successful toys in history, including the first movie toys for E.T.: The Extra-Terrestrial, Michael Jackson dolls, wrestling action figures, Pac-Man plug it in and play TV Games and an array of innovative products for millions of children. Friedman died on Monday, May 3, 2010 from complications caused by a rare blood disease. He is survived by his wife Karen Friedman, and his children Brooke Porter and her husband Tom, and Tony Friedman, and his step children Shannon and Andrew Farrell. JAKKS CEO Stephen Berman said, "Jack was a legendary toymaker and a real titan in our industry. He dedicated his talents to JAKKS Pacific for 15 years, and he will be sorely missed." JAKKS Board of Directors said, "We are greatly saddened by the passing of Jack Friedman. He was a visionary leader who guided the Company with wisdom and keen judgment. Toys were his passion, and his legacy will live on in JAKKS Pacific." Friedman founded JAKKS Pacific in January 1995, and he served as its Chairman and Chief Executive Officer through March 31, 2010. Under his leadership, JAKKS has grown into a Top 5 US publicly traded diversified toy company. Before JAKKS, he led LJN Toys until its sale to MCA in 1985, and then went on to form THQ, Inc. in 1989 and led it until 1995. Friedman was a generous philanthropist and supporter of the Company's JAKKS Cares program, which has benefited organizations such as The Toy Industry Foundation, Camp Ronald McDonald for Good Times, The Special Olympics, Feed the Children, Boys & Girls Clubs of America, Marine Toys for Tots and more. Under the program, the Company has donated over $40 million worth of toys and school supplies to children around the world. Friedman was a proud yo-yo champion and avid golfer, and recently retired from his regular duties at JAKKS Pacific to spend more time with his family. The funeral will be held at the Forest Lawn South Mortuary in Davie Florida on Friday, May 7th and there will be a Memorial Service at the Malibu Jewish Center on Thursday, May 13th. In lieu of flowers, donations in the name of Jack Friedman can be made to one of the following organizations: The Toy Industry Foundation (TIF) - donations.toyindustryfoundation.org or research under the direction of Dr. Gary Schiller at UCLA's Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Center - www.cancer.ucla.edu/giving

SILBERMAN--Arlene. The community of West End Synagogue, A Reconstructionist Congregation, mourns the loss of this down to earth grande dame. Arlene had it all - beauty, charm, intelligence, humor and, most of all, the glowing love of and for her amazing husband of 61 years. Our sympathies to her Charles and their four sons and their families.

ERTUG--Ali Can. Sotheby's is deeply saddened by the tragic loss of our colleague and friend, Ali Can Ertug, who died in Manhattan on Monday night. Ali Can played a key role in the development of Sotheby's new auctions of Turkish Contemporary Art in London and in Sotheby's expanding presence in Turkey. In a very short time with us, and at far too young an age, he leaves an indelible mark. We extend our condolences to his family and his friends. We will miss him.
FRANK--Ross, Dr.,died May 4, 2010. Ross was a 35-year resident of Greenwich, CT where he practiced psychiatry. He leaves behind wife Beverly, four children and four grandchildren.

EGERT--Molly, died May 4, 2010, age 96. This gentle, loving woman who found beauty in life everywhere was so adored and will be forever missed.

An article on Monday about the Obama administration's efforts to prevent a nuclear arms race in the Middle East misstated the number of years that elapsed between Israel's 1981 destruction of a nuclear reactor in Iraq and the 2007 destruction of a nuclear reactor in Syria. It was 26 years, not 16.
HAVES--Hyman H.,94, May 03, 2010. Beloved father, grandfather, uncle and great-uncle.

An article on April 26 about efforts to hold Indian officials accountable for two outbursts of mass sectarian killings, including one in Gujarat State in 2002, misidentified the capital of Gujarat. It is Gandhinagar, not Ahmedabad.

A SECURITY guard in a sharkskin suit did his churlish best to impose order on a scene so chaotic it recalled the gate-storming days of Studio 54. To no avail, it seemed. Hordes of art students, models and filmmakers hurled themselves toward him, hoping to sweet-talk, cajole or just bully their way into Deitch Projects on Wooster Street. Gawkers, gamines and gaudy streetwalkers were on hand to celebrate the May Day opening for the art world incendiary Shepard Fairey (second photo from bottom right), and a simultaneous send-off for Jeffrey Deitch (pink suit at bottom). The dealer who introduced an insular art world to the likes of Stephen Sprouse and Debbie Harry is about to shutter his gallery to become director of the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art.

CHANEY--John J.,of New York City, formerly of Murray City, OH, died May 1, 2010, age 99. He was a retired Business Manager of N. W. Ayer, New York and a parishioner of St. John the Evangelist Catholic Church. Survived by nieces and nephews. Interment in Calvary Cemetery, Cleveland, OH. Services by Johnson-Romito, Bedford, OH.

VILLA--Roy Wayne Anthony, April 21, 1935 (full moon, Easter Sunday) -- May 1, 2010. He was New York ("the center of the universe"), from Juilliard, the Art Students' League, the Oak Room Bar, Carnegie Hall and the Met Museum, to Gray's Papaya and Row 41, Seat B at the fights at the Garden. Scolding us to "let reality walk you in the door", he edited the world toward beauty, humor and a happy life. "Point is this, kids: Every time you're out having a fun time and cracking a couple of jokes, good tips always, and simply loving the gift of a daily hello." We see him now at the Stanhope outdoor cafe, tuxedoed and tapdancing down the middle of Fifth. A pure pleasure to know him. As he said last week, he was his oldest friend. Ours, too. Robin Villa and the Friends of Roy

LEVINSON--Betsy Ann, lifelong resident of Stamford, CT, and dedicated philanthropist passed away Tuesday morning at the age of 64. Mrs. Levinson was an involved member of the Stamford community. In addition, she served as President of the William and Sylvia Silberstein Foundation, giving generously to various medical and medical research institutions including Stamford Hospital and various other Stamford charities. Levinson was also a member of the Stamford Yacht Club. Born in Hammond, Indiana on May 9, 1945 to William and Sylvia Silberstein, Betsy is survived by her daughter Debra Lynn Dietz, her son-in-law, Bryan and her beloved grandsons Grant and Mason. She is also survived by two brothers, Bruce Silberstein and his wife Carolyn, New York, NY, and Sigmund Silberstein and his wife Donna, Boca Raton, FL. Services will be held at Gallagher Funeral Home, located at 2900 Summer Street, Stamford CT at 11am on Thursday, May 6. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Stamford Hospital in memory of Betsy Levinson.

An article in some editions on Monday about the Mets' 11-5 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies on Sunday omitted, in some copies, a player involved in a discussion in the outfield as the Mets changed pitchers after Johan Santana had allowed 10 runs. Besides Jason Bay and Jeff Francoeur, Gary Matthews Jr. also discussed the turn the game had taken.

A chart on Tuesday with an article about United States auto sales for April used an erroneous image of a Hyundai Sonata, the car that led the industry in sales gains with a 56.9 percent increase over the previous April. It was the 2011 model -- not the 2010 model shown -- that went on sale in February and accounted for almost all Sonata sales in April.

HARTOGS--Nelly Wollman (Gutwirth), 95, MSW, Ph.D. Antwerp holocaust refugee. Survived by children Michael (Joan) and Nancy, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, cousins, friends. Services at Plaza Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam, May 7, 11:30am.

FLIESLER--Alan, 78, Woodside, NY, on May 3. Adman, art director, artist, choral singer. Attended Cooper Union, Queens College, Music & Art High School. Loved by Christine, Vicki, Nancy, Marni and Martine.

An obituary on April 27 about Alice Miller, the author of ''The Drama of the Gifted Child'' and other books, misstated her professional credentials. Before writing her first book, she practiced psychoanalysis; she did not practice psychiatry.

GAISMAN--Catherine V. (Kitty)- an outstanding philanthropist died on May 1, 2010 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 91. Throughout her adult life, she was a champion and partner to many charities, in health care, education, the arts, and both the Catholic and Jewish faiths. Kitty, as many affectionately knew her, was a passionate gourmet cook. She hosted many dinners at her home that would rival the best restaurants. She loved her dogs, vegetable garden, her home, and all her family and friends. Holidays were particularly important family times for Kitty; she was the center point around whom all would gather. She truly had an extraordinary grace about her. Kitty is survived by her sister, two nephews, a niece, a grand niece, and her loving and devoted companion. We will deeply miss her. Family will receive friends on Saturday May 8th, from 4-6pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian burial will take place Monday 10am at The Cathedral of St. Patrick. Entombment to follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

An article on April 6 about planned archaeological excavations at the Tell Zeidan site in Syria included an incorrect reference from Gil J. Stein, director of the Oriental Institute at the University of Chicago, to the site's history. There is no evidence that a German expedition made an earlier request to excavate the site or that such a request was rejected.

SILBERMAN--Arlene, 81, died on May 3rd. Adored wife of Charles for 61++ years, beloved mother of David (and Claire Engers), Rick (and Ruth Buchman), Jeff, and Steve (and Brenda Brooks) and loving grandmother of Matthew, Peter, Eric, Jon, Daniel, and Anna. The author of Growing Up Writing (New York: Times Books, 1989), Ms. Silberman had a distinguished career as a free-lance writer, appearing frequently in Readers Digest, McCall's, Ladies Home Journal, and all the other prominent women's magazines of the day. A Memorial Service will be held on Wednesday, May 5, at 2pm at South Gate Community Center, 3145 South Gate Circle, also known as South Tuttle Ave. Circle, Sarasota, FL. Contributions may be made to the Arlene Silberman Memorial Fund at Congregation Kol HaNeshama, 1633 Boathouse Circle, Sarasota, FL 34231 or to All Faiths Food Bank, 717 Cattlemen Road, Sarasota, FL 34231-2852.

It wasn't so much the extraordinary that kept Thomas H. Connell III on his toes -- not the singing horse or the stumbling soldier or the curious incident of the dog, ''Falstaff'' and the beckoning tree stump. It was the routine things -- the fire-breathing dragons, the indoor blizzards, Valhalla collapsing in flames as the Rhine overflows -- that night after night were the truest tests of his skill. A stage manager at the Metropolitan Opera, Mr. Connell spent the past three decades in a crucial though unsung job that requires the combined abilities of a musician, linguist, conjurer, computer whiz, psychotherapist and animal wrangler. He owed his nerves of steel and split-second decision-making ability, he often said, to his former career as a Navy pilot. But, as he also said, setting a plane down on the deck of an aircraft carrier was far easier than pulling off Wagner without a hitch.

A picture caption on April 11 with an article about deadly street battles in Bangkok between anti-government protesters and the military overstated what was known about the man shown carrying a rifle. While the man had been seen talking with an anti-government protester, the photographer, who supplied the details, ultimately could not confirm that he was indeed a security guard for the protesters, or even affiliated with them.

When President Obama visited Louisiana on Sunday, he told fishermen that BP would reimburse them for lost earnings. ''BP is responsible for this leak -- BP will be paying the bill,'' he said. But liability for the oil spill in the gulf may not be so clear. In a sign of the complex legal battle to come, the Coast Guard has notified several parties, including BP and Transocean, the owner of the rig, that they are potentially ''responsible parties'' in the oil spill, and could face liability.

A stage manager at the Metropolitan Opera, Mr. Connell spent the past three decades in a crucial though unsung job that requires the combined abilities of a musician, linguist, conjurer, computer whiz, psychotherapist and animal wrangler. Despite consecutive incidents at Philadelphia's Citizen Bank Park involving fans who ran onto the playing field during Phillies games, Major League Baseball is not yet reconsidering game security. ''We play 2,400 games over the course of a season,'' the M.L.B. spokesman Pat Courtney said. ''When this happens two games in a row, in the short view it seems to be a concern but over the course of the season, you see it's an isolated thing.''

McDONELL--Bruce George, 71, died at home in Pinehurst, NC on May 5th after fighting colon cancer for seven years. Mr. McDonell was born February 3, 1939 to the late Vincent McDonell and Hazel George. He is survived by his wife Tommy McDonell and is four pets. He graduated from the University of Southern California (BA) and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MS) with a degree in Architecture. Bruce worked as a Project Manager for the City of New York's Department of Design and Construction. Some of his many projects include The Museum of Natural History's Planetarium, PS 1, The New York Hall of Science, and the Queens Museum. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Association of Cancer Resources: Colon Cancer (http://www.acor.org/ donate/now) or to the Queens Museum of Art, Flushing, NY, 11368-3398. A memorial will be done in New York City for friends within a month or so.

The Yankees took a 9-1 lead against the Red Sox with a six-run sixth inning Friday, but it was a troubling inning for the Yanks in one respect. Second baseman Robinson Cano, one of the hottest hitters in the American League, left the game after he was hit by a Josh Beckett pitch. Cano tried to jump out of the way, but the ball struck his left knee. Cano walked to first base, but after a few moments he left the game. The severity of the injury was unclear.

Nick Johnson exited Friday's game in the fifth inning because of a sore right wrist. The same wrist required surgery in 2008, when Johnson was limited to 38 games with Washington. It was unclear how Johnson was injured. Marcus Thames pinch-hit for Johnson, who was 0 for 2, in the fifth inning.

Does it seem like overstating things to say that "Friday Night Lights'' is the greatest television soap opera of all time? The series, which returned to NBC Friday night for its fourth season after an earlier run on DirecTV, whispers its heartaches and longings; it is melodrama that always manages to steer clear of feeling melodramatic. Often the show seems like a lesson in resilience to those members of its audience who are Eastern and privileged and lap it up. The people who live in the series' fictional town of Dillon, Texas, never seem undone by the swelter of deprivation; they just go about the business of getting by.

BOSTON - From the Yankees' perspective, their decision to skip Andy Pettitte's next start came easily. When a nearly 38-year-old pitcher complains of elbow tightness 27 games into what they hope is another championship season, they see no reason to take unnecessary risks. They are taking a similarly cautious approach with Jorge Posada, who was held out of the lineup Friday night for a third consecutive game, and with Mariano Rivera, who had not pitched in a week because of a muscle pull in his rib cage but was expected to be available Friday night.

Overview | How did the authorities find and apprehend Faisal Shahzad, the man who confessed to placing a bomb in Times Square? In this lesson, students learn how one person passing through one of America's busiest places can be tracked down through technology and detective work. They create a flowchart that shows each step-and misstep-in the process, then research how Shahzad's experience with law enforcement. would differ had he not become a U.S. citizen. They finish the lesson by debating all sides of a related civil rights issue.

Monologue | Thursday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: Hey, it turns out the prime suspect in the failed attempt to bomb Times Square is not the brightest. They figured out the events leading up to Saturday. First, Faisal Shahzad buys an S.U.V. off Craigslist, using a traceable email, and fills it with, basically, wedding sparklers. Then he drives two different cars into New York -- the one with the bomb in it and a getaway car. He plants the bomb but leaves the keys to the getaway car in the car with the bomb in it. So he has to take the subway home. And then, once he gets home, he realizes he also left the key to his apartment in the SUV with the bomb in it, and has to get his landlord to let him in. If this isn't the work of a stoner, I don't know what is.

I don't see how last night's British election results, which left David Cameron's Tories a couple of dozen seats short of a working majority in Parliament, are anything but bad news for the United Kingdom. I defer to wiser heads on the ins-and-outs of the parliamentary maneuvering that's about to begin, but two things seem clear. First, as The Telegraph puts it this morning, no matter what kind of government gets formed in the next few days, "the only certainty is another general election," and sooner rather than later. And second, as The Economist's Buttonwood suggests, the next election will probably be precipitated by resistance - from regional parties and the Liberal Democrats as well as Labour - to the hard budgetary choices a Prime Minister Cameron will be forced to make. Cameron campaigned as a change agent this time, but if he finds himself facing the voters again in a year or so, it will be as the face of fiscal austerity - which is a role that no politician wants to inhabit.

The legal battle over Roman Polanski's possible sentencing in the United States on a 33-year-old sex charge continues, as prosecutors on Thursday registered opposition to Mr. Polanski's request that recent secret testimony in the case be unsealed. Mr. Polanski, who fled the United States before sentencing in 1978, and his lawyers have asked the Los Angeles County Superior Court to provide them with transcripts of testimony by Roger Gunson, the original prosecutor in the case. In court filings, Mr. Polanski's lawyers have said Mr. Gunson described a plan under which Judge Laurence J. Rittenband intended to use Mr. Polanski's time in prison for psychiatric evaluation as his punishment in the case. In their brief on Thursday, Los Angeles County District Attorney Steve Cooley and Deputy District Attorney David Walgren said that the testimony should remain sealed and noted that the authorities in Switzerland, where Mr. Polanski is being held pending possible extradition, have not requested transcripts of the sealed testimony. A hearing on the request is set for Monday.

Palin Endorses Fiorina for Senate | Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska, announced on Thursday her support of Carly Fiorina, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, in California's crowded United States Senate race. Ms. Palin, the 2008 Republican nominee for vice president, apparently does not hold a grudge against Ms. Fiorina for saying during that campaign that Ms. Palin could not run a major company. Ms. Palin, a favorite of the Tea Party movement, shared her choice on her Facebook page. The endorsement disappointed conservative DeVore supporters. On Thursday night, the three Republican candidates -- Ms. Fiorina, former Congressman Tom Campbell and Assemblyman Chuck DeVore -- clashed over immigration, gun control and the rights of terrorism suspects in their only debate before the June primary. They are hoping to unseat Senator Barbara Boxer in November. [The New York Times, The Los Angeles Times, The San Jose Mercury News]

On March 20, the Plastiki, a 60-foot vessel made from recycled plastic bottles, set sail from San Francisco Bay on an 11,000-mile voyage to Sydney, Australia. The goal of the voyage, masterminded and financed by a banking heir, David de Rothschild, is to call attention to environmental issues like bottled water and plastic waste. Solar panels and windmills power the vessel, and the crew uses Skype, Twitter and blogs to stay in touch with the outside world. They've also posted regular video updates.

Want to join a mailing list or other e-mail group but don't want the rest of the messages in your Gmail in-box to get lost? Gmail has supported "plus" addressing for years, and with it, you can get multiple addresses out of one @gmail.com account. All you need to do is stick a + sign and another word after your account name in your Gmail address when signing up for the mailing list or group.

Given the speed with which Hong Kong's colonial buildings have been torn down, it's fortunate that the old British marine police headquarters survived at all. The 19th-century white-stucco structure had been neglected for more than a decade. Most visitors to the bustling Tsim Sha Tsui area probably did not notice its elegant curving staircase entrance, set back from the neon and noise of Salisbury Road. Late last year the complex, known as 1881 Heritage (1881heritage.com), began reopening in stages, first with a few luxury shops. The main building, Hullett House (hulletthouse.com) now has a number of restaurants, a bar and a boutique hotel that opened last month. Perhaps most impressively, the renovation has been done with care.

Allowing T-Mobile to put in a cellphone tower at a Boy Scout camp in El Cerrito would have brought the scouts $2,200 a month, money that could be put use good use expanding programs. But that was before opponents, who can no longer base their cases on fear of the health effects of radio frequency radiation, began to try a new approach. LONDON -- After one of the most passionately contested elections in decades, the Conservative Party was headed toward big, though not necessarily decisive, gains in Britain early on Friday. Incomplete results from 650 House of Commons constituencies across the country pointed to a strong performance on Thursday by the opposition party, led by David Cameron, though the size of the increase in the Conservative vote raised doubts about the party's ability to win the majority needed to be sure of regaining power after 13 years of Labour control.

(13, 49) NEED TO KNOW Alison Stewart, a Peabody Award-winning broadcast journalist, and Jon Meacham, the editor of Newsweek and the winner of a 2009 Pulitzer Prize for his biography ''American Lion: Andrew Jackson and the White House,'' both above, are the hosts of this new weekly news and public affairs series, which moves into the slots once filled by ''Now on PBS'' and ''Bill Moyers Journal.'' This premiere episode looks at the 50th anniversary of the birth control pill, the ''open-carry'' gun movement and the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City and former President Bill Clinton are interviewed. Maria Hinojosa, a senior correspondent for ''Now,'' is among the series's reporters. The comedian Andy Borowitz will close each program. NOON (MLB Network) ALL-TIME GAMES In honor of the sportscaster Ernie Harwell, who died on Tuesday, this episode looks backs at his call of the game between the Boston Red Sox and the Detroit Tigers on Sept. 18, 1996, at which Roger Clemens pitched his second 20-strikeout game. The program is followed at 3 by the rebroadcast of a November episode of ''Studio 42 With Bob Costas,'' in which Mr. Harwell, who turned 92 in January, discussed his 55-year career as an announcer for the Brooklyn Dodgers, the New York Giants, the Baltimore Orioles and the Detroit Tigers, as well as his battle with cancer. He also recited the speech he gave at his induction into the National Baseball Hall of Fame on Aug. 2, 1981.

BENDER--Robert B.,died on May 5, 2010 at his home in Old Westbury, NY at 68 years old, with his wife Robin lovingly by his side. Robert had a 40 plus year career in the Garment industry, owning and running textile companies. He was a vivacious man with a magnetic personality who always made people laugh. Robert loved life and was passionate about many things, including his family, food, golf, sports and politics. Robert is survived by his wife, Robin; his five children, Howard, Leonard, Stacey, Lindsay and Alex; and his eight grandchildren, Zachary, Hannah, Kendall, Noah, Chloe, Ryan, Avery and Leah. You will always be in our hearts. We love you. Services today, 12 noon at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, LI.

An article on Monday about an effort in China to excise Chinese maladaptations of the English language in translated signs, placards, menus and other written materials misidentified a Chinese diplomatic position in the United States formerly held by Zhao Huimin, now the director general of Beijing's Foreign Affairs Office, who has been helping to lead that effort. He was a deputy consul general, not ambassador. The article also rendered incorrectly the transliterated name of a flawed but popular computerized Chinese dictionary that some linguists consider a source of the Chinglish problem. It is the Jinshan Ciba, not Jingshan Ciba.

HOUSTON -- A Saudi man was sentenced Thursday to four years in prison for selling counterfeit computer parts to the Marine Corps for use in Iraq and Afghanistan. The sentencing of the Saudi, Ehab Ashoor, 48, who lived in Sugar Land, Tex., was part of a broader federal crackdown on shady businesses that supply shoddy computer goods to the military and federal agencies.

A picture caption on April 20 with the Memo From Jerusalem article, about Israel's somber mood on its 62nd birthday, described incorrectly a memorial wall at the Mount Herzl Military Cemetery where an Israeli man was shown grieving. The wall is in memory of fallen soldiers and civilians whose burial place is unknown; the wall is not the Victims of Terror memorial, which is located nearby.

Neanderthals mated with some modern humans after all and left their imprint in the human genome, a team of biologists has reported in the first detailed analysis of the Neanderthal genetic sequence. The biologists, led by Svante Paabo of the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology in Leipzig, Germany, have been slowly reconstructing the genome of Neanderthals, the stocky hunters that dominated Europe until 30,000 years ago, by extracting the fragments of DNA that still exist in their fossil bones. Just last year, when the biologists first announced that they had decoded the Neanderthal genome, they reported no significant evidence of interbreeding.

An article on Thursday about liability questions surrounding the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico misstated the amount of diesel fuel that was on the rig before it collapsed. It was about 750,000 gallons -- not 750,000 barrels. (A barrel equals 42 gallons.)

GAISMAN--Catherine V. (Kitty)- an outstanding philanthropist died on May 1, 2010 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 91. Throughout her adult life, she was a champion and partner to many charities, in health care, education, the arts, and both the Catholic and Jewish faiths. Kitty, as many affectionately knew her, was a passionate gourmet cook. She hosted many dinners at her home that would rival the best restaurants. She loved her dogs, vegetable garden, her home, and all her family and friends. Holidays were particularly important family times for Kitty; she was the center point around whom all would gather. She truly had an extraordinary grace about her. Kitty is survived by her sister, two nephews, a niece, a grand niece, and her loving and devoted companion. We will deeply miss her. Family will receive friends on Saturday May 8th, from 4-6pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian burial will take place Monday 10am at The Cathedral of St. Patrick. Entombment to follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

Identifying the force driving the Yankees' early success is not difficult. The rotation's earned run average stands at 3.17, which is all the more remarkable considering Javier Vazquez's miseries. That is the second-lowest team E.R.A. in the American League behind Tampa Bay (2.61) and the fifth-best in baseball. The Cardinals, at 2.52, entered Thursday's games with the lowest in the majors. The Yankees are waiting for Mark Teixeira and Nick Johnson to hit consistently, and for Alex Rodriguez's power output to increase. but none of the offensive woes has truly dragged them down because their top four starters are pitching so well. Patricia Rico, a central figure in women's track and field for more than 50 years and the first woman to be the president of USA Track and Field, the sport's governing body, died Sunday in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. She was 76 and lived in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. The cause was pulmonary fibrosis, said her daughter, Elizabeth.

There are few baseball players who inspire a love-hate relationship among their team's fans more than the Mets' Carlos Beltran and the Red Sox' J. D. Drew. Both are seen as fragile and nonchalant. Both have been All-Stars and garnered votes for the Most Valuable Player award. But most significant is the perception among some fans that neither player has lived up to his lucrative contract. Drew signed for five years and $70 million before the 2007 season, and Beltran signed for seven years and $119 million before the 2005 season.

WASHINGTON -- Henry M. Paulson Jr., the former Treasury secretary who led the Bush administration's response to the 2008 financial crisis, on Thursday endorsed calls for greater scrutiny and regulation of capital markets. In testimony to the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, Mr. Paulson called the regulatory system that he confronted as secretary, from 2006 to 2009, ''archaic and outmoded.'' The commission, which is examining the cause of the financial crisis that pushed the country into recession, has a Dec. 15 deadline to report to Congress.

He is Eduardo Stein, not Eduard.

Combine one part nervous traders, one part Greek crisis and one part trader error. Stir in one part central bank complacency. Bring to boil. Panic. That combination produced one of the wildest days ever in financial markets, with the Dow Jones industrial average, at one point, down almost 1,000 points while the euro sank to its lowest level in more than a year. There were substantial declines in emerging markets, whose economies had seemed to be booming, and in developed markets fearful of renewed recessions.

An article in some editions on Thursday about the New School's plan to build a 16-story University Center in Greenwich Village misidentified one of the materials to be used. The building will be brass and glass, not bronze and glass.

FRIEDMAN--Jack Friedman. The Board of Directors of JAKKS Pacific, Inc. mourns the passing of its Chairman and Founder, Jack Friedman, whose extraordinary leadership molded the Company and whose friendship we will cherish always.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Thursday about Thomas H. Connell III, the chief stage manager at the Metropolitan Opera, misstated the date of an interview with Joe Clark, a retired Met technical director, who commented on the nature of the stage manager's job. Mr. Clark spoke with The Times on April 23, not ''last week.''

A news analysis article on April 28 about President Obama's determination to stick to his timeline for withdrawing American combat troops from Iraq gave an outdated rank for a spokesman for Gen. Ray Odierno, the American commander in Iraq, and a correction in this space last Friday misstated the spokesman's middle initial. He is Stephen R. Lanza, not Stephen G., and he is now a major general, not a brigadier general. (He was promoted late last year.)

ERTUG--Ali Can. Sotheby's is deeply saddened by the tragic loss of our colleague and friend, Ali Can Ertug, who died in Manhattan on Monday night. Ali Can played a key role in the development of Sotheby's new auctions of Turkish Contemporary Art in London and in Sotheby's expanding presence in Turkey. In a very short time with us, and at far too young an age, he leaves an indelible mark. We extend our condolences to his family and his friends. We will miss him.

BAROUK--David, 82. Died Thursday April 22, 2010. Our beloved father was hardworking, strong, loving, and gentle. He arrived to this country with minimal financial means and left a legacy for posterity. His hard work and perseverance gave birth to an institution in Fort Lee, NJ, The Sharon Cinema, which has now become The Sharon Plaza. Through the fruits of his labor, he gave the gift of survival by building a Daycare floor for Cancer patients at the Rabin Medical Center in Israel. Through this selfless gift, he has provided state of the art care for cancer patients who need it most. It is through his example that we will follow in his footsteps. We love you Dad, you will be terribly missed. He leaves behind his three children: Asaf, Sharon and Karen Barouk and granddaughter, Mia.

There was an interesting qualifying session in Barcelona today, with a few different changes: First, Mark Webber scored his second pole position of the season and the third of his career. 9 P.M. (Showtime) VICKY CRISTINA BARCELONA (2008) ''There will always be an audience that hungers for a certain kind of Woody Allen movie, but it's a relief that he has moved away from the safety and provincialism of his New York,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this comedy, in which two young American women (Rebecca Hall as the sensible Vicky, and Scarlett Johansson as the dreamy Cristina) sample Catalan culture amid the splendors of Gaudí's Spain. The tastiest morsels: the celebrated painter Juan Antonio (Javier Bardem, whom Ms. Dargis calls a national treasure) and Maria Elena (Penélope Cruz, above left, with Mr. Bardem and Ms. Johansson), his unstable former wife. The film is ''bathed in light so lusciously golden and honeyed that you might be tempted to lick the screen,'' Ms. Dargis said. She added, ''What Mr. Allen says about life and disappointment still sounds very Woody, but these days he seems content to speak through his characters, not just for them.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Judy Valente examines the challenges facing Father Patrick Lee, a Roman Catholic priest in Chicago who ministers to parishioners who disagree with the church's teachings on issues like birth control, homosexuality, abortion and divorce, and who have been further alienated by the recent sexual abuse crisis. In another segment, Lucky Severson interviews Scott Neeson, the founder of the Cambodian Children's Fund, which helps some of the youngest Cambodians obtain food, shelter and an education.

PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. -- His work with the print media done, Lucas Glover stepped outside for a television Q. and A. He stood smiling behind the camera until a member of the crew gently directed to a spot in front of the lens. Eleven months after winning the United States Open at Bethpage Black, Glover remains as unpretentious as a low-country boil. While he admittedly could live without the higher profile that comes with being a major winner, he is certainly not happy that his game has gone into retreat.

On Thursday evening, Joey Pero walked past Lincoln Center and stepped into the lobby of a luxury high-rise apartment building on West 66th Street and told the doorman, ''We're here to see Wynton.'' SIMIONATO--Giulietta. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of the great mezzo-soprano Giulietta Simionato. With her rich, colorful voice and intense stage personality, she exemplified Italian opera singing at its best. She made her Met debut in 1959 and sang some of her finest portrayals with the company. We share in the sadness of her many friends and admirers and offer our sincere condolences to those closest to her. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

An article on Friday about the arrest of the former Giants linebacker Lawrence Taylor on charges of third-degree rape and soliciting prostitution referred incorrectly to disciplinary action taken against him by the N.F.L. He was suspended once, in 1988, for violating the league's substance-abuse policy; he was not suspended ''several times.''

You can add Vanguard to the list of brokerage companies that have lowered their trading commissions and waived trading fees on exchange-traded funds, a move that will apply to all 46 of its funds. Exchange-traded funds are basically mutual funds that trade like stocks. They are pegged to indexes that track different parts of the market. E.T.F.'s also tend to be less expensive and more tax-efficient than their mutual fund counterparts.

PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. - The final 30 minutes of Jay Haas's round on Friday reminded him why 29 years as a full-time member of the PGA Tour was enough. Poised to become the oldest golfer to make the 36-hole cut at the Players Championship, Haas, 56, played the last five holes of his second round in four over par and missed advancing to the weekend. Julius Boros made the cut in 1975 at Colonial Country Club when he was 55 years 174 days old.

An article on Friday about a federal crackdown on businesses that supply shoddy computer goods to the military and federal agencies misstated the plea by Ehab Ashoor, 48, of Sugar Land, Tex., who was convicted of selling counterfeit computer parts to the Marine Corps. Mr. Ashoor is appealing his conviction and four-year prison sentence. He did not plead guilty.

Updated at 3:21 p.m. to note that there are some Continental Visas out there too. When Northwest and Delta merged, holders of the U.S. Bank credit cards that earned Northwest miles had to switch cards to continue to earn miles with the newly merged airline. Why? Delta had long worked with American Express, and the merged carrier decided to keep that relationship intact and cease selling miles to U.S. Bank to give away to its cardholders.

Walter Sear, an audio engineer whose steadfast devotion to pre-digital recording technology led him to maintain a studio with vintage, analog equipment, a risk that paid off in recent years as musicians like Norah Jones, Wilco and Wynton Marsalis flocked there for its rich natural sound, died on April 29 in Manhattan. He was 80 and lived on the Upper West Side. The cause was complications of a subdural hematoma, or bleeding from the brain, after he injured himself in a fall, said his daughter Julia.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about high-speed trading's possible role in Thursday's abrupt market sell-off misstated the time it was taken. The picture, which showed visitors to the New York Stock Exchange watching monitors, was taken after the Dow Jones index plunged nearly 1,000 points within minutes -- not as the plunge was taking place.

LANSKY--David, died in Delray Beach, Florida on May 3, 2010 at the age of 94. An NYU graduate, he built a successful career in New York City as president of Pioneer Mounting & Finishing, which produced advertising displays and the first 3-D glasses for watching movies. David enjoyed leading discussions at NYU School of Continuing Education and Bible-study groups at Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York and Temple Sinai in Delray Beach, and served on the Jewish Board of Education. He started Aspire Industries to retrain ex-offenders for jobs, and was a "Big Brother" to teens in crisis at Hawthorne Cedar Knolls School in Westchester. His experience arbitrating business disputes for the American Board of Arbitrators inspired him to think about peaceful ways to resolve international disputes. David was predeceased by his wife Loretta and survived by his beloved companion, Sara; his five children: Bruce, Ted, Robert, Elaine and Mitchell; his nine grandchildren; and his eight great-grandchildren. We are deeply saddened by his passing and will miss his love, generosity, and courage. A memorial service will be held 9:45am Sunday, May 9 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Ave. near 91st Street in New York City. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to either The Landrum Bolling Peace Fund or the Buckingham All-Age School in Hopeton, Jamaica in David Lansky's name.

FLORIDA CITY, Fla. -- Thousands of Burmese pythons, the offspring of former pets, have invaded the Everglades, eating birds, bunnies, even alligators. It has gotten so bad that Congress is considering an outright ban on buying or selling nine kinds of giant snakes. But an odd thing has happened here in the swamp: the pythons have become celebrities. The snakes are fast becoming an element of Florida lore, attracting ''oohs'' and ''ahhs'' from tourists, along with groans from biologists and even python hunters like Bob Freer.

In lieu of flowers, please support Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, Parkinson's research, or DonorsChoose.org.

PHILADELPHIA -- Simon Gagne, the injured Philadelphia Flyers forward who had been cleared to play on Friday, did not seem to be hampered at all as he galloped toward his teammates after scoring a winning goal -- and keeping their fragile Stanley Cup hopes alive. Gagne tipped in a shot by Philadelphia defenseman Matt Carle at 4 minutes 40 seconds of overtime to lift the Flyers to a 5-4 victory over the Boston Bruins. The Bruins lead the best-of-seven series, three games to one, with Game 5 to be played on Monday in Boston.

Bedbugs can be very expensive house guests. The costs of temporarily moving out while your home is debugged, steam cleaning fabrics and extermination can run up very quickly. According to a recent article in New York magazine, one family spent at least $70,000 trying to rid their Upper East Side home of bedbugs. Of course, people who don't live on the Upper East Side may not have to pay as much, but getting alternative lodging and extensive dry cleaning is costly no matter where you live.

Eskendereya, once considered an early favorite to win the Kentucky Derby, was retired Friday after his owner reached a deal with Jess Jackson, the wine impresario who co-owns the reigning Horse of the Year, Rachel Alexandra. His owner, Ahmed Zayat, who owns Zayat Stables, is in bankruptcy proceedings after Fifth Third Bank said his racing operation defaulted on a $34 million loan.

Fighting for His Vision of California's Coastline | Peter M. Douglas is strongly identified with the California Coastal Commission in part because he was a co-author of both the ballot initiative that created it and the 1976 law making the agency permanent. Over the years, commission actions have helped preserve much of Highway 1 as a two-lane road weaving through farmland, rocks and empty dunes. The question now is whether both Mr. Douglas, 67, and the 12-member commission can weather the state's next budget and continue enforcing the 1976 Coastal Act. Mr. Douglas said he was deeply concerned that an item in Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger's proposed budget could limit the agency's access to state legal services. The commission, based in San Francisco, is one of the nation's most powerful - and litigious - land-use authorities.When Is a Bay Not a Bay? | A major development proposed in Redwood City is, depending on whom you ask, either on the shore of San Francisco Bay - or actually in the bay itself. Which one it is may not ultimately have any legal bearing on whether the project can be built. But the developer and the project's opponents are fighting over the question as if it will decide the matter.

ZEA--Alice Joy, List Industry Pioneer, died at 91. Former Chairman and CEO of AZ Marketing Services died May 1st at her home in Darien CT. Born on January 26, 1919 in Brooklyn, NY, daughter of Samuel and Norma Katz, she received her B.A. in psychology from NYU in 1940. In 1944 she married James Gwin Zea. In 1962, she went to work for her brother Arthur Martin Karl, founder and president of Names Unlimited. In 1971 she joined Direct Media in Rye, NY, and in 1976, she opened her own list brokerage firm, AZ Lists in Greenwich, CT. In 1995, Zea received the Woman of the Year Award from Women's Direct Marketing International, an organization that she helped found in 1970. In 2000 Zea received the Silver Apple Award from the Direct Marketing Club of New York. Zea was considered a pioneer by women in the direct marketing industry. Throughout her professional life, she was a mentor and role model for women in business. Zea is survived by her daughters, Kristi Zea of Valley Cottage, NY, and Marni Zea Clippinger of Cambridge, Mass., and her two grand daughters, Norma Zea Kuhling, and Emma Zea Clippinger

California HOLLYWOOD BOWL- June 12-Oct. 8. It's become somewhat de rigueur to pair a pop act with an orchestra (one gets a little extra bombast, the other a little extra edge), and each summer, the Hollywood Bowl plays matchmaker. On June 15 Sting will perform with the Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra; on July 2-4 Vince Gill will team up with the Los Angeles Philharmonic; on Aug. 13-14 Harry Connick Jr. and his Big Band will do the same; and on Oct. 2 Carrie Underwood will sing alongside the Hollywood Bowl Orchestra. Other notable bookings: the Playboy Jazz Festival (June 12- 13), Femi Kuti and the Positive Force (July 7), Kings of Leon (July 12), B. B. King and Buddy Guy (Aug. 11), and the Neville Brothers (Aug. 18). (323) 850-2000, hollywoodbowl.com.

An article on April 4 about a massacre of 25 members of a Sunni family in the Iraqi village of Hawr Rajab near Baghdad rendered the name of a victim incorrectly. The name, Ipti Hal, provided by surviving relatives, was the victim's given name, not her full name; therefore a subsequent reference should not have identified her as ''Ms. Hal.'' A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message the day the article was published; this correction was delayed because of repeated, but unsuccessful, efforts to contact the surviving relatives to learn the surname.
