The Hall of Famer Dave Winfield, 58, is an executive vice president and senior adviser for the San Diego Padres and an analyst for ''Baseball Tonight'' on ESPN. Winfield played for six teams, including the Padres and the Yankees, during a 22-year career in which he won a World Series with the 1992 Toronto Blue Jays. He is also spokesman for Ask.com, whose Answers for the Cure program benefits Susan G. Komen for the Cure, an organization that raises money for breast cancer. To honor his mother, Arline, who died of breast cancer, Winfield is encouraging people to download a special baseball-themed search page at Ask.com/forthecure.Q.Many major league players use pink bats and wear pink wrist bands and ribbons for Mother's Day to raise awareness about breast cancer. How important is it to spread this message?A.It's extremely important, and we need to get tested early; that can make all the difference. My mother passed away in 1988, and the cancer was detected in 1987. I was playing with the Yankees at that time and we had just finished playing the Twins in Minnesota and she said she was going to the doctor because she felt a lump in her breast and she was going to get it checked out. Even with the sizable resources and connections I had, there wasn't enough time to catch it.Q.How do you feel about players associated with steroids in terms of Hall of Fame enshrinement?A.Truth be told, these guys took a calculated risk to improve their performance, to get a contract, to win awards, and to be considered one of the best in the game by maximizing their performance. But the Hall of Fame? I don't think they belong; I don't think they deserve it. They walked away with a lot of money, a lot of awards and a lot of broken records, which they will keep, but they took a different path than the path I think guys should have taken who played the game.Q.What is the highlight of your baseball career?A.Winning the World Series in Toronto. Growing up, we would play baseball and every practice would end with the same scenario: I'm up at the plate, there's men on base and the World Series is on the line and bam, you get that hit and win it all. It took me almost 20 years in the game to achieve that reality. You achieve something great, you become an immortal, and that's something that can never be taken away from you.Q.Any regrets in baseball?A.On a serious note, I wish that George Steinbrenner and I had a different and more friendly relationship when I played in New York because it made it tougher than it needed to be. I spoke to George extensively a couple of years ago, before his health became an issue, and all of the bad stuff is behind us. You don't want to see anyone in ill health, but I'm glad we settled our issues some time ago. On a fun note, I regret the fact that I never had a chance to pitch in the major leagues. I was a pitcher in college, but I never even got a chance to mop up in the pros. I would have loved to kick that leg up high and pull a Juan Marichal on somebody, or if some batter was digging in to much at the plate, to pull a Bob Gibson and hit somebody in the ribs and say, ''What, what, what are you going to do?''Q.Derek Jeter idolized you as a young player. What does that mean to you?A.It means a great deal. I found out that I was his idol growing up shortly after he made it to the major leagues. To hear that from a young player is great, even greater now that he has become the Yankee captain, a legend who is the team's all-time hits leader. It's a good thing, believe me.Q.Where would Dave Winfield, in his prime, fit in on the current Yankees?A.Who plays right field? They would have to play somewhere else, I guess. Oh, Swish, my man Nick. I'm sorry, but he'll be all right.Q.Why did you elect to go into the Hall of Fame as a Padre instead of a Yankee?A.It was a tough decision, but in the end, the Padres were the team that drafted me right out of college and allowed me to play major league baseball without going to the minor leagues, and I accomplished a lot of good things. How can I not say I was a part of the great Yankee organization? You can only choose one hat, and I went with the team that took me to the dance.Q.Are you concerned with the fact that fewer African-Americans are playing baseball?A.Yes, I am, and we need to do something to stem the tide and turn the situation around. I have a seminar I teach about the problems that African-Americans now have playing baseball in urban areas. One problem is that it costs a lot of money to play nowadays in urban areas. When I was growing up, America was different. Back then, African-Americans weren't that interested in sports other than baseball. Now there's a lot of competition from football and basketball and even the X Games. In the end, I think it's up to each individual community to take the necessary steps to see that the sport is alive and well and available to everyone in every community.

LEDOGAR--Stephen J.,left us on May 3, 2010. Beloved of all his family, tireless and passionate worker for his country, avid cyclist, U.S. Navy pilot, possessed of great decency and a memorable sense of humor. Foreign Service officer in U.S. Dept. of State for 38 years -- Ambassador and Chief Negotiator of major Arms Control treaties, including the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, now finally resurrected for U.S. ratification; the Chemical Weapons Ban Treaty in effect since 1997; the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty of 1990. Surviving are his wife Marcia Hubert, daughter Lucy van Beever, son Charles, sister Anne Leyden, brothers Edward and Robert, and three grandchildren. We will keep his humor, kindness and wisdom in our hearts forever. Private services in near future locally; autumn interment at Rock Creek Cemetery, Washington, D.C.

Before a world championship match, players spend months looking at their opponent's games and studying opening systems, often with the aid of computers and databases. They also hire trainers, who are called seconds, to help. It is a time- and labor-intensive process. That is one of the reasons that fans look forward to the matches. They want to see what the players will do and what new ideas they have discovered, particularly in the openings.

The annual Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon, hosted by the Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy, took place May 5 in the Conservatory Garden at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street. For three hours, the splendor of an earlier age was captured by the 1,200 guests in flowery millinery and spring-summer clothes. Sure, the style of dress is an anachronism, but what a beautiful spectacle! The elaborate hats are not a trend; they are worn in a spirit of fun and celebration. The event raised $2.4 million and honored Patsy and Jeff Tarr (in Picture 2, with Gillian Miniter, left, the committee's president) and Betsy Messerschmitt. The lunch, in its 28th year, evolved after Elizabeth Barlow Rogers (1) founded the conservancy in 1980; the committee was established two years later. This year, the early April heat caused the garden to bloom 14 days early, so the print dresses and overloaded hats stood in for the missing flowers. But make no mistake about the women under the brims: they are serious. They see to it that every dollar raised goes to restoring and maintaining the park.

I'm surprised there are no new theaters opening. That there aren't tells me there's more to the story than meets the eye. Usually, when demand is high and supply is short, prices rise, and entrepreneurs set about increasing supply. Has there been a change to licensing requirements? Is it too risky -- though it seems less risky than investing in a show? In any case, I'm glad that Broadway and, by extension, all theater is alive and well. LUCAS MANSELL of New York City, responding to Patrick Healy's article about a shortage of stages on Broadway.

LEDOGAR--Stephen J.,left us on May 3, 2010. Beloved of all his family, tireless and passionate worker for his country, avid cyclist, U.S. Navy pilot, possessed of great decency and a memorable sense of humor. Foreign Service officer in U.S. Dept. of State for 38 years -- Ambassador and Chief Negotiator of major Arms Control treaties, including the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, now finally resurrected for U.S. ratification; the Chemical Weapons Ban Treaty in effect since 1997; the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty of 1990. Surviving are his wife Marcia Hubert, daughter Lucy van Beever, son Charles, sister Anne Leyden, brothers Edward and Robert, and three grandchildren. We will keep his humor, kindness and wisdom in our hearts forever. Private services in near future locally; autumn interment at Rock Creek Cemetery, Washington, D.C.

This week, the paint company Benjamin Moore will present its Hue Awards for the best use of color in architecture and interiors, and the lifetime achievement award will go to the New York design team of William Diamond and Anthony Baratta, whose sophisticated, bold, and vividly-colored interiors have been featured in The New York Times Magazine. Although the choice of Diamond Baratta would seem a no-brainer, this is the first time that the award has gone to interior designers; past winners were the architects Steven Holl, Ettore Sottsass, and Ricardo Legorreta. Diamond Baratta is known for custom-designing everything from fabrics to braided rugs, and paint colors are no exception. But in an odd coincidence, the designers have always used Benjamin Moore paint bases. And when they told told the company that they were donating their $5000 prize money to the Center for Special Studies at New York-Presbyterian Hospital, which provides specialized care to people with HIV and AIDS, Benjamin Moore matched Diamond Baratta's donation. Baratta credits Diamond with being the firm's color maven. ''Bill is really the maestro of color selection,'' he said. ''It's like music--you have to have perfect pitch.'' Above, a few of the firm's colorful interiors. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Paris-based fashion designer Rick Owens claims he fell into designing furniture simply because he needed something to sit on. And truth be told, the Art Deco and Robert Mallet-Stevens pieces he coveted were too big for his budget - and too polite in scale for the former French Socialist Party Headquarters that he now calls his home and office. ''Like a typical American, I over-sized everything,'' says Owens, a Los Angeles transplant. And he's not kidding. ''Pavane for a Dead Princess,'' the first U.S. exhibition of his furniture designs, opens this weekend at Jeanne Greenberg Rohatyn's Salon 94 and includes a bed, modeled on his own, in alabaster and marble, and a matching daybed. Combined weight: two tons. As of Tuesday afternoon, Owens had yet to see the bed assembled and was busy trawling for nuts and bolts that his team of Parisian sculptors assumed they could pick up upon arrival in New York. Never mind how the furniture was going to make it up the stairs. ''I think I was inspired by the space,'' Owens said of Rohatyn's Upper Eastside gallery, which is in her townhouse. ''It seemed like the perfect place for alabaster.''

PLAYWRIGHTS justly lament the incredible shrinking of the American theater. As the costs of producing have risen over the last few decades, the plays being regularly produced have been getting smaller and smaller. A cast of five actors now seems deluxe at an Off Broadway theater, and stories are rife of literary managers and dramaturges gently suggesting to playwrights that their work might be more marketable if they could airbrush out a few more characters. But the truism that less is more is as viable an argument in theater as it is in other aesthetic realms. Strictly speaking, all that is required to create a potent dramatic event is two characters. Put a pair onstage, and you automatically have a relationship, and from the complicated ways in which two people relate to each other can grow myriad dramatic developments. The people up there will connect or they will conflict, and the result will be any of a number of compelling possibilities: betrayal, conciliation, destruction, erotic attraction.

On Saturday at the Players Championship, it was Fred Funk's turn. Although Funk, 53, has 33 years more wear on his chassis than McIlroy, he still managed to turn TPC Sawgrass into Route 66. Funk's six-under effort, punctuated with an exclamation point of a par at 18, left him with a 54-hole total of eight-under 208.

If there were ever an indicator that Berlin has outgrown its image as untamed bohemian playground, this might be it. Soho House Berlin, a 40-room hotel and private club aimed at the young and affluent, is set to open on May 10 in Mitte, a district once dominated by squatters and unemployed artists. Located in a massive late-Bauhaus structure that opened as a department store in 1928 and was seized by the Nazis and, later, the post-war Communist regime, Soho House Berlin (Torstrasse 1; 49-30-405-04-40; www.sohohouseberlin.com) includes a movie theater, a spa, a state-of-the-art gym and a heated rooftop pool made from volcanic stone. The rooms, each of which are equipped with an old-fashioned gramophone and a selection of vinyl LPs, start at 100 euros a night, about $130, for nonmembers (75 euros with membership).

THE NEWS Germany, Europe's largest economy and the most important -- and most reluctant -- partner in trying to help Greece forestall a financial meltdown, agreed to lend it up to $30 billion over three years, part of an international bailout package negotiated over the weekend. The European Central Bank said it would accept Greek bonds as collateral regardless of any credit downgrades.

WESTERMAN--William, Chairman and CEO of Riviera Holdings Company died on April 18 of heart failure. He was 78 years old. In 1991, he became a consultant to the Riviera and guided the company through bankruptcy reorganization and has been involved with the Riviera ever since, expanding the property and moving into Black Hawk, Colorado. Prior to the Riviera, he was President and CEO of Alusuisse Flexible Packaging, which merged with CelluCraft where he was the President and CEO. He worked for RKO General, Rapid American Corporation and Ordinance Management Engineering Training Agency where he served in the military and civil service teaching and consulting on production and inventory control systems. He is a BA and BS graduate of Lehigh University, with an MS from State University of Iowa and an MBA from New York University. All degrees were awarded with high honors and he was named to Phi Beta Kappa, Tau Beta Pi and Beta Gamma Sigma. In addition he is the co-author of Principals and Design of Production Control Systems; Prentice-Hall, which was translated into three languages and used for many years in US Industrial Engineering colleges. He is survived by Rosemary Handlon, his wife of 54 years, his children, Leslie (Donna) Westerman, John (Helen) Westerman, Julie (Pete) Bostwick, Philip (Maura) Westerman, Ann (Pat) Trait and 14 grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held in June followed by a private burial in Breckenridge, Colorado. Contributions can be made to Province of Meribah, 240 Emory Road Mineola, NY 11501 or Deseret Foundation, 8th Ave. and C St., Salt Lake City, Utah, 84143.

Neanderthals and modern humans were neighbors way back when. But was there more to their relationship? Apparently so. Scientists reconstructing the genome of Neanderthals say the species most likely had a dalliance or two in the Middle East 60,000 to 100,000 years ago. A result: 1 percent to 4 percent of the genome of non-Africans today is derived from Neanderthals, say scientists at the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology in Leipzig, Germany. Some scientists question whether there is enough archaeological evidence yet to support the idea, but Svante Paabo, a biologist who led the effort, is convinced: ''Those of us who live outside Africa carry a little Neanderthal DNA in us,'' he said. Good to know. It remains to be seen whether truth will rob a favored putdown of its sting. Perhaps it will become fashionable to be, in some infinitesimal measure, a caveman.

SNORKELING WITH A HUMPBACK MOTHER AND CALF IN THE SILVER BANK SANCTUARY, OFF THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC, APRIL 5, 2010 Thornton Kirby, 45, president of the South Carolina Hospital Association in Columbia, S.C. ''I grew up wanting to be a marine biologist but eventually realized you didn't get to play with dolphins and whales every day, so I ended up going in a different direction. I finally got to be in the water with whales during the week I spent on the boat of a company called the Aggressor Fleet. Silver Bank is very shallow and safe, so it's a good place for whales to bring newborn calves and let them grow for several months before they have to go back to the Arctic. If you find a mother whale that's not troubled by having snorkelers there, you have an incredible encounter. It's almost as if the calf wants an audience: it begins rolling around on its side and flapping its pectoral fins, slapping its tail and doing flips and turns -- just entirely playful behavior. Once you realize you're safe and they're not going to harm you in any way, you're completely impressed by the complexity of their relationship, and how she is nurturing and raising this calf to be prepared for a huge journey.'' As told to Seth Kugel
Dance Claudia La Rocco

SCHROEDER--Robert (Bob, a.k.a. "Grenna") Arthur, 87, died peacefully in his sleep on April 22. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Joan, and his children, Mary Joan, Amy, Robert Jr., Genevieve, and James. He was a beloved father, grandfather of eight and great-grandfather of two. Raised in Forest Hills as the son of German immigrants, he was a member of the greatest generation. He served as a radio operator in WWII aboard the destroyer escort, USS Decker, making multiple Atlantic crossings into the Mediterranean, including defense of the convoy from enemy torpedo bombers launched from North Africa, for which the ship was awarded a Battle Star. After the War, he attended Cornell University and graduated from Columbia University in 1951, before joining his father and brother as a Buick dealer in Jamaica and later Bellrose. He and Joan proudly raised their children in West Hempstead and Garden City. A wonderful photographer and voracious reader, he loved the Times, football (Giants), baseball (Yankees and Mets), tennis, the beach and his family. He was loved and is missed.

PRINCE--Richard, 89, died peacefully at home on April 11. Born in New York City in 1920 to Jane Gottfried and William Prince, Dick worked as a young man in his grandfathers' company, Gottfried Baking Co. He attended Stuyyesant High School, studied Baking Technology at The Dunwoody Institute, and MIT. He served in the Merchant Marines during WWII. After the War he married Harriett Huntley. Dick was the loving father of Laura, Barbara and Madeleine. His work in the baking industry continued at Hanscom Bakeries. He became president of the Gottfried Baking Company, a member of the Young Presidents' Organization (YPO) and served on the Board of Trustees of the Daughters of Jacob. In the 1970's Dick lived in Greenwich Village, and in Bedford Village, NY. His newly formed company, Lisi America gave him the opportunity to refine and market baking machinery concepts. In the 80's he formulated and manufactured floral foam products. He developed international markets for them and became a consultant to Chinese and American companies seeking business and manufacturing opportunities. Dick's greatest pleasures were cooking, sailing, traveling and enjoying his family including granddaughter Rachel, grandson Eric Sagotsky and sons-in-law Ron Gullickson and Barry Sagotsky. With Lee Pope, his loving partner of 35 years he helped establish the Schoolhouse Theater in Westchester County. He remained a consummate New Yorker who knew and loved every block of his dear city. He will be deeply missed by all who enjoyed his warm, adventurous and jovial manner. A celebration of Dick's life will be held in September at The Schoolhouse Theater. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Schoolhouse Theater, PO Box 300, 3 Owens Road, Croton Falls, NY 10519.

BLOOM--Norton A. Passed away on May 5, 2010 at the age of 87. Norton was a prominent figure in realty as a broker, investor and mortgage banker. At an early age he was educated in Israel and spoke the language fluently. He served with distinction in the United States Air Corp during WWII. Norton will be sorely missed by his relatives, friends and business associates. May he rest in peace.

Following is the second set of responses from Lyudmila Bloch, an international etiquette expert, protocol consultant and author of ''The Golden Rules of Etiquette at the Plaza.'' Many people simply don't care, perhaps unable to grasp any sense of social contract. McDONELL--Bruce George, 71, died at home in Pinehurst, NC on May 5th after fighting colon cancer for seven years. Mr. McDonell was born February 3, 1939 to the late Vincent McDonell and Hazel George. He is survived by his wife Tommy McDonell and is four pets. He graduated from the University of Southern California (BA) and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MS) with a degree in Architecture. Bruce worked as a Project Manager for the City of New York's Department of Design and Construction. Some of his many projects include The Museum of Natural History's Planetarium, PS 1, The New York Hall of Science, and the Queens Museum. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Association of Cancer Resources: Colon Cancer (http://www.acor.org/ donate/now) or to the Queens Museum of Art, Flushing, NY, 11368-3398. A memorial will be done in New York City for friends within a month or so.

McNAMARA--James Ardle, diplomat, trade expert and Texaco executive, died on April 15 in Stamford, CT. He was 77. Born April 26, 1932 in Santa Barbara, CA, he earned a BA and MA, served his country in the Korean War, and had a distinguished civil service career as a U.S. Foreign Service officer and an Assistant US Trade Representative. He later joined Texaco, Inc. as Director of Government Relations. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Sandra Pedlar McNamara, his son, daughter, and five grandchildren.

An article last Sunday on the complexity of the issues of our age misidentified the university where Joseph Tainter, the author of a book on complexity, is an anthropologist. It is Utah State University, not the University of Utah.

Given the speed with which Hong Kong's colonial buildings have been torn down, it's fortunate that the old British marine police headquarters survived at all. The 19th-century white-stucco structure had been neglected for more than a decade. Most visitors to the bustling Tsim Sha Tsui area probably did not notice its elegant curving staircase entrance, set back from the neon and noise of Salisbury Road. Late last year the complex, known as 1881 Heritage (1881heritage.com), began reopening in stages, first with a few luxury shops. The main building, Hullett House (hulletthouse.com) now has a number of restaurants, a bar and a boutique hotel that opened last month. Perhaps most impressively, the renovation has been done with care. The site is not a museum, but it is true to its architectural and historical past. The Moreton Bay fig trees in the garden were first brought to the former colony by visiting seamen. Details in Hullett House, like floor boards and door frames, have been retained from the original structure. Stables Grill CQ is situated in a space where, indeed, horses were once kept. As a reminder of the darker elements of the city's colonial past, jail cells make up part of the interior of the Mariner's Rest bar. More pleasant is the veranda of The Parlour, where you can have a champagne brunch on the weekends.

PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. - One streak ended for Phil Mickelson in the third round of the Players Championship when his 12-foot par putt on No. 18 slid two feet past the hole. Mickelson had gone 24 holes without a bogey and was hoping to post a double-digit total to apply more pressure on the late starters Saturday. His round of six-under 66 gave him a 54-hole score of nine-under 207.

It seems wherever you look there's a photo festival happening somewhere in the world, but perhaps the most anticipated one is the International Festival of Fashion & Photography in Hyeres, France. The festival, which takes place April 30 to May 3, is located at the Villa Noailles, a former modernist residence that has since become a venue for cultural events. Each year ten up-and-coming photographers exhibit their work to the public and an esteemed jury of media professionals. This year's highlights include Carlo van de Roer's ethereal Polaroid portraits, James Reeve's nocturnal cityscapes, and Yann Gross's Ugandan skateboarder series. Hyeres 2010 will also feature a Walter Pfeiffer retrospective and a new video by Steven Klein depicting his fashion photography from the past ten years. Klein's highly structured, subversive images are a good counterbalance to Pfeiffer's more jocular, candid photos. In case you can't make the festival this weekend, the exhibitions run until May 30. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

After BP's Texas City, Tex., refinery blew up in 2005, killing 15 workers, the company vowed to address the safety shortfalls that caused the blast. The next year, when a badly maintained oil pipeline ruptured and spilled 200,000 gallons of crude oil over Alaska's North Slope, the oil giant once again promised to clean up its act.

An article last Sunday about the graphic artists Michael Amzalag and Mathias Augustyniak behind the design firm, M/M (Paris), misattributed a quotation about their latest work for the Prada brand. It was Mr. Augustyniak -- not Mr. Amzalag -- who said: ''It's like looking at a planet from afar. You can see a continent, but it's impossible to say what's inside. They're inhabitants of the Prada world.''

EVEN with the Red Sox beanie pulled over the trademark mane of black hair, it's not hard to spot Sarah Silverman in the lobby at the Bowery Hotel: she's the grown woman dressed like a 14-year-old boy. Promoting her new memoir, ''The Bedwetter'' -- which was No. 9 last week on The New York Times nonfiction hardcover list -- Ms. Silverman saunters toward me in an American Apparel sweatshirt, Free City sweats, and worn Adidas. ''In 18 months of working with her, I don't think I ever saw Sarah in a shirt that didn't have a number on it,'' says David Hirshey, her editor at HarperCollins, which paid $2.5 million for her book. ''She dresses as if she's always ready for a touch football game.'' ''Wait, am I dressing like a 14-year-old boy, or are all 14-year-old boys dressing like me?'' she asks in that voice that sounds as if it belongs to a baby with really bad allergies. ''Remember, they're my demo.''

Photography enjoys special favor in Spain right now, its growing popularity the result of exciting new photographers coming onto the scene and increasing attention from major museums and collectors. So it should be no surprise that the second annual incarnation of the Madridfoto fair (eng.madridfoto.es), being held this year from May 12 to 16 at the Palacio de Deportes de la Comunidad, promises to be even bigger and better than the inaugural event, which attracted over 12,000 visitors, the event's organizers said. This year, 50 galleries, almost half from outside Spain, are exhibiting works. Prices start at about 1,000 euros (about $1,300), ranging up to about 10,000. Beyond your budget? You don't have to be a buyer or professional to attend (except on opening day), and general admission is a more reasonable 15 euros.

ANGELL--Callie. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art mourn with great sorrow the sudden passing of Callie Angell, Adjunct Curator of the Andy Warhol Film Project. Callie was an invaluable colleague, joining the Museum in 1979 as an assistant curator of Film and Video. With a quiet demeanor, yet a strong presence, Callie's profound intellect, intuitive sense and tenacious research made her study of the legendary artist Andy Warhol indispensable to the appreciation of contemporary culture. Thanks to her passion and scholarship, she has left us an enduring resource with the first volume of the catalogue raisonne of the films of Andy Warhol. A member of an illustrious literary family, she was a gifted writer and editor. Her passing has left a void in the New York art world. She will be truly missed. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director Donna De Salvo, Chief Curator and Associate Director for Programs

I saw a birth announcement the other day and groaned. In recent years, I'd learned to accept the flood of trendy tots named Madison, but this was my first Madicyn. If you care about spelling, my advice is to pour yourself a stiff drink before untying that pink or blue ribbon and reading news of the blessed event. In a similar vein, leafing through the newspaper these days is like crawling through a minefield of makeshift names. An article will catch my eye -- say, something about a tornado that just missed ripping through a preschool beauty pageant -- and I dread what's coming next. They're going to interview the pint-size witnesses, and I'm about to meet little Brittney, Brittny, Brittneigh, Brit'nee, Brittani and Bryttney. If you absolutely have to name your child after a rugged French peninsula, then get out a dictionary and look it up. It's Brittany.

ALL-NIGHTERS By the time I was 14 and a half, my brother had his driver's license and he reluctantly agreed to drive me to my 5 a.m. swim practices. Clarkson pool was a 15-minute drive west along Lakeshore Boulevard. He'd stomp, annoyed and grouchy, down to the kitchen, pajamas sticking out the bottoms of his jeans, and grab the keys to the station wagon. Backing out of the driveway he'd put on a tape, which, in my memory, was always Billy Bragg's ''Talking With the Taxman About Poetry.'' The car warmed and my brother turned up the volume. Music made the dark morning drive feel like a movie. We wouldn't talk; we would just listen to the lyrics, to the guitar loud, plangent, and watch Mississauga landmarks pass. An amputated lighthouse, the corn starch factory. The funeral home where we once stared into our next-door neighbor's open casket, Port Credit marina, Pizza Pizza. I longed to say something to him as a friend, an equal, to dissolve the feeling that I was a child needing a drive, but couldn't think of what that would be.

California HOLLYWOOD BOWL- June 12-Oct. 8. It's become somewhat de rigueur to pair a pop act with an orchestra (one gets a little extra bombast, the other a little extra edge), and each summer, the Hollywood Bowl plays matchmaker. On June 15 Sting will perform with the Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra; on July 2-4 Vince Gill will team up with the Los Angeles Philharmonic; on Aug. 13-14 Harry Connick Jr. and his Big Band will do the same; and on Oct. 2 Carrie Underwood will sing alongside the Hollywood Bowl Orchestra. Other notable bookings: the Playboy Jazz Festival (June 12- 13), Femi Kuti and the Positive Force (July 7), Kings of Leon (July 12), B. B. King and Buddy Guy (Aug. 11), and the Neville Brothers (Aug. 18). (323) 850-2000, hollywoodbowl.com.

GAISMAN--Catherine V. (Kitty)- an outstanding philanthropist died on May 1, 2010 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 91. Throughout her adult life, she was a champion and partner to many charities, in health care, education, the arts, and both the Catholic and Jewish faiths. Kitty, as many affectionately knew her, was a passionate gourmet cook. She hosted many dinners at her home that would rival the best restaurants. She loved her dogs, vegetable garden, her home, and all her family and friends. Holidays were particularly important family times for Kitty; she was the center point around whom all would gather. She truly had an extraordinary grace about her. Kitty is survived by her sister, two nephews, a niece, a grand niece, and her loving and devoted companion. We will deeply miss her. Family will receive friends on Saturday May 8th, from 4-6pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian burial will take place Monday 10am at The Cathedral of St. Patrick. Entombment to follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery.
PALOGER--Raymond Irresistible. Irreplaceable. Unforgettable. Justine

Even before the recent oil spill, the Gulf of Mexico was hardly pristine. The Gulf, like almost all large bodies of water, must balance industry and recreation, fishing and development. It provides up to one-third of the country's commercial fishing and shellfish -- along with 27 percent of its domestically produced oil and 20 percent of domestic natural gas. Mexico, too, with its big oil industry and growing population, puts its own stresses on the Gulf. Here are five environmental challenges -- beyond the Deepwater Horizon rig that is spewing thousands of gallons of oil. Erosion - The Gulf of Mexico shoreline is home to more than half the coastal wetlands of the lower 48 states, a habitat for fish and other wildlife and a protective barrier against inland storm damage. In Louisiana, wetlands are wasting away at a rate equivalent to about one football field every 38 minutes. The Mississippi and other rivers that once washed over wetlands, replenishing them with sediment, have been constricted by levees, starving marshes of their main building material. Coastal lands are sinking, a process accelerated by oil and gas drilling. In some areas, the shoreline could move inland by up to 33 miles over the next 30 years.

HULSER--John V.,PhD. On May 7, 2010, John V. Hulser, PhD passed away at the age of 83. Born in College Point, New York he was raised in Madison, CT and lived for many years in Shrewsbury, VT. From 1997 to 2005 he lived in Ocean City, Maryland before moving to Glen Burnie (MD). John received his masters from Yale and his PhD in sociology from the Univ. of Connecticut. He was a college professor for the New York Institute of Technology. John was a member of St. Bernadettes Catholic Church (MD) and the Knight of Columbus in Ocean City (MD). He was the second largest Scottish Highland Cattle Breeder in the United States. John owned a Bed & Breakfast in Shrewsbury, VT and he was an avid collector of many things. He is survived by his companion Faye Burns of Glen Burnie (MD); his daughters Beth A. Morel of Signal Mountain (TN) and Meg M. Bounty of Ashford (CT) and four granddaughters. Services by the family owned Kirkley-Ruddick Funeral Home in Glen Burnie, MD. All services are private. For more information or to post condolences, please visit www.kirkleyruddickfuneral home.com
Theater Ben Brantley

Perhaps it's a cliché to speak of mothers and food. But like every other cliché, this one has a kernel of truth. Many of us -- happily, dreamily, thankfully -- associate our mothers (and motherly love) with a certain recipe. The Op-Ed editors asked five artists to draw and describe the dish they most think of when they think of their mothers. My favorite dish is my mother's baked macaroni and cheese topped with toasted breadcrumbs. Crunchy, smooshy, cheesy and dense -- it's the perfect comfort food for endless Michigan winters. As a kid I would devour the stuff. My mother would always sneak in a few broccoli spears. She would pretend they were actual trees and dare me to eat them, saying, ''I bet you can't eat a tree.''

Full disclosure: I love the heat; I like humidity. It's in my blood (Cuban) and my upbringing (in Miami). So it didn't take long for me to fall for hot power vinyasa yoga, a vigorous class taught in a room steamy enough to simulate the tropics in summer. Flowing from one warrior pose to another, down into plank position and back up again, in 95- to 100-degree heat is grueling. It jacks up your heart rate and sledgehammers your stamina. After 75 minutes or so, you leave behind an outline of your body - in sweat, not chalk - on your yoga towel.

Scarlett Johansson is a very good actress, but since we don't need any more articles about the brand kitten's style, let's enjoy a big gulp of the contemporary culture provided by 032c, the Berlin-based magazine that is published twice a year. The latest issue, the 19th, is just out. I adore 032c. Many of us are feeling a little discouraged by the bombardment of stuff on the Web that doesn't inform or surprise, and 032c is an antidote for that. It sort of destroys the notion that printed journals don't have the quickness or relevance of blogs. No, they just have to be serious about what they do.

At least 200 owners of 1999 through 2003 Ford Windstar minivans have filed complaints about rear axles breaking, but the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has never opened a safety investigation. ''When driving my 2002 Ford Windstar minivan on the highway we noticed a loud slamming noise from the rear, causing the vehicle to lose control, swerving to the right shoulder and stalling with the tail still in the middle of the two-lane highway,'' wrote one consumer. ''The tractor-trailer behind us, who was very alert, nearly missed a rear-end collision with our vehicle.''

Joseph Palanivel Jeyapaul is accused of having assaulted a 14-year-old girl. It was in Minnesota -- not in India, where he returned after serving in the United States.

MALINOW--M. Rene, MD, who as a basic and clinical scientist was among the first who showed the importance of exercise, cholesterol and homocysteine in heart disease, findings which are now in medical textbooks and led to changes in people's behavior and health, died April 20 at his home in Portland, OR. He was 90. Dr. Malinow, who was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina, got his medical degree from Buenos Aires Medical School at the age of 23. He completed a fellowship in cardiology at the Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago, IL. He practiced medicine at the Hospital Ramos Mejia in Buenos Aires until 1963, when he moved to Portland, OR to work at the Oregon National Primate Research Center, where he remained as chief of cardiovascular diseases for 40 years. Dr. Malinow published more than 300 studies, which received over 14,000 citations and delivered hundreds of invited lectures in over 20 countries. He was recipient of the 1996 Achievement Award from the American College for the Advancement in Medicine. He was a former fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and former member of the New York Academy of Sciences. Dr. Malinow was a mentor to hundreds of physicians and scientists in three continents. He will be remembered not only for his distinguished contribution to science but as a devoted husband and father as well. In addition to his wife of 57 years, Tita Malinow of Portland, OR, Dr. Malinow is survived by two sons, Roberto from San Diego, CA and Sebastian from Portland, OR; one daughter, Ana Malinow Rajkovic from Pittsburgh, PA; and six grandchildren, Max and Chester Malinow; Andrei, Adi and Gabriel Rajkovic; and Rose Aria Malinow. The family has requested that flowers not be sent and that expressions of sympathy be directed to The Alzheimer's Association Oregon Chapter and Chamber Music Northwest.

BOSTON -- When the Yankees signed Nick Johnson in December to be their designated hitter, they knew precisely what they were getting: an on-base machine with a lengthy injury history. Johnson has lived up to that reputation on both counts, and now he is expected to miss several weeks after a magnetic resonance imaging test revealed an inflamed tendon in his right wrist. A torn tendon sheath in that same wrist required surgery in 2008 and limited him to 38 games for Washington, but it was unclear whether Johnson had injured the same tendon. Even before receiving the results of the M.R.I. test, the Yankees anticipated losing him for a while, and they recalled the utility player Kevin Russo from Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre.

FISK--Robert Carter died May 2, 2010 of a heart attack. Mr. Fisk was born December 14, 1941 to Mary Harriman Fisk and Shirley Carter Fisk in New York City. He was the eldest grandchild of Averell Harriman, governor of New York, President Roosevelt's Ambassador to Great Britain and Russia, and Ambassador at Large in the John F. Kennedy administration. His great-grandfather, E.H. Harriman created the modern Union Pacific Railroad. He attended the Dalton School in NYC, The Choate School in Wallingford, CT and Yale University in New Haven, CT where he was a member of the Manuscript Society. He received his law degree from George Washington University in 1967. He served in the U.S. Army medical services corps as a hospital adjutant including duty in Tay Ninh City, Viet Nam, a MUST hospital unit, during the height of that war. He was awarded the Bronze Star. He practiced law in Washington DC for more than 40 years, first in the Legal Services Program and later in private practice. His focus was on legal representation for those whose financial resources were limited. He was a strong supporter of the World Wildlife Fund, often traveling to far-flung places. Robert was an avid fisherman, tennis player and skier and regularly invited friends to his home to share major sports events. He served on the board of Brooks School in Andover, MA, the National Councils of the World Wildlife Fund and The National Parks and Conservation Association. He served on the vestry of St. John's Episcopal Church in Arden, NY, where members of the family have lived for many years. He is survived by his three daughters, Katherine Carroll of Baltimore, MD, Caroling Easterling of Rockville, MD, and Mary Dowdle of Haymarket, VA; his sister Kathleen Ames of Brookline, MA, and brother Averell Fisk of Arden, NY. After only a couple of months with Nissan North America, the marketing executive Joel Ewanick is headed for Detroit to help with the rebuilding of General Motors brands. LOS ANGELES-Roman Polanski's legal options narrowed, as a judge here denied his request to unseal testimony about a sentencing plan in his 33-year-old sex case. Lawyers for Mr. Polanski had hoped to use the testimony, by a retired prosecutor, Roger Gunson, to fight his extradition by authorities in Switzerland. Mr. Gunson's conditional testimony was taken earlier this year, so that it could be used if he were not available to testify in a sentencing hearing, should Mr. Polanski be returned to the United States. In denying the request, Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Peter Espinoza said of the Swiss: "I'm satisfied that they have information that they need." Mr. Polanski fled the United States in 1978, on the eve of his sentencing for having unlawful sex with a 13-year-old girl. His lawyers have argued that Judge Laurence J. Rittenband, who is now deceased, improperly used Mr. Polanski's psychiatric evaluation in a California prison as his punishment, and that Mr. Gunson's testimony, if provided to the Swiss, would show that Mr. Polanski does not qualify for extradition under a treaty between Switzerland and the United States.

Rescuers found the bodies on Monday morning of 17 of their colleagues who were killed while trying to reach trapped coal miners in western Siberia, bringing the death toll in the disaster to 30, with 60 still missing, Ellen Barry reports from Moscow. Officials had suspended rescue operations for nearly a day after two explosions sealed the miners in caverns filling with water and smoke, saying they could not try to save the men until methane gas had dropped to safe levels. The agonizing wait marred Russia's celebration of Victory Day ("For Russians, an Old Victory Lives On," on Lens), which brought millions of Russians onto the streets for lavish parades and fireworks displays.

Last week, National Review's editors quoted my praise for Utah's soon-to-be ex-senator, Bob Bennett, in the course of arguing that conservatives shouldn't feel any regret over his Tea Party-abetted defeat. Since the case against Bennett emphasized his support for the bipartisan Wyden-Bennett health care bill, NR's editorial focuses on that legislation's drawbacks:

"As a historian, I'm pessimistic that we are any smarter than those before us, and therefore will avoid the mistakes of greed, hubris, and fear. I have no idea exactly how Russia, India, or China would act in a world in which the United States was but one power, nearly equal to others. However, the balance of the current global system has been favorable for far more for far longer than any other in recent history. Watching it potentially degrade, therefore, should raise great caution in everyone's eyes. If I had to hazard my own guess, a world without an imperfect America acting in a global manner as it has done would be closer to a post-Rome than a post-Britain scenario: bits of the current system slowly flaking off, numerous local conflicts threatening to impinge on the higher interests of bigger powers, a number of regional powers jockeying for influence, and the onset of decades of attempts to come to a new balance, one that may not necessarily privilege openness and freedom as its highest goods."

4:23 p.m. | Updated The Broadway revival of "La Cage Aux Folles," which racked up 11 Tony Award nominations last week - including one for best revival of a musical - will hit the road for a national tour starting in the fall of 2011, the show's producers have announced. The revival of Jerry Herman and Harvey Fierstein's musical, which opened April 18 at the Longacre Theater, stars Kelsey Grammer as Georges, Douglas Hodge as Albin and Robin De Jesus as Jacob. There is no word yet on the casting for the tour, said Jim Byk, a spokesman for the producers. But the rest of the Tony-nominated creative team is set to tour: the director Terry Johnson; the choreographer Lynne Page; the set designer Tim Shortall; the costume designer Matthew Wright; the lighting designer Nick Richings; the sound designer Jonathan Deans; and the orchestrator/musical supervisor Jason Carr. The original production of 'La Cage' opened on Aug. 21, 1983 at the Palace Theater, won six Tony Awards in 1984, including best musical, and was followed by a national tour.

The sound that Gustavo Dudamel heard on Thursday night while conducting the Los Angeles Philharmonic wasn't necessarily the one he was hoping to make: during a performance of Dvorak's Cello Concerto, Mr. Dudamel, who made his debut as the Philharmonic's music director in October, injured his neck during Thursday's performance but was back at the podium on Friday, The Los Angeles Times reported. Mr. Dudamel finished the concerto on Thursday but was replaced for the rest of the program by the associate conductor Lionel Bringuier. Deborah Borda, the president of the Philharmonic, told The Los Angeles Times that Mr. Dudamel had "heard a loud pop and lost sensation in parts of his body"; a medical consultation later showed that he had pulled a muscle in his neck area. After going home to rest Mr. Dudamel returned to conduct the same program on Friday. On Monday, he was scheduled to begin a national tour with the Philharmonic in San Francisco.

Bracing for More Budget Cuts | Get ready to hear more bad news from Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger on Friday about the state's finances. He is scheduled to release an updated budget plan, which is likely to include even deeper cuts to state services than those proposed in January, The San Francisco Chronicle reported. Governor Schwarzenegger included $6.9 billion in federal aid in his January budget, but so far, the state has received less than $3 billion. The state's controller, John Chiang, reported last Friday that the state collected $3.6 billion less in tax revenue in April than had been projected. Despite a budget deficit that could run over $20 billion, both Republicans and Democrats in the Legislature have pledged not to seek new taxes this year. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

An article today about a man who did not officially have a first name until he was 19 asks the question, "What's in a name?" Do you like your name? How did you get it? How has it shaped you? If, like this man, you had to officially name yourself now, would you keep the name you've had all your life, or take another? Why?

When business owners visit our firm to discuss the sale of their businesses, they are often accompanied by another person. Typically that person is a spouse, lawyer, accountant, partner with an equity stake or family member who works in the business. But every so often the other person is introduced as "a friend." At this point I hope for the best but prepare mentally for the worst.

Paintings by Édouard Manet rarely come up for sale, let alone self-portraits, of which he painted only two. WOLFSON--Cecil. We honor the life and mourn the passing of Cecil Wolfson, beloved husband of Barbara of 53 years and treasured and devoted father of Michael. A true southern gentleman in every sense of the word, he was loved and respected by everyone who knew him. Though he endured inordinate physical hardship in his final years, he always maintained his joyful spirit, humor, warmth and caring for his many lifelong friends as well as for those he had only just met. After a life built around good deeds, family and friends, may he find the peace and comfort that he so deeply deserves. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Cecil Wolfson Fund for The Wolfson Childrens Hospital, 841 Prudential Drive, Jacksonville, FL 32207. Barbara and Michael Wolfson

Devra G. Kleiman, a conservation biologist who reintroduced into the wild the tiny endangered monkey known as the golden lion tamarin, and who learned so much about the lives of giant pandas that scientists could later help them reproduce in captivity, died on April 29 in Washington. She was 67 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md. The cause was cancer, said her husband, Ian Yeomans.

Appeals to raise money for AIDS are ubiquitous -- but the gap between what is needed and what is collected is enormous, and growing. In February, Michel Sidibé, the executive director of Unaids, estimated that $27 billion would be needed this year to fight the disease. Nothing close to that amount is on tap. Even counting what middle-income countries spend on AIDS in their own health budgets, the total has been estimated at $14 billion.

Hollywood has the famous one, and New York already has at least three. But on Monday, the city will get another walk of fame. This one will be outside the Apollo Theater, on West 125th Street. The shiny golden plaques honoring famous performers will be rectangular - not star shaped, as in Hollywood. And officials at the Apollo have proofread the plaques before they install them. (Someone in Hollywood apparently forgot to check the one for the actress Julia Louis-Dreyfus that was unveiled recently. It arrived lacking the ''o'' and the hyphen.)

JERUSALEM -- The Obama administration announced Sunday that indirect, American-brokered talks had resumed between Israel and the Palestinians, capping a year of efforts by Washington to revive the peace process. The American special envoy to the region, George J. Mitchell, is expected to shuttle between the two sides over the next four months as mediator of the so-called proximity talks. They are aimed at forging a joint vision of the outlines of a solution based on the creation of a Palestinian state alongside Israel.

8 P.M. (BET) AMERICAN VIOLET (2008) Nicole Beharie (above right with Alfre Woodard, who plays her mother) is Dee Roberts, a young African-American mother of four who is charged with distributing narcotics in a school zone in her small Texas town and risks going to court instead of accepting a plea bargain for a crime she insists she didn't commit. Xzibit plays the father of her two youngest children; his desire for custody may be at the root of Dee's predicament. Michael O'Keefe is the local district attorney who is sued for racial discrimination by a lawyer (Tim Blake Nelson) from the American Civil Liberties Union on Dee's behalf. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that this film from Tim Disney, based on real events in 2000, ''has the quasi-documentary feel of a well-made television drama.'' He added that it is ''beautifully acted by Ms. Beharie, whose high-strung character is no angel.'' 8 P.M. (NBC) CHUCK After Chuck (Zachary Levi) comes to believe that one of his dreams predicts danger for a visiting head of state, General Beckman (Bonita Friedericy) has him checked out by a C.I.A. psychiatrist (Christopher Lloyd).

SCHWARTZ--Martin F.,age 91, MBA, PhD, 1st Lt. US Army, of Yonkers and Greenport, NY. Professor Emeritus, Rockland Community College. Died May 9. We celebrate his extraordinary life. Son of Bette and Sholom Schwartz, brother of Asher, husband of 52 years to Florence Shishko Schwartz. Survived by children, Debbie (David Rapaport) and Nomi (Ben Freed), six outstanding grandchildren, extended family. Appreciated as a professor, octogenarian lecturer and lay rabbi, authority on countless subjects and a man who treasured everything in life. Services Tuesday at 1pm at Bet Am Shalom, 295 Soundview Ave., White Plains.

Interment will be at a later date at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

WOLFE--Ethyle R. Brooklyn College mourns the passing of Provost Emerita Ethyle R. Wolfe. In the course of her distinguished career at the College, she chaired the Department of Classics, served as dean of the School of Humanities and as provost and vice-president for academic affairs. Most importantly, she was one of the original faculty architects of the renowned Brooklyn College Core Curriculum, as well as the founder of the Brooklyn College Humanities Institute, renamed in her honor upon her retirement in 1989. The faculty and students at Brooklyn College continue to be effected by the profound legacy of Dr. Wolfe's endeavors. Karen L. Gould, President

An article on Wednesday about an admission by a University of Virginia lacrosse player, George Huguely, that he became violent with a fellow student the night she died, according to a court document, misstated the surname of an officer who arrested Mr. Huguely in 2008 in Lexington, Va. She is R. L. Moss, not Moff.

ANDERSON--James Howard, II, passed away unexpectedly on May 6, 2010, at his home in New York City. Jim was born in Cold Spring Harbor, Long Island, on January 24, 1966, to Carlton Edwin Anderson and Diane Sullivan Anderson. He attended CSH High and graduated Penn State University in 1988. Jim entered the trading program at Paine Webber and rose to Executive Director, Head of Fixed Income for UBS Wealth Management. He mentored scores of Wall Street professionals and was well respected and honored for his trading and financial acumen. Jim brought great energy and integrity to his work, but family was his life. He married his complete love Carolyn McDuffie Anderson, June 1st, 1991; together they parented two children. He was a deeply devoted and proud father to James Howard III, 13, and Charlotte McDuffie, 10. Jim is also survived by his mother Diane and stepfather Daniel Barry of Huntington Bay, NY; siblings Deborah Morris of Fernandina Beach, FL, Diana and husband Jonathan Yeisley of Simsbury, CT, and Carlton and wife Pepper Anderson of Greenwich, CT; aunt Donna and uncle Bill Folkerts of Valhalla, NY; a large extended family and a deep collection of admiring friends and colleagues. Jim touched many lives. Although all mourn his profoundly untimely passing, we will cherish the selfless, generous and inspiring memory of Jim and Daddy always. Funeral services will be held at St. Bartholomew's Church in Manhattan (stbarts.org), on Tuesday, May 11th, at 2pm, reception following. Those wishing to make a memorial contribution may consider the charity of their choice in Jim's memory, or Carolyn Anderson as trustee for the James and Charlotte Anderson Education Trust.

WASHINGTON -- President Obama nominated Solicitor General Elena Kagan as the nation's 112th justice, choosing his own chief advocate before the Supreme Court to join it in ruling on cases critical to his view of the country's future. After a monthlong search, Mr. Obama informed Ms. Kagan and his advisers on Sunday of his choice to succeed the retiring Justice John Paul Stevens.

Investigators seeking an explanation for the brief stock market panic last week said Sunday that they were focusing increasingly on how a controlled slowdown in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, meant to bring about stability, instead set off uncontrolled selling on electronic exchanges. It was an unintended consequence of a system built to place a circuit breaker on stocks in sharp decline. In theory, trades slow down so that sellers can find buyers the old-fashioned way, by hand, one by one. The electronic exchanges did not slow down in tandem, causing problems, according to two officials familiar with the investigation.

PERKIEL--Frank Efraim, 85, passed away on April 10, 2010. Frank was born and spent his youth in Warsaw, Poland. Upon Nazi Germany's invasion of Poland on September 1, 1939, Frank took up arms in defense of Warsaw against the German army. In the ensuing months following Poland's occupation, Frank remained in Warsaw as a volunteer for the Joint Jewish Distribution Committee. Between 1940 and 1943, Frank lived in the Warsaw Ghetto, active in its Zionist organization, and was secretary of a Jewish Youth Committee, an underground elementary school teacher, and a member of the Jewish resistance smuggling food into and messages in and out of the Ghetto, culminating in his leading the escape of 20 Jews from the Ghetto, following which he secretly lived for a time outside the Ghetto, working with the Polish Jewish underground. In May, 1943, Frank surrendered himself to the Nazi SS to rejoin his father and brother, who remained incarcerated in the Ghetto. After his arrest and deportation, and in the ensuing three years up to his liberation on May 5, 1945 by American invasionary forces from the Mauthausen death camp, Frank miraculously survived eight Nazi labor/concentration camps in Poland, Germany, Czechoslovakia and Austria. Between the end of the war and 1949, Frank lived in US-occupied zones in Austria and Germany, was employed by the UN Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, served the American military in the covert intelligence activities, and headed the Immigration Department of Jewish Agency for Palestine. In April, 1949, Frank and his now-deceased wife, Ella Zlotnik, herself a survivor of Nazi atrocities, immigrated to New York City where he remained and raised his family. He became a successful businessman and in 1966 founded Galaxy Metals Inc. Frank epitomized the human spirits of strength, defiance of evil, survival and hope...his forever enduring legacy. Frank is survived by his son Mitchel H. Perkiel and daughter-in-law Lois Perkiel, and his daughter Anita Perkiel Sarna and son-in-law Mark Sarna, and his six grandchildren, Joshua, Alexa and Griffin Perkiel and Danielle, Ilana and Ari Sarna.

The Advertising column on Friday, about sales of commercial time for shows that will appear during the 2010-11 television season, misstated the surname of an executive at Unilever who commented on the state of the advertising market. He is Rob Master, not Rob Norman.
ZUCKER--Dr. Howard D.,died peacefully May 7 at 93. His four children, eight grandchildren, friends and colleagues will miss him.

Expect to see more reviews of baguettes with brie and Bordeaux wine bars on Yelp. The site for local business ratings and reviews has opened in France at Yelp.fr. Yelp has already expanded beyond the United States to Canada, England and Ireland. Yelp France will be the first non-English Yelp site, and Yelp users anywhere will be able to choose to read the reviews in French or English and write them in either language.

There was quite a stir at eBay last week when a former associate of Tiger Woods's tried to auction a set of irons he said Woods had used to win four consecutive major championships in 2000-1. The asking price was $250,000. When Woods denied the irons were the ones he used in those events, eBay removed the item from its Web site. But there are plenty of rare golf items available on eBay, it just depends what you define as rare. I, for example, did not know I owned a rare golf ball because I saved one of those multicolored Ping balls from the early 1980s. That was when orange and neon yellow golf balls were a popular fad in the golf ball marketplace and Ping went one step further and made balls of various combinations: half orange and half neon yellow, half white and have neon yellow, half white and half pink, half blue and half gold. There were dozens of combinations.
EVERITT--David S.,57, of Huntington on May 7, 2010. Husband of Laurie, father of Anthony and Gregory, son of Sylvia and brother of Judy. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

HORWITZ--Susanne Oppenheimer. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Susanne (Susie) Oppenheimer Horwitz. We extend our condolences to her beloved husband, Marvin; to her daughters, Janie and her husband Adam; to Deborah and her husband, Gregg; and to her entire family. John M. Shapiro, President; Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

Lena Horne, who was the first black performer to be signed to a long-term contract by a major Hollywood studio and who went on to achieve international fame as a singer, died on Sunday night at New York-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center in New York. She was 92 and lived in Manhattan. Her death was announced by her son-in-law, Kevin Buckley.

WEBER--Ida Reitberg, died May 9, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Hyman. Survived by her three sons; Doctors Fred, Robert and Gerald Weber and their wives Karen and Mary Ann; a daughter Lynda Heller, seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren and her cherished Bernard and Lorraine and Marvin and Rose whose unselfish devotion never failing to bring a big smile to her face. Mom, we will miss your humor, kindness, wisdom, indomitable spirit and lastly your singing and dancing. Services to be held at 11am, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke. Woodbury, NY 11797 on May 10, 2010. Interment at Cedar Pak Cemetery in Westwood, New Jersey.

ANGELL--Callie, 62, on May 5, 2010. Daughter of Roger Angell and the late Evelyn B. Nelson, step daughter to Carol R. Angell, sister to Alice Angell of Portland, ME and John Henry Angell of Portland, OR and aunt to three beloved nieces. A loving daughter and unique friend, a brilliant writer and scholar, and a joyful participant in the world, she will be missed forever.

Google has long dabbled in the clean energy business. Now the company is investing in the generation of green power. On Monday, Google said that it invested $38.8 million in two North Dakota wind farms built by NextEra Energy Resources, a subsidiary of the FPL Group, a $16 billion electricity company based in Florida. Google's investment represents a minority interest in a $190 million round of financing for the projects.

This is the time of year when people often take golf lessons. Or at least they should. An awful lot of things get out of whack over the winter. For starters, you're probably gripping your club like a snow shovel. Just as you would take your car for a spring tuneup, now is a good time to take your golf game to a P.G.A. professional. But does the average golfer know how to take a golf lesson? Do we get the most out of our hour with an instructor?

An article on Thursday about an exhibition in San Francisco by the photographer Jennifer Karady, ''In Country: Soldiers' Stories From Iraq and Afghanistan,'' referred incorrectly at two points to a 33-year-old Army veteran who is the subject of a picture in the exhibition. As the article noted elsewhere, the veteran is Starlyn Lara, and thus Ms. Lara, not ''Ms. Starlyn.'' It also referred incorrectly to an incident that was the basis for a photo of Andy Davis, a former Army staff sergeant. A fellow soldier was hit in the eyes by shrapnel from an artillery shell, not shot in the eye by a sniper.

At the ripe age of 28, Jon Zimmer is sort of an old fogey. That is, he is obsessive about the sound quality of his music. A onetime audio engineer who now works as a consultant for Stereo Exchange, an upscale audio store in Manhattan, Mr. Zimmer lights up when talking about high fidelity, bit rates and $10,000 loudspeakers.
LESCHER--Mary Cantwell. May 10th, 1930-Feb. 1st, 2000. Missed today and every day. Margaret, Jon, Anna & Katie

President Obama made another effort last week to project fiscal discipline - and reminded Congressional Democrats why he sometimes exasperates them. Amid heightened public concern over spending, the White House disclosed that Mr. Obama wanted increased authority to strip wasteful projects from spending bills.

WITKIN--Louis, 96. It is with love and sadness that the family of Louis Witkin announce his death on May 8 in Augusta, ME. He is predeceased by his wife Beatrice Witkin and survived by his daughter Judith Sandegren, his son Steve R. Witkin and three grandchildren J. Alexander Hurd, Andre J. Witkin and Deborah I. Witkin.

FRANK--Eva. The family of Eva Frank sadly announces the loss of their beloved mother, sister, aunt, grandmother and great-aunt on May 6, 2010. She is deeply mourned by all those who were graced by her love. With love from your sons Dennis, Ronald, your daughter Jacqueline, your brother Felix Posen and his wife Jane, your grandchildren Jacob and Hugo, step-grandchildren Sophia and Grace and their mom Abbey, and all your nieces, nephews and their children. We love you, we miss you. The funeral will be at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 St, New York on Tuesday May 11th, 2010, at 11:45am. Shiva will be held for four days beginning Tuesday evening at her old apartment: 210 West 90th St #

I remember when golf shoes were not only funny looking things with plastic flaps over the laces, but they hurt your feet, too. The rigid heel cuffs would give me blisters and the metal spikes created pressure points on the soles of your feet. But we wore them anyway. Hey, we had carrying bags without kick stands, too. I love my golf shoes now. I would wear them around the house as slippers except the synthetic spikes leave a trail in the living room carpet so my wife would know how many times I went to the freezer for ice cream after she's gone to bed.

An article on Thursday about Facebook users' privacy concerns referred incorrectly to the type of information the site uses to customize advertising for individual users. It uses both public and private information on the user's profile page, not public information alone.

ESTREN--Solomon, MD, on May 8, 2010. Beloved husband of the late Elaine, devoted father, grandfather, uncle, doctor, healer, mentor and friend. Survived by his loving children Mark, Richard, Robert, Jonathan and Elizabeth, seven grandchildren, three nieces and one nephew. Served with distinction for more than 50 years as a hematologist in private practice and at Mt Sinai Medical Center, and for 25 years as a New York City Police Surgeon. Co-discoverer of Estren-Dameshek Syndrome. Translator of Tannhauser's Textbook of Metabolism and Metabolic Disorders. Services Tuesday, May 11, at 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mt Sinai School of Medicine.

Concert albums have long been a way to sell a performer's songs all over again, and fans have responded with enthusiasm. Two live albums are due this month: ''Good Evening, New York City,'' released by Paul McCartney in 2009, will be sold starting Tuesday with a bonus DVD, and ''Live on the Sunset Strip,'' coming May 18, is a 1966 three-set recording by Otis Redding. Albums don't sell in the numbers they once did, since fans can buy individual tracks. Madonna's ''Sticky & Sweet Tour,'' above, has sold 45,000 units since its release on April 26. SHELLY FREIERMAN

In the end, a British election campaign that included many twists and turns concluded as so many have before, with a defeated prime minister walking out of 10 Downing Street to resign and a newly-minted one walking in through the same famous front door.

Let’s just say I saw it coming. When the waitress at the furiously fashionable Ralph’s, the restaurant at the new Ralph Lauren boutique in Saint-Germain-des-Prés, threaded her way through the tight maze of brown leather armchairs in the snug, beamed dining room — complete with hunt-themed oil paintings and a gas fire — and placed a small bowl of deep-fried olives on the table, my friend Marie-Odile, a châtelaine in town for the day from Bordeaux, rolled her eyes. “Deep-fried olives!” she said. “Only you Americans would think of doing such a thing. You deep-fry everything, don’t you?”

The latest online column from Richard Black of the BBC demonstrates why he's at the top of the heap among those of us trying to make sense of global climate trends and diplomacy. He deconstructs the merits and drawbacks of the Hartwell Paper, an endeavor by a variegated crew of economists, political scientists and others to chart a reality-based path toward limiting risks from climate extremes while, in the long haul, curbing emissions of greenhouse gases.
Tarik Saleh’s dystopian vision of a depleted, smog-engulfed, financially collapsed Europe in the year 2024 seems a touch too close to home.
“Beetle Queen Conquers Tokyo” says less about Japan than it does about America’s continuing fascination with modern Japanese culture.

WEDNESDAY'S PUZZLE - Today's puzzle works a little better in the newspaper. Six shaded boxes make more sense of the theme, but since neither Across Lite nor the New York Times Java applet can do shading, electronic solvers get circles instead. It still works. There's also a difference in the 47 Across clue because Across Lite doesn't handle superscripts either. My geeky XPF initiative is an attempt to reduce these restrictions by extending the digital definition of crosswords in a standard way. We'll see how far I get.

One fate the conservative commentator Daniel Pipes doesn't have to worry about is drowning in conceptual complexity. He keeps his theories simple. His theory about why Faisal Shahzad tried to blow up a bomb in Times Square last week is "jihadi intent."
Animal conservation groups are working to establish pathways for big cats to travel through human-populated areas. One such corridor is in place for Costa Rica's jaguars.

A look inside the building designed by Charles McKim in 1906 to house J. P. Morgan’s personal office and library. The Morgan Library & Museum is embarking on a $4.5 million project that will gently restore it.

It is the Wall Street equivalent of a perfect game of baseball - 27 up, 27 down, the final score measured in millions of dollars a day. Despite the running unease in world markets, four giants of American finance managed to make money from trading every single day during the first three months of the year, The New York Times's Eric Dash reports.

This week's restaurant review is of Fatty 'Cue, the newest outpost of Zakary Pelaccio's roving band of big-flavored marauders, the Fatty Crew. It's on the south side of Williamsburg, down the street from the Dressler and Peter Luger, and serves barbecue that's as informed by American traditions as it is by the Malaysian flavors that have made Mr. Pelaccio, over the years, into a sort of Johnny Appleseed of dried shrimp and hot peppers.
Patrick Patten, author of the blog Handride, is part of a group called the Thoroughbred Bloggers Alliance.

One of Jasper Johns's seminal Flag paintings, from 1960-1966, that had belonged to Michael Crichton, the best-selling writer, became the star of Christie's post-war and contemporary art auction on Tuesday night when it brought $28.6 million. That figure was a record for the artist at auction, though the painting did not manage to beat the record for a work by a living artist, as many had speculated it might. (That record is held by Lucian Freud's painting "Benefits Supervisor," which sold for $33.6 million at Christie's in New York two years ago.)

Can Tavern on the Green be resurrected in our lifetime? Tuesday, for the second day, the designated new operator of the landmark restaurant in Central Park, Dean J. Poll, conducted negotiations with the Hotel and Motel Trades Council, which represents some 400 employees who have been looking for work since the restaurant shuttered early on Jan. 1.

The street artist known as Poster Boy, who cuts up and rearranges subway posters, often to witty effect, won't be riding the subway anytime soon. He's at Riker's Island, sentenced to 11 months for vandalism, the blog animalnewyork reported.

This is the time of year when Millburn students are obsessed with strawberries -- the festival kind. There are three Strawberry Festivals remaining: Deerfield School on May 19 (rain date May 20), Wyoming School on May 26 (rain date May 27) and Glenwood School on June 9 (rain date June 10). Gwen Orel remembers the excitement of the Strawberry Festival when she was growing up in Millburn.

"The Pitmen Painters," the hit British play about a group of miners who find a creative outlet that doesn't involve ballet dancing or stripping off their clothes to music, will open the new season at Manhattan Theater Club in September. The play by Lee Hall (the screenwriter of "Billy Elliot" and a Tony Award-winner for its musical adaptation) will begin previews at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater on Sept. 14 and open on Sept. 30, the theater company said on Tuesday. As its producer Bob Boyett said in January, the play will transfer with its London cast as well as its director, Max Roberts.

The new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum's Costume Institute, "American Woman: Fashioning a National Identity," examines the evolution of style in this country and the appreciation of the breeze-easy female. Replacing the cosseted woman with a spirited American paradigm trumpeted more than the exchange of a corset for a shift dress, however. It sparked an upheaval in social etiquette: Women of independent means began buying their own jewelry. Fashion may have rattled the cage for change, yet it was gems and precious metals that broke the chains of Europe.

As the mining city of Mezhdurechensk began to bury its dead on Tuesday, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin flew to the site of the disaster in western Siberia, vowing to discover whether human error or lax safety standards had contributed to one of the most lethal mine disasters here since the collapse of the Soviet Union.

The Walt Disney Company's movie studio roared back to life in the most recent quarter, with operating income increasing to $223 million from $13 million in the year-ago period. The only problem: executives who have since been fired were largely to thank.

After splitting with the chef Laurent Tourondel, Jimmy Haber, who now owns the BLT Restaurant Group with a new partner, has shed the BLT name for a new series of restaurants patterned after the BLT Burgers in New York, Hong Kong and Las Vegas. The company held an online contest in April for a new name, offering $4,000 to the winner. Go Burger is the winner. It is also the name of the company's burger truck.

In San Francisco, since the passage of Proposition 13, the property tax burden has shifted from commercial to residential property owners. In 1975, commercial property owners paid 59 percent of property taxes. Today, they pay 43 percent, according to Phil Ting, San Francisco's assessor-recorder. That's true even, though San Francisco's population has remained relatively flat, and the city has seen a downtown building boom.

Corey Lee, who was the chef de cuisine at Thomas Keller's French Laundry until August, when he resigned to open his own restaurant in San Francisco, is now on track to do just that. In late July he plans to open Benu. The name means "phoenix," or rebirth, in ancient Egyptian.

I moved to New York a year ago and felt at once at home. In the haggard buildings and bloodshot skies, in trains that never stopped running, like my racing mind at night, I recognized my insomniac self. If New York were a patient, it would be diagnosed with agrypnia excitata, a rare genetic condition characterized by insomnia, nervous energy, constant twitching, and dream enactment. An apt description of a city that never sleeps, a place where one comes to reinvent himself.

The East End of London has been the focus of contemporary fashion, design and music in the the city for the last decade. But suitable places to stay have been slow in coming. The Hoxton Hotel arrived in 2006, and Terence Conran's 17-room Boundary opened its doors last year. Now two new arrivals are vying for the attention of design-savvy travelers.

Tired of costly cable bills, many Americans have talked about "cutting the cord" and relying on the Internet's patchwork of streaming television and movie services. Decoder admits it's a tantalizing proposition. But a new report reminds us that more people than ever are forking over monthly payments for TV.

In 2005 conservation groups filed suit against the Gulf of Mexico Fishery Management Council, which regulates fishing in the gulf, over its stewardship of the red snapper, a favorite catch of commercial and recreational fishermen. The suit alleged that despite ample evidence of enormous declines in stocks of red snapper, the council had failed to institute catch limits and other protections required under federal law.

Brooklyn's proud history as a beermaking capital took a big bow Tuesday afternoon when for the first time, the city gave landmark status to a former brewery: the William Ulmer complex, four buildings constructed in the German round-arch style between 1872 and 1890 in Bushwick.

If the Park Slope neighborhood of Brooklyn seems a little less cool next January, it may be because Maggie Gyllenhaal and Peter Sarsgaard are simultaneously out of town, at least for part of the day: the wife-and-husband actors with Brooklyn's highest per-capita concentration of vowels will once again appear together in a production at the Classic Stage Company, that East Village theater company said on Tuesday. This time, they will be in Chekhov's "Three Sisters." The production will reunite Ms. Gyllenhaal and Mr. Sarsgaard with the director Austin Pendleton and their co-star Mamie Gummer, from the production of "Uncle Vanya" that Classic Stage Company presented in 2009. Via Eve Tushnet, I see that Maggie Gallagher got there first on the point I made in yesterday's column - namely, that a lot of the differences between "red" and "blue" family structures, as sketched in Naomi Cahn and June Carbone's recent book, are driven by higher abortion rates in liberal states. And it really is striking, when you dig into the data, how much of the blue-state advantage in preventing teen births is made possible by abortion. Rhode Island's teen pregnancy rate is identical to West Virginia's, but West Virginia's teen birth rate is 33 percent higher. California's teen pregnancy rate is higher than Alabama's, but California's teen birth rate is 20 percent lower. Kentucky and Maryland have the same teen pregnancy rates, but Kentucky has almost 60 percent more teenage births. And so on ...

Our panel of economists is back with a final installment of answers to your questions about the Greek debt crisis and its repercussions. The panelists are Yves Smith, the financial analyst behind the "Naked Capitalism" blog and "ECONned," who heads Aurora Advisors, a management consulting firm specializing in corporate finance advisory and financial services; Carmen M. Reinhart, an economic historian at the University of Maryland whose recent book, "This Time Is Different," chronicles 800 years' worth of debt crises and sovereign defaults; and Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, an author of "13 Bankers: The Wall Street Takeover and the Next Financial Meltdown," and a Daily Economist here at Economix.

Herszenhorn reports from Washington.

CARMEL, Calif. -- Electric vehicles, from a collectible standpoint, haven't generally been around long enough to establish market value. But a notable exception did go across the block Saturday here at the Bonhams auction of classic motorcycles. It was a 1974 Corbin Electric, which the auctioneer said was, in its day, the "first full-sized street-legal electric motorcycle."

It was my son who turned me on to the pleasures of orange. It is, as he often tells us, his second favorite color, right behind purple. Over the years I have bought him countless orange balls, pencils, place mats; asked for orange items of clothing from relatives for Christmas and birthdays; prepared him orange food (Kraft macaroni and cheese comes to mind, as well as Doritos).

To all the other economic indicators in the city, add Stuyvesant High School. For the first time in recent memory, the school, the crown jewel of the city school system, will qualify for federal financing reserved for the poorest schools.

In my post yesterday on the role that the Wyden-Bennett health care bill played in Bob Bennett's primary defeat, I linked to Michael Cannon's free-market critique of the Paul Ryan/Tom Coburn proposal, which shared some features with Wyden-Bennett without inspiring any anti-Ryan or anti-Coburn backlash on the right. Ramesh Ponnuru points out that Cannon subsequently corrected and revised that critique. I regret missing that revision, not least because Cannon's apparent misapprehensions about the Ryan-Coburn bill were similar to mine.
